The verse emphasizes that the Messenger and his companions endured poverty, hardship, and tribulations, to the point where they questioned when Allah's help would arrive. However, it reassures that Allah's help and victory are indeed near for those who persevere with faith and patience.
orig: أم حسبتم أن تدخلوا الجنة ولما يأتكم مثل الذين خلوا من قبلكم مستهم البأساء والضراء وزلزلوا حتى يقول الرسول والذين آمنوا معه متى نصر الله ألا إن نصر الله قريب

translation: They ask you (O Muhammad) what they should spend. Say: Whatever you spend of good must be for parents and kindred and orphans and the poor and the wayfarer, and whatever you do of good deeds, truly Allah knows it well.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of spending on one's parents, relatives, orphans, the poor, and travelers in need. It encourages generosity and charity towards those who are less fortunate or in difficult circumstances. The interpretation highlights that any good deed or charitable spending will be known and appreciated by Allah.
orig: يسألونك ماذا ينفقون قل ما أنفقتم من خير فللوالدين والأقربين واليتامى والمساكين وابن السبيل وما تفعلوا من خير فإن الله به عليم

translation: Kampf ist euch vorgeschrieben, obwohl er euch zuwider ist. Doch es könnte sein, dass ihr etwas verabscheut, währenddessen es gut für euch ist. Und es könnte sein, dass ihr etwas liebt, währenddessen es schlecht für euch ist. Aber Allah weiß, und ihr wisst nicht.
interpretation: Diese Verse erinnert uns daran, dass wir nicht immer wissen, was das Beste für uns ist. Manchmal müssen wir Dinge tun, die uns schwerfallen oder unangenehm sind, aber letztendlich zu unserem Wohl dienen. Andererseits können Dinge, die uns zunächst angenehm erscheinen, in Wirklichkeit schädlich für uns sein. Allah allein hat das vollkommene Wissen darüber, was gut und schlecht für uns ist. Daher sollten wir uns auf Sein Wissen verlassen und Ihm vertrauen, anstatt uns von oberflächlichen Annehmlichkeiten oder Abneigungen leiten zu lassen.
orig: كتب عليكم القتال وهو كره لكم وعسى أن تكرهوا شيئا وهو خير لكم وعسى أن تحبوا شيئا وهو شر لكم والله يعلم وأنتم لا تعلمون

translation: They ask you about the sacred month - about fighting therein. Say, "Fighting therein is great [sin], but averting [people] from the way of Allah and disbelief in Him and [preventing access to] al-Masjid al-Haram and the expulsion of its people therefrom are greater [evil] in the sight of Allah. And fitnah is greater than killing." And they will continue to fight you until they turn you back from your religion if they are able. And whoever of you reverts from his religion [to disbelief] and dies while he is a disbeliever - for those, their deeds have become worthless in this world and the Hereafter, and those are the companions of the Fire, they will abide therein eternally.
interpretation: Cette verse aborde la question de la guerre pendant les mois sacrés. Elle affirme que bien que le combat pendant ces mois soit un péché grave, empêcher les gens de suivre la voie d'Allah, renier Sa religion, interdire l'accès à la Mosquée sacrée et en expulser ses habitants constituent des péchés encore plus graves aux yeux d'Allah. La fitna (sédition, tentation de renoncer à sa foi) est également pire que le meurtre. Les mécréants continueront à combattre les musulmans jusqu'à ce qu'ils les fassent renoncer à leur religion s'ils le peuvent. Ceux qui apostasient verront leurs bonnes actions annulées dans ce monde et dans l'au-delà, et seront voués au Feu éternel de l'Enfer.
orig: يسألونك عن الشهر الحرام قتال فيه قل قتال فيه كبير وصد عن سبيل الله وكفر به والمسجد الحرام وإخراج أهله منه أكبر عند الله والفتنة أكبر من القتل ولا يزالون يقاتلونكم حتى يردوكم عن دينكم إن استطاعوا ومن يرتدد منكم عن دينه فيمت وهو كافر فأولئك حبطت أعمالهم في الدنيا والآخرة وأولئك أصحاب النار هم فيها خالدون

translation: Indeed, those who have believed and those who have emigrated and fought in the cause of Allah - those expect the mercy of Allah, and Allah is Forgiving and Merciful.
interpretation: This verse highlights the virtues of those who have believed, migrated for the sake of their faith, and strived in the path of Allah. It promises that such individuals can expect and hope for Allah's mercy, as He is the Most Forgiving and Most Merciful. Their faith, sacrifices, and efforts in the way of Allah qualify them to be recipients of His boundless grace and compassion.
orig: إن الذين آمنوا والذين هاجروا وجاهدوا في سبيل الله أولئك يرجون رحمت الله والله غفور رحيم

translation: They ask you about wine and gambling. Say, "In them is great sin and [yet, some] benefit for people. But their sin is greater than their benefit." And they ask you what they should spend. Say, "The surplus [beyond needs]." Thus Allah makes clear to you the verses [of revelation] that you might give thought.
interpretation: This verse addresses the prohibition of intoxicants and gambling. It acknowledges that there may be some perceived benefits in them, but emphasizes that their sinful and harmful aspects outweigh any benefits. The verse also guides believers on how to spend their wealth - instructing them to spend what is surplus after fulfilling their needs and obligations. The interpretation encourages contemplation on these divine revelations.
orig: يسألونك عن الخمر والميسر قل فيهما إثم كبير ومنافع للناس وإثمهما أكبر من نفعهما ويسألونك ماذا ينفقون قل العفو كذلك يبين الله لكم الآيات لعلكم تتفكرون

translation: And they ask you about orphans. Say, "Reforming them is better. And if you mix your affairs with theirs, they are your brothers. And Allah knows the corrupter from the reformer. And if Allah willed, He could have put you in difficulty. Indeed, Allah is Exalted in Might and Wise."
interpretation: This verse discusses the proper treatment of orphans. It encourages reforming and improving their condition, as that is better for them. If one's affairs become intertwined with orphans, they should be treated as brothers. Allah knows those who intend corruption from those who intend reform. The verse reminds that if Allah willed, He could have made matters difficult, but out of His wisdom and mercy, He has made a way for people to deal justly with orphans.
orig: في الدنيا والآخرة ويسألونك عن اليتامى قل إصلاح لهم خير وإن تخالطوهم فإخوانكم والله يعلم المفسد من المصلح ولو شاء الله لأعنتكم إن الله عزيز حكيم

translation: And do not marry polytheistic women until they believe. And a believing slave woman is better than a polytheist, even though she might please you. And do not marry polytheistic men [to your women] until they believe. And a believing slave is better than a polytheist, even though he might please you. Those invite [you] to the Fire, but Allah invites to Paradise and to forgiveness, by His permission. And He makes clear His verses to the people that perhaps they may remember.
interpretation: This verse prohibits Muslims from marrying polytheists, whether men or women, until they embrace Islam. It emphasizes the superiority of a believing slave over a non-believing free person, even if the latter may seem more appealing. The verse contrasts the path of polytheists, who invite towards Hellfire, with the invitation of Allah towards Paradise and forgiveness. It serves as a reminder for people to reflect upon Allah's signs and guidance.
orig: ولا تنكحوا المشركات حتى يؤمن ولأمة مؤمنة خير من مشركة ولو أعجبتكم ولا تنكحوا المشركين حتى يؤمنوا ولعبد مؤمن خير من مشرك ولو أعجبكم أولئك يدعون إلى النار والله يدعو إلى الجنة والمغفرة بإذنه ويبين آياته للناس لعلهم يتذكرون

translation: And they ask you about menstruation. Say, "It is a discomfort, so keep away from wives during menstruation. And do not approach them until they are pure. And when they have purified themselves, then come to them from where Allah has ordained for you. Indeed, Allah loves those who are constantly repentant and loves those who purify themselves."
interpretation: This verse provides guidance on how to deal with menstruation. It instructs men to avoid intimate relations with their wives during their menstrual periods, as it is considered a state of impurity. However, once the woman has completed her period and purified herself, intimacy can be resumed. The verse emphasizes that Allah loves those who repent and purify themselves, highlighting the importance of following these guidelines with a pure intention and seeking forgiveness for any lapses.
orig: ويسألونك عن المحيض قل هو أذى فاعتزلوا النساء في المحيض ولا تقربوهن حتى يطهرن فإذا تطهرن فأتوهن من حيث أمركم الله إن الله يحب التوابين ويحب المتطهرين

translation: Your wives are a tilth for you, so go to your tilth when or how you will, and send (good deeds) before you for yourselves, and fear Allah, and know that you will (one day) meet Him. And give good tidings to those who believe.
interpretation: This verse is using the metaphor of a tilth (cultivable land) to refer to the intimate relationship between husband and wife. It gives the husband the right to approach his wife in whatever manner he desires, as long as it is through the proper means (i.e. vaginal intercourse). However, it also reminds believers to fear Allah, do good deeds, and keep in mind that they will be accountable to Him. The last part gives glad tidings to the believers.
orig: نساؤكم حرث لكم فأتوا حرثكم أنى شئتم وقدموا لأنفسكم واتقوا الله واعلموا أنكم ملاقوه وبشر المؤمنين

translation: And do not make Allah a target for your oaths against doing good and fearing Allah and making peace among people. And Allah is All-Hearer, All-Knower.
interpretation: "Do not use Allah's name in vain when swearing oaths to prevent yourself from doing good deeds, being righteous, and reconciling disputes among people. Allah hears all that you say and knows your intentions."
orig: ولا تجعلوا الله عرضة لأيمانكم أن تبروا وتتقوا وتصلحوا بين الناس والله سميع عليم

translation: Allah does not impose blame upon you for what is unintentional in your oaths, but He imposes blame upon you for what your hearts have earned. And Allah is Forgiving and Forbearing.
interpretation: Allah does not hold you accountable for mistaken or unintentional oaths, but He holds you accountable for the intentions and determinations of your hearts. Allah is Most Forgiving towards those who repent, and Most Forbearing with those who sin out of weakness.
orig: لا يؤاخذكم الله باللغو في أيمانكم ولكن يؤاخذكم بما كسبت قلوبكم والله غفور حليم

translation: For those who swear not to have sexual relations with their wives is a waiting time of four months, but if they go back, then indeed Allah is Oft-Forgiving, Most Merciful.
interpretation: "This verse refers to the practice of 'ila' in pre-Islamic times, where a husband would take an oath to avoid intimacy with his wife. Islam limited this practice to a maximum of four months, after which the husband must either revoke his oath and resume marital relations, or proceed with an irrevocable divorce. The verse highlights Allah's mercy by allowing the revocation of such oaths without penalty."
orig: للذين يؤلون من نسائهم تربص أربعة أشهر فإن فاءوا فإن الله غفور رحيم

translation: And if they decide on divorce - then indeed, Allah is All-Hearing, All-Knowing.
interpretation: If the couple decides to proceed with divorce, Allah is All-Aware of their circumstances and intentions. He hears their words and knows what is in their hearts. Therefore, they should approach this decision with sincerity, wisdom, and mindfulness of Allah's knowledge of their situation.
orig: وإن عزموا الطلاق فإن الله سميع عليم

translation: Divorced women must wait for three monthly periods before remarrying, and it is not lawful for them to conceal what Allah has created in their wombs, if they believe in Allah and the Last Day. Their husbands have the better right to take them back during this period, if they desire reconciliation. And women have rights similar to those held over them to be honoured with kindness, although men have a degree over them. And Allah is Mighty, Wise.
interpretation: This verse outlines the waiting period ('iddah) for divorced women, which is three menstrual cycles. During this time, they cannot conceal their pregnancy if they believe in Allah and the Last Day. Their former husbands have the right to take them back if they desire reconciliation. Women have rights similar to what is expected of them, but men have a degree over them in responsibilities. This reflects the wisdom and might of Allah.
orig: والمطلقات يتربصن بأنفسهن ثلاثة قروء ولا يحل لهن أن يكتمن ما خلق الله في أرحامهن إن كن يؤمن بالله واليوم الآخر وبعولتهن أحق بردهن في ذلك إن أرادوا إصلاحا ولهن مثل الذي عليهن بالمعروف وللرجال عليهن درجة والله عزيز حكيم

translation: Divorce is twice, then [there must be] either an acceptable retention or a release with kindness. And it is not lawful for you to take back anything of what you have given them, unless both fear that they will not maintain the limits of Allah. But if you fear that they will not maintain the limits of Allah, then there is no blame upon either of them concerning what she ransoms herself with. These are the limits of Allah, so do not transgress them, and whoever transgresses the limits of Allah - it is those who are the wrongdoers.
interpretation: L'interprétation de ce verset est que le divorce n'est permis que deux fois, après quoi le mari doit soit retenir son épouse de manière convenable, soit la libérer avec bonté. Il n'a pas le droit de reprendre ce qu'il lui a donné, sauf si les deux craignent de ne pas pouvoir respecter les lois d'Allah. Dans ce cas, la femme peut se racheter en rendant une partie de sa dot. Cependant, il est interdit de transgresser les lois d'Allah, et ceux qui le font sont des injustes.
orig: الطلاق مرتان فإمساك بمعروف أو تسريح بإحسان ولا يحل لكم أن تأخذوا مما آتيتموهن شيئا إلا أن يخافا ألا يقيما حدود الله فإن خفتم ألا يقيما حدود الله فلا جناح عليهما فيما افتدت به تلك حدود الله فلا تعتدوها ومن يتعد حدود الله فأولئك هم الظالمون

translation: And if he has divorced her [for the third time], then she is not lawful unto him thereafter until she has married another husband. Then, if the other husband divorces her, it is no sin on both of them that they reunite, provided they think they can keep the limits ordained by Allah. These are the limits of Allah, which He makes plain for the people who have knowledge.
interpretation: This verse outlines the conditions under which a divorced couple can remarry each other. If a man divorces his wife for the third time, she cannot remarry him until she marries another man and that marriage is consummated and then dissolved. If she marries another man and he divorces her, then she and her first husband can remarry without any sin, as long as they believe they can uphold the limits set by Allah. The verse emphasizes the importance of respecting Allah's limits and provides guidance for those who understand the wisdom behind these laws.
orig: فإن طلقها فلا تحل له من بعد حتى تنكح زوجا غيره فإن طلقها فلا جناح عليهما أن يتراجعا إن ظنا أن يقيما حدود الله وتلك حدود الله يبينها لقوم يعلمون

translation: And when you divorce women and they have reached their term, then retain them in a righteous manner or release them in a righteous manner. And do not retain them harmfully to transgress, and whoever does that has certainly wronged himself. And do not make the verses of Allah a mockery, and remember the favor of Allah upon you, and what has been revealed to you of the Book and wisdom by which He instructs you. And fear Allah, and know that Allah is Ever-Aware of everything.
interpretation: This verse provides instructions on how to treat divorced women with kindness and respect. It emphasizes the importance of being righteous in either retaining or releasing them, and warns against harming or oppressing them out of spite. It also reminds believers not to mock Allah's verses and to be grateful for His favors, the Qur'an, and the wisdom He has bestowed upon them. The verse concludes by urging the fear of Allah and reminding that He is Ever-Aware of all things.
orig: وإذا طلقتم النساء فبلغن أجلهن فأمسكوهن بمعروف أو سرحوهن بمعروف ولا تمسكوهن ضرارا لتعتدوا ومن يفعل ذلك فقد ظلم نفسه ولا تتخذوا آيات الله هزوا واذكروا نعمت الله عليكم وما أنزل عليكم من الكتاب والحكمة يعظكم به واتقوا الله واعلموا أن الله بكل شيء عليم

translation: And when you divorce women and they have reached their term, do not prevent them from remarrying their husbands if they mutually agree on equitable terms. This is an admonition for whoever among you believes in Allah and the Last Day. That is more virtuous for you and purer. And Allah knows, and you do not know.
interpretation: This verse instructs Muslim men not to prevent divorced women from remarrying their former husbands if they both desire to reconcile on fair and reasonable terms. It emphasizes the importance of facilitating reconciliation between divorced spouses, as this is virtuous and pure in the sight of Allah. The verse reminds believers of their faith in Allah and the Last Day, encouraging them to follow this guidance for the sake of their spiritual well-being. It also highlights Allah's supreme knowledge, contrasting it with human ignorance.
orig: وإذا طلقتم النساء فبلغن أجلهن فلا تعضلوهن أن ينكحن أزواجهن إذا تراضوا بينهم بالمعروف ذلك يوعظ به من كان منكم يؤمن بالله واليوم الآخر ذلكم أزكى لكم وأطهر والله يعلم وأنتم لا تعلمون

translation: Mothers shall nurse their children for two whole years, for those who desire to complete the nursing period. And the father is responsible for providing their sustenance and clothing in an honorable manner. No soul is burdened beyond its capacity. A mother should not be harmed because of her child, nor a father because of his child. The same applies to the heir. If they desire weaning by mutual consent and consultation, there is no blame upon them. And if you desire to have your children nursed by a substitute, there is no blame upon you as long as you give what is due, in a fair manner. Fear Allah and know that Allah is All-Seer of what you do.
interpretation: This verse lays down guidelines for the nursing period and responsibilities of parents towards their children. It emphasizes the importance of mutual consultation, fairness, and moderation in fulfilling these duties, while recognizing that no one should be overburdened beyond their capacity. It also allows for the option of hiring a wet nurse if needed, as long as proper compensation is provided. The verse ultimately reminds believers to fear Allah and be mindful that He is aware of their actions.
orig: والوالدات يرضعن أولادهن حولين كاملين لمن أراد أن يتم الرضاعة وعلى المولود له رزقهن وكسوتهن بالمعروف لا تكلف نفس إلا وسعها لا تضار والدة بولدها ولا مولود له بولده وعلى الوارث مثل ذلك فإن أرادا فصالا عن تراض منهما وتشاور فلا جناح عليهما وإن أردتم أن تسترضعوا أولادكم فلا جناح عليكم إذا سلمتم ما آتيتم بالمعروف واتقوا الله واعلموا أن الله بما تعملون بصير

translation: And those who are taken in death among you and leave wives behind - they, [the wives, shall] wait four months and ten [days]. And when they have fulfilled their term, then there is no blame upon you for what they do with themselves in an acceptable manner. And Allah is [fully] Acquainted with what you do.
interpretation: This verse outlines the waiting period ('iddah) for widows before they can remarry. It states that a woman whose husband has passed away must wait for four months and ten days before remarrying. After this period, she is free to make her own choice regarding remarriage in a lawful and acceptable manner, and there is no blame on others for her decision. Allah is fully aware of people's actions.
orig: والذين يتوفون منكم ويذرون أزواجا يتربصن بأنفسهن أربعة أشهر وعشرا فإذا بلغن أجلهن فلا جناح عليكم فيما فعلن في أنفسهن بالمعروف والله بما تعملون خبير

translation: There is no blame upon you for that to which you indirectly allude concerning a proposal to women or for what you conceal within yourselves. Allah knows that you will have them in mind. But do not make a secret contract with them except in honorable terms, and do not determine to tie the marriage knot until the decreed period reaches its term. And know that Allah knows what is in your souls, so beware of Him. And know that Allah is Oft-Forgiving, Most Forbearing.
interpretation: This verse is addressing the issue of proposing marriage to women. It states that there is no sin in indirectly hinting at the desire to marry a woman or keeping such intentions to oneself, as Allah knows what is in people's hearts. However, one should not make a secret commitment or contract with the woman, except through proper and honorable means. Additionally, the marriage should not be formalized until the prescribed waiting period (e.g., for a widow or divorced woman) has ended. The verse reminds believers that Allah is aware of their innermost thoughts and intentions, so they should be mindful of Him and His commands. It also highlights Allah's attributes of being Oft-Forgiving and Most Forbearing.
orig: ولا جناح عليكم فيما عرضتم به من خطبة النساء أو أكننتم في أنفسكم علم الله أنكم ستذكرونهن ولكن لا تواعدوهن سرا إلا أن تقولوا قولا معروفا ولا تعزموا عقدة النكاح حتى يبلغ الكتاب أجله واعلموا أن الله يعلم ما في أنفسكم فاحذروه واعلموا أن الله غفور حليم

translation: There is no blame upon you if you divorce women you have not touched nor specified for them an obligation. But give them [a gift of] compensation - the wealthy according to his capability and the poor according to his capability - a provision according to what is acceptable, a duty upon the good-doers.
interpretation: Allah is saying that if a man divorces his wife before consummating the marriage and before specifying her dowry, he is not sinful. However, he must give her a gift or compensation according to his financial means, as an obligation upon the righteous believers.
orig: لا جناح عليكم إن طلقتم النساء ما لم تمسوهن أو تفرضوا لهن فريضة ومتعوهن على الموسع قدره وعلى المقتر قدره متاعا بالمعروف حقا على المحسنين

translation: And if you divorce them before you have touched them and you have already specified for them an obligation, then [give] half of what you specified - unless they forego the right or the one in whose hand is the marriage contract foregoes it. And to forego it is nearer to righteousness. And do not forget graciousness between you. Indeed Allah, of whatever you do, is Seeing.
interpretation: This verse discusses the case of divorce before consummation of marriage. It instructs that if a man divorces his wife before intimate relations, and he had already assigned a dowry (mahr) for her, he must give her half of the specified dowry. However, the wife or the husband can forgo this right if they wish. The verse encourages forgoing the dowry as an act of righteousness and reminds believers to maintain graciousness and kindness towards each other, as Allah is All-Aware of their deeds.
orig: وإن طلقتموهن من قبل أن تمسوهن وقد فرضتم لهن فريضة فنصف ما فرضتم إلا أن يعفون أو يعفو الذي بيده عقدة النكاح وأن تعفوا أقرب للتقوى ولا تنسوا الفضل بينكم إن الله بما تعملون بصير

translation: Guard strictly the prayers, especially the middle prayer, and stand before Allah in devotion.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of maintaining the obligatory prayers, particularly the middle prayer, which is the Asr (afternoon) prayer. It encourages Muslims to perform their prayers with utmost devotion, sincerity, and humility before Allah. The verse reminds believers to be steadfast in their worship and to stand humbly in the presence of Allah, acknowledging His greatness and submitting to His commands.
orig: حافظوا على الصلوات والصلاة الوسطى وقوموا لله قانتين

translation: But if you fear (an enemy), then (pray) on foot or riding. And when you are secure, then remember Allah as He has taught you that which you did not know.
interpretation: If you are in a situation of fear or danger from an enemy, you can pray on foot or while riding, according to your circumstances. But when you are safe and secure, then perform the prayer properly with all its requirements, as Allah has taught you through His Messenger the ways of worship that you did not know before.
orig: فإن خفتم فرجالا أو ركبانا فإذا أمنتم فاذكروا الله كما علمكم ما لم تكونوا تعلمون

translation: And those among you who are taken in death and leave wives behind - for their wives is a bequest: maintenance for one year without turning them out. But if they leave [of their own accord], then there is no blame upon you for what they do with themselves in an acceptable way. And Allah is Exalted in Might and Wise.
interpretation: This verse outlines the rights of widows in Islam. It instructs that if a man passes away leaving a wife behind, she is entitled to be provided with housing and maintenance for one year after his death. However, if she chooses to leave the residence of her own accord before the year is over, then there is no sin upon the heirs for not providing for her beyond that point, as long as she is treated fairly and her rights are fulfilled. This ruling reflects Allah's wisdom in upholding justice and protecting the rights of widows.
orig: والذين يتوفون منكم ويذرون أزواجا وصية لأزواجهم متاعا إلى الحول غير إخراج فإن خرجن فلا جناح عليكم في ما فعلن في أنفسهن من معروف والله عزيز حكيم

translation: And for divorced women is a provision according to what is reasonable - a duty upon the righteous.
interpretation: This verse establishes the obligation upon divorced husbands to provide maintenance for their divorced wives during the waiting period ('iddah). This provision is considered a right of the divorced wife and a duty upon the righteous, God-fearing husbands. The provision should be given "according to what is reasonable," meaning it should be commensurate with the husband's financial means and the wife's standard of living during the marriage.
orig: وللمطلقات متاع بالمعروف حقا على المتقين

translation: Thus does Allah make clear to you His verses that you might use reason.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the purpose behind Allah revealing His signs and verses, which is to encourage people to use their intellect and reasoning abilities to comprehend and reflect upon the profound wisdom and guidance contained within them. It serves as a reminder for individuals to ponder over the divine revelations with an open and rational mind, allowing them to derive meaningful lessons and insights that can guide their thoughts and actions towards righteousness and spiritual growth.
orig: كذلك يبين الله لكم آياته لعلكم تعقلون

translation: Have you not seen those who left their homes, though they were thousands, for fear of death? Then Allah said to them, 'Die'; then He restored them to life. Truly, Allah is the Possessor of Bounties for mankind, but most people are ungrateful.
interpretation: This verse refers to a group of Israelites who fled their homes out of fear of death from a plague. Allah commanded them to die, and they died. Then Allah brought them back to life to show His power and grace. It teaches that Allah has control over life and death, and that He bestows favors upon people, but most are ungrateful for His blessings.
orig: ألم تر إلى الذين خرجوا من ديارهم وهم ألوف حذر الموت فقال لهم الله موتوا ثم أحياهم إن الله لذو فضل على الناس ولكن أكثر الناس لا يشكرون

translation: And fight in the cause of Allah and know that Allah is All-Hearing, All-Knowing.
interpretation: This verse commands the believers to strive and fight in the cause of Allah, which includes defending the faith, protecting the oppressed, and establishing justice. However, it emphasizes that this struggle should be undertaken with the awareness that Allah is All-Hearing, listening to every word and intention, and All-Knowing, aware of every action and circumstance. This awareness should instill a sense of accountability and sincerity in the believers, ensuring that their motives and actions align with the principles of Islam and the pleasure of Allah.
orig: وقاتلوا في سبيل الله واعلموا أن الله سميع عليم

translation: Who is it that will lend Allah a goodly loan so He may multiply it for him manifold? And Allah straitens and amplifies, and unto Him you will be returned.
interpretation: This verse encourages people to spend in the way of Allah and do good deeds, which Allah will reward them for multiplying their rewards manifold. It emphasizes that Allah has control over provision and can increase or decrease it as He wills, and that ultimately all will return to Him on the Day of Judgment.
orig: من ذا الذي يقرض الله قرضا حسنا فيضاعفه له أضعافا كثيرة والله يقبض ويبسط وإليه ترجعون

translation: Have you not considered the chiefs of the Children of Israel after Moses, when they said to a prophet of theirs, "Appoint for us a king so we may fight in the way of Allah?" He said, "Would you perhaps refrain from fighting if fighting was prescribed for you?" They said, "And why should we not fight in the cause of Allah when we have been driven out from our homes and our children?" But when fighting was prescribed for them, they turned away, except for a few of them. And Allah is Knowing of the wrongdoers.
interpretation: This verse refers to an incident involving the Children of Israel after the time of Prophet Moses. They asked one of their prophets to appoint a king for them so they could fight in the way of Allah. However, when fighting was prescribed for them, most of them turned away from it, except for a few. The interpretation highlights their initial enthusiasm to fight for the cause of Allah, but their lack of commitment when actually called upon to fight. It serves as a lesson on the importance of steadfastness and fulfilling one's promises, and Allah's knowledge of those who act wrongfully.
orig: ألم تر إلى الملإ من بني إسرائيل من بعد موسى إذ قالوا لنبي لهم ابعث لنا ملكا نقاتل في سبيل الله قال هل عسيتم إن كتب عليكم القتال ألا تقاتلوا قالوا وما لنا ألا نقاتل في سبيل الله وقد أخرجنا من ديارنا وأبنائنا فلما كتب عليهم القتال تولوا إلا قليلا منهم والله عليم بالظالمين

translation: And their Prophet said to them, 'Indeed, Allah has sent to you Saul as a king.' They said, 'How can he have kingship over us while we are more worthy of kingship than him and he has not been given any wealth?' He said, 'Indeed, Allah has chosen him over you and has increased him abundantly in knowledge and stature. And Allah gives His sovereignty to whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing [in favor] and All-Knowing.'
interpretation: This verse describes the reaction of the Israelites when their prophet informed them that Allah had appointed Saul as their king. They questioned his worthiness, citing their own superiority and Saul's lack of wealth. However, the prophet explained that Allah had chosen Saul based on his knowledge and physical stature, emphasizing that Allah bestows sovereignty upon whomever He wills, as He is All-Knowing and All-Encompassing in His wisdom.
orig: وقال لهم نبيهم إن الله قد بعث لكم طالوت ملكا قالوا أنى يكون له الملك علينا ونحن أحق بالملك منه ولم يؤت سعة من المال قال إن الله اصطفاه عليكم وزاده بسطة في العلم والجسم والله يؤتي ملكه من يشاء والله واسع عليم

translation: And their prophet said to them, 'The sign of his kingship is that the chest will come to you in which is reassurance from your Lord and a remnant of what the family of Moses and the family of Aaron had left, carried by the angels. Indeed in that is a sign for you, if you are believers.'
interpretation: Cette interprétation souligne que le signe de la royauté du prophète était l'arrivée de l'Arche d'alliance, contenant la sécurité et la tranquillité de Dieu ainsi que les reliques laissées par Moïse et Aaron. L'Arche, portée par les anges, était une preuve évidente de la véracité du prophète pour ceux qui avaient la foi.
orig: وقال لهم نبيهم إن آية ملكه أن يأتيكم التابوت فيه سكينة من ربكم وبقية مما ترك آل موسى وآل هارون تحمله الملائكة إن في ذلك لآية لكم إن كنتم مؤمنين

translation: So when Talut set out with the armies, he said: 'Allah will test you with a river. Whoever drinks from it is not with me, and whoever does not taste it is indeed with me, except for whoever scoops up a little with his hand.' But they drank from it, except a few of them. And when he had crossed it along with those who believed with him, they said: 'We have no power this day against Jalut and his soldiers.' But those who were certain that they would meet Allah said: 'How many a small company has overcome a mighty host by Allah's leave! And Allah is with the patient.'
interpretation: This verse describes a test that Allah put the believers through under the leadership of Prophet Talut (Saul). The river was a means to distinguish the truly faithful from those who lacked determination. Those who drank from the river excessively failed the test, while those who exercised restraint by taking only a handful of water passed. When faced with the mighty army of Jalut (Goliath), the believers were divided into two groups: those who feared defeat, and those who had firm faith in Allah's help and remained steadfast. The latter group reminded the former that with Allah's aid, a small force can overcome a much larger enemy. The verse emphasizes the importance of patience, restraint, and unwavering faith in the face of adversity.
orig: فلما فصل طالوت بالجنود قال إن الله مبتليكم بنهر فمن شرب منه فليس مني ومن لم يطعمه فإنه مني إلا من اغترف غرفة بيده فشربوا منه إلا قليلا منهم فلما جاوزه هو والذين آمنوا معه قالوا لا طاقة لنا اليوم بجالوت وجنوده قال الذين يظنون أنهم ملاقو الله كم من فئة قليلة غلبت فئة كثيرة بإذن الله والله مع الصابرين

translation: And when they went forth to meet Goliath and his forces, they said: 'Our Lord! Pour out constancy on us and make our footsteps firm, and give us victory over the disbelieving people.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the battle between the Israelites and the Philistines, led by Goliath. The Israelites prayed to Allah to grant them patience, steadfastness, and victory over the disbelieving Philistines. It teaches us to put our trust in Allah and seek His help in times of difficulty and adversity.
orig: ولما برزوا لجالوت وجنوده قالوا ربنا أفرغ علينا صبرا وثبت أقدامنا وانصرنا على القوم الكافرين

translation: So they defeated them by Allah's permission, and David killed Goliath, and Allah gave him the kingship and wisdom, and taught him from what He willed. And if not for Allah's repelling some people by means of others, the earth would have been corrupted, but Allah is full of bounty over the worlds.
interpretation: This verse describes the victory of the believers led by Prophet David over the disbelievers, and how Allah granted David the ability to kill the mighty Goliath. It also mentions that Allah bestowed upon David kingship, wisdom, and knowledge according to His will. The verse further states that if Allah did not repel some people by means of others, the earth would have been corrupted with injustice and oppression. However, Allah is Gracious and Merciful towards all the worlds, maintaining balance and order through His divine wisdom.
orig: فهزموهم بإذن الله وقتل داوود جالوت وآتاه الله الملك والحكمة وعلمه مما يشاء ولولا دفع الله الناس بعضهم ببعض لفسدت الأرض ولكن الله ذو فضل على العالمين

translation: These are the verses of Allah which We recite to you in truth, and indeed you are from among the Messengers.
interpretation: This verse affirms that the Qur'an consists of the true words of Allah, revealed to the Prophet Muhammad, who is one of the noble Messengers sent by Allah to guide humanity. It establishes the divine origin and truthfulness of the Qur'anic revelations.
orig: تلك آيات الله نتلوها عليك بالحق وإنك لمن المرسلين

translation: Those messengers - some of them We endowed with greater virtue than others. Among them were those to whom Allah spoke directly, and some He raised in rank. We gave Jesus son of Mary profound miracles and supported him with the holy spirit. Had Allah willed, those after them would not have fought one another after receiving the clear revelations. But they differed - some believed while others disbelieved. Yet had Allah willed, they would not have fought one another. But Allah does whatever He desires.
interpretation: This verse highlights the exalted status of the messengers and prophets, and that Allah favored some over others. It mentions that Jesus, son of Mary, was given clear signs and miracles, and was supported by the holy spirit. The verse then states that if Allah had willed, the people after the prophets would not have differed and fought among themselves despite receiving clear revelations. However, they differed, with some believing and others disbelieving. Ultimately, Allah does as He wills, and had He willed, they would not have fought.
orig: تلك الرسل فضلنا بعضهم على بعض منهم من كلم الله ورفع بعضهم درجات وآتينا عيسى ابن مريم البينات وأيدناه بروح القدس ولو شاء الله ما اقتتل الذين من بعدهم من بعد ما جاءتهم البينات ولكن اختلفوا فمنهم من آمن ومنهم من كفر ولو شاء الله ما اقتتلوا ولكن الله يفعل ما يريد

translation: O you who believe! Spend of that with which We have provided for you, before a Day comes when there will be no bargaining, nor friendship, nor intercession. And it is the disbelievers who are the Zalimun (wrong-doers).
interpretation: Allah is commanding the believers to spend from the wealth He has provided them, in obedience to Him and in charitable ways, before the Day of Resurrection comes. On that Day, there will be no opportunity to engage in trade or business to earn more wealth, no close relationships or friendships that could benefit anyone, and no intercession that could rescue the disbelievers from Allah's punishment. The disbelievers are the true wrongdoers for rejecting faith and failing to spend in Allah's cause.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا أنفقوا مما رزقناكم من قبل أن يأتي يوم لا بيع فيه ولا خلة ولا شفاعة والكافرون هم الظالمون

translation: Allah - there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of existence. Neither drowsiness overtakes Him nor sleep. To Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. Who is it that can intercede with Him except by His permission? He knows what is [presently] before them and what will be after them, and they encompass not a thing of His knowledge except for what He wills. His Kursi extends over the heavens and the earth, and their preservation tires Him not. And He is the Most High, the Most Great.
interpretation: This verse affirms the Oneness and Absoluteness of Allah, the Eternal and Ever-Living God who sustains all of existence. It emphasizes that He is unlike His creation, free from any need for sleep or rest. Everything in the heavens and earth belongs to Him, and no one can intercede with Him except by His permission. His knowledge encompasses all things, and nothing is hidden from Him. His authority and dominion extend over the heavens and the earth, yet their preservation does not burden Him in the least. He is the Most High, the Most Great, exalted above all creation.
orig: الله لا إله إلا هو الحي القيوم لا تأخذه سنة ولا نوم له ما في السماوات وما في الأرض من ذا الذي يشفع عنده إلا بإذنه يعلم ما بين أيديهم وما خلفهم ولا يحيطون بشيء من علمه إلا بما شاء وسع كرسيه السماوات والأرض ولا يئوده حفظهما وهو العلي العظيم

translation: There shall be no compulsion in [acceptance of] the religion. The right course has become clear from the wrong. So whoever disbelieves in Taghut and believes in Allah has grasped the most trustworthy handhold with no break in it. And Allah is Hearing and Knowing.
interpretation: This verse establishes the principle of freedom of religion and prohibits compulsion in matters of faith. It declares that the truth has been made distinct from falsehood, and those who reject false deities and believe in Allah have grasped a firm handhold that will never break. Allah is All-Hearing and All-Knowing of the choices people make regarding their beliefs.
orig: لا إكراه في الدين قد تبين الرشد من الغي فمن يكفر بالطاغوت ويؤمن بالله فقد استمسك بالعروة الوثقى لا انفصام لها والله سميع عليم

translation: Allah is the Protector of those who believe. He brings them out from darkness into light. And those who disbelieve - their protectors are false deities, bringing them out from light into darkness. Those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally.
interpretation: This verse highlights the contrasting realities of believers and disbelievers. Allah guides the believers from the darkness of ignorance, misguidance, and disbelief to the light of faith, knowledge, and righteousness. However, the disbelievers follow false deities and are led from the light of truth to the darkness of falsehood and error. The verse emphasizes that the ultimate destination of the disbelievers is the Hellfire, where they will abide forever, while the believers will attain salvation under Allah's protection.
orig: الله ولي الذين آمنوا يخرجهم من الظلمات إلى النور والذين كفروا أولياؤهم الطاغوت يخرجونهم من النور إلى الظلمات أولئك أصحاب النار هم فيها خالدون

translation: Have you not considered the one who argued with Abraham about his Lord because Allah had given him kingship? When Abraham said, "My Lord is the one who gives life and causes death," he said, "I give life and cause death." Abraham said, "Then surely Allah brings up the sun from the east, so bring it up from the west." So the disbeliever was dumbstruck. And Allah does not guide the wrongdoing people.
interpretation: This verse refers to a debate between the Prophet Abraham and a disbelieving king who claimed to have the power to give life and cause death. When Abraham pointed out that it is Allah who gives life and causes death, the king arrogantly claimed to have the same power. Abraham then challenged him to bring the sun from the west if he truly had such power, which left the disbeliever speechless and unable to respond. The verse emphasizes that Allah alone has supreme power and authority, and that He does not guide those who persist in wrongdoing and disbelief.
orig: ألم تر إلى الذي حاج إبراهيم في ربه أن آتاه الله الملك إذ قال إبراهيم ربي الذي يحيي ويميت قال أنا أحيي وأميت قال إبراهيم فإن الله يأتي بالشمس من المشرق فأت بها من المغرب فبهت الذي كفر والله لا يهدي القوم الظالمين

translation: Or [consider such an example] as the one who passed by a township which had fallen into ruin. He said, 'How will Allah bring this to life after its death?' So Allah caused him to die for a hundred years; then He revived him. He said, 'How long have you remained?' He replied, 'I have remained a day or part of a day.' He said, 'Rather, you have remained one hundred years. Look at your food and drink - it has not spoiled, but look at your donkey. And We have made you a sign for the people. And look at the bones - how We raise them and then We cover them with flesh.' And when it became clear to him, he said, 'I know that Allah is over all things competent.'
interpretation: This verse presents an example of Allah's power to resurrect the dead. A man passed by a ruined town and doubted how Allah could revive it after its destruction. Allah caused him to die for a hundred years, then revived him. When he awoke, he thought he had been dead for only a day or part of a day, but Allah showed him signs that he had been dead for a century: his food and drink were unspoiled, his donkey had decayed, and Allah showed him how bones can be reassembled and covered with flesh. This example demonstrates Allah's ability to bring the dead back to life on the Day of Resurrection.
orig: أو كالذي مر على قرية وهي خاوية على عروشها قال أنى يحيي هذه الله بعد موتها فأماته الله مائة عام ثم بعثه قال كم لبثت قال لبثت يوما أو بعض يوم قال بل لبثت مائة عام فانظر إلى طعامك وشرابك لم يتسنه وانظر إلى حمارك ولنجعلك آية للناس وانظر إلى العظام كيف ننشزها ثم نكسوها لحما فلما تبين له قال أعلم أن الله على كل شيء قدير

translation: And [mention, O Muhammad], when Abraham said, "My Lord, show me how You give life to the dead." [Allah] said, "Have you not believed?" He said, "Yes, but [I ask] only that my heart may be satisfied." [Allah] said, "Take four birds and commit them to yourself. Then [after slaughtering them] put on each hill a portion of them; then call them - they will come [flying] to you in haste. And know that Allah is Exalted in Might and Wise."
interpretation: Cette verse décrit l'épisode où le prophète Abraham demanda à Dieu de lui montrer comment Il redonne vie aux morts. Bien qu'Abraham croyait déjà en Dieu, il voulait avoir une preuve tangible pour apaiser son cœur. Dieu lui ordonna alors de prendre quatre oiseaux, de les tuer et de disperser leurs morceaux sur différentes collines. Puis, quand Abraham les appela, les oiseaux revinrent à la vie et volèrent vers lui. Ceci fut un signe de la puissance et de la sagesse de Dieu pour ressusciter les morts le Jour du Jugement.
orig: وإذ قال إبراهيم رب أرني كيف تحيي الموتى قال أولم تؤمن قال بلى ولكن ليطمئن قلبي قال فخذ أربعة من الطير فصرهن إليك ثم اجعل على كل جبل منهن جزءا ثم ادعهن يأتينك سعيا واعلم أن الله عزيز حكيم

translation: The example of those who spend their wealth in the way of Allah is like a seed which grows seven spikes, in each spike there are one hundred grains. And Allah multiplies [His reward] for whom He wills. And Allah is all-Encompassing and Knowing.
interpretation: This verse uses a parable to illustrate the immense rewards awaiting those who spend their wealth in the cause of Allah. Their act of spending is likened to a seed that produces seven ears of grain, each containing a hundred grains. This represents the manifold increase in reward that Allah bestows upon the charitable. The verse emphasizes Allah's power to multiply rewards without limit for whomever He wills, as He is Infinite and All-Knowing.
orig: مثل الذين ينفقون أموالهم في سبيل الله كمثل حبة أنبتت سبع سنابل في كل سنبلة مائة حبة والله يضاعف لمن يشاء والله واسع عليم

translation: Those who spend their wealth in the way of Allah and then do not follow up what they have spent with reminders of it or [other] injury, for them is their reward with their Lord, and there will be no fear concerning them, nor will they grieve.
interpretation: This verse is praising those who spend their wealth for the sake of Allah without expecting anything in return, whether it be gratitude or praise from others. Their reward is with Allah, and they will have no fear or grief on the Day of Judgment.
orig: الذين ينفقون أموالهم في سبيل الله ثم لا يتبعون ما أنفقوا منا ولا أذى لهم أجرهم عند ربهم ولا خوف عليهم ولا هم يحزنون

translation: Kind speech and forgiveness are better than charity followed by injury. And Allah is Free of need and Forbearing.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of treating others with kindness, compassion, and forgiveness. It suggests that offering kind words and forgiving others is superior to giving charity while causing harm or offense. The verse also highlights that Allah is Self-Sufficient and does not need our charity, and that He is Forbearing and pardons our shortcomings.
orig: قول معروف ومغفرة خير من صدقة يتبعها أذى والله غني حليم

translation: O you who have believed, do not invalidate your charities with reminders or injury as one who spends his wealth only to be seen by the people and does not believe in Allah and the Last Day. His example is like that of a smooth rock upon which is dust and is hit by a downpour that leaves it bare. They are unable [to keep] anything of what they have earned. And Allah does not guide the disbelieving people.
interpretation: This verse warns believers not to nullify their charitable deeds by reminding the recipients of their favors or hurting them. It likens the one who spends wealth only to show off and does not believe in Allah and the Hereafter to a smooth rock covered with dust that is washed away by rain, leaving it bare. Such people will not benefit from their deeds in the Hereafter, and Allah does not guide the disbelievers.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا لا تبطلوا صدقاتكم بالمن والأذى كالذي ينفق ماله رئاء الناس ولا يؤمن بالله واليوم الآخر فمثله كمثل صفوان عليه تراب فأصابه وابل فتركه صلدا لا يقدرون على شيء مما كسبوا والله لا يهدي القوم الكافرين

translation: And the example of those who spend their wealth seeking the pleasure of Allah and assuring their souls is like a garden on a high ground which is hit by a downpour, so it yields its fruit twofold. And if it is not hit by a downpour, then a drizzle [is sufficient]. And Allah is Seeing of what you do.
interpretation: This verse uses the parable of a fertile garden to illustrate the reward for those who spend their wealth sincerely for the sake of pleasing Allah and strengthening their faith. Just as a garden on elevated land benefits greatly from rain, whether heavy or light, those who spend in Allah's cause will be abundantly rewarded, regardless of how much they give. Their reward is multiplied manifold by Allah's grace, and He is fully aware of their intentions and deeds.
orig: ومثل الذين ينفقون أموالهم ابتغاء مرضات الله وتثبيتا من أنفسهم كمثل جنة بربوة أصابها وابل فآتت أكلها ضعفين فإن لم يصبها وابل فطل والله بما تعملون بصير

translation: Would one of you wish to have a garden of date-palms and vines, with rivers flowing beneath it, with all kinds of fruits for him therein, and he is afflicted with old age and has weak offspring, then it is struck by a whirlwind containing fire, so it gets burnt? Thus does Allah make the signs clear for you, that you may reflect.
interpretation: This verse uses a parable to illustrate the transient nature of worldly possessions and pleasures. It describes a person who has a lush garden with rivers, fruits, and offspring, but then old age strikes, rendering the offspring weak. Then a fiery whirlwind destroys the garden. This parable teaches that no matter how prosperous one may be in this life, everything is temporary and can be taken away suddenly. The verse encourages reflection on the impermanence of worldly things and the importance of focusing on the Hereafter.
orig: أيود أحدكم أن تكون له جنة من نخيل وأعناب تجري من تحتها الأنهار له فيها من كل الثمرات وأصابه الكبر وله ذرية ضعفاء فأصابها إعصار فيه نار فاحترقت كذلك يبين الله لكم الآيات لعلكم تتفكرون

translation: O you who believe! Spend of the good things which you have earned, and of that which We bring forth from the earth for you, and do not aim at that which is bad to spend from it, (though) you would not accept it save if you closed your eyes to it. And know that Allah is Free of all wants, Worthy of all praise.
interpretation: This verse instructs the believers to spend from the good and pure things they have earned through lawful means, and from the pure and wholesome provisions that Allah has produced from the earth. It prohibits them from intending to give away impure, harmful, or worthless things in charity, which they themselves would not accept except by closing their eyes to its defects. It reminds them that Allah is Self-Sufficient, not in need of their charity, and Worthy of all praise for His bounties.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا أنفقوا من طيبات ما كسبتم ومما أخرجنا لكم من الأرض ولا تيمموا الخبيث منه تنفقون ولستم بآخذيه إلا أن تغمضوا فيه واعلموا أن الله غني حميد

translation: Satan threatens you with poverty and orders you to immorality, while Allah promises you forgiveness from Him and bounty. And Allah is All-Encompassing and All-Knowing.
interpretation: This verse contrasts the promises of Satan with those of Allah. Satan tries to mislead people by threatening them with poverty and tempting them towards immorality. On the other hand, Allah promises forgiveness for sins and abundant provision for those who follow His guidance. The verse emphasizes that Allah's knowledge and bounties are vast, unlike Satan's deception and false promises.
orig: الشيطان يعدكم الفقر ويأمركم بالفحشاء والله يعدكم مغفرة منه وفضلا والله واسع عليم

translation: He gives wisdom to whom He wills, and whoever has been given wisdom has certainly been given much good. And none will remember except those of understanding.
interpretation: Allah bestows wisdom, which is the ability to comprehend the truth and act accordingly, upon whomever He wills from among His servants. Whoever is granted this wisdom has indeed been blessed with an immense good. However, only those who possess sound intellect and understanding truly benefit from this wisdom and take heed of its lessons.
orig: يؤتي الحكمة من يشاء ومن يؤت الحكمة فقد أوتي خيرا كثيرا وما يذكر إلا أولو الألباب

translation: And whatever you spend for sustenance or whatever you vow as a vow, indeed Allah knows it. And for the wrongdoers there are no helpers.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that Allah is fully aware of all our expenditures and vows. It encourages spending in His cause and fulfilling our vows, as nothing is hidden from Him. Additionally, it warns that those who commit wrongdoings will find no helpers or protectors on the Day of Judgment.
orig: وما أنفقتم من نفقة أو نذرتم من نذر فإن الله يعلمه وما للظالمين من أنصار

translation: If you disclose your charitable expenditures, that is well, but if you conceal them and give them to the poor, it is better for you, and He will remove from you some of your misdeeds [thereby]. And Allah, with what you do, is All-Acquainted.
interpretation: This verse highlights the virtue of giving charity secretly. While public charity is permissible, concealing one's charitable acts and giving directly to the needy is superior and more rewarding. It purifies the giver from sins and misdeeds. Ultimately, Allah is fully aware of all our actions, whether done publicly or privately.
orig: إن تبدوا الصدقات فنعما هي وإن تخفوها وتؤتوها الفقراء فهو خير لكم ويكفر عنكم من سيئاتكم والله بما تعملون خبير

translation: Not upon you is their guidance, but Allah guides whom He wills. And whatever good you [believers] spend is for yourselves, and you do not spend except seeking the Countenance of Allah. And whatever you spend of good - it will be fully repaid to you, and you will not be wronged.
interpretation: Cette interprétation souligne que le Prophète n'est pas responsable de guider les gens vers la foi, car c'est Allah qui guide qui Il veut. Elle encourage également les croyants à dépenser leurs richesses dans de bonnes causes, non pas pour être vus des autres, mais pour chercher l'agrément d'Allah. Allah promet de récompenser pleinement ces dépenses charitables, sans que les croyants ne soient lésés.
orig: ليس عليك هداهم ولكن الله يهدي من يشاء وما تنفقوا من خير فلأنفسكم وما تنفقون إلا ابتغاء وجه الله وما تنفقوا من خير يوف إليكم وأنتم لا تظلمون

translation: For the poor who are confined in the way of Allah, unable to travel in the land. The ignorant person considers them self-sufficient due to their dignity. You can recognize them by their appearance. They do not ask people imploringly. And whatever good you spend, Allah is truly Aware of it.
interpretation: This verse refers to a category of poor people who are unable to travel and earn a living due to being engaged in the cause of Allah. They are too dignified to beg, so an ignorant person may assume they are wealthy. Allah advises recognizing them by their modest appearance and not their words, and spending on them, for He is fully Aware of such good deeds.
orig: للفقراء الذين أحصروا في سبيل الله لا يستطيعون ضربا في الأرض يحسبهم الجاهل أغنياء من التعفف تعرفهم بسيماهم لا يسألون الناس إلحافا وما تنفقوا من خير فإن الله به عليم

translation: Those who spend their wealth by night and day, privately and publicly, they will have their reward with their Lord, and they will have no fear, nor will they grieve.
interpretation: This verse encourages spending in the way of Allah, whether openly or secretly, day or night. Those who give charitably out of their wealth with sincerity will be rewarded by Allah, and they will have no fear of the future or grief over what has passed.
orig: الذين ينفقون أموالهم بالليل والنهار سرا وعلانية فلهم أجرهم عند ربهم ولا خوف عليهم ولا هم يحزنون

translation: Those who consume interest cannot stand [on the Day of Resurrection] except as one stands who is being beaten by Satan into insanity. That is because they say, 'Trade is [just] like interest.' But Allah has permitted trade and has forbidden interest. So whoever has received an admonition from his Lord and desists may have what is past, and his affair rests with Allah. But whoever returns [to dealing in interest or usury] - those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide eternally therein.
interpretation: Cette verse condamne fermement l'intérêt usuraire (riba) et le compare à la folie provoquée par Satan. Elle établit une distinction claire entre le commerce licite et l'intérêt illicite. Ceux qui persistent dans la pratique de l'intérêt après avoir été avertis seront voués au châtiment éternel de l'Enfer. En revanche, ceux qui s'abstiennent de l'intérêt après avoir reçu l'avertissement divin seront pardonnés pour leurs péchés passés, et leur sort relèvera de la miséricorde d'Allah.
orig: الذين يأكلون الربا لا يقومون إلا كما يقوم الذي يتخبطه الشيطان من المس ذلك بأنهم قالوا إنما البيع مثل الربا وأحل الله البيع وحرم الربا فمن جاءه موعظة من ربه فانتهى فله ما سلف وأمره إلى الله ومن عاد فأولئك أصحاب النار هم فيها خالدون

translation: Allah destroys interest and gives increase for charities. And Allah does not like every ungrateful sinner.
interpretation: This verse highlights the contrasting consequences of interest (riba) and charity (sadaqat). Interest, which involves exploiting others for personal gain, is condemned and will be destroyed by Allah. On the other hand, charity, which involves giving selflessly to others, is praised and will be multiplied by Allah. The verse also emphasizes that Allah does not love those who are ungrateful disbelievers and persist in sinful ways.
orig: يمحق الله الربا ويربي الصدقات والله لا يحب كل كفار أثيم

translation: Indeed, those who have believed and done righteous deeds and established prayer and given zakah will have their reward with their Lord, and there will be no fear concerning them, nor will they grieve.
interpretation: This verse promises a great reward for those who have faith in Allah and do good deeds, which include establishing regular prayer and paying the obligatory charity (zakah). Such believers will receive their deserved recompense from Allah on the Day of Judgment. They will have no fear of punishment or grief over what they have left behind in this world.
orig: إن الذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات وأقاموا الصلاة وآتوا الزكاة لهم أجرهم عند ربهم ولا خوف عليهم ولا هم يحزنون

translation: O you who have believed, fear Allah and give up what remains [due to you] of interest, if you should be believers.
interpretation: This verse commands the believers to have taqwa (consciousness and fear) of Allah and to completely abandon dealing with interest or usury (riba) if they are truly believers. It emphasizes the incompatibility of faith and interest-based transactions, as interest exploits others and promotes injustice. The verse calls for a complete rejection of the interest-based economic system and a transition towards an interest-free economy based on principles of fairness and mutual benefit.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا اتقوا الله وذروا ما بقي من الربا إن كنتم مؤمنين

translation: But if you do not do it, then be informed of a war from Allah and His Messenger. But if you repent, you shall have your principal amounts, you shall not wrong nor shall you be wronged.
interpretation: This verse warns those who deal in usury (interest-based transactions) that if they persist in this practice, they will be at war with Allah and His Messenger. However, if they repent and abandon this unlawful practice, they will not be punished for past transactions, and their principal amounts will be returned to them without any injustice or oppression.
orig: فإن لم تفعلوا فأذنوا بحرب من الله ورسوله وإن تبتم فلكم رءوس أموالكم لا تظلمون ولا تظلمون

translation: But if the debtor is in a difficult situation, then grant him respite until an easier time. And if you give charity, it is better for you, if you only knew.
interpretation: This verse encourages creditors to show patience and leniency towards debtors facing financial difficulties. It advises granting them an extension or deferment until their circumstances improve, making it easier for them to repay their debts. Additionally, it promotes the virtue of giving charity willingly, as it is beneficial for the giver, both in this life and the Hereafter, if they truly understand the wisdom behind it.
orig: وإن كان ذو عسرة فنظرة إلى ميسرة وأن تصدقوا خير لكم إن كنتم تعلمون

translation: And fear a Day when you will be returned to Allah. Then every soul will be compensated for what it earned, and they will not be wronged.
interpretation: This verse serves as a stern warning to have consciousness of Allah and fear the Day of Resurrection when all souls will be held accountable for their deeds. It emphasizes that on that Day, absolute justice will prevail, and every person will be recompensed precisely according to their actions, without any injustice or wrongdoing.
orig: واتقوا يوما ترجعون فيه إلى الله ثم توفى كل نفس ما كسبت وهم لا يظلمون

translation: O you who believe! When you contract a debt for a fixed period, write it down. Let a scribe write it down in justice between you. Let no scribe refuse to write as Allah has taught him. So let him write. Let him (the debtor) who incurs the liability dictate, and he must fear Allah, his Lord, and diminish not anything of what he owes.
interpretation: This verse instructs believers to record their financial transactions and debt contracts in writing, with witnesses present. It emphasizes the importance of honesty, justice, and accountability in financial dealings, and urges debtors to fulfill their obligations completely without diminishing anything. The verse also provides guidance on the proper procedures for recording debts, including the use of scribes and witnesses.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا إذا تداينتم بدين إلى أجل مسمى فاكتبوه وليكتب بينكم كاتب بالعدل ولا يأب كاتب أن يكتب كما علمه الله فليكتب وليملل الذي عليه الحق وليتق الله ربه ولا يبخس منه شيئا فإن كان الذي عليه الحق سفيها أو ضعيفا أو لا يستطيع أن يمل هو فليملل وليه بالعدل واستشهدوا شهيدين من رجالكم فإن لم يكونا رجلين فرجل وامرأتان ممن ترضون من الشهداء أن تضل إحداهما فتذكر إحداهما الأخرى ولا يأب الشهداء إذا ما دعوا ولا تسأموا أن تكتبوه صغيرا أو كبيرا إلى أجله ذلكم أقسط عند الله وأقوم للشهادة وأدنى ألا ترتابوا إلا أن تكون تجارة حاضرة تديرونها بينكم فليس عليكم جناح ألا تكتبوها وأشهدوا إذا تبايعتم ولا يضار كاتب ولا شهيد وإن تفعلوا فإنه فسوق بكم واتقوا الله ويعلمكم الله والله بكل شيء عليم

translation: And if you are on a journey and cannot find a scribe, then a security deposit [should be] taken. And if one of you entrusts another, then let him who is entrusted discharge his trust and let him fear Allah, his Lord. And do not conceal testimony, for whoever conceals it - his heart is indeed sinful. And Allah is Knowing of what you do.
interpretation: Jika dalam perjalanan dan tidak menemukan penulis, maka hendaklah ada barang jaminan yang dipegang. Jika sebagian dari kalian mempercayai sebagian yang lain, maka yang dipercaya hendaklah menunaikan amanatnya dan bertakwa kepada Allah. Janganlah menyembunyikan persaksian, karena barangsiapa menyembunyikannya, sungguh hatinya berdosa. Allah Maha Mengetahui apa yang kalian kerjakan.
orig: وإن كنتم على سفر ولم تجدوا كاتبا فرهان مقبوضة فإن أمن بعضكم بعضا فليؤد الذي اؤتمن أمانته وليتق الله ربه ولا تكتموا الشهادة ومن يكتمها فإنه آثم قلبه والله بما تعملون عليم

translation: To Allah belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. And whether you show what is within yourselves or conceal it, Allah will bring you to account for it. Then He will forgive whom He wills and punish whom He wills. And Allah is over all things competent.
interpretation: هذه الآية تؤكد على سلطان الله وملكه المطلق على كل شيء، وأنه يعلم السر والنجوى، وأنه سيحاسب الناس على أفعالهم وأقوالهم وأفكارهم، سواء أظهروها أم أخفوها. وهو وحده القادر على المغفرة والعفو، أو العقاب والجزاء، حسب حكمته وعدله.
orig: لله ما في السماوات وما في الأرض وإن تبدوا ما في أنفسكم أو تخفوه يحاسبكم به الله فيغفر لمن يشاء ويعذب من يشاء والله على كل شيء قدير

translation: The Messenger believes in what has been revealed to him from his Lord, and so do the believers. Each one believes in Allah, His Angels, His Books, and His Messengers. They say, 'We make no distinction between any of His Messengers,' and they say, 'We hear and we obey. We seek Your forgiveness, our Lord, and to You is the return.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the core beliefs of Islam: faith in Allah, His angels, His books, and His messengers without discriminating among them. It highlights the obedience and submission of the believers to Allah, seeking His forgiveness and acknowledging that the final return is to Him.
orig: آمن الرسول بما أنزل إليه من ربه والمؤمنون كل آمن بالله وملائكته وكتبه ورسله لا نفرق بين أحد من رسله وقالوا سمعنا وأطعنا غفرانك ربنا وإليك المصير

translation: Allah does not burden a soul beyond its capacity. For it is what it has earned, and upon it is what it has incurred. 'Our Lord, do not hold us accountable if we forget or make a mistake. Our Lord, do not place upon us a burden like the one You placed upon those before us. Our Lord, do not burden us with what we cannot bear. Pardon us, forgive us, and have mercy upon us. You are our Protector, so help us against the disbelieving people.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes Allah's justice and mercy. He does not burden anyone beyond their capacity. Each person is accountable for their own deeds. The believers humbly ask Allah not to hold them accountable for unintentional mistakes or forgetfulness, and not to burden them with obligations beyond their ability to fulfill, as He did with previous nations. They seek Allah's forgiveness, mercy, and protection against those who disbelieve.
orig: لا يكلف الله نفسا إلا وسعها لها ما كسبت وعليها ما اكتسبت ربنا لا تؤاخذنا إن نسينا أو أخطأنا ربنا ولا تحمل علينا إصرا كما حملته على الذين من قبلنا ربنا ولا تحملنا ما لا طاقة لنا به واعف عنا واغفر لنا وارحمنا أنت مولانا فانصرنا على القوم الكافرين

translation: Alif Lam Mim
interpretation: These are among the letters that are occasionally combined at the beginning of some chapters in the Qur'an. Their meanings are known only to Allah. Some scholars suggest they may represent divine names or indicate that the Qur'an consists of such letters and words. However, the exact significance is a matter of divine knowledge.
orig: الم

translation: Allah - there is no deity except Him, the Ever-Living, the Sustainer of existence.
interpretation: This verse affirms the Oneness of Allah and His unique attribute of being the sole Living and Eternal Being upon Whom all of creation depends for its existence and sustenance. It emphasizes that there is no other true deity worthy of worship besides Allah, Who is the source of all life and the One Who maintains and provides for all that exists.
orig: الله لا إله إلا هو الحي القيوم

translation: The Book has been sent down to you with the truth, confirming what was before it, and the Torah and the Gospel were sent down.
interpretation: This verse affirms the divine origin of the Qur'an and its consistency with previous revelations, namely the Torah and the Gospel. It emphasizes that the Qur'an is a continuation and confirmation of the same universal truth revealed to previous prophets, reinforcing the concept of one God and one message throughout human history. The verse establishes the Qur'an as the final, complete, and authoritative divine scripture, while acknowledging the previous revelations as part of the same tradition.
orig: نزل عليك الكتاب بالحق مصدقا لما بين يديه وأنزل التوراة والإنجيل

translation: It is a guide for the people, and He has sent down the Criterion. Indeed, those who disbelieve in the verses of Allah will have a severe punishment, and Allah is Exalted in Might, the Lord of Retribution.
interpretation: This verse highlights the Qur'an as a guide for humanity, containing the criterion to distinguish truth from falsehood. It warns those who reject Allah's revelations that they will face a severe punishment, as Allah is Mighty and capable of enforcing His retribution.
orig: من قبل هدى للناس وأنزل الفرقان إن الذين كفروا بآيات الله لهم عذاب شديد والله عزيز ذو انتقام

translation: Indeed, nothing on earth or in the heaven is hidden from Allah.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes Allah's absolute and perfect knowledge of everything in the universe. It means that nothing, whether on earth or in the heavens, is concealed from Allah's awareness and knowledge. Allah's knowledge encompasses all things, seen and unseen, apparent and hidden. This affirms Allah's attribute of being All-Knowing and All-Aware.
orig: إن الله لا يخفى عليه شيء في الأرض ولا في السماء

translation: It is He who shapes you in the wombs as He wills. There is no deity except Him, the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes Allah's complete control and wisdom in the process of human development in the womb. It highlights that Allah alone is the Creator who shapes and forms the fetus in whatever way He wills, without any partner or associate. The attributes "al-'Azeez" (the Exalted in Might) and "al-Hakeem" (the Wise) affirm Allah's absolute power and perfect wisdom in this remarkable creation.
orig: هو الذي يصوركم في الأرحام كيف يشاء لا إله إلا هو العزيز الحكيم

translation: It is He who has sent down to you, [O Muhammad], the Book; in it are verses [that are] precise - they are the foundation of the Book - and others unspecific. As for those in whose hearts is deviation [from truth], they will follow that of it which is unspecific, seeking discord and seeking an interpretation [suitable to them]. And no one knows its [true] interpretation except Allah. But those firm in knowledge say, 'We believe in it. All is from our Lord.' And no one will be reminded except those of understanding.
interpretation: This verse distinguishes between the clear, unambiguous verses of the Qur'an that form the basis of faith, and the allegorical verses that are open to interpretation. It warns against following the allegorical verses with ill intent or a deviant heart, seeking to cause discord or derive an interpretation that suits one's desires. Only Allah knows the true meaning of the allegorical verses. The verse praises those firmly grounded in knowledge who submit to the Qur'an as being from their Lord, and states that only those with sound understanding will truly benefit from its teachings.
orig: هو الذي أنزل عليك الكتاب منه آيات محكمات هن أم الكتاب وأخر متشابهات فأما الذين في قلوبهم زيغ فيتبعون ما تشابه منه ابتغاء الفتنة وابتغاء تأويله وما يعلم تأويله إلا الله والراسخون في العلم يقولون آمنا به كل من عند ربنا وما يذكر إلا أولو الألباب

translation: Our Lord, let not our hearts deviate after You have guided us and grant us from Yourself mercy. Indeed, You are the Bestower.
interpretation: This verse is a supplication to Allah, asking Him not to let our hearts deviate from the right path after He has guided us to it. It also asks Allah to bestow His mercy upon us, as He is the Giver of all good things. The verse emphasizes our need for Allah's continuous guidance and mercy, and our inability to remain steadfast on the path without His help and grace.
orig: ربنا لا تزغ قلوبنا بعد إذ هديتنا وهب لنا من لدنك رحمة إنك أنت الوهاب

translation: Our Lord, indeed You are the Gatherer of the people for a Day about which there is no doubt. Indeed, Allah does not fail in His promise.
interpretation: "This verse emphasizes Allah's power and ability to gather all people on the Day of Resurrection, which is an inevitable event that will undoubtedly occur. It highlights Allah's truthfulness and affirms that He never breaks His promise regarding this momentous Day."
orig: ربنا إنك جامع الناس ليوم لا ريب فيه إن الله لا يخلف الميعاد

translation: Indeed, those who disbelieve - never will their wealth or their children avail them against Allah at all. And it is they who are fuel for the Fire.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that for those who reject faith in Allah, their wealth and children will be of no benefit to them in the Hereafter. Their material possessions and offspring, which they take pride in during this worldly life, will not help them escape the punishment of the Fire. In fact, the verse states that they themselves will become the "fuel" that feeds the Fire of Hell. This serves as a stern warning against prioritizing worldly gains over faith and obedience to Allah.
orig: إن الذين كفروا لن تغني عنهم أموالهم ولا أولادهم من الله شيئا وأولئك هم وقود النار

translation: Such was the manner of Pharaoh's people and those before them. They denied Our signs, so Allah seized them for their sins. And Allah is severe in penalty.
interpretation: "This verse draws a parallel between the arrogant rejection of Allah's signs by Pharaoh and his people, and those before them who exhibited similar obstinate behavior. Their persistent denial of Allah's revelations and miracles led to their ultimate punishment and destruction by Allah, Who is strict in meting out retribution for such blatant defiance and disbelief."
orig: كدأب آل فرعون والذين من قبلهم كذبوا بآياتنا فأخذهم الله بذنوبهم والله شديد العقاب

translation: Say to those who disbelieve, 'You will be overcome and gathered together to Hell, and wretched is the resting place.'
interpretation: This verse warns the disbelievers that they will be defeated and forced into Hell, which is described as a terrible abode. It serves as a stern warning about the consequences of rejecting faith and highlights the ultimate triumph of truth over falsehood.
orig: قل للذين كفروا ستغلبون وتحشرون إلى جهنم وبئس المهاد

translation: There has certainly been for you a sign in the two companies which met - one company fighting in the cause of Allah and another of disbelievers. They saw them twice their [own] number by [their] eyesight. But Allah supports with His victory whom He wills. Indeed in that is a lesson for those of vision.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Battle of Badr, where the outnumbered Muslim army prevailed against the disbelieving Quraysh forces. It highlights that although the disbelievers appeared greater in number, Allah granted victory to the believers who were fighting for His cause. The verse emphasizes that this event serves as a profound lesson for those who have spiritual insight and can perceive the divine wisdom behind such occurrences.
orig: قد كان لكم آية في فئتين التقتا فئة تقاتل في سبيل الله وأخرى كافرة يرونهم مثليهم رأي العين والله يؤيد بنصره من يشاء إن في ذلك لعبرة لأولي الأبصار

translation: Beautified for people is the love of desires - of women, and sons, and hoarded heaps of gold and silver, and branded horses, and cattle and plantations. That is the enjoyment of the present life; but with Allah is an excellent abode.
interpretation: Allah has made attractive to people the love of worldly desires, such as women, children, wealth in the form of gold, silver, branded horses, cattle, and agriculture. However, these are merely temporary pleasures of this worldly life. The true and everlasting abode of excellence and happiness is with Allah in the Hereafter for those who believe and do righteous deeds.
orig: زين للناس حب الشهوات من النساء والبنين والقناطير المقنطرة من الذهب والفضة والخيل المسومة والأنعام والحرث ذلك متاع الحياة الدنيا والله عنده حسن المآب

translation: Say, "Shall I inform you of something better than that? For those who fear Allah, will be gardens under which rivers flow, wherein they abide eternally, and purified spouses and approval from Allah." And Allah is All-Seer of His servants.
interpretation: This verse promises the believers who have taqwa (consciousness of Allah) the highest rewards in the Hereafter: everlasting gardens beneath which rivers flow, purified spouses, and the pleasure of Allah. It emphasizes that these rewards are far superior to the fleeting pleasures of this world, and that Allah is All-Aware of those who strive to obey Him.
orig: قل أؤنبئكم بخير من ذلكم للذين اتقوا عند ربهم جنات تجري من تحتها الأنهار خالدين فيها وأزواج مطهرة ورضوان من الله والله بصير بالعباد

translation: Those who say, 'Our Lord, we have believed, so forgive us our sins and protect us from the punishment of the Fire.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the believers who acknowledge their sins and imperfections, and humbly seek forgiveness from Allah. They recognize their faith in Allah and ask Him to forgive their shortcomings and protect them from the torment of Hell. It highlights the importance of repentance, humility, and seeking Allah's mercy and protection.
orig: الذين يقولون ربنا إننا آمنا فاغفر لنا ذنوبنا وقنا عذاب النار

translation: The patient ones, the truthful ones, the obedient ones, those who spend (in Allah's cause), and those who seek forgiveness before dawn.
interpretation: This verse praises and commends those who possess noble qualities: "The patient ones" refers to those who persevere through difficulties with steadfastness. "The truthful ones" are those who are honest in speech and actions. "The obedient ones" are those who submit to Allah's commands. "Those who spend" generously from what Allah has provided them. "Those who seek forgiveness before dawn" refers to those who sincerely repent and ask Allah's forgiveness during the last portion of the night, which is a blessed time.
orig: الصابرين والصادقين والقانتين والمنفقين والمستغفرين بالأسحار

translation: Allah bears witness that there is no deity except Him, and [so do] the angels and those of knowledge - [that He is] maintaining [creation] in justice. There is no deity except Him, the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
interpretation: This verse affirms the Oneness of Allah and His attribute of being the only true God worthy of worship. It states that Allah Himself, the angels, and those endowed with knowledge all testify to this fact. It also highlights Allah's justice in maintaining the entire creation, and describes Him as the Almighty and the Wise.
orig: شهد الله أنه لا إله إلا هو والملائكة وأولو العلم قائما بالقسط لا إله إلا هو العزيز الحكيم

translation: Indeed, the religion in the sight of Allah is Islam. And those who were given the Scripture did not differ except after knowledge had come to them - out of jealous animosity between themselves. And whoever disbelieves in the verses of Allah, then indeed, Allah is swift in [taking] account.
interpretation: Cette interprétation souligne que l'islam est la seule religion acceptée par Dieu. Les différences entre les gens du Livre (juifs et chrétiens) sont survenues après qu'ils aient reçu la connaissance, par jalousie et animosité entre eux. Quiconque nie les versets d'Allah sera tenu responsable rapidement par Dieu.
orig: إن الدين عند الله الإسلام وما اختلف الذين أوتوا الكتاب إلا من بعد ما جاءهم العلم بغيا بينهم ومن يكفر بآيات الله فإن الله سريع الحساب

translation: But if they dispute with you, say, 'I have submitted myself to Allah, and whoever follows me.' And say to those who were given the Scripture and the unlearned, 'Have you submitted yourselves?' If they submit, then they are rightly guided; but if they turn away, then your duty is only to convey the message. And Allah is Seeing of [His] servants.
interpretation: This verse instructs the Prophet Muhammad to declare his submission to Allah and invite others, both People of the Scripture and the unlearned, to submit themselves to Allah as well. If they accept Islam, they will be rightly guided, but if they reject it, the Prophet's responsibility is only to convey the message, as Allah is the Seer and Judge of His servants' deeds.
