The phrase "Little do you remember" serves as a reminder of humanity's forgetfulness and negligence in heeding this crucial command.
orig: اتبعوا ما أنزل إليكم من ربكم ولا تتبعوا من دونه أولياء قليلا ما تذكرون

translation: And how many a town have We destroyed, and Our punishment came upon it at night or while they were taking a midday nap?
interpretation: This verse serves as a warning and reminder of Allah's ability to swiftly punish nations that persist in disbelief and disobedience. It highlights that Allah's punishment can come at any time, whether during the night when people are asleep or in the day when they are resting. The destruction of such towns is a consequence of their rejection of faith and moral corruption. The verse emphasizes the importance of heeding divine guidance and maintaining righteousness to avoid a similar fate.
orig: وكم من قرية أهلكناها فجاءها بأسنا بياتا أو هم قائلون

translation: So when Our punishment came to them, their cry was only that they said: 'Indeed, we have been wrongdoers.'
interpretation: The interpretation is that when the punishment and torment of Allah came upon the disbelievers who rejected the message of the Prophets, they had no excuse or plea except to admit that they had wronged themselves by disbelieving and committing sins. Their confession of being wrongdoers came too late to be of any benefit to them.
orig: فما كان دعواهم إذ جاءهم بأسنا إلا أن قالوا إنا كنا ظالمين

translation: Then We will surely question those to whom (the Message) was sent, and We will surely question the Messengers.
interpretation: This verse indicates that on the Day of Judgment, Allah will hold accountable both those who received the divine message through the Messengers, as well as the Messengers themselves. The people will be questioned about how they responded to the Message, and the Messengers will be questioned about how they conveyed it. This highlights the gravity of the trust placed upon the Messengers and the responsibility of the recipients to heed the Message. No one will be excused or overlooked on that Day.
orig: فلنسألن الذين أرسل إليهم ولنسألن المرسلين

translation: So We will narrate to them with knowledge, and We were not absent.
interpretation: Allah is stating that He will recount the stories and events of the past nations to the Prophet Muhammad and the believers with full knowledge and accuracy, as He was not absent or unaware of what transpired with those nations. This verse affirms Allah's perfect knowledge and emphasizes the truthfulness of the Qur'anic narratives about previous peoples.
orig: فلنقصن عليهم بعلم وما كنا غائبين

translation: And the weighing [of deeds] that Day will be the truth. So those whose scales are heavy - it is they who are the successful.
interpretation: On the Day of Judgment, the weighing of people's deeds will be done with complete justice and fairness. Those whose good deeds outweigh their bad deeds will be the truly successful ones, who will attain salvation and eternal bliss in Paradise.
orig: والوزن يومئذ الحق فمن ثقلت موازينه فأولئك هم المفلحون

translation: And those whose scales are light - they are the ones who will lose themselves for what injustice they were doing toward Our verses.
interpretation: This verse warns those whose good deeds are outweighed by their evil deeds on the Day of Judgment. They will have failed to achieve salvation and will suffer the consequences of rejecting God's revelations and denying the truth. It emphasizes the importance of faith, righteous conduct, and heeding divine guidance to avoid spiritual and eternal loss.
orig: ومن خفت موازينه فأولئك الذين خسروا أنفسهم بما كانوا بآياتنا يظلمون

translation: And We have certainly established you upon the earth and made for you therein ways of livelihood. Little are you grateful.
interpretation: Allah reminds us of His great blessing upon humanity by granting us the ability to live on earth and providing us with the means of sustenance. However, most people fail to appreciate this immense favor and show little gratitude towards their Lord.
orig: ولقد مكناكم في الأرض وجعلنا لكم فيها معايش قليلا ما تشكرون

translation: And We have certainly created you, [O Mankind], and given you [human] form. Then We said to the angels, 'Prostrate to Adam,' so they prostrated, except for Iblees. He was not of those who prostrated.
interpretation: This verse highlights the unique status of human beings as Allah's honored creation. Allah first created humankind and fashioned them in the best form. Then, as a test of obedience, Allah commanded the angels to prostrate before Adam, which they all did except Iblees (Satan), who arrogantly refused. This event underscores the elevated rank of humans over angels and the importance of submitting to Allah's commands without arrogance.
orig: ولقد خلقناكم ثم صورناكم ثم قلنا للملائكة اسجدوا لآدم فسجدوا إلا إبليس لم يكن من الساجدين

translation: He said: 'What prevented you from prostrating when I commanded you?' He said: 'I am better than him. You created me from fire and created him from clay.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the dialogue between Allah and Iblis (Satan) after Iblis disobeyed Allah's command to prostrate before Adam. Iblis displayed arrogance and considered himself superior to Adam because he was created from fire while Adam was created from clay. This shows Iblis's pride and disobedience, which led to his expulsion from Paradise.
orig: قال ما منعك ألا تسجد إذ أمرتك قال أنا خير منه خلقتني من نار وخلقته من طين

translation: He said: "Then get out from this (Paradise), for you are outcast. And never will it be yours to act arrogantly therein. So get out. Indeed, you are of the degraded."
interpretation: This verse refers to Allah's command to Iblis (Satan) to leave Paradise after he disobeyed Allah by refusing to prostrate to Adam. It emphasizes that arrogance and disobedience have no place in Paradise, and those who exhibit such traits will be expelled and disgraced. The interpretation highlights the severe consequence of arrogance and rebellion against Allah's commands.
orig: قال فاهبط منها فما يكون لك أن تتكبر فيها فاخرج إنك من الصاغرين

translation: He will say, "Reprieve me until the Day they are resurrected."
interpretation: This verse refers to the request that the disbelievers will make on the Day of Judgment, asking for a delay or postponement until the Day of Resurrection. It suggests their denial of the Resurrection and their desire to avoid facing the consequences of their disbelief. However, their request will be denied, as the Day of Resurrection is an inevitable reality that they will have to face.
orig: قال أنظرني إلى يوم يبعثون

translation: It is said that you are one of the theorists
interpretation: This verse suggests that the person being addressed is considered to be among those who engage in speculation or theorizing, implying that their ideas or views are based on theoretical reasoning rather than concrete evidence or practical experience.
orig: قال إنك من المنظرين

translation: He (Shaytan) said: "Because You have sent me astray, surely I will sit in wait against them (human beings) on Your Straight Path."
interpretation: This verse refers to the conversation between Allah and Shaytan (Satan) after Allah had expelled Shaytan from Paradise for disobeying His command to prostrate before Adam. Shaytan blamed Allah for his misguidance and vowed to mislead humanity by sitting on the Straight Path, which is the path of truth, guidance, and righteousness prescribed by Allah. Shaytan's aim is to lead people astray from this path through deception and temptation.
orig: قال فبما أغويتني لأقعدن لهم صراطك المستقيم

translation: Then We will come to them from before them and from behind them and on their right and on their left, and You will not find most of them grateful.
interpretation: This verse implies that disbelievers will be surrounded by Allah's punishment and torment from all sides on the Day of Judgment. They will find no escape or refuge. Despite Allah's countless blessings upon them, most of them were ungrateful and rejected faith.
orig: ثم لآتينهم من بين أيديهم ومن خلفهم وعن أيمانهم وعن شمائلهم ولا تجد أكثرهم شاكرين

translation: He (Allah) said: 'Get out from this (Paradise) disgraced and expelled. Whoever of them (mankind) will follow you, then I will fill Hell with you all.'
interpretation: This verse indicates that Shaytan (Satan) was expelled from Paradise due to his arrogance and disobedience to Allah. Those who follow his path and obey him will also be condemned to Hell. It serves as a warning against being misguided by Shaytan and highlights the severe consequences of defying Allah's commands.
orig: قال اخرج منها مذءوما مدحورا لمن تبعك منهم لأملأن جهنم منكم أجمعين

translation: And O Adam! Dwell you and your wife in Paradise and eat from wherever you will but do not approach this tree, lest you be among the wrongdoers.
interpretation: This verse addresses Adam and his wife, granting them permission to reside in Paradise and partake of its provisions freely, except for a single tree which they are forbidden from approaching. The prohibition against this tree serves as a test of their obedience to God's command. Disobeying this command would render them among the wrongdoers who transgress against divine injunctions.
orig: ويا آدم اسكن أنت وزوجك الجنة فكلا من حيث شئتما ولا تقربا هذه الشجرة فتكونا من الظالمين

translation: Then Satan whispered to them, to uncover what was hidden from them of their private parts, and he said, 'Your Lord has only forbidden you this tree lest you become angels or become of the immortals.'
interpretation: Satan tempted Adam and Eve to disobey God's command by suggesting that God had forbidden them from eating the fruit of the tree out of jealousy, fearing that they would become angels or immortal beings like Him. This was a deception aimed at sowing doubts about God's wisdom and motives.
orig: فوسوس لهما الشيطان ليبدي لهما ما ووري عنهما من سوآتهما وقال ما نهاكما ربكما عن هذه الشجرة إلا أن تكونا ملكين أو تكونا من الخالدين

translation: And I swear to them (both): 'Verily, I am indeed one of the sincere well-wishers for you.'
interpretation: Allah is swearing by Himself that He is sincerely advising and guiding Musa (Moses) and Harun (Aaron) to the right path and to convey His message to Fir'awn (Pharaoh) and his people. This shows Allah's mercy and care for His messengers, assuring them of His support and guidance in their mission.
orig: وقاسمهما إني لكما لمن الناصحين

translation: Then he misled them with deception. So when they tasted of the tree, their private parts became manifest to them, and they began to cover themselves with the leaves of Paradise. And their Lord called out to them, 'Did I not forbid you from that tree, and tell you that Satan is a clear enemy unto you?'
interpretation: Allah is describing how Satan deceived Adam and Eve into eating from the forbidden tree, causing them to become aware of their nakedness and attempt to cover themselves with leaves. Allah then called out to them, reminding them that He had warned them against the tree and that Satan was their sworn enemy, seeking to misguide them.
orig: فدلاهما بغرور فلما ذاقا الشجرة بدت لهما سوآتهما وطفقا يخصفان عليهما من ورق الجنة وناداهما ربهما ألم أنهكما عن تلكما الشجرة وأقل لكما إن الشيطان لكما عدو مبين

translation: They said: 'Our Lord! We have wronged ourselves. If You forgive us not, and bestow not upon us Your Mercy, we shall certainly be of the losers.'
interpretation: This verse shows the humility and repentance of Adam and Eve after disobeying God's command. They acknowledged their mistake, sought forgiveness, and pleaded for God's mercy, recognizing that without it, they would be among the losers in this life and the Hereafter. It teaches us to take responsibility for our sins, turn to God in sincere repentance, and seek His forgiveness and guidance.
orig: قالا ربنا ظلمنا أنفسنا وإن لم تغفر لنا وترحمنا لنكونن من الخاسرين

translation: He said, "Go down, some of you enemies to others, and for you on the earth is a dwelling place and enjoyment for a time."
interpretation: This verse refers to the expulsion of Adam and Eve from Paradise after their disobedience. God commanded them to descend to Earth, where they and their progeny would face enmity, trials and a temporary abode until the Day of Judgment. It highlights the consequences of sin, the temporary nature of this worldly life, and the ongoing struggle between good and evil.
orig: قال اهبطوا بعضكم لبعض عدو ولكم في الأرض مستقر ومتاع إلى حين

translation: He said: 'In it you shall live, and in it you shall die, and from it you shall be brought forth.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the earth as the source of human life, where people live their lives, die, and are ultimately resurrected from it on the Day of Judgment. It highlights the temporary nature of human existence on earth and the ultimate return to Allah for accountability and judgment.
orig: قال فيها تحيون وفيها تموتون ومنها تخرجون

translation: O children of Adam, We have bestowed upon you clothing to conceal your private parts and as adornment. But the clothing of righteousness - that is best. That is from the signs of Allah that perhaps they will remember.
interpretation: This verse teaches that while physical clothing covers the body, the true "clothing" that is most valuable is righteousness and piety. It reminds us that outward adornment is temporary, but inward virtue through consciousness of Allah is far more important and lasting. The reference to Allah's "signs" suggests that our clothing and sense of modesty should remind us of our Creator and inspire us to live righteously.
orig: يا بني آدم قد أنزلنا عليكم لباسا يواري سوآتكم وريشا ولباس التقوى ذلك خير ذلك من آيات الله لعلهم يذكرون

translation: O children of Adam! Let not Satan seduce you, in the same manner as he got your parents out of the Garden, stripping them of their raiment, to expose their shame: for he and his tribe watch you from a position where you cannot see them: We made the evil ones friends (only) to those without faith.
interpretation: This verse warns the children of Adam (humanity) against being deceived by Satan, just as he deceived Adam and Eve and caused them to be expelled from Paradise by stripping them of their clothing and exposing their shame. Satan and his followers watch humans from where they cannot see them. Allah has appointed the devils as allies only for those who do not believe.
orig: يا بني آدم لا يفتننكم الشيطان كما أخرج أبويكم من الجنة ينزع عنهما لباسهما ليريهما سوآتهما إنه يراكم هو وقبيله من حيث لا ترونهم إنا جعلنا الشياطين أولياء للذين لا يؤمنون

translation: And when they commit an immorality, they say, 'We found our fathers doing it, and Allah has commanded us to do it.' Say, 'Allah does not command immorality. Do you say about Allah that which you do not know?'
interpretation: This verse condemns the practice of blindly following traditions and cultural norms that go against the teachings of Islam. It criticizes those who justify their immoral actions by claiming that their ancestors did the same and that it is sanctioned by Allah. The verse makes it clear that Allah does not command indecency or immorality, and that attributing such commands to Him without knowledge is a grave sin.
orig: وإذا فعلوا فاحشة قالوا وجدنا عليها آباءنا والله أمرنا بها قل إن الله لا يأمر بالفحشاء أتقولون على الله ما لا تعلمون

translation: Say, "My Lord has enjoined justice, and set your faces upright at every place of worship and call upon Him, being sincere to Him in religion. As He brought you forth in the beginning, so shall you return."
interpretation: This verse commands believers to be just and upright in their dealings, to worship Allah sincerely without associating any partners with Him, and to call upon Him alone. It reminds us that just as Allah created us from nothing, we will ultimately return to Him on the Day of Resurrection to account for our deeds.
orig: قل أمر ربي بالقسط وأقيموا وجوهكم عند كل مسجد وادعوه مخلصين له الدين كما بدأكم تعودون

translation: A group He guided, and a group deserved to be misguided. They took the devils as allies instead of Allah, and they thought that they were guided.
interpretation: This verse refers to two distinct groups of people: one that was guided by Allah to the straight path, and another that was justly left to go astray due to their own choices and actions. The latter group took the devils (shayatin) as their allies and protectors instead of Allah, falsely believing that they were rightly guided. This highlights the grave consequence of associating partners with Allah and following the misguiding whispers of the shayatin, which leads to misguidance and eternal loss.
orig: فريقا هدى وفريقا حق عليهم الضلالة إنهم اتخذوا الشياطين أولياء من دون الله ويحسبون أنهم مهتدون

translation: O Children of Adam! Take your adornment at every masjid, and eat and drink, but waste not by excess, indeed He likes not the wasters.
interpretation: This verse teaches moderation and balance in our lives. We are encouraged to adorn ourselves and enjoy the lawful provisions of Allah, but we must avoid extravagance and wasteful excess. The verse reminds us that Allah dislikes those who are wasteful and indulgent beyond what is necessary.
orig: يا بني آدم خذوا زينتكم عند كل مسجد وكلوا واشربوا ولا تسرفوا إنه لا يحب المسرفين

translation: Say, "Who has forbidden the adornment of Allah which He has produced for His servants and the good things of sustenance?" Say, "They are for those who believe during the worldly life, but they will be exclusive for them on the Day of Resurrection." Thus do We detail the verses for a people who know.
interpretation: هذه الآية تشير إلى أن الله لم يحرم على عباده التمتع بزينة الحياة الدنيا والنعم التي أنعم بها عليهم، بل هي مباحة للمؤمنين في الحياة الدنيا، وسيكون لهم في الآخرة نصيب خالص منها دون الكافرين. وهذا تفصيل من الله لآياته لقوم يفقهون ويعلمون حكمته.
orig: قل من حرم زينة الله التي أخرج لعباده والطيبات من الرزق قل هي للذين آمنوا في الحياة الدنيا خالصة يوم القيامة كذلك نفصل الآيات لقوم يعلمون

translation: Say, "My Lord has only forbidden indecencies, shameful deeds, whether open or secret, sins and wrongful oppression, that you associate with Allah anything for which He has sent down no authority, and that you say about Allah what you do not know."
interpretation: Allah has prohibited all indecent and shameful acts, whether committed openly or secretly, as well as sins, oppression and injustice. He has also forbidden associating partners with Him without any evidence or proof, and speaking about Him without knowledge.
orig: قل إنما حرم ربي الفواحش ما ظهر منها وما بطن والإثم والبغي بغير الحق وأن تشركوا بالله ما لم ينزل به سلطانا وأن تقولوا على الله ما لا تعلمون

translation: And for every nation is a term, so when their time has come, they cannot remain behind an hour, nor can they precede it.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the inevitability of the appointed time decreed by Allah for every nation or community. When that appointed time arrives, they cannot delay or postpone it even for a single hour, nor can they hasten or advance it. This highlights Allah's complete control over the destinies of nations and the certainty of His decree.
orig: ولكل أمة أجل فإذا جاء أجلهم لا يستأخرون ساعة ولا يستقدمون

translation: O children of Adam, if there come to you messengers from among you relating to you My verses, then whoever fears Allah and reforms - there will be no fear concerning them, nor will they grieve.
interpretation: This verse addresses all of humanity, referring to them as the "children of Adam." It states that Allah will send messengers from among the people themselves to convey His revelations and teachings. Those who have fear of Allah and mend their ways by following the guidance of these messengers will have no cause for fear or grief in this world or the Hereafter.
orig: يا بني آدم إما يأتينكم رسل منكم يقصون عليكم آياتي فمن اتقى وأصلح فلا خوف عليهم ولا هم يحزنون

translation: And those who deny Our signs and are arrogant toward them - those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally.
interpretation: This verse warns against denying Allah's revelations and signs, and being arrogant towards them. Those who reject faith out of arrogance and persist in disbelief will be the dwellers of Hellfire, wherein they will abide forever as a punishment for their arrogance and denial.
orig: والذين كذبوا بآياتنا واستكبروا عنها أولئك أصحاب النار هم فيها خالدون

translation: So who does more wrong than he who forges a lie against Allah, or denies His signs? Those - their share of the Book will reach them. Until when Our messengers come to them taking them in death, they will say, 'Where are those you used to invoke besides Allah?' They will say, 'They have departed from us,' and will bear witness against themselves that they were disbelievers.
interpretation: This verse condemns those who invent lies against Allah or reject His revelations. It warns that they will face the consequences of their actions on the Day of Judgment when the messengers of Allah take their souls. At that time, the false deities they worshipped besides Allah will disown them, and they will admit to their own disbelief.
orig: فمن أظلم ممن افترى على الله كذبا أو كذب بآياته أولئك ينالهم نصيبهم من الكتاب حتى إذا جاءتهم رسلنا يتوفونهم قالوا أين ما كنتم تدعون من دون الله قالوا ضلوا عنا وشهدوا على أنفسهم أنهم كانوا كافرين

translation: He (Allah) will say: "Enter, along with the peoples who passed away before you - of jinn and men - into the Fire." Every time a new people enter, they will curse their sister-people until, when they have all been gathered together, the last of them will say of the first of them: "Our Lord! These are the ones who led us astray, so give them a double punishment of the Fire." He will say: "For each one there is a double (punishment), but you do not know."
interpretation: This verse describes the scene on the Day of Judgment when Allah will command the disbelievers from among the jinn and humans to enter Hell. Each successive group will curse the previous one for leading them astray, until the last group will ask Allah to double the punishment for the first group that misguided them. However, Allah will respond that each group will receive a double punishment for their disbelief and sins, but they were unaware of this reality during their worldly life.
orig: قال ادخلوا في أمم قد خلت من قبلكم من الجن والإنس في النار كلما دخلت أمة لعنت أختها حتى إذا اداركوا فيها جميعا قالت أخراهم لأولاهم ربنا هؤلاء أضلونا فآتهم عذابا ضعفا من النار قال لكل ضعف ولكن لا تعلمون

translation: And the foremost of them will say to the last of them, "Then you had no favor over us, so taste the punishment for what you used to earn."
interpretation: This verse refers to the dialogue between the leaders and followers in Hell. The leaders will say to their followers that they had no superiority or favor over them that caused them to go astray. Rather, each person is responsible for their own actions and choices. Therefore, they will be held accountable and punished accordingly for their misdeeds and disbelief.
orig: وقالت أولاهم لأخراهم فما كان لكم علينا من فضل فذوقوا العذاب بما كنتم تكسبون

translation: Indeed, those who denied Our verses and were arrogant toward them - the gates of Heaven will not be opened for them, and they will not enter Paradise until a camel enters into the eye of a needle. And thus do We recompense the criminals.
interpretation: This verse warns those who reject God's revelations and act arrogantly that they will be deprived of entering Paradise. It uses a metaphor, saying that it is as impossible for them to enter Paradise as it is for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle. This metaphor emphasizes the extreme difficulty, or rather impossibility, of arrogant disbelievers attaining salvation. The verse implies that humility, faith, and obedience to God's commandments are essential for attaining His mercy and entrance into Paradise.
orig: إن الذين كذبوا بآياتنا واستكبروا عنها لا تفتح لهم أبواب السماء ولا يدخلون الجنة حتى يلج الجمل في سم الخياط وكذلك نجزي المجرمين

translation: For them is a bed of Hell, and over them coverings [of fire]. And thus do We recompense the wrongdoers.
interpretation: This verse warns the wrongdoers and disbelievers of a severe punishment in Hellfire. It describes their abode in Hell as a "bed" and coverings of fire over them, indicating intense torment and suffering with no escape. This is the ultimate recompense for those who persist in wrongdoing and reject faith, highlighting the grave consequences of their actions.
orig: لهم من جهنم مهاد ومن فوقهم غواش وكذلك نجزي الظالمين

translation: And those who believe and do righteous deeds - We will not tax any soul beyond its capacity. Those are the companions of Paradise; they will abide therein eternally.
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that Allah will not burden a person beyond their ability and capacity. Those who have faith and perform good deeds will be rewarded with Paradise, where they will dwell forever. It emphasizes Allah's justice and mercy, as He does not impose obligations that are impossible for people to fulfill. The righteous believers will be rewarded with an eternal abode in Paradise as a result of their faith and good actions.
orig: والذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات لا نكلف نفسا إلا وسعها أولئك أصحاب الجنة هم فيها خالدون

translation: And We will remove whatever is in their breasts of resentment, [so] rivers will flow beneath them. And they will say, 'Praise to Allah, who has guided us to this; and we would never have been guided if Allah had not guided us. Certainly the messengers of our Lord had come with the truth.' And they will be called, 'This is Paradise, which you have been made to inherit for what you used to do.'
interpretation: This verse describes the state of the believers in Paradise. Their hearts will be purified of any ill feelings or resentment towards one another. Rivers will flow beneath the lofty dwellings in Paradise. They will praise and thank Allah for guiding them to this blessed state, acknowledging that it was only through His guidance that they were able to attain it. They will affirm that the messengers of Allah had indeed brought the truth. And they will be welcomed into Paradise as an inheritance, a reward for their righteous deeds in the worldly life.
orig: ونزعنا ما في صدورهم من غل تجري من تحتهم الأنهار وقالوا الحمد لله الذي هدانا لهذا وما كنا لنهتدي لولا أن هدانا الله لقد جاءت رسل ربنا بالحق ونودوا أن تلكم الجنة أورثتموها بما كنتم تعملون

translation: And the inhabitants of Paradise will call out to the inhabitants of the Fire, 'We have found what our Lord promised us to be true; have you found what your Lord promised to be true?' They will say, 'Yes.' Then a caller will announce between them, 'The curse of Allah is upon the wrongdoers'
interpretation: This verse describes the dialogue between the people of Paradise and the people of Hellfire on the Day of Judgment. The people of Paradise confirm that Allah's promise of reward for the believers has been fulfilled, while the people of Hellfire admit that Allah's warning of punishment for the disbelievers has also come true. An announcer then declares that Allah's curse is upon the wrongdoers who rejected faith and did evil deeds.
orig: ونادى أصحاب الجنة أصحاب النار أن قد وجدنا ما وعدنا ربنا حقا فهل وجدتم ما وعد ربكم حقا قالوا نعم فأذن مؤذن بينهم أن لعنة الله على الظالمين

translation: Those who hinder (others) from the Path of Allah and seek to make it crooked, and they are disbelievers in the Hereafter.
interpretation: This verse refers to those who actively prevent people from following the straight path of Allah and try to distort and misguide them. They reject the belief in the Hereafter and the accountability of their actions on the Day of Judgment. Their disbelief causes them to obstruct others from the truth and spread misguidance.
orig: الذين يصدون عن سبيل الله ويبغونها عوجا وهم بالآخرة كافرون

translation: And between them will be a partition, and on the elevations will be men who recognize all by their marks. And they will call out to the companions of Paradise, 'Peace be upon you.' They have not yet entered it, but they long for it.
interpretation: This verse describes a barrier or partition between Paradise and Hell, with men stationed on elevated positions who can recognize the people of each abode by their distinguishing marks. These men will call out greetings of peace to the inhabitants of Paradise, even though they themselves have not yet entered it, but they aspire to attain it.
orig: وبينهما حجاب وعلى الأعراف رجال يعرفون كلا بسيماهم ونادوا أصحاب الجنة أن سلام عليكم لم يدخلوها وهم يطمعون

translation: And when their eyes are turned towards the companions of the Fire, they will say: 'Our Lord, do not place us with the wrongdoing people.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the believers on the Day of Judgment. When they see the disbelievers being punished in Hell, they will pray to Allah not to be joined with the oppressors and wrongdoers. It shows their fear of Allah's punishment and their desire to be kept away from those who rejected faith and did evil deeds.
orig: وإذا صرفت أبصارهم تلقاء أصحاب النار قالوا ربنا لا تجعلنا مع القوم الظالمين

translation: And the inhabitants of the Heights will call out to men they recognize by their marks, saying, 'Your hoardings availed you not, nor your arrogance.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the Day of Judgment when those who achieved salvation will call out to the arrogant disbelievers whom they recognize by their marks or characteristics. They will rebuke them, saying that neither their wealth nor their arrogance benefited them in any way, as these worldly things are of no value in the Hereafter.
orig: ونادى أصحاب الأعراف رجالا يعرفونهم بسيماهم قالوا ما أغنى عنكم جمعكم وما كنتم تستكبرون

translation: Is this not the company of those about whom you swore that Allah would never bestow His mercy upon them? (It was said to them): Enter Paradise, you shall have no fear, nor shall you grieve.
interpretation: This verse refers to the believers who were persecuted and mocked by the disbelievers for their faith. The disbelievers swore that Allah would never bestow His mercy upon the believers. However, Allah proved them wrong and admitted the believers into Paradise, where they will have no fear or grief.
orig: أهؤلاء الذين أقسمتم لا ينالهم الله برحمة ادخلوا الجنة لا خوف عليكم ولا أنتم تحزنون

translation: And the companions of the Fire will call to the companions of Paradise, 'Pour upon us some water or from whatever Allah has provided you.' They will say, 'Indeed, Allah has forbidden them both to the disbelievers.'
interpretation: This verse describes a scene on the Day of Judgment where the disbelievers who are in Hellfire will desperately call out to the believers in Paradise, begging them to send some water or provisions given to them by Allah. However, the believers will respond that Allah has forbidden the disbelievers from receiving any such relief or blessings, as a punishment for their disbelief and rejection of faith.
orig: ونادى أصحاب النار أصحاب الجنة أن أفيضوا علينا من الماء أو مما رزقكم الله قالوا إن الله حرمهما على الكافرين

translation: Those who took their religion as a diversion and play, and were deluded by the life of this world. So today We will forget them as they forgot the meeting of this Day of theirs and as they used to reject Our signs.
interpretation: This verse refers to those who did not take their religion seriously and were distracted by the temporary pleasures and amusements of this worldly life. As a result, they neglected the reality of the Day of Judgment and denied Allah's revelations. On that Day, they will be forgotten and neglected by Allah, just as they forgot and neglected the meeting of that inevitable Day during their worldly lives.
orig: الذين اتخذوا دينهم لهوا ولعبا وغرتهم الحياة الدنيا فاليوم ننساهم كما نسوا لقاء يومهم هذا وما كانوا بآياتنا يجحدون

translation: And We had certainly brought them a Book which We detailed with knowledge - a guidance and mercy for a people who believe.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the Qur'an is a divinely revealed Book from Allah, which provides detailed knowledge, guidance, and mercy for those who have faith and believe in it. The Qur'an is presented as a comprehensive source of guidance encompassing all aspects of life, both spiritual and worldly. Its teachings serve as a means of attaining Allah's mercy and blessings for those who embrace it wholeheartedly.
orig: ولقد جئناهم بكتاب فصلناه على علم هدى ورحمة لقوم يؤمنون

translation: Do they await anything but its interpretation? On the Day its interpretation comes, those who had forgotten it before will say, 'The messengers of our Lord had certainly brought the truth. Are there any intercessors who could intercede for us, or could we be sent back to do other than what we did?' They have certainly lost themselves, and lost from them is whatever they used to invent.
interpretation: This verse warns those who deny the truth that they will realize it on the Day of Judgment, but it will be too late. They will wish for a second chance or intercessors to help them, but their pleas will be in vain. They have ruined their own souls by rejecting the truth and inventing falsehoods. The interpretation emphasizes the finality of the Day of Judgment and the consequences of denying God's revelations.
orig: هل ينظرون إلا تأويله يوم يأتي تأويله يقول الذين نسوه من قبل قد جاءت رسل ربنا بالحق فهل لنا من شفعاء فيشفعوا لنا أو نرد فنعمل غير الذي كنا نعمل قد خسروا أنفسهم وضل عنهم ما كانوا يفترون

translation: Indeed, your Lord is Allah, who created the heavens and earth in six days - then He established Himself upon the Throne. He covers the night with the day, being in pursuit of it rapidly; and [created] the sun, the moon, and the stars, subjected by His command. Unquestionably, His is the creation and the command; blessed is Allah, Lord of the worlds.
interpretation: This verse affirms the Oneness of Allah as the sole Creator and Sustainer of the universe. It highlights His absolute power and control over the entire creation, including the alternation of night and day, and the subjugation of celestial bodies like the sun, moon, and stars to His command. The interpretation emphasizes Allah's transcendence, majesty, and worthiness of praise as the Lord of all worlds.
orig: إن ربكم الله الذي خلق السماوات والأرض في ستة أيام ثم استوى على العرش يغشي الليل النهار يطلبه حثيثا والشمس والقمر والنجوم مسخرات بأمره ألا له الخلق والأمر تبارك الله رب العالمين

translation: Call upon your Lord in humility and privately. Indeed, He does not like transgressors.
interpretation: This verse encourages believers to supplicate to Allah in a humble and sincere manner, without arrogance or ostentation. It emphasizes the importance of having a direct and personal connection with Allah through prayer and invocation. The verse also warns against transgressing the limits set by Allah, as He does not approve of those who exceed boundaries or act unjustly.
orig: ادعوا ربكم تضرعا وخفية إنه لا يحب المعتدين

translation: And do not cause corruption on the earth after its reformation. And invoke Him in fear and aspiration. Indeed, the mercy of Allah is near to the doers of good.
interpretation: This verse commands believers not to spread corruption and mischief on earth after it has been reformed and set in order by Allah. It encourages them to call upon Allah with a mindset of hope and fear - hope for His mercy and blessings, and fear of His punishment for disobedience. The verse concludes with the reassuring message that Allah's mercy is close to those who do good deeds and strive to please Him.
orig: ولا تفسدوا في الأرض بعد إصلاحها وادعوه خوفا وطمعا إن رحمت الله قريب من المحسنين

translation: And it is He who sends the winds as good tidings before His mercy until, when they have carried heavy rainclouds, We drive them to a dead land and We send down rain therein and bring forth thereby [some] of all the fruits. Thus will We bring forth the dead; perhaps you may be reminded.
interpretation: Allah est Celui qui envoie les vents porteurs de bonnes nouvelles avant Sa miséricorde (la pluie). Lorsque les vents transportent des nuages chargés de pluie, Il les dirige vers une terre aride et y fait descendre l'eau, faisant ainsi pousser toutes sortes de fruits. De même, Allah redonnera vie aux morts le Jour de la Résurrection afin que vous vous souveniez de Son pouvoir et de Sa miséricorde.
orig: وهو الذي يرسل الرياح بشرا بين يدي رحمته حتى إذا أقلت سحابا ثقالا سقناه لبلد ميت فأنزلنا به الماء فأخرجنا به من كل الثمرات كذلك نخرج الموتى لعلكم تذكرون

translation: And the good land - its vegetation emerges by permission of its Lord, but that which is bad - nothing emerges except sparsely, with difficulty. Thus do We diversify the signs for a people who are grateful.
interpretation: "This verse draws an analogy between the land and the human soul. The fertile land that receives rain and nourishment produces abundant vegetation, just as the pure soul that receives the guidance of Allah flourishes with faith and good deeds. Conversely, the barren land that lacks nourishment yields little or no vegetation, just as the corrupt soul deprived of faith yields only misery and hardship. Allah presents these contrasting examples as signs for those who reflect and are grateful for His guidance."
orig: والبلد الطيب يخرج نباته بإذن ربه والذي خبث لا يخرج إلا نكدا كذلك نصرف الآيات لقوم يشكرون

translation: We had certainly sent Noah to his people, and he said, 'O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. Indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a tremendous Day.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the core message of Prophet Noah's preaching to his people, which was to worship Allah alone and abandon idolatry. Noah warned them of the severe punishment that awaits those who persist in disbelief and polytheism on the Day of Judgment, described as a "tremendous Day."
orig: لقد أرسلنا نوحا إلى قومه فقال يا قوم اعبدوا الله ما لكم من إله غيره إني أخاف عليكم عذاب يوم عظيم

translation: The chiefs of his people said: 'Verily, we see you in manifest error.'
interpretation: The leaders and prominent figures among his people accused him of being clearly misguided, implying that his beliefs and teachings were erroneous and deviated from the truth.
orig: قال الملأ من قومه إنا لنراك في ضلال مبين

translation: He said, 'O my people, there is no error in me, but I am a messenger from the Lord of the worlds.'
interpretation: This verse suggests that the Prophet is affirming his role as a messenger sent by God, the Lord of all creation. He is denying any personal flaws or deviations from the truth, and asserting that his message comes directly from the Divine source.
orig: قال يا قوم ليس بي ضلالة ولكني رسول من رب العالمين

translation: I convey to you the messages of my Lord and advise you, and I know from Allah what you do not know.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the Prophet Muhammad's role was to convey the revelations and teachings from God, and to provide sincere advice and guidance to people. He also had knowledge from God that others did not possess, enabling him to guide them to the truth.
orig: أبلغكم رسالات ربي وأنصح لكم وأعلم من الله ما لا تعلمون

translation: Do you wonder that there has come to you a reminder from your Lord through a man from among you, to warn you and that you may fear Allah and that you may receive mercy?
interpretation: The verse is questioning the people's astonishment at the fact that a reminder from Allah, in the form of the Qur'an, was brought to them through a man from among themselves, i.e., the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ. It emphasizes that this is a means for them to be warned, to fear Allah, and to attain His mercy.
orig: أوعجبتم أن جاءكم ذكر من ربكم على رجل منكم لينذركم ولتتقوا ولعلكم ترحمون

translation: But they denied him, so We saved him and those with him in the ship. And We drowned those who denied Our signs. Indeed, they were a blind people.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Noah and his people. Despite Noah's repeated warnings and calls to worship the One True God, his people rejected his message and denied him. As a result, God saved Noah and the believers who were with him in the ark, while drowning those who persisted in disbelief and denial of God's signs and revelations. The verse emphasizes that those who denied God's signs were spiritually blind, unable to perceive the truth and guidance that was sent to them.
orig: فكذبوه فأنجيناه والذين معه في الفلك وأغرقنا الذين كذبوا بآياتنا إنهم كانوا قوما عمين

translation: And to 'Aad (people), (We sent) their brother Hud. He said: 'O my people! Worship Allah! You have no other Ilah (God) but Him. Will you not then be afraid (of Him)?'
interpretation: The interpretation is that Allah sent the Prophet Hud to the 'Aad people, who were known for their physical strength and prosperity, but had deviated from the worship of the One True God. Hud called them to worship Allah alone, as there is no deity worthy of worship except Him. He warned them to have fear of Allah and be mindful of the consequences of associating partners with Him.
orig: وإلى عاد أخاهم هودا قال يا قوم اعبدوا الله ما لكم من إله غيره أفلا تتقون

translation: The chiefs of those who disbelieved from his people said, 'We see you in foolishness, and we consider you one of the liars.'
interpretation: The leaders and influential people among those who disbelieved from the nation of the Prophet accused him of being foolish and considered him a liar in his claim of prophethood and the message he brought. This verse highlights the arrogance and rejection of the disbelievers towards the truth brought by the Prophet, as they dismissed him based on their own misconceptions and stubbornness.
orig: قال الملأ الذين كفروا من قومه إنا لنراك في سفاهة وإنا لنظنك من الكاذبين

translation: He said: 'O my people! There is no foolishness in me, but I am a Messenger from the Lord of the worlds.'
interpretation: This verse indicates that Prophet Noah asserted his sanity and soundness of mind to his people, denying any foolishness or madness on his part. He affirmed that he was a Messenger sent by Allah, the Lord and Sustainer of all the worlds, with the divine truth and guidance.
orig: قال يا قوم ليس بي سفاهة ولكني رسول من رب العالمين

translation: I convey to you the messages of my Lord, and I am a sincere adviser to you.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the role of the Prophet Muhammad as a messenger who faithfully conveys the message of God without any alteration or personal agenda. He is described as a "sincere adviser," indicating his genuine concern for the well-being and guidance of the people he was sent to. The verse highlights the Prophet's truthfulness, sincerity, and commitment to his mission as a messenger of God.
orig: أبلغكم رسالات ربي وأنا لكم ناصح أمين

translation: Or are you amazed that there has come to you a reminder from your Lord through a man from among you, that he may warn you? And remember when He made you successors after the people of Noah and increased you in stature extensively. So remember the favors of Allah that you might succeed.
interpretation: This verse questions whether the people are amazed that a reminder from Allah has come to them through a man from among themselves, whose purpose is to warn them. It reminds them of Allah's favor upon them, as He made them successors after the people of Noah and granted them increased physical stature. The verse urges them to remember Allah's blessings so that they may attain success.
orig: أوعجبتم أن جاءكم ذكر من ربكم على رجل منكم لينذركم واذكروا إذ جعلكم خلفاء من بعد قوم نوح وزادكم في الخلق بسطة فاذكروا آلاء الله لعلكم تفلحون

translation: They said, "Have you come to us to make us worship Allah alone and abandon what our forefathers used to worship? Then bring us what you have promised us, if you are one of the truthful."
interpretation: "The disbelievers are questioning the Prophet's message of worshiping One God alone, as it goes against the polytheistic beliefs and practices of their forefathers. They are challenging him to bring about the punishment he is warning them of, if he is truly a truthful messenger."
orig: قالوا أجئتنا لنعبد الله وحده ونذر ما كان يعبد آباؤنا فأتنا بما تعدنا إن كنت من الصادقين

translation: He said, 'Verily, disgrace and wrath from your Lord have fallen upon you. Do you dispute with me over names which you have named - you and your fathers - for which Allah has sent down no authority? Then wait, I am with you among those who wait.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the Prophet's rebuke of the idolaters who worshipped false gods and idols that they had named themselves, without any sanction from Allah. He warns them that they have incurred Allah's wrath and disgrace by associating partners with Him. He challenges their practice of naming and worshipping deities for which Allah has revealed no proof or justification. The Prophet declares that he will wait alongside them for Allah's judgment, as he is among those who patiently await Allah's decree.
orig: قال قد وقع عليكم من ربكم رجس وغضب أتجادلونني في أسماء سميتموها أنتم وآباؤكم ما نزل الله بها من سلطان فانتظروا إني معكم من المنتظرين

translation: So We saved him and those with him by mercy from Us, and We cut off the roots of those who denied Our signs, for they were not believers.
interpretation: This verse refers to Allah saving Prophet Nuh (Noah) and his followers who believed in his message, while destroying the disbelievers who denied Allah's signs and refused to accept the truth. It highlights Allah's mercy towards the believers and His punishment for those who persist in disbelief and rejection of faith, cutting off their lineage and legacy.
orig: فأنجيناه والذين معه برحمة منا وقطعنا دابر الذين كذبوا بآياتنا وما كانوا مؤمنين

translation: And to Thamud (people, We sent) their brother Salih. He said: 'O my people! Worship Allah! You have no other Ilah (God) but Him. (La ilaha ill-Allah: none has the right to be worshipped but Allah). Indeed there has come to you a clear sign from your Lord. This she-camel of Allah is a sign unto you; so leave her to graze in Allah's land, and touch her not with harm, lest a painful torment should seize you.'
interpretation: Allah commanded the Prophet Salih to call his people, the tribe of Thamud, to worship Allah alone and to avoid worshipping idols. Allah provided them with a clear sign, a miraculous she-camel, as proof of Salih's prophethood. Salih warned them not to harm the she-camel, otherwise a severe punishment from Allah would strike them.
orig: وإلى ثمود أخاهم صالحا قال يا قوم اعبدوا الله ما لكم من إله غيره قد جاءتكم بينة من ربكم هذه ناقة الله لكم آية فذروها تأكل في أرض الله ولا تمسوها بسوء فيأخذكم عذاب أليم

translation: And remember when He made you successors after the people of 'Aad and settled you in the land - you taking for yourselves palaces from its plains and carving out homes from the mountains. So remember the favors of Allah and do not commit evil in the land, spreading corruption.
interpretation: This verse reminds the believers of Allah's favors upon them, when He made them successors on earth after destroying the people of 'Aad for their disobedience. The believers were given the ability to build palaces on the plains and carve homes out of mountains, enjoying the blessings of the land. However, they are warned not to become arrogant or ungrateful, and to avoid spreading corruption and evil on earth. The interpretation emphasizes gratitude, humility, and righteousness in the face of Allah's bounties.
orig: واذكروا إذ جعلكم خلفاء من بعد عاد وبوأكم في الأرض تتخذون من سهولها قصورا وتنحتون الجبال بيوتا فاذكروا آلاء الله ولا تعثوا في الأرض مفسدين

translation: The arrogant leaders among his people said to those who were oppressed and believed, "Do you really believe that Salih is sent by his Lord?" They replied, "We do indeed believe in that which he has been sent with."
interpretation: This verse describes the reaction of the arrogant and powerful people of Thamud when Prophet Salih called them to worship Allah alone. The arrogant leaders mocked the believers who were weak and oppressed, questioning whether they truly believed that Salih was a messenger sent by God. The oppressed believers, however, responded with firm conviction, affirming their belief in Salih's message and his divine appointment as a prophet.
orig: قال الملأ الذين استكبروا من قومه للذين استضعفوا لمن آمن منهم أتعلمون أن صالحا مرسل من ربه قالوا إنا بما أرسل به مؤمنون

translation: Those who were arrogant said: 'Verily, we disbelieve in that which you believed.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the arrogant and proud disbelievers who rejected the message of faith brought by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). Their arrogance and pride prevented them from accepting the truth and submitting to God's guidance. They declared their disbelief in the very message that the believers had accepted, revealing their stubborn rejection of faith.
orig: قال الذين استكبروا إنا بالذي آمنتم به كافرون

translation: But they hamstrung the she-camel and insolently defied the command of their Lord, and said: 'O Salih, bring us what you threatened us with, if you are one of the Messengers.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the people of Thamud who arrogantly rejected the message of Prophet Salih and killed the miraculous she-camel that Allah had sent as a sign. They defiantly challenged Salih to bring upon them the punishment he had warned them about if he was truly a messenger of Allah. This shows their stubbornness and disbelief despite witnessing a clear miracle.
orig: فعقروا الناقة وعتوا عن أمر ربهم وقالوا يا صالح ائتنا بما تعدنا إن كنت من المرسلين

translation: But the awful cry overtook them at the sunrise. So they ended up lying motionless in their dwellings.
interpretation: This verse describes the punishment that befell an ungrateful nation who rejected the message of their prophet. The "awful cry" refers to a powerful blast or scream that struck them, causing them to fall down dead in their homes. This punishment came suddenly upon them at sunrise, leaving them lying motionless and lifeless in their dwellings. The verse serves as a warning against denying God's signs and messengers, as it highlights the severe consequences of such denial.
orig: فأخذتهم الرجفة فأصبحوا في دارهم جاثمين

translation: So he turned away from them and said, 'O my people, I have certainly conveyed to you the message of my Lord and advised you, but you do not like those who advise you.'
interpretation: The interpretation is that the prophet is expressing his frustration with his people for rejecting his message and advice, despite his sincere efforts to guide them. He recognizes that they have a dislike for those who advise them, even when the advice comes from a well-wishing source.
orig: فتولى عنهم وقال يا قوم لقد أبلغتكم رسالة ربي ونصحت لكم ولكن لا تحبون الناصحين

translation: And (mention) Lut, when he said to his people: 'Do you commit the abomination while you are seeing? You approach men with lust instead of women. Nay, you are a people who behave senselessly.'
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that Allah is reminding the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) about the story of Prophet Lut (peace be upon him) and how he warned his people against the grave sin of homosexuality. Lut condemned his people for committing this "abomination" that no one in the world had committed before. He criticized them for lusting after men instead of women, which goes against natural human instincts and is an act of senselessness and ignorance.
orig: ولوطا إذ قال لقومه أتأتون الفاحشة ما سبقكم بها من أحد من العالمين

translation: Verily, you practice your lusts on men instead of women. Nay, but you are a people transgressing beyond bounds.
interpretation: This verse condemns the abhorrent practice of homosexuality among the people of Lut (Lot). It highlights that they engaged in lustful acts with men instead of women, which goes against the natural order established by Allah. Their actions are described as a transgression and an excess, indicating the gravity of this sin in the sight of Allah.
orig: إنكم لتأتون الرجال شهوة من دون النساء بل أنتم قوم مسرفون

translation: But the answer of his people was not except that they said, 'Expel them from your city. Indeed, they are people who keep themselves pure.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the response of the people of Lut (Lot) when he preached against their immoral practices, particularly homosexuality. Instead of accepting his message and repenting, they arrogantly demanded that he and his followers be expelled from their city, accusing them of being "those who keep themselves pure" in a mocking and derogatory manner.
orig: وما كان جواب قومه إلا أن قالوا أخرجوهم من قريتكم إنهم أناس يتطهرون

translation: So We saved him and his family, except his wife; she was of those who remained behind.
interpretation: Allah saved Prophet Lut and his believing family members from the punishment that befell the people of Sodom, except his wife who disbelieved and remained behind with the disbelievers, thus suffering the same fate as them.
orig: فأنجيناه وأهله إلا امرأته كانت من الغابرين

translation: And We rained upon them a rain [of stones]. Then see how was the end of the criminals.
interpretation: "This verse refers to the punishment that Allah inflicted upon the people of Lut (Lot) for their grave sin of homosexuality and rejecting the message of their prophet. Allah rained down upon them a shower of stones, destroying them utterly. The interpretation highlights the severe consequences of defying Allah's commands and persisting in sinful behavior, even after being warned by a prophet."
orig: وأمطرنا عليهم مطرا فانظر كيف كان عاقبة المجرمين

translation: And to Madyan (We sent) their brother Shu'aib. He said: 'O my people! Worship Allah! You have no other Ilah (God) but Him. Verily, a clear proof has come to you from your Lord. So give full measure and full weight and wrong not people in their goods, and do not make mischief on the earth after it has been set in order. That will be better for you, if you are believers.'
interpretation: This verse is addressing the people of Madyan, to whom Allah sent the Prophet Shu'aib as a messenger. Shu'aib called his people to worship Allah alone and to abandon idolatry, as clear evidence and proof had come to them from their Lord. He instructed them to give full measure and weight in their transactions and not to defraud people of their rights or possessions. He also warned them against committing corruption and mischief on the earth after it had been set in order by Allah. Shu'aib advised them that adhering to these commands would be better for them if they truly believed in Allah.
orig: وإلى مدين أخاهم شعيبا قال يا قوم اعبدوا الله ما لكم من إله غيره قد جاءتكم بينة من ربكم فأوفوا الكيل والميزان ولا تبخسوا الناس أشياءهم ولا تفسدوا في الأرض بعد إصلاحها ذلكم خير لكم إن كنتم مؤمنين

translation: And do not sit on every path, threatening and hindering from the way of Allah those who believe, seeking to make it crooked. And remember when you were few and He increased you. And look at the consequences for the corrupters.
interpretation: This verse prohibits obstructing people from the path of Allah and creating difficulties for believers. It reminds the believers of their humble beginnings when they were few in number, and how Allah increased them. It also warns them to reflect on the ultimate fate of those who spread corruption and mischief on earth.
orig: ولا تقعدوا بكل صراط توعدون وتصدون عن سبيل الله من آمن به وتبغونها عوجا واذكروا إذ كنتم قليلا فكثركم وانظروا كيف كان عاقبة المفسدين

translation: And if a group among you believes in that which I have been sent with, and a group does not believe, then be patient until Allah judges between us. And He is the best of judges.
interpretation: This verse teaches Muslims to be patient and tolerant towards those who reject the message of Islam. It advises them not to force their beliefs on others, but rather to wait for Allah's judgment, as He is the best of judges and will ultimately decide between truth and falsehood. The verse promotes the values of patience, wisdom, and respect for differing beliefs.
orig: وإن كان طائفة منكم آمنوا بالذي أرسلت به وطائفة لم يؤمنوا فاصبروا حتى يحكم الله بيننا وهو خير الحاكمين

translation: The arrogant leaders of his people said, 'We will surely drive you out, O Shu'ayb, and those who have believed with you from our city, or you must return to our religion.' He said, 'Even if we were unwilling?'
interpretation: This verse refers to the arrogant leaders of the people of Prophet Shu'ayb (peace be upon him) who threatened to expel him and his followers from their city unless they abandoned their faith and reverted to the pagan religion of the disbelievers. The interpretation highlights the intolerance and oppression faced by the believers at the hands of the arrogant disbelievers, who sought to impose their falsehood upon them by force.
orig: قال الملأ الذين استكبروا من قومه لنخرجنك يا شعيب والذين آمنوا معك من قريتنا أو لتعودن في ملتنا قال أولو كنا كارهين

translation: We should indeed invent a lie against Allah if we returned to your religion after Allah has delivered us from it. And it is not for us to return to it unless Allah, our Lord, should will. Our Lord comprehends all things in knowledge; upon Allah we have relied. Our Lord, decide between us and our people in truth, and You are the best of those who give decision.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes complete reliance on Allah and rejecting any return to disbelief or falsehood after being guided to the truth. It highlights that reverting to a false religion would be tantamount to "inventing a lie against Allah," which is unacceptable. The interpretation stresses putting one's trust in Allah, seeking His guidance, and asking Him to judge between truth and falsehood, as He is the best arbiter.
orig: قد افترينا على الله كذبا إن عدنا في ملتكم بعد إذ نجانا الله منها وما يكون لنا أن نعود فيها إلا أن يشاء الله ربنا وسع ربنا كل شيء علما على الله توكلنا ربنا افتح بيننا وبين قومنا بالحق وأنت خير الفاتحين

translation: And the eminent ones who disbelieved among his people said, 'If you follow Shu'ayb, you will indeed be the losers.'
interpretation: The arrogant and influential leaders who rejected the message of Prophet Shu'ayb warned his followers that if they continued to follow him, they would suffer great loss and misfortune. This interpretation highlights the opposition and threats faced by the Prophet from the powerful elite who feared losing their status and wealth if they accepted his teachings of monotheism and social justice.
orig: وقال الملأ الذين كفروا من قومه لئن اتبعتم شعيبا إنكم إذا لخاسرون

translation: Then the earthquake seized them, so they became lifeless bodies in their dwelling.
interpretation: This verse describes the punishment that befell a disobedient people who rejected the message of their prophet. The "earthquake" or violent shaking of the earth represents God's wrath and punishment. As a result, they became "lifeless bodies" or corpses, lying motionless in their homes, having been struck down for their disbelief and defiance of God's commands.
orig: فأخذتهم الرجفة فأصبحوا في دارهم جاثمين

translation: Those who denied Shu'ayb - it was as though they had never resided therein. Those who denied Shu'ayb - it was they who were the losers.
interpretation: This verse highlights the consequence of rejecting the message of the Prophet Shu'ayb. Those who denied and opposed him were utterly destroyed, as if they had never lived in prosperity in their dwellings. Their denial of the truth and persistence in wrongdoing led to their downfall and loss in this world and the Hereafter.
orig: الذين كذبوا شعيبا كأن لم يغنوا فيها الذين كذبوا شعيبا كانوا هم الخاسرين

translation: So he turned away from them and said: 'O my people! I have indeed conveyed to you the messages of my Lord and advised you, so how could I grieve for a disbelieving people?'
interpretation: The interpretation is that the Prophet is expressing his disappointment and sadness at his people's rejection of his message, despite his sincere efforts to convey the truth to them. He has fulfilled his duty of conveying the message of God and advising them, but they have chosen to disbelieve. He cannot grieve endlessly over their disbelief, as they have made their choice willfully.
orig: فتولى عنهم وقال يا قوم لقد أبلغتكم رسالات ربي ونصحت لكم فكيف آسى على قوم كافرين

translation: And We did not send any prophet to a town but We seized its people with suffering and hardship so that they might humble themselves.
interpretation: Allah sends hardships and difficulties upon people as a test and reminder to turn to Him in humility and submission. These trials are a means for spiritual growth and purification, encouraging people to seek forgiveness, repent, and become more devoted to Allah.
orig: وما أرسلنا في قرية من نبي إلا أخذنا أهلها بالبأساء والضراء لعلهم يضرعون

translation: Then We changed the evil for the good, until they increased in number and wealth. And they said, 'Our ancestors were touched by hardship and ease.' So We seized them suddenly while they did not perceive.
interpretation: Allah is describing how He replaced the hardship and difficulties faced by the disbelievers with ease, prosperity, and an abundance of wealth and children. However, they became arrogant and ungrateful, attributing their success to their ancestors rather than to Allah's favors. As a result, Allah suddenly seized them with punishment while they were unaware and unprepared.
orig: ثم بدلنا مكان السيئة الحسنة حتى عفوا وقالوا قد مس آباءنا الضراء والسراء فأخذناهم بغتة وهم لا يشعرون

translation: And if the people of the towns had believed and feared Allah, We would have opened upon them blessings from the heaven and the earth; but they denied, so We seized them for what they were earning.
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of faith (Iman) and righteousness (Taqwa) for attaining blessings from Allah. It states that if the people of the towns had embraced faith and lived righteously, Allah would have showered them with abundant blessings from the heavens and the earth. However, they rejected the message and denied the truth, so Allah punished them for their misdeeds and disbelief.
orig: ولو أن أهل القرى آمنوا واتقوا لفتحنا عليهم بركات من السماء والأرض ولكن كذبوا فأخذناهم بما كانوا يكسبون

translation: Then, do the people of the towns feel secure from Our punishment coming to them at night while they are asleep?
interpretation: This verse questions the false sense of security that the disbelievers have, thinking that Allah's punishment will not strike them unexpectedly while they are unaware or heedless. It serves as a warning that Allah's torment can come at any time, even while they are asleep at night, when they least expect it. The verse aims to instill a sense of fear and consciousness of Allah in their hearts.
orig: أفأمن أهل القرى أن يأتيهم بأسنا بياتا وهم نائمون

translation: Or were the inhabitants of the towns secure from the coming of Our punishment upon them in the morning while they were playing?
interpretation: This verse warns people against complacency and heedlessness towards Allah's punishment. It questions whether the people of the towns felt secure that Allah's punishment would not come upon them suddenly, even while they were engaged in vain pursuits and amusements. The verse serves as a reminder that Allah's punishment can strike at any time, without warning, and that one should not be deceived by a false sense of security or indulge in frivolous activities that distract from remembering Allah.
orig: أوأمن أهل القرى أن يأتيهم بأسنا ضحى وهم يلعبون

translation: Then did they feel secure from the plan of Allah? But no one feels secure from the plan of Allah except the losing people.
interpretation: This verse warns against feeling secure from Allah's plan and punishment. It emphasizes that only those who are destined for loss and failure feel secure from Allah's decree and scheme. The true believers should always be mindful of Allah's power and remain vigilant against complacency and arrogance.
orig: أفأمنوا مكر الله فلا يأمن مكر الله إلا القوم الخاسرون

translation: Have they not been guided by the example of those who inherited the earth before them, that if We willed, We could have afflicted them for their sins, and sealed their hearts, leaving them deaf?
interpretation: This verse suggests that Allah has the power to punish those who disobey Him, just as He punished previous nations that rejected His messengers. He could afflict them with calamities for their sins and seal their hearts, making them unable to understand the truth. This serves as a warning and reminder to reflect on the consequences of disbelief and wrongdoing.
orig: أولم يهد للذين يرثون الأرض من بعد أهلها أن لو نشاء أصبناهم بذنوبهم ونطبع على قلوبهم فهم لا يسمعون

translation: Those were the towns, whose story We relate unto thee. And verily their messengers brought them clear proofs, but they would not believe what they had before denied. Thus doth Allah seal up the hearts of those who disbelieve.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah relates the stories of previous nations to the Prophet Muhammad as a lesson and warning. Those nations rejected the clear signs brought by the messengers sent to them, just as they had rejected the truth before. As a result, Allah sealed their hearts, preventing them from believing due to their persistent disbelief and stubbornness.
orig: تلك القرى نقص عليك من أنبائها ولقد جاءتهم رسلهم بالبينات فما كانوا ليؤمنوا بما كذبوا من قبل كذلك يطبع الله على قلوب الكافرين

translation: And We found not for most of them any covenant, and indeed, We found most of them defiantly disobedient.
interpretation: This verse suggests that most people do not uphold their covenants or commitments with Allah, and are instead rebellious and disobedient towards His commands.
orig: وما وجدنا لأكثرهم من عهد وإن وجدنا أكثرهم لفاسقين

translation: Then We sent after them Moses with Our signs to Pharaoh and his chiefs, but they oppressed them. So see how was the end of the corrupters.
interpretation: This verse reminds us of the consequences of oppression and corruption. Allah sent Moses with clear signs and miracles to Pharaoh and his people, but they rejected them arrogantly. As a result, they faced a terrible punishment and downfall. It serves as a warning to those who spread corruption and oppression on earth, that their actions will ultimately lead to their own destruction and a miserable end.
orig: ثم بعثنا من بعدهم موسى بآياتنا إلى فرعون وملئه فظلموا بها فانظر كيف كان عاقبة المفسدين

translation: And Moses said: "O Pharaoh! Verily, I am a messenger from the Lord of the Worlds,"
interpretation: This verse is a declaration by Prophet Moses to Pharaoh, asserting his status as a messenger sent by the one true God, the Lord and Sustainer of all the worlds and creations. It affirms the authority and divinity of Moses' message, challenging Pharaoh's claim to divinity and his oppression of the Israelites.
orig: وقال موسى يا فرعون إني رسول من رب العالمين

translation: It is incumbent upon me not to say about Allah except the truth. Verily, I have come to you with a clear proof from your Lord, so send the Children of Israel with me.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of speaking the truth about Allah and not making false claims. The Prophet is stating that he has brought a clear proof or evidence from Allah, and he is calling upon the people to let the Children of Israel go with him, as commanded by Allah.
orig: حقيق على أن لا أقول على الله إلا الحق قد جئتكم ببينة من ربكم فأرسل معي بني إسرائيل

translation: He said, 'If you have come with a sign, then bring it forth, if you are of the truthful ones.'
interpretation: This verse is a challenge to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to prove his prophethood by performing a miracle or showing a sign from Allah. It implies that the disbelievers demanded tangible proof of his claim to be a messenger of God. The interpretation is that the truthfulness of a prophet should be judged by the signs and miracles they present as evidence of their divine appointment, not merely by their words or assertions.
orig: قال إن كنت جئت بآية فأت بها إن كنت من الصادقين

translation: So he threw down his staff, and behold, it was a serpent, manifest.
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that when Moses threw down his staff by the command of Allah, it miraculously transformed into a real serpent, clearly visible and obvious to the eyes. This was one of the great signs and miracles granted to Moses by Allah to prove his prophethood and support his message.
orig: فألقى عصاه فإذا هي ثعبان مبين

translation: And he drew out his hand, and behold, it was white for the beholders.
interpretation: This verse refers to one of the miracles given to Prophet Moses by Allah. When he put his hand into his robe and drew it out, it shone with a brilliant white light, a sign from Allah to prove his prophethood to Pharaoh and the Egyptians. The interpretation is that Allah gave Moses tangible proof of his divinely-appointed mission through this miraculous sign, demonstrating Allah's power over the natural order.
orig: ونزع يده فإذا هي بيضاء للناظرين

translation: The chiefs of Pharaoh's people said, 'Indeed, this is a learned magician.'
interpretation: The interpretation is that the leaders and elite among Pharaoh's people accused Moses of being a skilled sorcerer or magician, rather than acknowledging his miracles as signs from God. They attributed his abilities to magic and sorcery, refusing to accept the truth that he was a prophet sent by God.
orig: قال الملأ من قوم فرعون إن هذا لساحر عليم

translation: They want to expel you from your land, so what do you command?
interpretation: This verse refers to the enemies of the believers who seek to drive them out of their homeland and deprive them of their rights. It calls upon the believers to respond firmly and decisively to such aggression and oppression, while seeking guidance and strength from God.
orig: يريد أن يخرجكم من أرضكم فماذا تأمرون

translation: They said, 'Imprison him and his brother and send marshals into the cities to round up
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) in the Qur'an. When Yusuf interpreted the King's dream and advised him to store grains for the coming years of famine, the officials accused him and his brother of some wrongdoing. They demanded that Yusuf be imprisoned and his brother detained, while sending people to gather information and evidence against them from other cities. This interpretation highlights the jealousy and false accusations faced by prophets, and the test of patience they endured.
orig: قالوا أرجه وأخاه وأرسل في المدائن حاشرين

translation: They come to you with every learned magician
interpretation: This verse suggests that the disbelievers will try to challenge the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) by bringing forth skilled magicians to compete against him and the divine message he brought. However, the verse implies that their attempts will be futile, as the truth of the Qur'an and the Prophet's message cannot be matched by mere magic or trickery.
orig: يأتوك بكل ساحر عليم

translation: And the sorcerers came to Pharaoh. They said, 'Indeed for us is a reward if we are the victors.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the encounter between Prophet Moses and the sorcerers of Pharaoh's court. The sorcerers came with arrogance, demanding a reward from Pharaoh if they were to defeat Moses. It highlights their materialistic mindset and lack of faith, as they sought worldly gains rather than the truth.
orig: وجاء السحرة فرعون قالوا إن لنا لأجرا إن كنا نحن الغالبين

translation: He said: 'Yes, and indeed you are among those closest to Me.'
interpretation: This verse suggests that God is acknowledging the privileged status of the one being addressed, who is considered among those closest to Him. It implies a special relationship of proximity and favor bestowed upon this individual by God.
orig: قال نعم وإنكم لمن المقربين

translation: They said: 'O Moses! Either you throw first or we be the first to throw?'
interpretation: This verse refers to the contest between Moses and the sorcerers of Pharaoh. The sorcerers challenged Moses to a duel of sorcery, asking him whether he would like to cast his staff first or have them cast their spells first. This was a test of faith for Moses and a chance for him to demonstrate the superiority of God's power over their trickery.
orig: قالوا يا موسى إما أن تلقي وإما أن نكون نحن الملقين

translation: He said: 'Cast ye (what ye have to cast)!' So when they had cast, they bewitched the people's eyes and struck terror into them, and produced a mighty spell.
interpretation: The interpretation is that the magicians were able to deceive the people by their trickery and illusions, making it appear as if their ropes and staffs had turned into real snakes. Their "mighty spell" refers to their impressive display of magic that struck awe and fear into the hearts of the onlookers.
orig: قال ألقوا فلما ألقوا سحروا أعين الناس واسترهبوهم وجاءوا بسحر عظيم

translation: And We inspired to Moses, 'Throw your staff,' and at once it lapped up whatever they were falsifying.
interpretation: This verse refers to the confrontation between Moses and the sorcerers of Pharaoh's court. When Moses threw down his staff, by Allah's command, it miraculously turned into a serpent that swallowed all the tricks and illusions conjured by the sorcerers. This demonstrated the superiority of Allah's power over their magic, proving that Moses was a true messenger of God and exposing the falsehood of their deceptive practices.
orig: وأوحينا إلى موسى أن ألق عصاك فإذا هي تلقف ما يأفكون

translation: So the truth was established, and what they used to do became null and void.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the truth prevailed, and all the falsehoods and wrongdoings that the disbelievers were engaged in became worthless and futile. It signifies the ultimate triumph of truth over falsehood, and the invalidity of all actions that go against the truth revealed by God.
orig: فوقع الحق وبطل ما كانوا يعملون

translation: So they were defeated there and returned disgraced.
interpretation: This verse refers to a group of people who were defeated and humiliated in a particular place or situation. The interpretation suggests that despite their efforts or expectations, they faced a decisive defeat and were forced to retreat in a state of disgrace or humiliation. This could be a reference to a military defeat, a political or ideological struggle, or any other context where one side emerged victorious while the other was overpowered and forced to retreat in a state of dishonor or shame.
orig: فغلبوا هنالك وانقلبوا صاغرين

translation: And the magicians fell down in prostration,
interpretation: This verse refers to the event when Prophet Moses confronted the magicians of Pharaoh's court. After Moses performed the miracle of throwing his staff which turned into a serpent, the magicians realized that this was not mere magic but a divine sign from God. As a result, they fell down in prostration, acknowledging the truth and embracing faith in God and Moses as His messenger.
orig: وألقي السحرة ساجدين

translation: They said, 'We have believed in the Lord of the worlds.'
interpretation: This verse signifies the acceptance of faith in the One True God, the Lord and Sustainer of all the worlds and creations. It represents a profound declaration of belief in the Divine Being who is the source of existence and to whom all beings owe their creation and sustenance. The interpretation highlights the essence of monotheism (Tawheed) and the recognition of Allah as the sole object of worship and obedience.
orig: قالوا آمنا برب العالمين

translation: The Lord of Moses and Aaron
interpretation: This verse refers to Allah as the Lord and Sustainer of Moses and Aaron, who were two great prophets sent to the Pharaoh and his people. It highlights Allah's authority and power over these noble messengers, and affirms His divine support for them in their mission to guide the people to the straight path.
orig: رب موسى وهارون

translation: Pharaoh said, "You believed in him before I gave you permission. Indeed, this is a conspiracy you conspired in the city to expel its people from it. But you are going to know.
interpretation: Pharaoh accuses the Israelites of conspiring against him and the people of the city by believing in Moses, with the intention of expelling them from their land. He threatens them with dire consequences for their supposed treachery.
orig: قال فرعون آمنتم به قبل أن آذن لكم إن هذا لمكر مكرتموه في المدينة لتخرجوا منها أهلها فسوف تعلمون

translation: I will surely cut off your hands and feet on opposite sides, then I will surely crucify you all together.
interpretation: This verse is a warning and a threat of punishment for those who commit crimes against society. The interpretation is that the authority will inflict severe punishment by cutting off the hands and feet of criminals from opposite sides, and then crucifying them altogether as a deterrent for others. This harsh punishment is meant to maintain law and order and protect the society from harm.
orig: لأقطعن أيديكم وأرجلكم من خلاف ثم لأصلبنكم أجمعين

translation: They said, 'Indeed we are returning to our Lord.'
interpretation: This verse indicates the firm belief in the Hereafter and accountability before God. It implies that the believers acknowledge that this worldly life is temporary, and that they will ultimately return to God for judgment and recompense for their deeds. The interpretation highlights the importance of maintaining faith, righteous conduct, and preparedness for the inevitable return to the Divine Creator.
orig: قالوا إنا إلى ربنا منقلبون

translation: And we are not blamed except for believing in the signs of our Lord when they came to us. Our Lord, pour upon us patience and let us die as Muslims
interpretation: The interpretation is that the believers are not blameworthy for accepting the signs and revelations from Allah. They ask Allah to bestow patience upon them and enable them to remain steadfast in their faith until the end of their lives.
orig: وما تنقم منا إلا أن آمنا بآيات ربنا لما جاءتنا ربنا أفرغ علينا صبرا وتوفنا مسلمين

translation: And the eminent among the people of Pharaoh said, 'Will you leave Moses and his people to cause corruption in the land and abandon you and your gods?' He said, 'We will kill their sons and keep their women alive; and indeed, we are subjugators over them.'
interpretation: This verse depicts the arrogance and cruelty of Pharaoh and his chiefs towards the Israelites. The chiefs express concern that Moses and his followers will cause corruption in the land and abandon the worship of Pharaoh's gods. Pharaoh responds with a cruel plan to oppress the Israelites by killing their sons and keeping their women alive as captives, demonstrating his tyrannical power over them.
orig: وقال الملأ من قوم فرعون أتذر موسى وقومه ليفسدوا في الأرض ويذرك وآلهتك قال سنقتل أبناءهم ونستحيي نساءهم وإنا فوقهم قاهرون
