translation: Moses said to his people, 'Seek help through Allah and be patient. Indeed, the earth belongs to Allah. He causes to inherit it whom He wills of His servants. And the [best] outcome is for the righteous.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of patience, trust in Allah, and righteousness. Moses encourages his people to seek help from Allah and remain steadfast, as the earth and its resources ultimately belong to Allah, Who grants them to whomever He wills from among His servants. The ultimate success and favorable outcome lie with those who fear Allah and lead a righteous life.
orig: قال موسى لقومه استعينوا بالله واصبروا إن الأرض لله يورثها من يشاء من عباده والعاقبة للمتقين

translation: They said: "We suffered afflictions before you came to us and after you came to us." He said: "It may be that your Lord will destroy your enemy and make you successors in the land, so that He may see how you act."
interpretation: This verse suggests that the believers were being persecuted and oppressed by their enemies before and after the Prophet's arrival. However, Allah reassures them that He will eventually destroy their oppressors and grant them sovereignty over the land, as a test of their faith and actions.
orig: قالوا أوذينا من قبل أن تأتينا ومن بعد ما جئتنا قال عسى ربكم أن يهلك عدوكم ويستخلفكم في الأرض فينظر كيف تعملون

translation: And We did seize Fir'awn's people with years of drought and shortness of fruits, that they might receive admonition.
interpretation: Allah is stating that He punished Fir'awn's (Pharaoh's) people with years of famine and scarcity of crops and fruits, so that they may be reminded of Allah's signs and power, and turn to Him in repentance and obedience. However, they remained arrogant and refused to believe.
orig: ولقد أخذنا آل فرعون بالسنين ونقص من الثمرات لعلهم يذكرون

translation: But when good came to them, they said, 'This is ours [due to us].' And if a bad [condition] struck them, they saw an evil omen in Moses and those with him. Unquestionably, their fortune is only with Allah, but most of them do not know.
interpretation: This verse criticizes the superstitious and ungrateful attitude of the disbelievers. When they experienced prosperity, they arrogantly claimed it as their own doing without gratitude to Allah. But when faced with adversity, they blamed it on Moses and his companions as an evil omen, instead of reflecting on their own sins. The verse emphasizes that their fortune, good or bad, is determined by Allah alone, but most people lack this understanding due to their ignorance.
orig: فإذا جاءتهم الحسنة قالوا لنا هذه وإن تصبهم سيئة يطيروا بموسى ومن معه ألا إنما طائرهم عند الله ولكن أكثرهم لا يعلمون

translation: And they say, 'No matter what sign you bring to bewitch us with, we will not be believers in you.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the obstinate disbelief of the idolaters of Mecca, who rejected the signs and miracles brought by the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him. Despite witnessing clear proofs and evidence, they arrogantly refused to believe, accusing the Prophet of sorcery or magic. Their hearts were hardened, and they chose to remain in denial and misguidance.
orig: وقالوا مهما تأتنا به من آية لتسحرنا بها فما نحن لك بمؤمنين

translation: So We sent upon them the flood and the locusts and the lice and the frogs and the blood as distinct signs, but they were arrogant and were a criminal people.
interpretation: "Allah sent upon the disobedient people a series of severe punishments in the form of natural disasters and plagues, which were clear signs of His power and warnings for them to repent. However, they remained arrogant and persisted in their sinful ways, refusing to submit to Allah's commands."
orig: فأرسلنا عليهم الطوفان والجراد والقمل والضفادع والدم آيات مفصلات فاستكبروا وكانوا قوما مجرمين

translation: And when the punishment descended upon them, they said, "O Moses, invoke for us your Lord by what He has promised you. If you remove the punishment from us, we will surely believe you, and we will send with you the Children of Israel."
interpretation: "When the punishment of plague, famine, or other afflictions befell the Israelites due to their disobedience, they turned to Moses for help. They asked him to pray to God and invoke the promise of relief that God had made with him. They promised that if the punishment was lifted, they would believe in Moses and allow the Children of Israel to leave with him. However, their faith was conditional and temporary, as they repeatedly broke their promises after being relieved."
orig: ولما وقع عليهم الرجز قالوا يا موسى ادع لنا ربك بما عهد عندك لئن كشفت عنا الرجز لنؤمنن لك ولنرسلن معك بني إسرائيل

translation: But when We removed from them the punishment for a term which they had to attain, behold, they broke their covenant.
interpretation: Allah is describing the behavior of those who were granted respite after being afflicted with punishment. Despite being given relief and a chance to reform, they reverted to their disbelief and disobedience, breaking their covenant with Allah. This verse highlights the importance of remaining steadfast on the path of faith and fulfilling one's promises to the Almighty.
orig: فلما كشفنا عنهم الرجز إلى أجل هم بالغوه إذا هم ينكثون

translation: So We took retribution from them, and drowned them in the sea, because they denied Our signs and were heedless of them.
interpretation: "Allah punished them for their disbelief and rejection of His signs by drowning them in the sea. This verse serves as a warning against denying Allah's revelations and being heedless of His signs, as it demonstrates His power to punish those who defy Him."
orig: فانتقمنا منهم فأغرقناهم في اليم بأنهم كذبوا بآياتنا وكانوا عنها غافلين

translation: And We caused the people who had been oppressed to inherit the eastern and western lands which We had blessed. And the good Word of your Lord was fulfilled for the Children of Israel because of their patience. And We destroyed what Pharaoh and his people had built and what they had erected.
interpretation: Allah mentions His favor upon the oppressed people, the Children of Israel, by granting them sovereignty over the blessed lands after years of subjugation by Pharaoh and his people. This was a fulfillment of Allah's promise to them for their patience and perseverance. Additionally, Allah destroyed all the constructions and monuments built by Pharaoh and his people, symbolizing the erasure of their oppressive reign.
orig: وأورثنا القوم الذين كانوا يستضعفون مشارق الأرض ومغاربها التي باركنا فيها وتمت كلمت ربك الحسنى على بني إسرائيل بما صبروا ودمرنا ما كان يصنع فرعون وقومه وما كانوا يعرشون

translation: And We took the Children of Israel across the sea, and they came upon a people devoted to their idols. They said, 'O Moses, make for us a god just as they have gods.' He said, 'Indeed, you are a people behaving ignorantly.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident when the Children of Israel, after crossing the Red Sea, encountered a people who were devoted to worshipping idols. The Israelites, influenced by this sight, asked Moses to make a god for them, just as those people had gods. Moses rebuked them, saying that they were behaving ignorantly by demanding an idol to worship, as this would be a form of polytheism and a grave sin in the sight of God.
orig: وجاوزنا ببني إسرائيل البحر فأتوا على قوم يعكفون على أصنام لهم قالوا يا موسى اجعل لنا إلها كما لهم آلهة قال إنكم قوم تجهلون

translation: Indeed, those - lost is what they were doing, and worthless is what they used to do.
interpretation: This verse highlights the futility and worthlessness of the actions and deeds of those who reject faith and truth. It emphasizes that their efforts and pursuits in life were misguided, vain, and devoid of any real value or substance. Their rejection of divine guidance rendered their actions fruitless and their endeavors baseless. The verse serves as a stark warning against following a path of disbelief and misguidance, as it ultimately leads to a complete loss and waste of one's life and deeds.
orig: إن هؤلاء متبر ما هم فيه وباطل ما كانوا يعملون

translation: He said, 'Shall I seek for you a god other than Allah, while He has favoured you over all the worlds?'
interpretation: In this verse, God reminds the believers that He has favoured them over all other nations and peoples by guiding them to the true faith and bestowing upon them countless blessings. Therefore, it is inconceivable and utterly illogical for them to seek or worship any other deity besides the One True God, who has honoured them with such a great favour.
orig: قال أغير الله أبغيكم إلها وهو فضلكم على العالمين

translation: And [mention, O Muhammad], when We saved you from the people of Pharaoh, who afflicted you with the worst torment - killing your sons and keeping your women alive. And in that was a great trial from your Lord.
interpretation: This verse reminds the believers of Allah's favor upon them when He saved them from Pharaoh's oppression. Pharaoh inflicted severe punishment on the Children of Israel, killing their sons and sparing their women to humiliate them. This was a great test from Allah, but through it, He demonstrated His power and mercy by delivering the believers from Pharaoh's tyranny.
orig: وإذ أنجيناكم من آل فرعون يسومونكم سوء العذاب يقتلون أبناءكم ويستحيون نساءكم وفي ذلكم بلاء من ربكم عظيم

translation: And We appointed for Moses thirty nights and completed them with ten more, so the appointed time of his Lord was forty nights. And Moses said to his brother Aaron: 'Take my place among my people, do right, and do not follow the way of the mischief-makers.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident when Allah summoned Moses to Mount Sinai to receive the Torah. Moses was commanded to fast for thirty nights in preparation. Allah then extended this period by ten more nights, making it a total of forty nights. Before leaving, Moses appointed his brother Aaron as his deputy over the Israelites, instructing him to guide them righteously and not follow the path of those who spread corruption.
orig: وواعدنا موسى ثلاثين ليلة وأتممناها بعشر فتم ميقات ربه أربعين ليلة وقال موسى لأخيه هارون اخلفني في قومي وأصلح ولا تتبع سبيل المفسدين

translation: And when Moses arrived at Our appointed time and his Lord spoke to him, he said, 'My Lord, show me [Yourself] that I may look at You.' [Allah] said, 'You will not see Me, but look at the mountain; if it should remain in place, then you will see Me.' But when his Lord appeared to the mountain, He rendered it level, and Moses fell unconscious. And when he awoke, he said, 'Exalted are You! I have repented to You, and I am the first of the believers.'
interpretation: This verse narrates the incident where Prophet Moses asked Allah to show Himself to him. Allah responded that Moses would not be able to bear the sight of Him, but instructed him to look at a mountain. When Allah manifested His glory on the mountain, it was leveled to dust, and Moses fell unconscious. Upon regaining consciousness, Moses realized his mistake in making such a request and repented, declaring his faith in Allah.
orig: ولما جاء موسى لميقاتنا وكلمه ربه قال رب أرني أنظر إليك قال لن تراني ولكن انظر إلى الجبل فإن استقر مكانه فسوف تراني فلما تجلى ربه للجبل جعله دكا وخر موسى صعقا فلما أفاق قال سبحانك تبت إليك وأنا أول المؤمنين

translation: He (Allah) said: 'O Moses! Verily, I have chosen you above men by My Messages and by My Speaking (to you). So hold that which I have given you and be among the grateful.'
interpretation: Allah chose Prophet Moses over others by honoring him with the revelation and speaking to him directly. This was a great favor upon Moses, so he was commanded to accept this honor with gratitude and be among those who are thankful to Allah for His blessings.
orig: قال يا موسى إني اصطفيتك على الناس برسالاتي وبكلامي فخذ ما آتيتك وكن من الشاكرين

translation: And We wrote for him on the Tablets every matter of instruction and clarification for all things, [saying], 'Take them with determination and command your people to take the best of it. I will show you the home of the defiantly disobedient.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the revelation given to Prophet Moses, peace be upon him. Allah instructed him to take the Tablets, which contained comprehensive guidance and details about all matters, with determination and firmness. He was also commanded to instruct his people to adhere to the best teachings contained therein. Furthermore, Allah warned that He would show the ultimate fate of those who defiantly disobey His commandments - the "home of the defiantly disobedient," which is a reference to Hell.
orig: وكتبنا له في الألواح من كل شيء موعظة وتفصيلا لكل شيء فخذها بقوة وأمر قومك يأخذوا بأحسنها سأريكم دار الفاسقين

translation: I will turn away from My verses those who are arrogant upon the earth without right; and if they should see every sign, they will not believe in it. And if they see the way of consciousness, they will not adopt it as a way; but if they see the way of error, they will adopt it as a way. That is because they denied Our verses and they were heedless of them.
interpretation: هذه الآية تحذر من الكبر والتكبر على الحق، وعدم الإيمان بآيات الله رغم رؤيتها، واتباع سبيل الغي والضلال بدلاً من سبيل الرشد والهدى. وتفسر سبب ذلك بأنهم كذبوا بآيات الله وأعرضوا عنها بغفلة وإهمال.
orig: سأصرف عن آياتي الذين يتكبرون في الأرض بغير الحق وإن يروا كل آية لا يؤمنوا بها وإن يروا سبيل الرشد لا يتخذوه سبيلا وإن يروا سبيل الغي يتخذوه سبيلا ذلك بأنهم كذبوا بآياتنا وكانوا عنها غافلين

translation: And those who deny Our signs and the meeting of the Hereafter - their deeds have become worthless. Are they recompensed except for what they used to do?
interpretation: This verse warns those who reject Allah's signs and deny the reality of the Hereafter that their deeds will be rendered futile and worthless. They will receive no reward except the consequences of their own misdeeds. It emphasizes that belief in Allah's revelations and the accountability of the Hereafter are essential for one's actions to have value and merit reward.
orig: والذين كذبوا بآياتنا ولقاء الآخرة حبطت أعمالهم هل يجزون إلا ما كانوا يعملون

translation: And the people of Moses made, after [his departure], from their ornaments a calf - a body for it of a lowing sound. Did they not see that it could neither speak to them nor guide them to any way? They took it [for worship], and they were wrongdoers.
interpretation: The interpretation is that the people of Moses, after he left them to receive the Torah, made an idol in the shape of a calf from their gold ornaments. This calf had a hollow body that made a lowing sound when air passed through it. Despite it being an inanimate object incapable of speech or guidance, they foolishly worshipped it, thus committing a grave injustice and wrongdoing.
orig: واتخذ قوم موسى من بعده من حليهم عجلا جسدا له خوار ألم يروا أنه لا يكلمهم ولا يهديهم سبيلا اتخذوه وكانوا ظالمين

translation: And when it fell into their hands, and they saw that they had gone astray, they said: 'If our Lord does not have mercy on us and forgive us, we shall certainly be among the losers.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of seeking forgiveness from Allah and relying on His mercy. It suggests that when people realize their mistakes and wrongdoings, they should turn to Allah with sincere repentance and seek His forgiveness and mercy. Without Allah's forgiveness and mercy, they will be among the losers in this life and the Hereafter. The verse emphasizes the need for humility, acknowledgment of one's sins, and reliance on Allah's infinite mercy and compassion.
orig: ولما سقط في أيديهم ورأوا أنهم قد ضلوا قالوا لئن لم يرحمنا ربنا ويغفر لنا لنكونن من الخاسرين

translation: And when Moses returned to his people, angry and grieved, he said, 'How wretched is that by which you replaced me after [my departure]! Did you hasten the command of your Lord?' And he threw down the tablets and seized the head of his brother, dragging him toward himself. [Aaron] said, 'O son of my mother, indeed the people oppressed me and were about to kill me, so let not the enemies rejoice over me and do not place me among the wrongdoing people.'
interpretation: Cet verset décrit le retour de Moïse après avoir reçu les commandements de Dieu sur le mont Sinaï. Il était en colère contre son peuple pour avoir adoré le veau d'or en son absence. Moïse a jeté les tablettes de la Loi par terre et a saisi la tête de son frère Aaron, le blâmant pour avoir permis cette idolâtrie. Aaron s'est excusé en disant que le peuple l'avait opprimé et menaçait de le tuer s'il ne les suivait pas. Il a imploré Moïse de ne pas le compter parmi les injustes. Cette scène illustre la désobéissance du peuple hébreu et la colère de Moïse face à leur manquement à la foi monothéiste.
orig: ولما رجع موسى إلى قومه غضبان أسفا قال بئسما خلفتموني من بعدي أعجلتم أمر ربكم وألقى الألواح وأخذ برأس أخيه يجره إليه قال ابن أم إن القوم استضعفوني وكادوا يقتلونني فلا تشمت بي الأعداء ولا تجعلني مع القوم الظالمين

translation: He said, 'My Lord, forgive me and my brother and admit us into Your mercy, for You are the most merciful of the merciful.'
interpretation: This verse is a supplication from a person asking Allah to forgive him and his brother, and to admit them into His vast mercy. It highlights Allah's attribute of being the most merciful of those who show mercy, emphasizing the need to turn to Him for forgiveness and mercy.
orig: قال رب اغفر لي ولأخي وأدخلنا في رحمتك وأنت أرحم الراحمين

translation: Indeed, those who took the calf [for worship] will be afflicted by anger from their Lord and humiliation in the life of this world, and thus do We recompense the inventors [of falsehood].
interpretation: "This verse warns those who worshipped the calf idol during the time of Prophet Moses that they will face Allah's wrath and disgrace in this worldly life. It also states that Allah punishes those who invent lies and falsehoods, attributing them to Allah."
orig: إن الذين اتخذوا العجل سينالهم غضب من ربهم وذلة في الحياة الدنيا وكذلك نجزي المفترين

translation: But those who have done evil, then repented after that and believed - indeed, after that, your Lord is Forgiving and Merciful.
interpretation: "This verse highlights the immense mercy and forgiveness of Allah. It assures those who have committed sins but then sincerely repented and embraced faith that Allah will pardon their previous misdeeds and shower them with His forgiveness and compassion. It emphasizes that true repentance and belief open the door to Allah's boundless mercy, regardless of one's past transgressions."
orig: والذين عملوا السيئات ثم تابوا من بعدها وآمنوا إن ربك من بعدها لغفور رحيم

translation: And when the anger subsided in Moses, he took up the tablets, and in their inscription was guidance and mercy for those who are in awe of their Lord.
interpretation: This verse indicates that after Moses' anger towards his people for worshipping the calf had subsided, he took the Tablets containing the divine commandments and teachings. These Tablets provided guidance and mercy for those who have a sense of reverence and fear of Allah, their Lord. The interpretation suggests that the Qur'anic teachings offer spiritual guidance and Allah's mercy, but only for those who approach them with a humble and God-fearing attitude.
orig: ولما سكت عن موسى الغضب أخذ الألواح وفي نسختها هدى ورحمة للذين هم لربهم يرهبون

translation: And Moses chose seventy men from his people for Our appointed time. And when the earthquake seized them, he said, 'My Lord, if You had willed, You could have destroyed them before and me [as well]. Would You destroy us for what the foolish among us have done? It was not but Your trial by which You left astray whom You willed and guided whom You willed. You are our Protector, so forgive us and have mercy upon us; and You are the best of forgivers.'
interpretation: هذه الآية تشير إلى حادثة طلب موسى من ربه أن يراه، فاختار الله سبعين رجلاً من قومه ليكونوا شهوداً على هذا الحدث العظيم. ولكن عندما أصابتهم الرجفة من هيبة الله، دعا موسى ربه بأن لا يعاقبهم جميعًا بسبب خطأ البعض منهم، وأن يغفر لهم ويرحمهم، لأن الله هو خير الغافرين.
orig: واختار موسى قومه سبعين رجلا لميقاتنا فلما أخذتهم الرجفة قال رب لو شئت أهلكتهم من قبل وإياي أتهلكنا بما فعل السفهاء منا إن هي إلا فتنتك تضل بها من تشاء وتهدي من تشاء أنت ولينا فاغفر لنا وارحمنا وأنت خير الغافرين

translation: And inscribe for us in this world a good, and in the Hereafter. Indeed, I have been guided to You. He said, 'My punishment - I afflict with it whom I will, but My mercy encompasses all things, so I will decree it for those who fear Me and give zakah and those who believe in Our verses.'
interpretation: Allah instructs the believers to ask Him for goodness in this life and in the Hereafter, acknowledging that they have been guided to worshipping Him alone. Allah then responds that His punishment is for whomever He wills, but His vast mercy encompasses all things. He decrees His mercy specifically for those who have taqwa (piety and consciousness of Allah), pay zakah (obligatory charity), and believe in the verses of the Qur'an.
orig: واكتب لنا في هذه الدنيا حسنة وفي الآخرة إنا هدنا إليك قال عذابي أصيب به من أشاء ورحمتي وسعت كل شيء فسأكتبها للذين يتقون ويؤتون الزكاة والذين هم بآياتنا يؤمنون

translation: Those who follow the Messenger, the unlettered Prophet, whom they find written in what they have of the Torah and the Gospel, who enjoins upon them what is right and forbids them what is wrong and makes lawful for them the good things and prohibits for them the evil and relieves them of their burden and the shackles which were upon them. So they who have believed in him, honored him, supported him and followed the light which was sent down with him - it is those who will be the successful.
interpretation: This verse describes the qualities and characteristics of the true followers of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). It praises those who follow him, the unlettered Prophet whose coming was foretold in the previous scriptures like the Torah and the Gospel. It highlights that he commands them towards righteousness, forbids them from evil, allows them the pure and good things, and prohibits the impure and evil. He relieves them from the burdens and shackles they were under. Those who believe in him, honor him, support him, and follow the light (Qur'an) revealed to him are the ones who will attain true success and salvation.
orig: الذين يتبعون الرسول النبي الأمي الذي يجدونه مكتوبا عندهم في التوراة والإنجيل يأمرهم بالمعروف وينهاهم عن المنكر ويحل لهم الطيبات ويحرم عليهم الخبائث ويضع عنهم إصرهم والأغلال التي كانت عليهم فالذين آمنوا به وعزروه ونصروه واتبعوا النور الذي أنزل معه أولئك هم المفلحون

translation: Say, "O people, indeed I am the Messenger of Allah to you all - to whom belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth. There is no deity except Him; He gives life and causes death." So believe in Allah and His Messenger, the unlettered prophet, who believes in Allah and His words, and follow him that you may be guided.
interpretation: This verse calls upon the Prophet Muhammad to convey to all people that he is the Messenger of Allah sent to guide them. It affirms Allah's sovereignty over the heavens and the earth, and that He alone is worthy of worship as the Giver of life and death. It commands belief in Allah and His final Messenger, the unlettered Prophet who himself believed in Allah's revelations. Obedience to the Prophet is crucial to attaining guidance.
orig: قل يا أيها الناس إني رسول الله إليكم جميعا الذي له ملك السماوات والأرض لا إله إلا هو يحيي ويميت فآمنوا بالله ورسوله النبي الأمي الذي يؤمن بالله وكلماته واتبعوه لعلكم تهتدون

translation: And among the people of Moses is a community which guides by truth and by it establishes justice.
interpretation: This verse refers to a righteous group among the followers of Prophet Moses who upheld the truth and acted with justice based on God's teachings. They served as a moral compass, guiding others towards righteousness and ensuring fairness in their society.
orig: ومن قوم موسى أمة يهدون بالحق وبه يعدلون

translation: And We divided them into twelve descendant tribes as distinct nations. And We inspired Moses when his people asked him for water, 'Strike the rock with your staff,' and twelve springs gushed forth from it. Each tribe knew their drinking place. And We shaded them with clouds and sent down upon them manna and quails, [saying], 'Eat from the good things with which We have provided you.' And they did not wrong Us, but they used to wrong themselves.
interpretation: This verse describes how Allah divided the Children of Israel into twelve tribes, and how He provided for them miraculously in the desert by commanding Moses to strike a rock with his staff, causing twelve springs to gush forth for each tribe to drink from. It also mentions that Allah shaded them with clouds and sent down manna and quails as sustenance for them. The verse emphasizes that they were not wronged by Allah, but rather they wronged themselves by their disobedience and lack of gratitude.
orig: وقطعناهم اثنتي عشرة أسباطا أمما وأوحينا إلى موسى إذ استسقاه قومه أن اضرب بعصاك الحجر فانبجست منه اثنتا عشرة عينا قد علم كل أناس مشربهم وظللنا عليهم الغمام وأنزلنا عليهم المن والسلوى كلوا من طيبات ما رزقناكم وما ظلمونا ولكن كانوا أنفسهم يظلمون

translation: And when it was said to them, "Dwell in this town and eat therefrom wherever you wish, and say, 'Relieve us of the burden of our sins,' and enter the gate in a posture of humility - We shall forgive your sins, and We shall increase the reward of the righteous."
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of the Israelites when they were commanded to enter a blessed town (often interpreted as Jerusalem or its vicinity) and were given specific instructions. The interpretation is that they were told to live humbly in this town, seek forgiveness through the words "Relieve us of our sins," and enter its gate in a posture of humility and submission to God. If they followed these commands, their sins would be forgiven, and the righteous among them would receive an increased reward from God.
orig: وإذ قيل لهم اسكنوا هذه القرية وكلوا منها حيث شئتم وقولوا حطة وادخلوا الباب سجدا نغفر لكم خطيئاتكم سنزيد المحسنين

translation: But those who were wrongdoers substituted a saying other than that which had been said to them, so We sent down upon them a punishment from the heaven for their wrongdoing.
interpretation: This verse refers to the people who deliberately changed the words revealed to them by Allah. As a consequence of their wrongdoing and distortion of the divine message, Allah punished them by sending down a torment or affliction from the heavens.
orig: فبدل الذين ظلموا منهم قولا غير الذي قيل لهم فأرسلنا عليهم رجزا من السماء بما كانوا يظلمون

translation: And ask them about the town that was by the sea - when they transgressed in [the matter of] the sabbath - when their fish came to them openly on their sabbath day, and the day they had no sabbath they did not come to them. Thus We tried them because they were defiantly disobedient.
interpretation: Cette interprétation décrit un peuple qui vivait près de la mer et qui transgressait les lois du sabbat. Un miracle se produisait le jour du sabbat où les poissons venaient à eux facilement, mais pas les autres jours. Cela était un test de Dieu pour voir s'ils resteraient obéissants, mais ils ont continué à désobéir, donc Dieu les a punis.
orig: واسألهم عن القرية التي كانت حاضرة البحر إذ يعدون في السبت إذ تأتيهم حيتانهم يوم سبتهم شرعا ويوم لا يسبتون لا تأتيهم كذلك نبلوهم بما كانوا يفسقون

translation: And [mention, O Muhammad], when a party of them said, "Why do you advise a people whom Allah is [about] to destroy or to punish with a severe punishment?" They [the advisors] said, "To be absolved before your Lord and perhaps they may fear Him."
interpretation: "This verse refers to the situation where some believers questioned the wisdom of advising the disbelievers, as they thought that Allah would punish them anyway. The response given was that the advisors were simply fulfilling their duty to convey the message, in order to be absolved of responsibility before Allah, and with the hope that the disbelievers might be guided towards piety."
orig: وإذ قالت أمة منهم لم تعظون قوما الله مهلكهم أو معذبهم عذابا شديدا قالوا معذرة إلى ربكم ولعلهم يتقون

translation: But when they forgot what they had been reminded of, We rescued those who had been forbidding evil, and We seized those who did wrong with a wretched punishment for their defiantly disobeying.
interpretation: This verse indicates that when people disregard the guidance and warnings given to them, Allah saves those who strive to prevent evil and punishes the wrongdoers for their sinful and rebellious behavior.
orig: فلما نسوا ما ذكروا به أنجينا الذين ينهون عن السوء وأخذنا الذين ظلموا بعذاب بئيس بما كانوا يفسقون

translation: But when they defied the command they had been forbidden, We said to them: 'Be you apes, despised and rejected.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the punishment inflicted upon the Jews who violated the sanctity of the Sabbath by fishing on that day, despite being commanded not to do so. As a consequence of their disobedience, they were transformed into despised apes, serving as a lesson and a deterrent for others. The interpretation emphasizes the grave consequences of defying God's commands and the importance of obedience and adherence to divine laws.
orig: فلما عتوا عن ما نهوا عنه قلنا لهم كونوا قردة خاسئين

translation: And [mention, O Muhammad], when your Lord proclaimed that He would surely send upon them until the Day of Resurrection those who would afflict them with the worst torment. Indeed, your Lord is swift in penalty; but indeed, He is Forgiving and Merciful.
interpretation: This verse refers to Allah's warning to those who persist in disbelief and wrongdoing. It indicates that Allah will continue to send upon them various forms of punishment and afflictions until the Day of Resurrection as a consequence of their misdeeds. However, it also highlights Allah's attributes of being swift in punishing the disobedient, while simultaneously being Forgiving and Merciful to those who repent and turn back to Him.
orig: وإذ تأذن ربك ليبعثن عليهم إلى يوم القيامة من يسومهم سوء العذاب إن ربك لسريع العقاب وإنه لغفور رحيم

translation: And We have divided them in the earth as nations, some of them righteous and some of them otherwise. And We tried them with good [times] and bad that perhaps they would return [to obedience].
interpretation: Allah is stating that He has divided humanity into different nations and tribes, some of whom are righteous and obedient to Him, while others are not. He tests them with both prosperity and adversity, so that they may turn back to Him and appreciate His blessings and seek His forgiveness during times of hardship.
orig: وقطعناهم في الأرض أمما منهم الصالحون ومنهم دون ذلك وبلوناهم بالحسنات والسيئات لعلهم يرجعون

translation: But there came after them a generation who inherited the Book, yet they chose (for themselves) the good things of this low life, saying: 'We shall be forgiven.' And if similar good things came their way, they would take them. Was not the covenant of the Book taken from them that they should not say anything about Allah except the truth? And they have studied what is in it. And the abode of the Hereafter is better for those who guard against evil. Have you then no sense?
interpretation: This verse criticizes those who claim to follow the scripture but are more interested in worldly gains and pleasures. It condemns their hypocrisy in expecting forgiveness while indulging in the "good things of this low life". It reminds them of the covenant they made to speak only the truth about Allah and to study the scripture sincerely. It warns that the Hereafter is far better for those who are righteous and understand the true purpose of life.
orig: فخلف من بعدهم خلف ورثوا الكتاب يأخذون عرض هذا الأدنى ويقولون سيغفر لنا وإن يأتهم عرض مثله يأخذوه ألم يؤخذ عليهم ميثاق الكتاب أن لا يقولوا على الله إلا الحق ودرسوا ما فيه والدار الآخرة خير للذين يتقون أفلا تعقلون

translation: And those who hold fast to the Book and establish prayer - indeed, We will not allow to be lost the reward of the reformers.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of adhering to the teachings of the revealed Book (the Qur'an) and establishing regular prayer. It promises that Allah will not let the reward of those who reform themselves and strive for righteousness go to waste. The verse encourages believers to be steadfast in following the guidance of the Qur'an and performing their religious obligations, as their efforts will be rewarded by Allah.
orig: والذين يمسكون بالكتاب وأقاموا الصلاة إنا لا نضيع أجر المصلحين

translation: And [mention] when We removed the mountain above them as if it was a dark cloud shading them and they were certain it was to fall upon them, [and Allah said], 'Take what We have given you with determination and remember what is in it that you might fear Allah.'
interpretation: Allah reminds the people of the time when He lifted the mountain over them as a warning and they thought it would fall on them. He commanded them to take the revelation He gave them with determination and remember its teachings so that they may have taqwa (fear of Allah).
orig: وإذ نتقنا الجبل فوقهم كأنه ظلة وظنوا أنه واقع بهم خذوا ما آتيناكم بقوة واذكروا ما فيه لعلكم تتقون

translation: And [mention, O Muhammad], when your Lord took from the children of Adam - from their loins - their descendants and made them testify of themselves, [saying to them], "Am I not your Lord?" They said, "Yes, we have testified." [This] - lest you should say on the day of Resurrection, "Indeed, we were of this unaware."
interpretation: This verse refers to the covenant Allah made with all human beings before their creation. Allah caused the souls of all human beings to testify that He is their Lord and Creator. This was done so that on the Day of Resurrection, no one can claim ignorance about Allah's Lordship. By acknowledging this covenant, human beings are held accountable for their beliefs and actions.
orig: وإذ أخذ ربك من بني آدم من ظهورهم ذريتهم وأشهدهم على أنفسهم ألست بربكم قالوا بلى شهدنا أن تقولوا يوم القيامة إنا كنا عن هذا غافلين

translation: Or you say, 'Our forefathers had associated partners with Allah before; and we were merely their descendants after them. Will You then destroy us for what the falsifiers did?'
interpretation: This verse addresses the excuse that some people may give for associating partners with Allah, claiming that they were merely following the tradition of their forefathers. The interpretation is that one cannot justify shirk (associating partners with Allah) by blaming their ancestors. Each person is responsible for their own beliefs and actions, and will be held accountable for them. Blindly following misguidance is not an acceptable excuse before Allah.
orig: أو تقولوا إنما أشرك آباؤنا من قبل وكنا ذرية من بعدهم أفتهلكنا بما فعل المبطلون

translation: And thus do We explain the verses so that they might return
interpretation: Allah explains the verses of the Qur'an in a clear and detailed manner, so that people may understand the guidance and wisdom contained within them, and return to the path of truth and righteousness.
orig: وكذلك نفصل الآيات ولعلهم يرجعون

translation: And recite to them the story of the one to whom We gave Our signs, but he detached himself from them; so Shaytan (Satan) followed him up, and he became of those who went astray.
interpretation: This verse refers to a person who was given knowledge and guidance from Allah, but he turned away from it and followed the temptations of Satan. The interpretation is a warning against arrogance, heedlessness, and succumbing to one's desires, which can lead a person astray from the straight path, even after being guided.
orig: واتل عليهم نبأ الذي آتيناه آياتنا فانسلخ منها فأتبعه الشيطان فكان من الغاوين

translation: And if We willed, We could have raised him by it, but he clung to the earth and followed his desires. So his example is like the example of a dog: if you chase it away, it pants, and if you leave it, it pants. That is the example of those who denied Our signs. So relate the stories that perhaps they will give thought.
interpretation: This verse is a metaphor comparing those who reject Allah's signs and follow their own desires to a dog. Just as a dog pants whether you chase it away or leave it alone, the disbelievers remain attached to worldly desires and pleasures, unable to elevate themselves spiritually. The story or parable is meant to make them reflect and reconsider their ways.
orig: ولو شئنا لرفعناه بها ولكنه أخلد إلى الأرض واتبع هواه فمثله كمثل الكلب إن تحمل عليه يلهث أو تتركه يلهث ذلك مثل القوم الذين كذبوا بآياتنا فاقصص القصص لعلهم يتفكرون

translation: Evil is the example of the people who denied Our signs, and used to wrong themselves.
interpretation: This verse condemns those who reject Allah's signs and evidence, and persist in wronging themselves by depriving themselves of guidance and truth. Their example is described as "evil", indicating the grave consequences of their disbelief and injustice towards their own souls.
orig: ساء مثلا القوم الذين كذبوا بآياتنا وأنفسهم كانوا يظلمون

translation: Whomever Allah guides, he is the rightly guided; and whomever He sends astray - it is they who are the losers.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that true guidance comes from Allah alone. Those whom Allah guides are truly guided, while those whom He allows to go astray have incurred a great loss, for they have missed the purpose of their existence and the path to eternal bliss.
orig: من يهد الله فهو المهتدي ومن يضلل فأولئك هم الخاسرون

translation: And We have certainly created for Hell many of the jinn and mankind. They have hearts with which they do not understand, they have eyes with which they do not see, and they have ears with which they do not hear. Those are like cattle; rather, they are more astray. It is they who are the heedless.
interpretation: This verse is a stern warning to those who willfully reject faith and follow their desires blindly. It compares them to cattle, or even worse, as they possess the faculties of reason and understanding but fail to use them properly. Their hearts are unable to comprehend the truth, their eyes cannot perceive the signs of God, and their ears are deaf to the divine guidance. They are the heedless ones, oblivious to the consequences of their actions and the impending punishment in the Hereafter.
orig: ولقد ذرأنا لجهنم كثيرا من الجن والإنس لهم قلوب لا يفقهون بها ولهم أعين لا يبصرون بها ولهم آذان لا يسمعون بها أولئك كالأنعام بل هم أضل أولئك هم الغافلون

translation: And to Allah belong the best names, so invoke Him by them. And leave [the company of] those who practice deviation concerning His names. They will be recompensed for what they have been doing.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of using Allah's beautiful names when calling upon Him and avoiding those who distort or misuse His names. It teaches us to invoke Allah using His perfect attributes and to stay away from those who deviate from the proper understanding and usage of His names, as they will be held accountable for their actions.
orig: ولله الأسماء الحسنى فادعوه بها وذروا الذين يلحدون في أسمائه سيجزون ما كانوا يعملون

translation: And among those We have created, there is a community which guides by truth and thereby maintains justice.
interpretation: This verse refers to the existence of a righteous community among humanity that upholds truth and justice. It implies that Allah has created a group of people who are guided by the truth revealed in His message, and they use this guidance to establish fairness and equity in their dealings and judgments.
orig: وممن خلقنا أمة يهدون بالحق وبه يعدلون

translation: And those who deny Our signs, We will gradually lead them to destruction in ways they do not know.
interpretation: This verse warns those who reject Allah's revelations and signs that they will be gradually led to their own destruction without realizing it. Their denial and disbelief will lead them down a path of misguidance and ruin, step by step, in a way that they are unaware of until it is too late. It implies that their punishment will come in an insidious and subtle manner, not all at once, as a result of their stubborn rejection of the truth.
orig: والذين كذبوا بآياتنا سنستدرجهم من حيث لا يعلمون

translation: But grant thou me respite, I will guide them aright by a gradual process.
interpretation: Allah is telling the Shaytan (Satan) to wait and not rush in misleading people, for Allah's plan is firm and steady. He will allow Shaytan to gradually misguide those who choose to follow him, but in the end, Allah's guidance will prevail over Shaytan's deception.
orig: وأملي لهم إن كيدي متين

translation: Have they not pondered over their Companion? He is not but a clear warner.
interpretation: This verse invites people to reflect upon the character and message of the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him. It emphasizes that he is a clear and evident warner sent by Allah to guide humanity towards the truth and righteousness. The verse prompts people to contemplate the noble qualities and truthfulness of the Prophet, rather than dismissing him or doubting his message.
orig: أولم يتفكروا ما بصاحبهم من جنة إن هو إلا نذير مبين

translation: Have they not looked at the dominion of the heavens and the earth and what Allah has created of things, and that it may be that their own term has drawn near? So in what statement after this will they believe?
interpretation: This verse invites people to reflect on the signs of Allah's power and greatness in the creation of the heavens and the earth, and all the creatures therein. It suggests that this reflection should lead them to realize that the Hour of Judgment may be near, and they should prepare for it by believing in Allah's revelations and the message of the Prophet. The verse implies that if they do not believe in the Qur'an, which is a clear and convincing message, then what other statement will they believe in?
orig: أولم ينظروا في ملكوت السماوات والأرض وما خلق الله من شيء وأن عسى أن يكون قد اقترب أجلهم فبأي حديث بعده يؤمنون

translation: Whomever Allah lets go astray, there is no guide for him; and He leaves them wandering blindly in their insolence.
interpretation: This verse indicates that those whom Allah has willed to be misguided, there is none who can guide them to the right path. It also states that Allah leaves such people to continue wandering in their arrogance and rebellion, unable to find the truth due to their own obstinacy and blindness of heart.
orig: من يضلل الله فلا هادي له ويذرهم في طغيانهم يعمهون

translation: They ask you about the Hour, when will be its appointed time? Say: "Its knowledge is only with my Lord. None can reveal its time but He. It lays heavily upon the heavens and the earth. It shall not come upon you except unexpectedly." They ask you as if you were eager in inquiring about it. Say: "Its knowledge is only with Allah, but most of the people do not know."
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that the knowledge of when the Hour (Day of Resurrection) will occur is known only to Allah. No one else can reveal its appointed time. The Hour is a tremendously significant event that will heavily impact the heavens and the earth. It will come suddenly and unexpectedly. The people question the Prophet about the Hour as if he has detailed knowledge of it, but he responds that its knowledge rests only with Allah, and most people do not comprehend this reality.
orig: يسألونك عن الساعة أيان مرساها قل إنما علمها عند ربي لا يجليها لوقتها إلا هو ثقلت في السماوات والأرض لا تأتيكم إلا بغتة يسألونك كأنك حفي عنها قل إنما علمها عند الله ولكن أكثر الناس لا يعلمون

translation: Say, 'I have no power to benefit or harm myself, except as Allah wills. If I had known the unseen, I would have enriched myself with all the good, and no harm would have touched me. I am only a warner and a bearer of good tidings for a people who believe.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the complete powerlessness of the Prophet Muhammad and all human beings before the will of Allah. It clarifies that no one can benefit themselves or prevent harm except by Allah's permission. If the Prophet had knowledge of the unseen, he would have sought all good for himself and avoided harm, but he is merely a messenger sent to warn and give glad tidings to the believers.
orig: قل لا أملك لنفسي نفعا ولا ضرا إلا ما شاء الله ولو كنت أعلم الغيب لاستكثرت من الخير وما مسني السوء إن أنا إلا نذير وبشير لقوم يؤمنون

translation: It is He who created you from one soul and created from it its mate that he might dwell in tranquillity with her; and when he covered her, she carried a light burden and passed some time with it, but when she grew heavy, they both called upon Allah, their Lord: If You give us a righteous child, we shall indeed be among the grateful.
interpretation: Allah created all human beings from a single soul, Adam, and created his wife, Eve, from him so that they may find peace and tranquility with each other. When Adam had relations with Eve, she became pregnant with a light burden. As her pregnancy progressed and the burden became heavier, they prayed to Allah to grant them a righteous child, promising to be among the grateful if their supplication was answered.
orig: هو الذي خلقكم من نفس واحدة وجعل منها زوجها ليسكن إليها فلما تغشاها حملت حملا خفيفا فمرت به فلما أثقلت دعوا الله ربهما لئن آتيتنا صالحا لنكونن من الشاكرين

translation: But when He gave them a good [child], they ascribed partners to Him concerning that which He had given them. Exalted is Allah above what they associate with Him.
interpretation: The interpretation is that when Allah blessed them with a righteous child, instead of being grateful to Allah alone, they associated partners with Him by attributing the blessing to others besides Allah. This is a condemnation of shirk (associating partners with Allah) and ingratitude for Allah's favors.
orig: فلما آتاهما صالحا جعلا له شركاء فيما آتاهما فتعالى الله عما يشركون

translation: Do they associate with Him those that do not create anything, while they are themselves created?
interpretation: This verse questions the absurdity of associating partners with Allah in worship, when those partners are themselves created beings incapable of creating anything. It highlights the illogical nature of idolatry and polytheism, as the idols or false deities have no power to create or benefit their worshippers in any way. The verse emphasizes that only Allah, the Creator of all things, is worthy of worship and should not be associated with any created beings or objects.
orig: أيشركون ما لا يخلق شيئا وهم يخلقون

translation: And they cannot aid them, nor can they aid themselves.
interpretation: This verse highlights the utter helplessness of the false deities that people worship besides Allah. It emphasizes that these idols or false gods have no power to assist their worshippers or even themselves. They are completely incapable of providing any support or protection, rendering their worship futile and misguided.
orig: ولا يستطيعون لهم نصرا ولا أنفسهم ينصرون

translation: And if you invite them to guidance, they will not follow you. It is the same for you whether you invite them or you remain silent.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the disbelievers are stubborn and unwilling to accept the truth, no matter how much you call them to it. Their rejection of guidance is not due to any fault in the way it is presented, but rather due to their own obstinacy and closed-mindedness. Therefore, the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ is told not to be disheartened if they do not respond positively to his call, as their reaction is not a reflection on him or his efforts.
orig: وإن تدعوهم إلى الهدى لا يتبعوكم سواء عليكم أدعوتموهم أم أنتم صامتون

translation: Indeed, those you call upon besides Allah are servants like you. So call upon them and let them respond to you, if you should be truthful.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the futility of worshipping anything other than Allah. It states that those beings that the idolaters invoke besides Allah are merely His servants, just like humans. They have no power to respond to prayers or supplications. If the idolaters truly believe these entities are worthy of worship, they should call upon them, and see if they can answer their calls. This verse highlights the absurdity of idol worship and affirms that only Allah is worthy of being supplicated and worshipped.
orig: إن الذين تدعون من دون الله عباد أمثالكم فادعوهم فليستجيبوا لكم إن كنتم صادقين

translation: Have they feet to walk with? Or have they hands to strike with? Or have they eyes to see with? Or have they ears to hear with? Say, 'Call your partners, then plot against me and give me no respite.'
interpretation: This verse challenges the polytheists to consider the absurdity of their beliefs in associating partners with Allah. It questions whether these alleged partners possess any faculties or abilities to warrant worship. The rhetorical questions highlight the falsehood of their beliefs, as these inanimate objects lack the basic senses and abilities that Allah has bestowed upon His creation. The verse then commands the Prophet Muhammad to confront the polytheists and challenge them to call upon their false deities, implying that they will be unable to cause him any harm or defend themselves against Allah's power.
orig: ألهم أرجل يمشون بها أم لهم أيد يبطشون بها أم لهم أعين يبصرون بها أم لهم آذان يسمعون بها قل ادعوا شركاءكم ثم كيدون فلا تنظرون

translation: Indeed, my ally is Allah, who has sent down the Book, and He protects the righteous.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of relying solely on Allah and seeking His protection and guidance. The interpretation is: "My true ally and supporter is Allah alone, the One who has revealed the Qur'an as a source of guidance. And He is the One who takes care of and protects those who are righteous and obedient to Him."
orig: إن وليي الله الذي نزل الكتاب وهو يتولى الصالحين

translation: And those you call upon besides Him are not able to help you, nor can they help themselves.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the futility of worshipping or calling upon any entity besides Allah. Those idols, objects, or beings that people associate as partners with Allah have no power whatsoever to help or benefit them, nor can they even help themselves. This highlights the importance of directing all worship and supplication solely to Allah, the One True God, who alone has the power to grant aid and respond to prayers.
orig: والذين تدعون من دونه لا يستطيعون نصركم ولا أنفسهم ينصرون

translation: And if you call them to guidance, they will not hear; and you see them looking at you, yet they do not see.
interpretation: This verse refers to the stubborn disbelievers who refuse to accept the truth and guidance brought by the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him. Despite his efforts to invite them to the right path, they turn a deaf ear and remain blind to the clear signs and evidence presented to them. Their hearts and minds are closed, and they choose to remain in their state of disbelief, even when the truth is evident before their eyes.
orig: وإن تدعوهم إلى الهدى لا يسمعوا وتراهم ينظرون إليك وهم لا يبصرون

translation: Take the pardon and enjoin what is good, and turn away from the ignorant ones.
interpretation: This verse encourages Muslims to adopt a forgiving and tolerant attitude towards those who wrong them, to promote virtuous conduct, and to disengage from those who persist in ignorance and folly. It emphasizes the importance of responding to provocation with patience and wisdom, rather than retaliation or escalation. The interpretation highlights the virtues of pardoning offences, advocating righteousness, and avoiding futile conflicts with the obstinate and foolish.
orig: خذ العفو وأمر بالعرف وأعرض عن الجاهلين

translation: And if an evil suggestion comes to you from Satan, then seek refuge in Allah. Indeed, He is the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing.
interpretation: This verse reminds us that when we are faced with evil thoughts or temptations from Satan, we should immediately seek refuge in Allah, Who is All-Hearing and All-Knowing. By turning to Allah and seeking His protection, we can resist the whispers of Satan and remain steadfast on the path of righteousness. This verse emphasizes the importance of having a strong connection with Allah and relying on Him for guidance and protection against the influence of evil.
orig: وإما ينزغنك من الشيطان نزغ فاستعذ بالله إنه سميع عليم

translation: Indeed, those who are conscious of Allah - when an evil suggestion comes to them from Satan, they remember [the truth] and at once they have insight.
interpretation: This verse indicates that for those who have taqwa (consciousness of Allah and fear of His punishment), when they are afflicted with an evil whisper or suggestion from Satan, they immediately remember Allah and His teachings. This remembrance gives them insight and clarity, allowing them to reject the evil suggestion and remain steadfast on the right path. The verse highlights the importance of taqwa as a shield against Satanic temptations and the power of remembering Allah to dispel such whispers.
orig: إن الذين اتقوا إذا مسهم طائف من الشيطان تذكروا فإذا هم مبصرون

translation: And their brothers (the evil ones) plunge them deeper into error, and never leave off (their evil doings).
interpretation: This verse refers to the misguided people who are led further astray by the evil ones (devils or their companions), who constantly encourage them to persist in their misguidance and sins, never allowing them to reflect or turn back to the right path.
orig: وإخوانهم يمدونهم في الغي ثم لا يقصرون

translation: And when they are not brought a sign, they say, 'Why did you not contrive one?' Say, 'I only follow what is revealed to me from my Lord. This [Qur'an] is enlightening vision from your Lord, and guidance and mercy for a people who believe.'
interpretation: This verse addresses the disbelievers who demanded miracles from the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ as proof of his prophethood. The interpretation is that the Prophet ﷺ is instructed to respond by saying that he does not have the ability to produce miracles on his own accord; rather, he can only convey what is revealed to him by Allah. The Qur'an itself is a clear sign and enlightening guidance from Allah, providing direction and mercy for those who have faith.
orig: وإذا لم تأتهم بآية قالوا لولا اجتبيتها قل إنما أتبع ما يوحى إلي من ربي هذا بصائر من ربكم وهدى ورحمة لقوم يؤمنون

translation: And when the Qur'an is recited, then listen to it and pay attention that you may receive mercy.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of attentively listening to the recitation of the Qur'an with a humble and receptive heart, as doing so can lead to attaining Allah's mercy and blessings. It encourages us to be fully present and focused when the Qur'an is being recited, rather than allowing our minds to wander or be distracted by other matters. By actively listening and reflecting upon the words of Allah, we open ourselves to receiving the guidance, wisdom, and spiritual nourishment contained within the Qur'an, ultimately leading us towards the path of mercy and forgiveness.
orig: وإذا قرئ القرآن فاستمعوا له وأنصتوا لعلكم ترحمون

translation: And remember your Lord within yourself humbly and with fear and without being loud in words, in the mornings and the evenings. And do not be among the heedless.
interpretation: This verse encourages us to remember Allah constantly, in a humble and fearful manner, not loudly or ostentatiously. It specifically mentions remembering Him in the mornings and evenings, which were times when the pre-Islamic Arabs made devotions to their gods. The verse warns us not to be among the heedless who neglect the remembrance of Allah.
orig: واذكر ربك في نفسك تضرعا وخيفة ودون الجهر من القول بالغدو والآصال ولا تكن من الغافلين

translation: Indeed, those who are near your Lord are not too arrogant to worship Him, and they glorify Him and prostrate to Him.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the humility and devotion of those who are closest to Allah. It indicates that the beings who are closest to Allah, such as the angels, do not consider themselves too exalted or superior to worship and submit to Him. Rather, they constantly glorify and praise Allah, and prostrate before Him in submission and reverence. This serves as a lesson for human beings to adopt a similar attitude of humility and submission towards their Creator.
orig: إن الذين عند ربك لا يستكبرون عن عبادته ويسبحونه وله يسجدون

translation: They ask you about the spoils of war. Say, 'The spoils of war are for Allah and the Messenger.' So fear Allah, settle your differences, and obey Allah and His Messenger, if you are believers.
interpretation: The interpretation focuses on the distribution of war spoils and the importance of obedience to Allah and the Prophet. It emphasizes that war spoils belong to Allah and the Prophet, who will distribute them justly. Muslims are commanded to fear Allah, resolve conflicts among themselves, and obey Allah and the Prophet if they are true believers.
orig: يسألونك عن الأنفال قل الأنفال لله والرسول فاتقوا الله وأصلحوا ذات بينكم وأطيعوا الله ورسوله إن كنتم مؤمنين

translation: The believers are only those who, when Allah is mentioned, their hearts become fearful, and when His verses are recited to them, it increases them in faith; and upon their Lord they rely.
interpretation: This verse describes the true qualities of believers. When Allah is remembered, their hearts are filled with awe and reverence. When the verses of the Qur'an are recited to them, it strengthens their faith and increases their conviction. Moreover, they place their complete trust and reliance in Allah alone.
orig: إنما المؤمنون الذين إذا ذكر الله وجلت قلوبهم وإذا تليت عليهم آياته زادتهم إيمانا وعلى ربهم يتوكلون

translation: Those who establish prayer and spend out of what We have provided for them
interpretation: This verse refers to the believers who faithfully perform their obligatory prayers and spend from the wealth that Allah has bestowed upon them in ways that are pleasing to Him. It highlights two important acts of worship: prayer and charity. Prayer is a means of maintaining a connection with Allah, while charity is a way of purifying one's wealth and helping those in need. Together, these acts demonstrate true faith and obedience to Allah's commands.
orig: الذين يقيمون الصلاة ومما رزقناهم ينفقون

translation: Those are the believers in truth. For them are degrees [of high position] with their Lord and forgiveness and noble provision.
interpretation: This verse affirms that those who truly believe in Allah and fulfill the requirements of faith will be granted elevated ranks and high positions in the Hereafter, as well as forgiveness for their sins and an honorable and bountiful provision from Allah.
orig: أولئك هم المؤمنون حقا لهم درجات عند ربهم ومغفرة ورزق كريم

translation: As your Lord brought you forth from your home with the truth, and indeed, a party of the believers were unwilling.
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident when the Prophet Muhammad left Mecca for the migration to Medina. Despite facing opposition from some believers who were reluctant to leave their homes and wealth behind, Allah commanded the Prophet to depart from Mecca "with the truth" or in accordance with the divine command and plan.
orig: كما أخرجك ربك من بيتك بالحق وإن فريقا من المؤمنين لكارهون

translation: They dispute with you concerning the truth after it was made clear, as if they were being driven to death while they were looking on.
interpretation: This verse refers to those who stubbornly argue against the truth of Islam, even after it has been made clear to them through evident proofs and signs. Their obstinacy is likened to being driven to their death while fully aware of their fate, yet they persist in their rejection. This emphasizes the severity of their rejection and their unwillingness to accept the truth, despite its clarity.
orig: يجادلونك في الحق بعدما تبين كأنما يساقون إلى الموت وهم ينظرون

translation: And [recall] when Allah promised you one of the two groups - that it would be yours - and you wished that the unarmed one would be yours. But Allah intended to establish the truth by His words and to cut off the root of the disbelievers.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Battle of Badr, where the Muslims were faced with two caravan routes - one heavily armed and the other lightly armed. The Muslims desired the lightly armed caravan, thinking it would be an easy target. However, Allah willed that the truth prevail and the disbelievers be defeated, even though they were more powerful militarily. This demonstrates that victory comes from Allah, not from material strength alone.
orig: وإذ يعدكم الله إحدى الطائفتين أنها لكم وتودون أن غير ذات الشوكة تكون لكم ويريد الله أن يحق الحق بكلماته ويقطع دابر الكافرين

translation: So that truth may prevail and falsehood may be vanquished, even though the guilty ones dislike it.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the ultimate triumph of truth over falsehood, regardless of the opposition or dislike from those who perpetrate evil deeds. It affirms that the truth will be established and falsehood will be defeated, even if those who commit crimes and injustices resist or detest it. The verse highlights the unwavering nature of truth and its eventual victory, while falsehood and wrongdoing will inevitably be exposed and overcome, despite the resistance of the wrongdoers.
orig: ليحق الحق ويبطل الباطل ولو كره المجرمون

translation: When you were calling upon your Lord for assistance, and He answered you, 'I will reinforce you with a thousand angels, coming one after another.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the Battle of Badr, where the outnumbered Muslim army sought Allah's help against the Meccan forces. Allah assured them of victory by sending angels to aid them, boosting their morale and granting them a decisive triumph despite being vastly outnumbered. The verse highlights Allah's power to provide unseen support and reassures believers that He answers sincere prayers and aids those who put their trust in Him.
orig: إذ تستغيثون ربكم فاستجاب لكم أني ممدكم بألف من الملائكة مردفين

translation: And Allah made it not but good tidings and so that your hearts would be assured thereby. And victory is not but from Allah. Indeed, Allah is Exalted in Might and Wise.
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that Allah sent the dream of the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ as a glad tiding and reassurance for the believers' hearts. The dream foretold the coming victory, which can only come from Allah alone. He is Mighty in His power and Wise in His decisions and decrees.
orig: وما جعله الله إلا بشرى ولتطمئن به قلوبكم وما النصر إلا من عند الله إن الله عزيز حكيم

translation: When He covered you with drowsiness as a security from Him, and sent down upon you water from the sky to purify you thereby, and to remove from you the evil whispers of Satan, and to strengthen your hearts and make your footsteps firm.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Battle of Badr, when Allah sent down a feeling of drowsiness and security upon the believers to calm their nerves before the battle. The "water from the sky" is interpreted as either literal rain that purified them physically, or a metaphorical "rain" of tranquility that purified their hearts from fear and Satan's whisperings. The verse highlights Allah's support and protection for the believers, strengthening their hearts and making their feet firm against the enemy.
orig: إذ يغشيكم النعاس أمنة منه وينزل عليكم من السماء ماء ليطهركم به ويذهب عنكم رجز الشيطان وليربط على قلوبكم ويثبت به الأقدام

translation: When your Lord inspired the angels, 'I am with you, so keep firm those who believe. I will cast terror into the hearts of those who disbelieve, so strike above the necks and strike from them every fingertip.'
interpretation: This verse is referring to the Battle of Badr, where Allah sent down angels to aid the believers against the disbelievers. The interpretation is that Allah commanded the angels to instill fear in the hearts of the disbelievers, and to strike them with force, either killing them or severing their limbs as punishment for their disbelief and opposition to the Prophet Muhammad and the Muslim community.
orig: إذ يوحي ربك إلى الملائكة أني معكم فثبتوا الذين آمنوا سألقي في قلوب الذين كفروا الرعب فاضربوا فوق الأعناق واضربوا منهم كل بنان

translation: That is because they opposed Allah and His Messenger. And whoever opposes Allah and His Messenger - then indeed, Allah is severe in penalty.
interpretation: This verse warns against opposing Allah and His Messenger, as those who do so will face severe punishment from Allah. It emphasizes the importance of obedience and submission to the commands of Allah and the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him. Opposing their guidance and rejecting their instructions is a grave sin that will be met with a stern penalty in the Hereafter.
orig: ذلك بأنهم شاقوا الله ورسوله ومن يشاقق الله ورسوله فإن الله شديد العقاب

translation: That is so; then taste the punishment, for indeed the disbelievers will have the punishment of the Fire.
interpretation: This verse warns the disbelievers that they will face the severe punishment of Hellfire for rejecting faith and denying the truth. It emphasizes that the consequences of disbelief are real and tangible, and that they will have to "taste" the torment as a result of their choices. The interpretation highlights the gravity of disbelief and the certainty of divine justice for those who persistently reject guidance.
orig: ذلكم فذوقوه وأن للكافرين عذاب النار

translation: O you who have believed, when you meet those who disbelieve advancing [for battle], do not turn your backs to them.
interpretation: This verse instructs the believers not to flee from the battlefield when facing the disbelievers in combat. It encourages steadfastness and bravery, prohibiting cowardice and retreat in the face of the enemy. The believers are commanded to stand firm and face the enemy with courage and determination, trusting in Allah's aid and support.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا إذا لقيتم الذين كفروا زحفا فلا تولوهم الأدبار

translation: And whoever turns his back to them on such a day, unless manoeuvring for battle or turning to join another company, he indeed has drawn upon himself wrath from Allah, and his abode is Hell - an evil destination!
interpretation: This verse warns against fleeing from the battlefield out of cowardice or weakness of faith. Turning one's back on the enemy, except for tactical manoeuvring or joining another Muslim group, is a grave sin that incurs Allah's wrath and leads to an evil destination in Hell. It emphasizes the importance of steadfastness, courage, and unwavering faith in the face of adversity during battles.
orig: ومن يولهم يومئذ دبره إلا متحرفا لقتال أو متحيزا إلى فئة فقد باء بغضب من الله ومأواه جهنم وبئس المصير

translation: So you did not kill them, but it was Allah who killed them. And you threw not, [O Muhammad], when you threw, but it was Allah who threw that He might test the believers with a good test. Indeed, Allah is Hearing and Knowing.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Battle of Badr, where the Muslims were victorious against the pagan Meccans. It emphasizes that the victory was not due to the Muslims' own strength, but rather it was Allah who granted them victory. The Prophet Muhammad's throwing of a handful of dust at the enemy was merely a symbolic act, while it was Allah who instilled fear in the hearts of the disbelievers. This battle served as a test for the believers, allowing them to prove their faith and gain a noble reward from Allah, who is All-Hearing and All-Knowing.
orig: فلم تقتلوهم ولكن الله قتلهم وما رميت إذ رميت ولكن الله رمى وليبلي المؤمنين منه بلاء حسنا إن الله سميع عليم

translation: That is because Allah is the One who weakens the plot of the disbelievers.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah diminishes and renders ineffective the schemes and plots of the disbelievers against the believers and the truth. It is a reassurance that no matter how much the disbelievers conspire and devise plans to undermine the believers, Allah will ultimately nullify their efforts and protect the believers from their harm.
orig: ذلكم وأن الله موهن كيد الكافرين

translation: If you [disbelievers] seek the victory - the victory has already come to you. And if you desist [from hostility], it is better for you; but if you return [to war], We will return, and never will you be helped by your [large] company at all, no matter how numerous it is. And indeed, Allah is with the believers.
interpretation: This verse is a warning to the disbelievers. If they seek victory against the believers, God has already granted victory to the believers. If the disbelievers cease their hostility, it is better for them. But if they persist in aggression, God will aid the believers and the disbelievers will not be helped by their large numbers or armies. Ultimately, God is with the believers and will grant them victory.
orig: إن تستفتحوا فقد جاءكم الفتح وإن تنتهوا فهو خير لكم وإن تعودوا نعد ولن تغني عنكم فئتكم شيئا ولو كثرت وأن الله مع المؤمنين

translation: O you who have believed, obey Allah and His Messenger and do not turn away from Him while you hear [His order].
interpretation: This verse commands the believers to obey Allah's commandments and the teachings of His Messenger Muhammad (peace be upon him). It emphasizes the importance of not disobeying or turning away from Allah and His Messenger after having heard and understood their instructions. Obedience to Allah and His Messenger is a fundamental duty for the believers.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا أطيعوا الله ورسوله ولا تولوا عنه وأنتم تسمعون

translation: And do not be like those who say, 'We hear,' while they do not hear.
interpretation: This verse warns against being hypocritical and merely paying lip service to faith without truly understanding or following its teachings. It advises against being like those who claim to listen but do not actually comprehend or act upon what they have heard. The verse emphasizes the importance of sincerity, comprehension, and putting one's beliefs into practice.
orig: ولا تكونوا كالذين قالوا سمعنا وهم لا يسمعون

translation: Indeed, the worst of living creatures in the sight of Allah are the deaf and dumb who do not use reason.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that those who willfully refuse to listen to the truth and remain silent in acknowledging it, despite having the ability to comprehend it, are considered the worst of creatures in Allah's sight. It condemns the attitude of stubbornly rejecting guidance and failing to use one's intellectual faculties to recognize the truth.
orig: إن شر الدواب عند الله الصم البكم الذين لا يعقلون

translation: And if Allah had known any good in them, He would have made them listen; and if He had made them listen, they would have turned away, being averse.
interpretation: This verse implies that Allah does not guide those whom He knows will not benefit from guidance and will persist in disbelief and rejection of the truth. If Allah knew there was any good or inclination towards faith in their hearts, He would have made them receptive to the message. However, since He knew their inner state of aversion and obstinacy, He did not force them to listen, as they would have still turned away from the truth.
orig: ولو علم الله فيهم خيرا لأسمعهم ولو أسمعهم لتولوا وهم معرضون

translation: O you who have believed, respond to Allah and to the Messenger when he calls you to that which gives you life. And know that Allah intervenes between a man and his heart and that to Him you will be gathered.
interpretation: This verse calls upon the believers to obey Allah and His Messenger when they are commanded to do something that will lead to their spiritual and eternal life. It reminds them that Allah has the power to intervene between a person and their heart, meaning He can guide or misguide whomever He wills. Ultimately, all people will be gathered before Allah on the Day of Judgment.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا استجيبوا لله وللرسول إذا دعاكم لما يحييكم واعلموا أن الله يحول بين المرء وقلبه وأنه إليه تحشرون

translation: And fear a trial which will not strike those who have wronged among you exclusively, and know that Allah is severe in penalty.
interpretation: This verse warns believers to be cautious and avoid falling into trials or afflictions that may arise due to wrongdoing. It emphasizes that such trials will not be limited to the wrongdoers alone but may affect others as well. The verse also reminds believers of Allah's severe punishment for those who persist in wrongdoing and disobedience.
orig: واتقوا فتنة لا تصيبن الذين ظلموا منكم خاصة واعلموا أن الله شديد العقاب

translation: And remember when you were few and oppressed in the land, fearing that people might abduct you, but He sheltered you, supported you with His victory, and provided you with good things - that you might be grateful.
interpretation: This verse reminds the believers of their humble beginnings, when they were few in number, oppressed, and living in fear of being persecuted or abducted by their enemies. However, Allah sheltered and protected them, granted them victory and strength, and provided them with lawful and pure sustenance. This is a reminder of Allah's blessings upon them, so that they may be grateful and appreciate the favors bestowed upon them by their Lord.
orig: واذكروا إذ أنتم قليل مستضعفون في الأرض تخافون أن يتخطفكم الناس فآواكم وأيدكم بنصره ورزقكم من الطيبات لعلكم تشكرون

translation: O you who have believed, do not betray Allah and the Messenger or betray your trusts while you know [the consequence].
interpretation: "This verse instructs the believers not to commit treachery against Allah by disobeying His commands, and not to betray the Messenger by rejecting his teachings. It also prohibits betraying the trusts placed upon them, whether they are material trusts like wealth and property, or moral trusts like secrets and covenants. This betrayal is particularly egregious when done knowingly and intentionally."
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا لا تخونوا الله والرسول وتخونوا أماناتكم وأنتم تعلمون

translation: And know that your possessions and your children are but a trial and that it is Allah with whom lies a great reward.
interpretation: This verse reminds believers that their wealth and children should not be the ultimate goal in life, as they are merely a test from Allah. True reward and success lie in pleasing Allah and earning His pleasure through righteous deeds and sincere faith.
orig: واعلموا أنما أموالكم وأولادكم فتنة وأن الله عنده أجر عظيم

translation: O you who believe! If you obey Allah, He will grant you a criterion [to judge between right and wrong] and will remit from you your evil deeds, and forgive you; and Allah is the Lord of mighty grace.
interpretation: This verse encourages believers to have taqwa (consciousness and fear of Allah) by obeying His commands. If they do so, Allah promises them several favors: 1) A furqan, which is a criterion to distinguish truth from falsehood and right from wrong. 2) The remission of their previous sins and evil deeds. 3) Forgiveness from Allah. 4) Attainment of Allah's immense grace and favor. This highlights the great reward and spiritual benefits that come with taqwa.
orig: يا أيها الذين آمنوا إن تتقوا الله يجعل لكم فرقانا ويكفر عنكم سيئاتكم ويغفر لكم والله ذو الفضل العظيم

translation: And [recall, O Muhammad], when those who disbelieved plotted against you to restrain you or kill you or evict you [from Makkah]. But they plan, and Allah plans. And Allah is the best of planners.
interpretation: This verse refers to the plots and schemes of the disbelievers against the Prophet Muhammad. They sought to imprison him, kill him, or expel him from Makkah, but Allah was protecting him and planning to defeat their evil schemes. The interpretation highlights that while the disbelievers made their plans, Allah is the best of planners, and His plan ultimately prevailed over their malicious intentions.
orig: وإذ يمكر بك الذين كفروا ليثبتوك أو يقتلوك أو يخرجوك ويمكرون ويمكر الله والله خير الماكرين

translation: And when Our verses are recited to them, they say, 'We have heard. If we willed, we could say the like of this. This is not but legends of the former peoples.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the arrogant attitude of the disbelievers who, when the verses of the Qur'an were recited to them, responded with arrogance and rejection. They claimed that they could produce something similar to the Qur'an if they wished, dismissing it as mere legends of ancient peoples. This interpretation highlights their stubbornness and lack of faith in the face of clear evidence and guidance from Allah.
orig: وإذا تتلى عليهم آياتنا قالوا قد سمعنا لو نشاء لقلنا مثل هذا إن هذا إلا أساطير الأولين

translation: And [mention, O Muhammad], when they said, "O Allah, if this should be the truth from You, then rain down upon us stones from the sky or bring us a painful punishment."
interpretation: "This verse refers to the arrogance and stubbornness of the disbelievers who challenged Allah and demanded a punishment if the message brought by the Prophet Muhammad was truly from Allah. Their demand for a sign was not out of a sincere desire to believe, but rather a mockery and rejection of the truth. The interpretation highlights the disbelievers' audacity in demanding a punishment from Allah, despite their disbelief and rejection of His signs and messengers."
orig: وإذ قالوا اللهم إن كان هذا هو الحق من عندك فأمطر علينا حجارة من السماء أو ائتنا بعذاب أليم

translation: And Allah would not punish them while you were among them, nor would Allah punish them while they seek forgiveness.
interpretation: This verse indicates that as long as the Prophet Muhammad was present among his people and they sought forgiveness from Allah, Allah would not punish them. It suggests that the presence of the Prophet and the act of seeking forgiveness are reasons for Allah's mercy and withholding of punishment.
orig: وما كان الله ليعذبهم وأنت فيهم وما كان الله معذبهم وهم يستغفرون

translation: And what is [the matter] with them that they are not punished by Allah while they obstruct [people] from al-Masjid al-Haram, and they were not [supposed to be] its guardians? Its guardians are not but the righteous, but most of them do not know.
interpretation: Allah questions why He does not punish those who prevent people from the Sacred Mosque in Makkah, when they have no authority over it. The true guardians of the Sacred Mosque are only the pious and God-fearing people, but most of the disbelievers do not understand this reality.
orig: وما لهم ألا يعذبهم الله وهم يصدون عن المسجد الحرام وما كانوا أولياءه إن أولياؤه إلا المتقون ولكن أكثرهم لا يعلمون

translation: And their prayer at the House was nothing but whistling and handclapping. So taste the punishment for what you used to disbelieve.
interpretation: This verse condemns the pagan Arabs who mocked and ridiculed the sacred rituals of Islam performed at the Ka'bah. Their "prayer" there was merely whistling and handclapping in mockery, rather than sincere worship of Allah.
