translation: And they were pursued in this world by a curse, and on the Day of Resurrection. Verily, 'Aad disbelieved in their Lord. So away with 'Aad, the people of Hud.
interpretation: This verse refers to the punishment that befell the people of 'Aad, who rejected the message of Prophet Hud and persisted in disbelief and disobedience. They were cursed in this worldly life by being destroyed by a furious wind, and they will be cursed on the Day of Resurrection by being condemned to Hell. The verse emphasizes the utter rejection of the people of 'Aad towards their Lord, and serves as a warning against following their footsteps of disbelief and defiance.
orig: وأتبعوا في هذه الدنيا لعنة ويوم القيامة ألا إن عادا كفروا ربهم ألا بعدا لعاد قوم هود

translation: And to Thamud (people, We sent) their brother Salih. He said: 'O my people! Worship Allah! You have no other Ilah (God) but Him. He brought you forth from the earth and settled you therein, then ask forgiveness of Him and turn to Him in repentance. Certainly, my Lord is Near (to all by His Knowledge), Most-Responsive.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Salih and his people, the Thamud. Allah sent Salih as a prophet to guide his people to worship Allah alone and abandon idolatry. Salih reminded them that Allah created them from the earth and gave them the ability to inhabit and thrive in it. He instructed them to seek forgiveness from Allah and repent sincerely to Him, as Allah is near to those who call upon Him and responds to their supplications.
orig: وإلى ثمود أخاهم صالحا قال يا قوم اعبدوا الله ما لكم من إله غيره هو أنشأكم من الأرض واستعمركم فيها فاستغفروه ثم توبوا إليه إن ربي قريب مجيب

translation: They said: "O Salih! You were one amongst us, a man of promise before this! Do you forbid us to worship what our fathers worshipped? Truly, we are in grave doubt concerning that to which you invite us."
interpretation: "The disbelievers of Thamud mocked Salih and questioned his message, claiming that he was once a respected man among them but now he is forbidding them from worshipping the idols that their forefathers worshipped. They expressed their skepticism and doubts about the message of Tawheed (Islamic Monotheism) that Salih was inviting them to."
orig: قالوا يا صالح قد كنت فينا مرجوا قبل هذا أتنهانا أن نعبد ما يعبد آباؤنا وإننا لفي شك مما تدعونا إليه مريب

translation: He said: 'O my people! See ye if (this) be a Clear Sign from my Lord, and that He hath sent Mercy unto me from His own Presence, but that the Mercy hath been obscured from your sight? Shall we compel you to accept it when ye are averse to it?'
interpretation: The Prophet is asking his people to reflect on the clear signs and mercy from God that he has received, but they are unable to see it due to their aversion. He questions how he can compel them to accept the truth when they are so opposed to it.
orig: قال يا قوم أرأيتم إن كنت على بينة من ربي وآتاني منه رحمة فمن ينصرني من الله إن عصيته فما تزيدونني غير تخسير

translation: O my people! This is the she-camel of Allah - a sign for you. So leave her to graze in Allah's land, and do not touch her with harm, or you will be seized by a near punishment.
interpretation: "The interpretation of this verse is that the she-camel was a miraculous sign from Allah to the people of Thamud to test their faith. They were commanded to let the she-camel graze freely and not harm her, or else they would face a severe and imminent punishment from Allah for their disbelief and disobedience."
orig: ويا قوم هذه ناقة الله لكم آية فذروها تأكل في أرض الله ولا تمسوها بسوء فيأخذكم عذاب قريب

translation: Then hamstring her, and he said: 'Enjoy yourselves in your homes for three days. That is a promise not to be belied.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the command given to the Prophet Salih to slaughter the miraculous she-camel as a test for the people of Thamud, who had demanded a miracle. After slaughtering the camel, Salih warned them that they would only have three days to enjoy their homes before punishment would strike them for their disbelief and disobedience. The "promise not to be belied" indicates that this warning from Allah was a true promise that would inevitably be fulfilled.
orig: فعقروها فقال تمتعوا في داركم ثلاثة أيام ذلك وعد غير مكذوب

translation: So when Our command came, We saved Salih and those who believed with him, by mercy from Us, and [saved them] from the disgrace of that day. Indeed, it is your Lord who is the Powerful, the Exalted in Might.
interpretation: "When the punishment from Allah came upon the disbelieving people of Thamud for rejecting the message of Prophet Salih, Allah saved Salih and those who believed with him from that torment, by His mercy and grace. He protected them from the humiliation and disgrace that befell the disbelievers on that fateful day. Verily, your Lord is truly the Almighty, the Invincible, whose power cannot be overcome."
orig: فلما جاء أمرنا نجينا صالحا والذين آمنوا معه برحمة منا ومن خزي يومئذ إن ربك هو القوي العزيز

translation: And those who did wrong were seized by the Shout, and they lay dead in their homes.
interpretation: This verse refers to the punishment that befell the wrongdoers who rejected the message of the Prophet. The "Shout" refers to a powerful blast or cry that struck them, causing them to die instantly in their homes. It serves as a warning to those who persist in disbelief and wrongdoing, emphasizing that Allah's punishment can come swiftly and leave no chance for escape or repentance.
orig: وأخذ الذين ظلموا الصيحة فأصبحوا في ديارهم جاثمين

translation: As if they had never dwelt therein. Verily, Thamud disbelieved in their Lord. So away with Thamud!
interpretation: This verse highlights the complete destruction of the people of Thamud, who denied their Lord and rejected the message of Prophet Salih. Their dwellings were left uninhabited, as if they had never lived there, due to their disbelief and defiance of Allah's commands. It serves as a stern warning against arrogance and rejection of divine guidance.
orig: كأن لم يغنوا فيها ألا إن ثمود كفروا ربهم ألا بعدا لثمود

translation: And certainly did Our messengers come to Abraham with good tidings; they said, 'Peace.' He said, 'Peace,' and did not delay in bringing [them] a roasted calf.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Abraham when the angels came to him in the form of guests to give him the good news of a son, despite his old age and his wife's barrenness. The angels greeted him with "Peace," and he responded with the same greeting, showing his hospitality. He then quickly brought a roasted calf to serve his guests, demonstrating his generosity and good manners.
orig: ولقد جاءت رسلنا إبراهيم بالبشرى قالوا سلاما قال سلام فما لبث أن جاء بعجل حنيذ

translation: But when he saw their hands not reaching towards it, he distrusted them and conceived a fear of them. They said: 'Fear not! We have been sent to the people of Lut'.
interpretation: When the angels saw that Prophet Ibrahim did not extend his hands to the food they brought, he became apprehensive and fearful of them, thinking they might not be true guests. However, the angels reassured him by stating that they were sent by Allah to the people of Prophet Lut (Lot) to destroy them for their evil deeds.
orig: فلما رأى أيديهم لا تصل إليه نكرهم وأوجس منهم خيفة قالوا لا تخف إنا أرسلنا إلى قوم لوط

translation: And his wife was standing, and she laughed. But We gave her good tidings of Isaac, and after Isaac, of Jacob.
interpretation: This verse refers to the glad tidings given to the wife of Prophet Abraham, who laughed in disbelief when she was told that she would bear a son at an old age. The interpretation is that Allah promised her a son named Isaac, and after Isaac, another son named Jacob, despite her initial doubt and laughter. It highlights Allah's power to grant children even in seemingly impossible circumstances.
orig: وامرأته قائمة فضحكت فبشرناها بإسحاق ومن وراء إسحاق يعقوب

translation: She said: 'Woe unto me! Shall I bear a child when I am an old woman, and this my husband is an old man? This is indeed a strange thing!'
interpretation: The interpretation is that Mary expressed her surprise and astonishment at being able to conceive a child despite her old age and the old age of her husband Zachariah. It was something extraordinary and beyond the usual laws of nature, which is why she exclaimed: "This is indeed a strange thing!"
orig: قالت يا ويلتى أألد وأنا عجوز وهذا بعلي شيخا إن هذا لشيء عجيب

translation: They said, "Do you wonder at the decree of Allah? May the mercy of Allah and His blessings be upon you, people of the household. Indeed, He is Praiseworthy and Glorious."
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as a declaration of respect and reverence towards the Prophet Muhammad's household (Ahl al-Bayt). It suggests that the people addressed the Prophet's family with honor, acknowledging the mercy and blessings of Allah upon them. The verse affirms that Allah's decree should not be a source of astonishment, as He is worthy of all praise and glory.
orig: قالوا أتعجبين من أمر الله رحمت الله وبركاته عليكم أهل البيت إنه حميد مجيد

translation: And when the fear had gone away from Abraham and the good tidings had reached him, he began to plead with Us concerning the people of Lot.
interpretation: This verse refers to the time when the angels who had come to destroy the people of Lot had reassured Abraham that they would not harm his family. After the initial fear had subsided and Abraham received the good news that his family would be spared, he began to plead with Allah on behalf of Lot's people, hoping that they might be saved from destruction due to their sinful ways.
orig: فلما ذهب عن إبراهيم الروع وجاءته البشرى يجادلنا في قوم لوط

translation: Indeed, Abraham was forbearing, penitent and [frequently] returning [to Allah].
interpretation: This verse highlights the praiseworthy qualities of Prophet Abraham (peace be upon him). He was 'halim' meaning forbearing, patient, and gentle. He was also 'awwah' which means that he turned to Allah frequently in repentance, humility, and submission. The verse emphasizes Abraham's devotion to Allah and his excellent moral character.
orig: إن إبراهيم لحليم أواه منيب

translation: O Ibrahim, turn away from this. Indeed, there has come the command of your Lord, and indeed, there will come to them a punishment which cannot be repelled.
interpretation: This verse is addressing Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) and instructing him to disassociate himself from the disbelievers and idolaters. It informs him that Allah's decree has been issued regarding their punishment, which is inevitable and cannot be averted or turned back.
orig: يا إبراهيم أعرض عن هذا إنه قد جاء أمر ربك وإنهم آتيهم عذاب غير مردود

translation: And when Our messengers came to Lut, he was anguished for them and felt for them great discomfort and said, 'This is a distressful day.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Lut (Lot) when the angels came to him in the form of handsome young men. Lut felt distressed and uncomfortable because he knew the evil intentions of his people towards these guests. He feared for their safety and considered it a difficult day, as his people were determined to commit an abominable act with the visitors.
orig: ولما جاءت رسلنا لوطا سيء بهم وضاق بهم ذرعا وقال هذا يوم عصيب

translation: And his people came rushing towards him, and aforetime they had been committing evil deeds. He said: O my people! Here are my daughters, they are purer for you. So fear Allah, and do not humiliate me with regard to my guests. Is there not among you a single right-minded man?
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Lut (Lot) when his people approached him with evil intentions towards his guests, who were actually angels in human form sent by Allah. Lut tried to reason with them and offered his daughters for marriage instead, as a way to prevent them from committing the grave sin of homosexuality. He urged them to fear Allah and not disgrace him by harming his guests. He questioned if there was not a single wise and right-minded man among them who would listen to reason.
orig: وجاءه قومه يهرعون إليه ومن قبل كانوا يعملون السيئات قال يا قوم هؤلاء بناتي هن أطهر لكم فاتقوا الله ولا تخزون في ضيفي أليس منكم رجل رشيد

translation: They said: "Certainly you have known that there is no desire for us in your daughters, and indeed, you know what we want."
interpretation: The verse refers to the people of Lut (Lot) who approached him with evil intentions towards his male guests. They were implying that they had no interest in his daughters (for marriage), but rather wanted to engage in homosexual acts with his male guests, which was considered a grave sin and transgression.
orig: قالوا لقد علمت ما لنا في بناتك من حق وإنك لتعلم ما نريد

translation: He said, 'If only I had the strength to overpower you, or could lean on some strong support.'
interpretation: This verse refers to someone who wishes they had the power or support to confront or overcome a difficult situation or challenge. It expresses a sense of weakness or helplessness in the face of adversity, and a desire for strength or backing from a reliable source. The interpretation highlights the human need for empowerment and assistance when facing obstacles or opposition.
orig: قال لو أن لي بكم قوة أو آوي إلى ركن شديد

translation: They said: 'O Lut! We are messengers from your Lord. They shall not reach you, so travel with your family in a part of the night, and let not any of you look back, except your wife. Indeed, she will be struck by that which strikes them. Their appointed time is the morning. Is not the morning near?'
interpretation: This verse refers to the angels who came to Prophet Lut (Lot) to warn him of the imminent destruction of the people of Sodom due to their wicked deeds. The angels instructed Lut to leave with his family during the night, except his wife who was destined to suffer the same fate as the disbelieving people. The appointed time for their punishment was the morning, indicating the closeness of their doom.
orig: قالوا يا لوط إنا رسل ربك لن يصلوا إليك فأسر بأهلك بقطع من الليل ولا يلتفت منكم أحد إلا امرأتك إنه مصيبها ما أصابهم إن موعدهم الصبح أليس الصبح بقريب

translation: So when Our command came, We made the highest part [of the city] its lowest and rained upon it stones of layered mud in succession.
interpretation: This verse describes the punishment that Allah inflicted upon the people of Lut (Lot) for their sinful ways. Allah turned their city upside down, destroying the arrogant and wealthy class by making them the lowest and humiliated. He also rained down upon them a shower of baked clay stones, which were firmly cemented together, signifying the severity and decisiveness of their punishment for defying His commands.
orig: فلما جاء أمرنا جعلنا عاليها سافلها وأمطرنا عليها حجارة من سجيل منضود

translation: Not a township but We shall destroy it before the Day of Resurrection, or punish it with terrible punishment. That is inscribed in the Book.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the punishment of Allah is inevitable for those who persist in disbelief and wrongdoing. Every community that rejects faith and disobeys Allah's commands will face destruction or a severe punishment, as decreed by Allah in the Divine Book (the Preserved Tablet). This serves as a warning to all people to embrace faith and righteousness, lest they suffer the consequences of their denial and transgressions.
orig: مسومة عند ربك وما هي من الظالمين ببعيد

translation: And to the people of Madyan, We sent their brother Shuaib. He said: 'O my people! Worship Allah. You have no other god besides Him. And do not give short measure and weight. I see you in prosperity, but I fear for you the punishment of an encompassing Day.'
interpretation: Allah sent the Prophet Shuaib to the people of Madyan to call them to worship Allah alone and abstain from dishonest business practices like giving less in measure and weight. Shuaib warned them that although he saw them prosperous, he feared for them the punishment of a Day that would encompass all people if they continued in their disbelief and corruption.
orig: وإلى مدين أخاهم شعيبا قال يا قوم اعبدوا الله ما لكم من إله غيره ولا تنقصوا المكيال والميزان إني أراكم بخير وإني أخاف عليكم عذاب يوم محيط

translation: O my people! Give full measure and full weight in justice, and wrong not people in respect of their goods. And do not evil in the earth, causing corruption.
interpretation: This verse commands people to be just and fair in their dealings with others, particularly in matters of trade and commerce. It instructs them to give full measure and weight without any deception or fraud. It also prohibits them from wrongfully taking or diminishing the possessions of others, and from spreading corruption and mischief on the earth through their actions.
orig: ويا قوم أوفوا المكيال والميزان بالقسط ولا تبخسوا الناس أشياءهم ولا تعثوا في الأرض مفسدين

translation: But Allah is the Best to guard, and He is the Most Merciful of those who show mercy, if you are believers.
interpretation: The interpretation is that Allah is the best Protector and Guardian for the believers. His mercy encompasses everything, and He is the most merciful of those who show mercy. However, this promise is conditional upon having true faith and being among the believers.
orig: بقيت الله خير لكم إن كنتم مؤمنين وما أنا عليكم بحفيظ

translation: They said: 'O Shu'aib! Does your prayer command you that we should forsake what our fathers worshipped, or that we should not do what we please with our property? Indeed you are the forbearing, the rightly-guided one!'
interpretation: The people of Shu'aib were questioning his call to abandon the idolatrous practices of their forefathers and to stop exploiting their wealth in unlawful ways. They were being sarcastic, implying that Shu'aib's teachings were unreasonable and that he was claiming to be forbearing and rightly-guided.
orig: قالوا يا شعيب أصلاتك تأمرك أن نترك ما يعبد آباؤنا أو أن نفعل في أموالنا ما نشاء إنك لأنت الحليم الرشيد

translation: He said: 'O my people! What think ye? If I am upon clear proof from my Lord, and He hath vouchsafed me a mercy from His presence, who shall help me against Allah if I disobey Him? So ye would but add to my ruin.'
interpretation: L'interprétation de ce verset est que le prophète Hud, sur lui la paix, exhorte son peuple à croire en Dieu et à suivre Ses commandements. Il leur dit qu'il a reçu des preuves claires de Dieu et que Dieu lui a accordé Sa miséricorde. Il ne veut pas désobéir à Dieu et s'écarter de ce que Dieu lui a ordonné, car cela ne ferait qu'augmenter sa perte et sa ruine. Il met sa confiance en Dieu et se tourne vers Lui.
orig: قال يا قوم أرأيتم إن كنت على بينة من ربي ورزقني منه رزقا حسنا وما أريد أن أخالفكم إلى ما أنهاكم عنه إن أريد إلا الإصلاح ما استطعت وما توفيقي إلا بالله عليه توكلت وإليه أنيب

translation: And O my people, let not my dissent cause you to suffer a fate similar to that of the people of Noah or of Hud or of Salih, nor were the people of Lot so far from you!
interpretation: "The verse is a warning from the Prophet to his people, urging them not to reject his message or be divided by dissent, lest they face the same punishment and destruction that befell the previous nations who denied their Prophets, such as the people of Noah, Hud, Salih, and Lot. It emphasizes that the fate of those nations is not distant or unrelated to them, reminding them of the grave consequences of disbelief and disobedience."
orig: ويا قوم لا يجرمنكم شقاقي أن يصيبكم مثل ما أصاب قوم نوح أو قوم هود أو قوم صالح وما قوم لوط منكم ببعيد

translation: And ask forgiveness of your Lord and repent to Him. Indeed, my Lord is Most Merciful and Affectionate.
interpretation: This verse encourages believers to seek forgiveness from Allah for their sins and to repent sincerely, turning back to Him with obedience and devotion. It emphasizes Allah's infinite mercy and loving kindness towards those who sincerely repent and strive to follow His guidance.
orig: واستغفروا ربكم ثم توبوا إليه إن ربي رحيم ودود

translation: They said: 'O Shu'aib! We do not understand much of what you say, and indeed, we see you as weak among us. And were it not for your family, we would surely have stoned you, for you are not strong against us.'
interpretation: The disbelievers mocked Shu'aib and claimed that his message was incomprehensible to them. They viewed him as a weak person among them, and if it were not for his family or tribe, they would have stoned him to death, as they did not consider him powerful enough to stop them.
orig: قالوا يا شعيب ما نفقه كثيرا مما تقول وإنا لنراك فينا ضعيفا ولولا رهطك لرجمناك وما أنت علينا بعزيز

translation: He said: 'O my people! Is my family dearer to you than Allah? And you have turned your backs on Him. Surely, my Lord encompasses whatever you do.'
interpretation: This verse implies that the Prophet's people valued their familial and tribal ties more than their obedience to Allah. They rejected the message of the Prophet, who was from their own tribe, due to arrogance and blind following of their ancestors. The verse warns them that Allah is aware of all their actions and that they will be held accountable for disbelieving in His message.
orig: قال يا قوم أرهطي أعز عليكم من الله واتخذتموه وراءكم ظهريا إن ربي بما تعملون محيط

translation: O my people! Work according to your position; I am working too. You will soon know who will receive a punishment that will disgrace him and who is a liar. So wait and watch; I too am waiting along with you.
interpretation: This verse encourages perseverance and patience in the face of opposition and disbelief. It suggests that the truth will eventually become clear, and those who reject it will face disgrace and punishment, while those who remain steadfast will be vindicated. The verse also implies that both the believers and disbelievers should wait and see the outcome, as the speaker (likely a prophet) is also waiting and watching along with them.
orig: ويا قوم اعملوا على مكانتكم إني عامل سوف تعلمون من يأتيه عذاب يخزيه ومن هو كاذب وارتقبوا إني معكم رقيب

translation: And when Our command came, We saved Shu'ayb and those who believed with him by mercy from Us. And the awful cry seized the wrongdoers, and they lay prostrate in their homes.
interpretation: "When Allah's decree and punishment came upon the disbelievers who rejected the message of Prophet Shu'ayb, We saved Shu'ayb and his followers by Our mercy and grace. As for the wrongdoers who persisted in disbelief and oppression, a mighty blast or cry from the angels seized them, leaving them dead and lying face down in their dwellings."
orig: ولما جاء أمرنا نجينا شعيبا والذين آمنوا معه برحمة منا وأخذت الذين ظلموا الصيحة فأصبحوا في ديارهم جاثمين

translation: As if they had never dwelt and flourished there. Ah! Behold! How the Madyan people too were removed (from sight) as were removed those before them, the people of Thamud!
interpretation: This verse highlights the transient nature of worldly life and the consequences of rejecting God's messages. The people of Madyan and Thamud were once prosperous civilizations, but they were utterly destroyed due to their disbelief and disobedience. Their fate serves as a warning to others not to follow in their footsteps and to heed the teachings of the prophets sent to guide them. The verse emphasizes that no matter how powerful or affluent a nation may be, it will inevitably face destruction if it turns away from the path of righteousness.
orig: كأن لم يغنوا فيها ألا بعدا لمدين كما بعدت ثمود

translation: And indeed, We sent Moses with Our signs and a clear authority
interpretation: This verse refers to Allah sending Prophet Moses with clear miracles and undeniable proofs of his prophethood. The "signs" (ayat) mentioned are the miracles Allah gave Moses, such as his staff turning into a serpent and his hand shining bright when he pulled it from his garment. The "clear authority" (sultan mubin) refers to the convincing arguments, evidence, and power that Moses was granted to support his message and mission from Allah.
orig: ولقد أرسلنا موسى بآياتنا وسلطان مبين

translation: To Pharaoh and his chiefs, but they followed the command of Pharaoh, and Pharaoh's command was not rightly guided.
interpretation: This verse is criticizing Pharaoh and his people for blindly following his misguided commands, even though they were clearly unjust and against the truth. It highlights the dangers of obedience to tyrannical rulers who lead their people astray through their arrogance and disbelief in God's signs and messengers.
orig: إلى فرعون وملئه فاتبعوا أمر فرعون وما أمر فرعون برشيد

translation: He will go ahead of his people on the Day of Resurrection and lead them into the Fire. Evil indeed is the place to which they are led.
interpretation: This verse warns against following misguided leaders who will lead their followers to Hellfire on the Day of Judgment. It emphasizes the grave consequences of blindly obeying those who promote falsehood and deviance, as they will be held accountable for misleading others away from the straight path. The interpretation highlights the importance of seeking true knowledge and guidance, and being cautious of those who exploit their influence for personal gain or misguided agendas.
orig: يقدم قومه يوم القيامة فأوردهم النار وبئس الورد المورود

translation: And they were followed in this world with a curse, and on the Day of Resurrection [they will be among] the despised.
interpretation: The interpretation is that those who reject faith and truth are cursed in this world, and on the Day of Judgment, they will be among the disgraced and rejected, deprived of Allah's mercy and favor. This emphasizes the grave consequences of disbelief and disobedience, both in this life and the Hereafter.
orig: وأتبعوا في هذه لعنة ويوم القيامة بئس الرفد المرفود

translation: That is from the news of the cities which We relate to you; of them, some are still standing and some have been harvested.
interpretation: This verse refers to the stories of previous nations and civilizations that Allah is relating to the Prophet Muhammad. Some of these nations continued to exist and thrive, while others were utterly destroyed and became like a harvested crop, leaving no trace behind. The interpretation highlights Allah's power to give life and take it away, and serves as a lesson for people to heed the warnings and follow the guidance revealed to them.
orig: ذلك من أنباء القرى نقصه عليك منها قائم وحصيد

translation: And We wronged them not, but they wronged themselves. And their gods which they called upon besides Allah availed them naught when the command of your Lord came; and they increased them naught but ruin.
interpretation: "Allah did not wrong them, but they wronged themselves by associating partners with Allah and rejecting faith. The false deities they invoked besides Allah could not help them at all when Allah's punishment came. In fact, their worship of those deities only led them further into destruction and ruin."
orig: وما ظلمناهم ولكن ظلموا أنفسهم فما أغنت عنهم آلهتهم التي يدعون من دون الله من شيء لما جاء أمر ربك وما زادوهم غير تتبيب

translation: And thus is the seizure of your Lord when He seizes the towns while they are committing wrong. Indeed, His seizure is painful and severe.
interpretation: This verse describes the severe punishment that Allah inflicts upon oppressive nations and societies that persist in wrongdoing and transgression. It serves as a warning that when Allah decides to punish a community for its sins and injustices, His punishment is indeed painful and intense. The verse emphasizes Allah's justice and reminds people to avoid oppression and injustice to escape such a severe reckoning.
orig: وكذلك أخذ ربك إذا أخذ القرى وهي ظالمة إن أخذه أليم شديد

translation: Indeed in that is a sign for whoever fears the punishment of the Hereafter. That is a Day for which all people will be gathered, and that is a Day which will be witnessed.
interpretation: "This verse highlights the certainty of the Day of Resurrection, which serves as a powerful sign and reminder for those who fear God's punishment in the Hereafter. It emphasizes that the Day of Gathering is an inescapable reality, where all of humanity will be assembled before God, and it will be a momentous occasion witnessed by all."
orig: إن في ذلك لآية لمن خاف عذاب الآخرة ذلك يوم مجموع له الناس وذلك يوم مشهود

translation: And We do not postpone it except for a limited term.
interpretation: Allah does not delay the punishment or the end of the world except for an appointed time known only to Him. This teaches us that everything has a set time and that Allah's plan is perfect and wise.
orig: وما نؤخره إلا لأجل معدود

translation: On the Day when no soul shall speak except by His permission, some among them will be wretched and some blessed.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Day of Judgment, when no one will be able to speak or intercede on behalf of another without Allah's permission. Some people will be miserable ("wretched") due to their disbelief and sins, while others will be blessed and happy due to their faith and good deeds. It emphasizes the helplessness of humans on that Day and the importance of seeking Allah's pleasure in this life.
orig: يوم يأت لا تكلم نفس إلا بإذنه فمنهم شقي وسعيد

translation: As for those who were wretched, they shall be in the Fire, wherein there will be for them gasping and rafing.
interpretation: This verse describes the dreadful fate of those who were rebellious and disobedient to Allah in this life. They will be consigned to the Fire of Hell, where they will suffer terribly, gasping and wheezing as a result of the intense heat and torment they endure. It serves as a stern warning of the grave consequences of rejecting faith and leading an ungodly life.
orig: فأما الذين شقوا ففي النار لهم فيها زفير وشهيق

translation: They will abide therein as long as the heavens and the earth endure, except as your Lord wills. Indeed, your Lord is the perpetual Doer of whatever He intends.
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that the believers will remain in Paradise forever, as long as the heavens and the earth exist, unless Allah wills otherwise. It emphasizes Allah's absolute power and authority, as He is the One who does whatever He intends without any restrictions or limitations.
orig: خالدين فيها ما دامت السماوات والأرض إلا ما شاء ربك إن ربك فعال لما يريد

translation: But as for those who are blessed, they will be in Paradise, abiding therein as long as the heavens and the earth endure, except what your Lord wills - a gift without an end.
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that those who have attained success and blessings from Allah will dwell eternally in Paradise, as long as the heavens and the earth exist, except if Allah wills otherwise. Their reward in Paradise is an uninterrupted and endless gift from Allah, not subject to any limitation or termination.
orig: وأما الذين سعدوا ففي الجنة خالدين فيها ما دامت السماوات والأرض إلا ما شاء ربك عطاء غير مجذوذ

translation: So do not be in doubt, [O Muhammad], as to what those [polytheists] are worshipping. They worship not except as their fathers worshipped before. And indeed, We will fully recompense them their portion undiminished.
interpretation: The interpretation is that Allah is instructing the Prophet Muhammad not to have any doubt about the false beliefs and practices of the idolaters. They are merely blindly following the misguided ways of their forefathers without any rational basis. However, Allah assures that He will fully recompense them for their actions, without any reduction or injustice.
orig: فلا تك في مرية مما يعبد هؤلاء ما يعبدون إلا كما يعبد آباؤهم من قبل وإنا لموفوهم نصيبهم غير منقوص

translation: And We did certainly give Moses the Book, but differences arose over it. And had it not been for a word that preceded from your Lord, it would have been judged between them. And indeed they are, concerning it, in disquieting doubt.
interpretation: Allah gave the Torah to Prophet Moses, but the people disagreed and differed over its interpretation and commandments. Had it not been for Allah's prior decree to delay judgement until the Day of Resurrection, He would have judged between them in this life regarding their differences. However, the disbelievers remain in disturbing doubt concerning the Quran revealed to Prophet Muhammad.
orig: ولقد آتينا موسى الكتاب فاختلف فيه ولولا كلمة سبقت من ربك لقضي بينهم وإنهم لفي شك منه مريب

translation: And verily, to each, your Lord will pay back in full their deeds. Surely, He is Well-Acquainted with what they do.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah is fully aware of every person's actions and intentions, and He will justly recompense each individual according to their deeds. No action will go unrewarded or unpunished. This serves as a reminder of Allah's perfect justice and knowledge, motivating people to be mindful of their actions and strive for righteousness.
orig: وإن كلا لما ليوفينهم ربك أعمالهم إنه بما يعملون خبير

translation: So remain on a right course as you have been commanded, along with those who turn to Allah with you, and do not transgress. Indeed, He is Seeing of what you do.
interpretation: The interpretation is: "Adhere firmly to the straight path that Allah has commanded you and those who repent with you. Do not deviate from it or exceed the proper limits, for Allah is Watchful over your deeds and will hold you accountable for them."
orig: فاستقم كما أمرت ومن تاب معك ولا تطغوا إنه بما تعملون بصير

translation: And do not incline toward those who do wrong, lest the Fire should touch you, and you would not have other than Allah any protectors, then you would not be helped.
interpretation: This verse warns against inclining towards or siding with the wrongdoers and oppressors. It cautions that doing so may lead one to be touched by the punishment of the Fire, and that there will be no protectors or helpers besides Allah to save them from this punishment.
orig: ولا تركنوا إلى الذين ظلموا فتمسكم النار وما لكم من دون الله من أولياء ثم لا تنصرون

translation: And establish prayer at the two ends of the day and at the approach of the night. Indeed, good deeds remove the evil deeds. That is a reminder for those who remember.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of performing the obligatory prayers at their appointed times, specifically the morning (Fajr), late afternoon ('Asr), and evening (Maghrib) prayers, as well as the night prayer (Isha). It also mentions that doing good deeds, such as performing prayers and other righteous acts, can erase the effects of previous sins and misdeeds. This serves as a reminder and encouragement for the believers to remain mindful of Allah and strive to do good deeds.
orig: وأقم الصلاة طرفي النهار وزلفا من الليل إن الحسنات يذهبن السيئات ذلك ذكرى للذاكرين

translation: And be patient, for indeed, Allah does not allow the reward of the doers of good to be lost.
interpretation: This verse encourages patience and perseverance in the face of adversity, with the promise that Allah will not allow the efforts and good deeds of the righteous to go unrewarded. It instills hope and motivation to remain steadfast on the path of righteousness, as the ultimate recompense from Allah is guaranteed for those who do good.
orig: واصبر فإن الله لا يضيع أجر المحسنين

translation: If only there had been among the generations before you people remaining with wisdom, who could forbid corruption on earth - except for a few whom We saved from among them. But the wrongdoers pursued the luxuries they were indulged in, and thus became criminals.
interpretation: Allah is questioning why there were not more people of understanding and wisdom in the previous generations who could have prevented corruption and mischief on earth. Only a few were saved from destruction because they heeded the warning and refrained from indulging in sinful luxuries. The majority, however, pursued their worldly pleasures and became transgressors deserving of punishment.
orig: فلولا كان من القرون من قبلكم أولو بقية ينهون عن الفساد في الأرض إلا قليلا ممن أنجينا منهم واتبع الذين ظلموا ما أترفوا فيه وكانوا مجرمين

translation: And your Lord would not have destroyed the towns unjustly, while their people were reformers.
interpretation: Allah does not destroy towns and villages unjustly while their inhabitants are obedient and righteous. He only punishes those who persist in disbelief, wrongdoing, and corruption after clear signs and warnings have been sent to them. This verse affirms Allah's justice and mercy, as He does not punish anyone except for a valid reason.
orig: وما كان ربك ليهلك القرى بظلم وأهلها مصلحون

translation: And if your Lord had willed, He could have made mankind one community; but they will not cease to differ.
interpretation: Allah is stating that if He had willed, He could have created all of humanity as a single nation following one religion and belief system without any differences. However, it is part of His divine wisdom and plan to allow differences and diversity among people in terms of beliefs, ideologies, and ways of life. This diversity serves as a test for people to exercise their free will and make choices, leading to accountability on the Day of Judgment.
orig: ولو شاء ربك لجعل الناس أمة واحدة ولا يزالون مختلفين

translation: Except those on whom your Lord has bestowed His Mercy. And for that He created them. And the Word of your Lord has been fulfilled: 'Surely I shall fill Hell with jinn and men together.'
interpretation: "This verse indicates that God's mercy is not extended to everyone, but only to those whom He has willed to receive it. It also affirms that the creation of humans and jinn was for a specific purpose determined by God. Additionally, it declares that Hell will be filled with both jinn and humans who have strayed from the path of righteousness, as a fulfillment of God's decree."
orig: إلا من رحم ربك ولذلك خلقهم وتمت كلمة ربك لأملأن جهنم من الجنة والناس أجمعين

translation: And all the stories of the messengers We relate to you in order to strengthen your heart thereby; and in this (Qur'an) there has come to you the truth, as well as an exhortation and a reminder for the believers.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the stories of the previous messengers narrated in the Qur'an serve to strengthen the Prophet's heart and resolve in facing difficulties and persevering in conveying the message of Islam. These stories contain the truth about the struggles of the prophets and their ultimate victory through faith and perseverance. They serve as lessons, exhortations, and reminders for the believers to remain steadfast in their belief and follow the path of righteousness.
orig: وكلا نقص عليك من أنباء الرسل ما نثبت به فؤادك وجاءك في هذه الحق وموعظة وذكرى للمؤمنين

translation: And say to those who do not believe, "Work according to your position, indeed, we are working.
interpretation: This verse is instructing the Prophet Muhammad to tell the disbelievers to continue doing what they are doing based on their position and beliefs, and that the believers will also continue working according to their faith and convictions. It suggests that both parties should persist in their ways, while implying that the truth will eventually become evident, and the believers will be vindicated for their efforts.
orig: وقل للذين لا يؤمنون اعملوا على مكانتكم إنا عاملون

translation: And wait, indeed we are waiting.
interpretation: This verse is a warning and a challenge from Allah to the disbelievers who rejected the message of Islam. It suggests that the disbelievers should wait for the consequences of their rejection, and Allah and His believers will also wait patiently, as they are certain of the truth and the eventual victory of Islam. It implies that the truth will prevail, and the disbelievers will face the consequences of their actions.
orig: وانتظروا إنا منتظرون

translation: And to Allah belong the unseen of the heavens and the earth, and to Him the matter will return in its entirety, so worship Him and put your trust in Him. And your Lord is not unaware of what you do.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes Allah's absolute knowledge and sovereignty over all that is unseen in the heavens and the earth. It instructs us to worship Allah alone, putting our complete trust in Him, for He is fully aware of all our actions and nothing escapes His knowledge. The "matter" refers to all affairs and events that will ultimately return to Allah for judgment and recompense.
orig: ولله غيب السماوات والأرض وإليه يرجع الأمر كله فاعبده وتوكل عليه وما ربك بغافل عما تعملون

translation: Alif Laam Raa. These are the verses of the Manifest Book.
interpretation: This verse consists of the Arabic letters 'Alif Laam Raa', known as the 'Muqatta'aat' or 'disjointed letters'. Their precise meaning is known only to Allah. However, they serve to draw attention to the divine origin and inimitable nature of the Qur'an. The verse then affirms that the subsequent verses are from the 'Manifest Book', referring to the clear and enlightening guidance of the Qur'an.
orig: الر تلك آيات الكتاب المبين

translation: Indeed, We have sent it down as an Arabic Qur'an that you might understand.
interpretation: This verse highlights the wisdom behind the revelation of the Qur'an in the Arabic language. It was revealed in a language that the Arabs could easily comprehend so that they might use their intellect to ponder over its teachings and guidance. The Arabic language, with its rich vocabulary and eloquent expression, serves as the perfect medium to convey the profound truths and universal message of the Qur'an.
orig: إنا أنزلناه قرآنا عربيا لعلكم تعقلون

translation: We relate unto you (Muhammad) the best of stories through Our Revelations unto you, of this Qur'an. And before this (Scripture), you were among those who knew nothing about it.
interpretation: This verse suggests that the Qur'an contains the most excellent narratives and teachings, revealed by Allah to guide humanity. It implies that before receiving divine revelation, the Prophet Muhammad was unaware of these profound truths, which Allah has now imparted to him through the Qur'an.
orig: نحن نقص عليك أحسن القصص بما أوحينا إليك هذا القرآن وإن كنت من قبله لمن الغافلين

translation: When Yusuf said to his father, 'O my father! I have seen eleven stars and the sun and the moon; I saw them prostrating themselves to me.'
interpretation: This verse refers to a dream that Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) had when he was young. The dream symbolically foretold his future status and the respect his family would have for him. The eleven stars represented his eleven brothers, while the sun and moon represented his parents. Their prostration in the dream indicated that one day they would all submit to Yusuf's authority and high rank, which was fulfilled when he became a powerful ruler in Egypt.
orig: إذ قال يوسف لأبيه يا أبت إني رأيت أحد عشر كوكبا والشمس والقمر رأيتهم لي ساجدين

translation: He said: 'O my son! Relate not your vision to your brothers, lest they should plot a plot against you, for Satan is to man an avowed enemy.'
interpretation: The interpretation is that the father is warning his son Yusuf (Joseph) against telling his brothers about his dream, in which he saw eleven stars and the sun and moon prostrating before him. This is because the brothers may become jealous and plot against him out of envy. The verse also highlights that Satan is an open enemy to humans, seeking to misguide them and sow discord among them.
orig: قال يا بني لا تقصص رؤياك على إخوتك فيكيدوا لك كيدا إن الشيطان للإنسان عدو مبين

translation: And thus will your Lord choose you and teach you the interpretation of narratives and complete His favor upon you and upon the family of Jacob, as He completed it formerly upon your forefathers, Abraham and Isaac. Indeed, your Lord is Knowing and Wise.
interpretation: This verse indicates that God has chosen the Prophet Muhammad and will teach him the true interpretation of events and narratives mentioned in the Quran. It also states that God will complete His favor upon the Prophet and his followers, just as He had previously bestowed His favor upon the Prophets Abraham and Isaac and their families. The verse emphasizes that God is All-Knowing and All-Wise in His choices and actions.
orig: وكذلك يجتبيك ربك ويعلمك من تأويل الأحاديث ويتم نعمته عليك وعلى آل يعقوب كما أتمها على أبويك من قبل إبراهيم وإسحاق إن ربك عليم حكيم

translation: There were certainly signs in Joseph and his brothers for the inquirers.
interpretation: This verse suggests that the story of Prophet Joseph and his brothers contains profound lessons and signs pointing to Allah's wisdom, power, and the truth of His message. The trials and events that Joseph and his brothers went through serve as reminders and examples for those who sincerely seek guidance and reflect upon the signs of Allah in the world around them.
orig: لقد كان في يوسف وإخوته آيات للسائلين

translation: When they said, 'Truly Joseph and his brother are dearer to our father than we, although we are a strong group. Indeed, our father is in clear error.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the jealousy and resentment of Joseph's brothers towards him and his brother Benjamin, as they felt that their father Jacob favored them more. They accused their father of being in "clear error" for showing more love and affection to Joseph and Benjamin. This interpretation highlights the theme of sibling rivalry and the consequences of envy and prejudice.
orig: إذ قالوا ليوسف وأخوه أحب إلى أبينا منا ونحن عصبة إن أبانا لفي ضلال مبين

translation: Kill Joseph or cast him out to some land, so that your father's favor will be exclusively for you, and you will be a righteous people after that.
interpretation: This verse refers to the jealous brothers of Prophet Joseph plotting against him out of envy for the special love and attention their father Jacob had for Joseph. They suggested either killing Joseph or banishing him from their land, thinking that this would make their father's love exclusively theirs and they would become righteous afterwards. However, this was a sinful and misguided plan stemming from jealousy and ill intentions towards their brother.
orig: اقتلوا يوسف أو اطرحوه أرضا يخل لكم وجه أبيكم وتكونوا من بعده قوما صالحين

translation: A speaker among them said, 'Do not kill Joseph, but throw him into the bottom of the well; some caravan may pick him up - if you must do something.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the plot of Joseph's brothers against him. One of them suggested that instead of killing Joseph, they should throw him into a well so that he may be found by a passing caravan. This would allow them to get rid of Joseph without directly committing murder. The interpretation highlights the deceitful intentions of Joseph's brothers and their lack of compassion towards their own brother.
orig: قال قائل منهم لا تقتلوا يوسف وألقوه في غيابت الجب يلتقطه بعض السيارة إن كنتم فاعلين

translation: They said: 'O our father! Why do you not trust us with Yusuf (Joseph) while we are indeed his well-wishers?'
interpretation: The brothers of Yusuf (Joseph) questioned their father Ya'qub's (Jacob's) lack of trust in them regarding Yusuf, claiming that they were sincere well-wishers and advisors for Yusuf's welfare.
orig: قالوا يا أبانا ما لك لا تأمنا على يوسف وإنا له لناصحون

translation: Send him with us tomorrow that he may enjoy himself and play, and verily, we shall take good care of him.
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as the brothers of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) trying to convince their father to send Yusuf with them by making false promises of taking good care of him. They wanted to get rid of Yusuf out of jealousy and resentment towards the love their father had for him.
orig: أرسله معنا غدا يرتع ويلعب وإنا له لحافظون

translation: He said: 'Truly it saddens me that you should take him away, and I fear lest the wolf should devour him while you are heedless of him.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Jacob (peace be upon him) when his sons asked to take their brother Benjamin with them. Jacob expresses his deep sadness at the thought of being separated from Benjamin, and his fear that a wolf might harm him while they are not vigilant enough in protecting him. The verse highlights Jacob's paternal love, concern, and apprehension for his son's safety.
orig: قال إني ليحزنني أن تذهبوا به وأخاف أن يأكله الذئب وأنتم عنه غافلون

translation: They said, 'If the wolf devours him while we are a strong group, then we would indeed be losers.'
interpretation: The verse is referring to the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) and his brothers. The brothers are expressing their concern that if the wolf were to devour Yusuf while they are a strong group, they would be considered failures and losers for not protecting him adequately. The verse highlights their sense of responsibility towards their younger brother and their fear of facing consequences if any harm were to come to him due to their negligence.
orig: قالوا لئن أكله الذئب ونحن عصبة إنا إذا لخاسرون

translation: So when they went away with him and agreed to put him into the bottom of the well, and We revealed to him that: 'You shall inform them of this affair of theirs when they perceive not.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) when his brothers plotted to get rid of him by throwing him into a well. Despite their evil intentions, Allah revealed to Yusuf that he would eventually inform them of their misdeed when they least expect it. This interpretation highlights Allah's protection and guidance for His chosen ones, even in the midst of adversity.
orig: فلما ذهبوا به وأجمعوا أن يجعلوه في غيابت الجب وأوحينا إليه لتنبئنهم بأمرهم هذا وهم لا يشعرون

translation: And they came to their father in the evening, weeping.
interpretation: This verse refers to the sons of Prophet Jacob (peace be upon him) returning to their father after leaving their younger brother Joseph behind, weeping and pretending to be grieved over his supposed death by a wolf. Their deceitful act was a test from Allah to Prophet Jacob for his patience and trust in the Divine plan.
orig: وجاءوا أباهم عشاء يبكون

translation: They said, "O our father, indeed we went racing with one another and left Joseph with our possessions, and the wolf ate him. But you would not believe us, even if we were truthful."
interpretation: The brothers of Joseph lied to their father about what happened to Joseph. They claimed that they left him with their belongings while they were racing, and a wolf attacked and ate him. They tried to convince their father that they were telling the truth, but their father did not believe them because he knew they were lying.
orig: قالوا يا أبانا إنا ذهبنا نستبق وتركنا يوسف عند متاعنا فأكله الذئب وما أنت بمؤمن لنا ولو كنا صادقين

translation: And they brought his shirt stained with false blood. He said, "Rather, your souls enticed you to something, so patience is most fitting. And Allah is the one sought for help against what you describe."
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident where Joseph's brothers brought his shirt stained with false blood as evidence to their father Jacob, claiming that Joseph had been killed by a wolf. However, Jacob did not believe their lie and remained patient, trusting in Allah's plan. The verse highlights the importance of patience and seeking Allah's help in difficult situations, even when faced with deception and betrayal.
orig: وجاءوا على قميصه بدم كذب قال بل سولت لكم أنفسكم أمرا فصبر جميل والله المستعان على ما تصفون

translation: And there came a caravan, and they sent their water-drawer. He let down his bucket into the well. He said: 'Good news! Here is a youth.' And they concealed him as merchandise, and Allah knew what they were doing.
interpretation: This verse describes the incident when Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) was taken out of the well by a caravan passing by. The caravan's water-drawer saw Yusuf in the well and exclaimed 'Good news! Here is a youth.' The caravan then decided to conceal Yusuf and sell him as merchandise, unaware that Allah was fully aware of their actions.
orig: وجاءت سيارة فأرسلوا واردهم فأدلى دلوه قال يا بشرى هذا غلام وأسروه بضاعة والله عليم بما يعملون

translation: And they sold him for a low price, a few dirhams counted out. And they were, concerning him, among the indifferent.
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident where Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) was sold by his brothers for a very low price, despite his great value. It highlights their indifference and lack of appreciation for their own brother, whom they treated like a commodity to be traded for a meager sum. The verse condemns their callous behavior and underscores the depths of jealousy and resentment that led them to commit such an act against their own flesh and blood.
orig: وشروه بثمن بخس دراهم معدودة وكانوا فيه من الزاهدين

translation: And the one from Egypt who bought him said to his wife, 'Make his residence honorable. Perhaps he will benefit us, or we may adopt him as a son.' And thus We established Joseph in the land to teach him the interpretation of events. And Allah is predominant over His affair, but most of the people do not know.
interpretation: This verse describes how Joseph was bought by a man from Egypt who recognized his potential and instructed his wife to treat Joseph well, hoping that he may benefit them or they could adopt him as a son. It also mentions that Allah established Joseph in the land and taught him the interpretation of dreams and events, as Allah has control over all affairs, though most people do not realize this.
orig: وقال الذي اشتراه من مصر لامرأته أكرمي مثواه عسى أن ينفعنا أو نتخذه ولدا وكذلك مكنا ليوسف في الأرض ولنعلمه من تأويل الأحاديث والله غالب على أمره ولكن أكثر الناس لا يعلمون

translation: And when he attained his full strength, We gave him wisdom and knowledge. Thus do We reward the doers of good.
interpretation: This verse indicates that when a person reaches maturity and full mental capacity, Allah bestows upon them wisdom and knowledge as a reward for their righteousness and good deeds. It emphasizes that those who do good and strive to follow the right path will be blessed with understanding, insight, and knowledge from Allah.
orig: ولما بلغ أشده آتيناه حكما وعلما وكذلك نجزي المحسنين

translation: And she, in whose house he was, sought to seduce him. She closed the doors and said, 'Come on, you.' He said, '[I seek] the refuge of Allah. Indeed, he is my lord, who has made good my residence. Indeed, wrongdoers will not succeed.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) and the wife of Al-Aziz who tried to seduce him. Despite her attempts to lure him by closing the doors and inviting him, Yusuf refused and sought refuge in Allah, recognizing that succumbing to her advances would be a grave sin and wrongdoing. He affirmed his faith in Allah, who had blessed him and provided him with a good residence, and declared that wrongdoers, like those who commit adultery, will never succeed or prosper.
orig: وراودته التي هو في بيتها عن نفسه وغلقت الأبواب وقالت هيت لك قال معاذ الله إنه ربي أحسن مثواي إنه لا يفلح الظالمون

translation: And she certainly determined [to seduce] him, and he would have inclined to her had he not seen the proof of his Lord. Thus [it was] that We should avert from him the evil and the immorality. Indeed, he was of Our chosen servants.
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that Zulaikha (the wife of al-Aziz) was determined to seduce Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) and he would have been inclined towards her if he had not seen a clear sign from Allah that reminded him of His Lord's greatness and power. This sign saved him from falling into the evil and immorality that Zulaikha desired. Prophet Yusuf was one of Allah's sincere and devoted servants, which is why Allah protected him from this trial.
orig: ولقد همت به وهم بها لولا أن رأى برهان ربه كذلك لنصرف عنه السوء والفحشاء إنه من عبادنا المخلصين

translation: And they raced to the door, and she tore his shirt from the back, and they found her husband at the door. She said, 'What is the recompense of one who intended evil for your wife but that he be imprisoned or a painful punishment?'
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident involving Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) and the wife of Al-Aziz (a high-ranking official) in Egypt. When she tried to seduce Yusuf, he fled towards the door, and she tore his shirt from behind. Her husband witnessed this scene, and she accused Yusuf of having ill intentions towards her. The verse highlights her attempt to justify her actions and demand punishment for Yusuf, despite being the one who had tried to commit an immoral act.
orig: واستبقا الباب وقدت قميصه من دبر وألفيا سيدها لدى الباب قالت ما جزاء من أراد بأهلك سوءا إلا أن يسجن أو عذاب أليم

translation: He said, "It was she who sought to seduce me," and a witness of her household bore witness, "If his shirt is torn from the front, then she has told the truth, and he is of the liars.
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident where Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) was falsely accused of attempted seduction by the wife of Al-Aziz (a high-ranking official). The verse presents Yusuf's defense, where he claims that it was the woman who tried to seduce him. A witness from her household testifies that if Yusuf's shirt is torn from the front, it would prove that the woman was telling the truth and Yusuf was lying. The physical evidence on Yusuf's shirt would reveal who was actually trying to seduce whom.
orig: قال هي راودتني عن نفسي وشهد شاهد من أهلها إن كان قميصه قد من قبل فصدقت وهو من الكاذبين

translation: And if his shirt is torn from the back, then she has told the truth, and he is of the liars.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) and the wife of al-Aziz (a ruler in Egypt at that time) who tried to seduce him. The torn shirt is presented as evidence - if it is torn from the back, it means that Yusuf was fleeing from her advances, proving his innocence and her guilt of attempting to seduce him. The interpretation highlights the importance of evaluating evidence objectively to arrive at the truth.
orig: وإن كان قميصه قد من دبر فكذبت وهو من الصادقين

translation: So when he saw his shirt torn from behind, he said: 'Indeed, it is of your guile. Surely, your guile is great.'
interpretation: The verse refers to the incident where Yusuf (Joseph) was falsely accused of attempting to seduce the wife of the Egyptian official he worked for. When the woman's attempt to seduce Yusuf failed, she tore his shirt from behind as he tried to leave. Upon seeing his torn shirt, Yusuf realized that it was a plot by the woman and her female companions to frame him, and he acknowledged the greatness of their deception or "guile".
orig: فلما رأى قميصه قد من دبر قال إنه من كيدكن إن كيدكن عظيم

translation: O Joseph, turn away from this [affair]. And you, [wife], ask forgiveness for your sin. Indeed, you were of the sinful.
interpretation: The interpretation is that God is commanding Prophet Joseph to turn away from the temptation of the wife of Al-Aziz and reject her advances. At the same time, God is commanding the wife to repent and seek forgiveness for her sinful desire and attempt to seduce Joseph. Her actions were a grave sin, and she is being called to acknowledge her wrongdoing and repent sincerely.
orig: يوسف أعرض عن هذا واستغفري لذنبك إنك كنت من الخاطئين

translation: And women in the city said, "The wife of the 'Aziz is seeking to seduce her slave boy; he has impassioned her with love. Verily, we see her in manifest error."
interpretation: "The interpretation of this verse is that the women in the city gossiped about the wife of Al-Aziz (a high-ranking official) attempting to seduce her slave boy, Yusuf (Joseph). They observed that she was deeply in love with him, and they considered her actions to be a clear misguidance and deviation from the right path."
orig: وقال نسوة في المدينة امرأت العزيز تراود فتاها عن نفسه قد شغفها حبا إنا لنراها في ضلال مبين

translation: So when she heard of their accusation, she sent for them and prepared a banquet for them; she gave each one of them a knife and said [to Joseph], "Come out before them." And when they saw him, they exalted him and cut their hands and said, "Perfect is Allah! This is not a human being. This is none but a noble angel."
interpretation: This verse describes the incident when the women of the city accused Joseph (peace be upon him) of trying to seduce the wife of Al-Aziz. When she heard their accusations, she invited them to her house and prepared a banquet. She gave each woman a knife and asked Joseph to come out before them. When the women saw Joseph's beauty, they were so awestruck that they cut their hands unintentionally, exclaiming that he could not be a mere human but rather a noble angel. This incident highlights Joseph's exceptional beauty and the women's intense admiration for him, despite their initial accusations.
orig: فلما سمعت بمكرهن أرسلت إليهن وأعتدت لهن متكأ وآتت كل واحدة منهن سكينا وقالت اخرج عليهن فلما رأينه أكبرنه وقطعن أيديهن وقلن حاش لله ما هذا بشرا إن هذا إلا ملك كريم

translation: She said, "It was he who solicited me," and a witness of her household bore witness, "If his shirt is torn from the front, then she has told the truth, and he is of the liars. And if his shirt is torn from the back, then she has lied, and he is of the truthful."
interpretation: The verse is referring to the incident where Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) was falsely accused by the wife of Al-Aziz of attempting to seduce her. She is trying to justify her actions by blaming Yusuf, but a witness from her household intervenes and provides a way to determine the truth by examining Yusuf's shirt. The torn shirt would reveal who was truly seeking whom.
orig: قالت فذلكن الذي لمتنني فيه ولقد راودته عن نفسه فاستعصم ولئن لم يفعل ما آمره ليسجنن وليكونا من الصاغرين

translation: He said: "O my Lord! The prison is dearer to me than that to which they invite me. And if You do not avert their plot from me, I shall incline towards them and become one of the ignorant."
interpretation: In this verse, Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) is praying to Allah, asking Him to save him from the temptation and plot of the women who are trying to seduce him. He says that prison is better for him than committing the sin they are inviting him to. He also asks Allah to protect him from their plot, otherwise he fears that he may be inclined towards them and become one of the ignorant people who indulge in sinful acts.
orig: قال رب السجن أحب إلي مما يدعونني إليه وإلا تصرف عني كيدهن أصب إليهن وأكن من الجاهلين

translation: So his Lord accepted his prayer and averted their plan from him. Indeed, He is the All-Hearing, the All-Knowing.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah accepted the sincere supplication of the Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) and protected him from the plot of the women who tried to seduce him. It highlights Allah's attribute of being All-Hearing, meaning He hears all supplications, and All-Knowing, meaning He has complete knowledge of all situations and affairs. The deliverance of Prophet Yusuf demonstrates Allah's power to avert evil plans and protect those who turn to Him in sincere faith and righteousness.
orig: فاستجاب له ربه فصرف عنه كيدهن إنه هو السميع العليم

translation: Then after they had seen the signs, they resolved to imprison him for a time.
interpretation: This verse refers to the decision made by the disbelievers to imprison Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) after witnessing the clear signs and miracles that proved his truthfulness. Despite the evidence, they stubbornly chose to reject him and imprison him unjustly for a period of time, driven by their envy, arrogance, and refusal to accept the truth.
orig: ثم بدا لهم من بعد ما رأوا الآيات ليسجننه حتى حين

translation: And there entered the prison with him two young men. One of them said: 'Verily, I saw myself (in a dream) pressing wine.' The other said: 'Verily, I saw myself (in a dream) carrying bread on my head and birds were eating thereof.' (They said): 'Inform us of the interpretation of this. Verily, we think you are one of the Muhsinun (doers of good).'
interpretation: This verse describes two young men who were imprisoned with Prophet Yusuf (Joseph). Each of them had a dream that they narrated to Yusuf, seeking its interpretation. One dreamt of pressing wine, and the other of carrying bread on his head from which birds were eating. They recognized Yusuf's piety and sought his help in interpreting their dreams, believing him to be a righteous person capable of providing the true meaning.
orig: ودخل معه السجن فتيان قال أحدهما إني أراني أعصر خمرا وقال الآخر إني أراني أحمل فوق رأسي خبزا تأكل الطير منه نبئنا بتأويله إنا نراك من المحسنين

translation: He said: "There will not come to you any food with which you are provided but I shall inform you of its interpretation before it comes to you. This is from what my Lord has taught me. Surely I have abandoned the religion of a people who do not believe in Allah and who are deniers of the Hereafter."
interpretation: This verse refers to Prophet Yusuf's (Joseph) interpretation of dreams while in prison. He tells his two fellow prisoners that before any food comes to them, he will inform them of its interpretation, which is a knowledge bestowed upon him by Allah. He also declares that he has abandoned the religion of those who disbelieve in Allah and deny the Hereafter.
orig: قال لا يأتيكما طعام ترزقانه إلا نبأتكما بتأويله قبل أن يأتيكما ذلكما مما علمني ربي إني تركت ملة قوم لا يؤمنون بالله وهم بالآخرة هم كافرون

translation: And I have followed the religion of my fathers, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob. It was not for us to associate anything with Allah. That is from the grace of Allah upon us and upon the people, but most people are not grateful.
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of following the pure monotheistic religion of the prophets Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, who were steadfast in worshipping Allah alone without associating any partners with Him. The Prophet Muhammad is affirming that he is following the same path of pure monotheism, which is a great blessing and favor from Allah upon him and all people. However, most people fail to recognize this blessing and do not show gratitude to Allah for guiding them to the straight path.
orig: واتبعت ملة آبائي إبراهيم وإسحاق ويعقوب ما كان لنا أن نشرك بالله من شيء ذلك من فضل الله علينا وعلى الناس ولكن أكثر الناس لا يشكرون

translation: O my two companions of the prison, are different lords better or Allah, the One, the Prevailing?
interpretation: The verse is emphasizing the oneness of God and rejecting the worship of multiple deities. It questions whether worshiping multiple lords or gods is better than worshiping the One True God, Allah, Who is Supreme and has absolute control over all things. The verse calls people to abandon polytheism and idol worship, and to embrace the belief in the Oneness of the Creator.
orig: يا صاحبي السجن أأرباب متفرقون خير أم الله الواحد القهار

translation: You worship not besides Him except [mere] names you have named, you and your forefathers, for which Allah has sent down no authority. The command belongs only to Allah. He has commanded that you worship not except Him. That is the correct religion, but most people do not know.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the falsehood of worshipping anything other than Allah. The idols and deities that people worship are mere names invented by humans, with no divine sanction or authority. True sovereignty and the right to be worshipped belong solely to Allah. He has commanded that we worship none but Him, for that is the true and upright religion. However, most people remain ignorant of this truth.
orig: ما تعبدون من دونه إلا أسماء سميتموها أنتم وآباؤكم ما أنزل الله بها من سلطان إن الحكم إلا لله أمر ألا تعبدوا إلا إياه ذلك الدين القيم ولكن أكثر الناس لا يعلمون

translation: O two companions of the prison! As for one of you, he will pour wine for his lord to drink; and as for the other, he will be crucified and from his head will the birds eat. The matter has been decreed concerning which you both did inquire.
interpretation: This verse refers to the interpretation of the dreams of the two prisoners who were in jail with Prophet Yusuf (Joseph). One of them would be released and serve wine to the king, while the other would be crucified and his head would be eaten by birds. The "matter" mentioned is the interpretation of their dreams, which was decreed by Allah.
orig: يا صاحبي السجن أما أحدكما فيسقي ربه خمرا وأما الآخر فيصلب فتأكل الطير من رأسه قضي الأمر الذي فيه تستفتيان

translation: And he said to the one whom he thought would be released of the two, "Mention me before your lord." But Satan caused him to forget the mention of his Lord, so he remained in prison for several years.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) in prison with two other men. One of them was to be released, and Yusuf asked him to mention him to the king so that he could be freed from the unjust imprisonment. However, Satan caused the man to forget mentioning Yusuf to the king, so Yusuf remained in prison for several more years. This highlights the test and tribulation that Yusuf faced, and how even after conveying the truth, he had to remain patient and trust in Allah's plan.
orig: وقال للذي ظن أنه ناج منهما اذكرني عند ربك فأنساه الشيطان ذكر ربه فلبث في السجن بضع سنين

translation: And the king said: 'Verily, I saw (in a dream) seven fat cows, whom seven lean ones were devouring, and seven green ears of corn, and seven others dry. O chiefs! Expound to me my vision, if you can interpret dreams.'
interpretation: This verse describes a dream seen by a king, in which he saw seven fat cows being devoured by seven lean ones, as well as seven green ears of corn and seven dry ones. He then asks his chiefs to interpret this dream for him, as they claim to have the ability to interpret dreams. The dream symbolizes a period of prosperity followed by a period of famine or hardship. The interpretation highlights the importance of being prepared for difficult times and managing resources wisely.
orig: وقال الملك إني أرى سبع بقرات سمان يأكلهن سبع عجاف وسبع سنبلات خضر وأخر يابسات يا أيها الملأ أفتوني في رؤياي إن كنتم للرؤيا تعبرون

translation: They said, 'These are mere dreams, and we are not interpreters of dreams.'
interpretation: This verse suggests that the people dismissed the dreams or visions described as meaningless fantasies, and they lacked the knowledge or ability to interpret them properly. It implies a rejection or disregard for the significance of dreams or revelations, considering them as mere illusions without any deeper spiritual or prophetic meaning.
orig: قالوا أضغاث أحلام وما نحن بتأويل الأحلام بعالمين

translation: And he who was saved of the two said, 'I will inform you of its interpretation, so send me forth.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) in the Qur'an. The one who was saved is the man who was imprisoned with Yusuf and had a dream that Yusuf interpreted for him. He asks to be sent to the king to interpret the king's dream, as he has faith in Yusuf's ability to provide the correct interpretation.
orig: وقال الذي نجا منهما وادكر بعد أمة أنا أنبئكم بتأويله فأرسلون

translation: Joseph, O truthful one, explain to us about seven fat cows being eaten by seven lean ones, and seven green ears of corn and others dry, so that I may return to the people that they might have knowledge.
interpretation: This verse refers to the dream of the king of Egypt, which Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) interpreted. The seven fat cows represent seven prosperous years, while the seven lean cows symbolize seven years of famine that will follow. Similarly, the seven green ears of corn signify the seven prosperous years, and the dry ones represent the years of famine. Through this dream, Allah was preparing Yusuf to guide the people in storing grain during the years of prosperity to sustain them during the famine years.
orig: يوسف أيها الصديق أفتنا في سبع بقرات سمان يأكلهن سبع عجاف وسبع سنبلات خضر وأخر يابسات لعلي أرجع إلى الناس لعلهم يعلمون

translation: He said: 'You shall sow for seven years diligently, and what you reap you shall leave in the ear, except a little whereof you eat.'
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as an advice given by Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) to the king of Egypt regarding the management of agricultural resources during the years of abundance and famine. He advised the king to cultivate the land diligently for seven years and store the harvested grains, leaving only a small portion for consumption. This was in preparation for the coming years of famine, allowing them to utilize the stored grains and survive the difficult times.
orig: قال تزرعون سبع سنين دأبا فما حصدتم فذروه في سنبله إلا قليلا مما تأكلون

translation: Then there will come after that seven difficult [years] which will consume what you advanced [stored] for them, except a little from what you will have guarded.
interpretation: This verse is referring to a prophecy about a period of seven years of drought and famine that will follow the seven years of abundance mentioned earlier. During this time of hardship, the people will consume most of the provisions they stored during the plentiful years, leaving only a small amount remaining that they were able to protect and preserve.
orig: ثم يأتي من بعد ذلك سبع شداد يأكلن ما قدمتم لهن إلا قليلا مما تحصنون

translation: Then will come a year after that, when people will be given rain and in it they shall press (wine and oil).
interpretation: This verse refers to a year of abundance and prosperity after a period of hardship. The "giving of rain" symbolizes relief and blessings, while "pressing" wine and oil signifies productivity, sustenance, and enjoyment of life's pleasures after difficulties. It conveys the cyclical nature of life, where difficulties are temporary and followed by times of ease and bounty.
orig: ثم يأتي من بعد ذلك عام فيه يغاث الناس وفيه يعصرون

translation: And the king said, 'Bring him to me.' But when the messenger came to him, [Joseph] said, 'Return to your master and ask him what is the case of the women who cut their hands. Indeed, my Lord is Knowing of their plot.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident when the women of the city gossiped about Zulaikha's infatuation with Prophet Yusuf (Joseph), peace be upon him. When the king summoned Yusuf, he asked the king to inquire about the truth from those women who had cut their hands, as they were witnesses to what had transpired. Yusuf was confident that Allah was aware of their scheming and the truth would be revealed.
orig: وقال الملك ائتوني به فلما جاءه الرسول قال ارجع إلى ربك فاسأله ما بال النسوة اللاتي قطعن أيديهن إن ربي بكيدهن عليم

translation: He said: "What was the matter with you when you sought to seduce Joseph?" They said: "Allah forbid! We know of no evil against him." The wife of the ruler said: "Now the truth is manifest; it was I who sought to seduce him, and he is indeed one of the truthful.
interpretation: Allah is clarifying the truth about the incident of Yusuf (Joseph) and the women who tried to seduce him. The women denied any wrongdoing, but the wife of the ruler admitted that she was the one who tried to seduce Yusuf, and that he was truthful in rejecting her advances. This verse highlights the importance of truthfulness and admitting one's mistakes.
orig: قال ما خطبكن إذ راودتن يوسف عن نفسه قلن حاش لله ما علمنا عليه من سوء قالت امرأت العزيز الآن حصحص الحق أنا راودته عن نفسه وإنه لمن الصادقين

translation: That is so he may know that I did not betray him in secret, and that Allah does not guide the plot of the betrayers.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the truthfulness of the Prophet Muhammad and that he did not betray the trust placed in him by God. It also conveys the message that Allah does not guide those who betray and plot against others, as betrayal and deception are not in accordance with His guidance.
orig: ذلك ليعلم أني لم أخنه بالغيب وأن الله لا يهدي كيد الخائنين

translation: And I do not absolve myself of blame; the soul is certainly prone to evil, except for those on whom my Lord has bestowed His Mercy. Truly, my Lord is Oft-Forgiving, Most Merciful.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the inherent weakness and tendency towards evil in the human soul or self (nafs). However, it also highlights that through Allah's Mercy and Forgiveness, one can overcome this propensity for evil. The interpretation is that human beings are not infallible and are naturally inclined towards wrongdoing, but with sincere repentance and seeking Allah's guidance, they can be forgiven and purified from their sins and misdeeds. It encourages humility, self-awareness, and reliance on Allah's infinite Mercy and Forgiveness.
orig: وما أبرئ نفسي إن النفس لأمارة بالسوء إلا ما رحم ربي إن ربي غفور رحيم

translation: And the king said, "Bring him to me that I may appoint him exclusively for myself." And when he spoke to him, he said, "Verily, today you are with us high-ranking and fully trusted."
interpretation: "This verse suggests that the king recognized Yusuf's exceptional abilities and wisdom, and wanted to employ him exclusively in his service. When Yusuf was brought before him, the king declared that from that day onwards, Yusuf would hold a position of high rank and trust in his court. This highlights the idea that true merit and integrity are eventually recognized and rewarded."
orig: وقال الملك ائتوني به أستخلصه لنفسي فلما كلمه قال إنك اليوم لدينا مكين أمين

translation: He said, 'Appoint me over the storehouses of the land. Indeed, I will be a careful guardian.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) when he interpreted the dream of the king and asked to be put in charge of the storehouses and granaries of Egypt. It highlights Yusuf's confidence in his abilities to manage resources efficiently and responsibly, describing himself as "careful" and "knowledgeable".
orig: قال اجعلني على خزائن الأرض إني حفيظ عليم

translation: And thus We established Joseph in the land to settle therein wherever he willed. We bestow Our mercy on whom We please, and We never allow the reward of the righteous to be wasted.
interpretation: God granted Prophet Joseph authority and power in Egypt, allowing him to settle wherever he wished as a reward for his patience and righteousness. This verse emphasizes God's mercy, which He bestows upon whomever He wills, and that He never fails to reward those who do good deeds and remain steadfast in their faith.
orig: وكذلك مكنا ليوسف في الأرض يتبوأ منها حيث يشاء نصيب برحمتنا من نشاء ولا نضيع أجر المحسنين

translation: But the reward of the Hereafter is better for those who believed and were righteous.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that the ultimate and everlasting reward in the Hereafter is far superior to any worldly gains for those who have faith and lead a righteous life, fearing Allah and avoiding sins. It encourages believers to prioritize the eternal bliss of the Hereafter over temporary pleasures of this world.
orig: ولأجر الآخرة خير للذين آمنوا وكانوا يتقون

translation: And Joseph's brothers came and entered upon him; and he recognized them, but he was to them unknown.
