interpretation: This verse refers to the reunion of Prophet Joseph with his brothers after many years of separation. Despite recognizing them, he did not reveal his identity to them immediately. This could be interpreted as Joseph's wisdom and patience in dealing with a delicate situation, allowing events to unfold gradually before revealing the truth.
orig: وجاء إخوة يوسف فدخلوا عليه فعرفهم وهم له منكرون

translation: And when he had furnished them with their provisions, he said: Bring me a brother of yours from your father. Do you not see that I give full measure and that I am the best of hosts?
interpretation: In this verse, Yusuf (Joseph) is testing his brothers to see if they have changed and are now truthful. He demands that they bring their brother (Benjamin) as proof of their honesty, reminding them that he is generous and hospitable. This tests their sincerity and willingness to reunite the family after their past mistake of betraying Yusuf.
orig: ولما جهزهم بجهازهم قال ائتوني بأخ لكم من أبيكم ألا ترون أني أوفي الكيل وأنا خير المنزلين

translation: But if you do not bring him to me, there will be no measure [of provisions] for you with me, nor will you approach me.
interpretation: Allah is warning that if the brothers do not bring back Benjamin, they will be deprived of provisions and access to the prophet. This emphasizes the importance of honesty and fulfilling promises, as well as the consequences of breaking covenants with Allah and His messengers.
orig: فإن لم تأتوني به فلا كيل لكم عندي ولا تقربون

translation: They said, 'We will try to turn his father away from him, and we will surely do it.'
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as the brothers of Yusuf (Joseph) plotting to separate him from his father Ya'qub (Jacob). They planned to convince their father to send Yusuf away with them, so they could carry out their evil intentions against him without his father's knowledge or protection. The phrase "we will surely do it" shows their determination and resolve to execute their plan.
orig: قالوا سنراود عنه أباه وإنا لفاعلون

translation: And he said to his servants, "Put their merchandise back into their saddlebags so that they may recognize it when they return to their people, that they may come back."
interpretation: This verse suggests that the Prophet Joseph instructed his servants to secretly place the merchandise or goods that his brothers had brought back into their saddlebags. The purpose was so that when they returned home and discovered the goods, they would realize their mistake and come back to Joseph, allowing for reconciliation and the revelation of his true identity to them.
orig: وقال لفتيانه اجعلوا بضاعتهم في رحالهم لعلهم يعرفونها إذا انقلبوا إلى أهلهم لعلهم يرجعون

translation: But when they returned to their father, they said: 'O our father! The measure has been denied to us, so send our brother with us that we may obtain the measure, and indeed we will be its guardians.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) and his brothers. After being denied provisions due to not bringing their brother Benjamin, the brothers plead with their father Jacob to send Benjamin with them on their next journey, promising to guard and protect him. The verse highlights their desperation for provisions and their willingness to take responsibility for Benjamin's safety in order to obtain what they need.
orig: فلما رجعوا إلى أبيهم قالوا يا أبانا منع منا الكيل فأرسل معنا أخانا نكتل وإنا له لحافظون

translation: He said, 'Shall I trust you with him except as I trusted you with his brother before? But Allah is the best guardian, and He is the most merciful of the merciful.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) when his father Ya'qub (Jacob) was hesitant to send his youngest son Benjamin with his brothers, fearing they might harm him like they did with his brother Yusuf. The interpretation is that one should put their trust in Allah, who is the best protector and the most merciful, rather than relying solely on human assurances.
orig: قال هل آمنكم عليه إلا كما أمنتكم على أخيه من قبل فالله خير حافظا وهو أرحم الراحمين

translation: And when they opened their baggage, they found their merchandise returned to them. They said, 'O our father, what more could we desire? This, our merchandise, has been returned to us. We will get supplies for our family, protect our brother, and obtain an extra camel-load. That will be an easy measurement.'
interpretation: This verse describes the surprise and joy of Joseph's brothers when they found their merchandise returned to them upon opening their bags. They saw this as a blessing, allowing them to provide for their family, protect their brother Benjamin, and even obtain an extra camel-load of provisions. The phrase "easy measurement" suggests that this unexpected gain was a small but significant favor from God.
orig: ولما فتحوا متاعهم وجدوا بضاعتهم ردت إليهم قالوا يا أبانا ما نبغي هذه بضاعتنا ردت إلينا ونمير أهلنا ونحفظ أخانا ونزداد كيل بعير ذلك كيل يسير

translation: He said, 'I will not send him with you until you give me a solemn pledge by Allah that you will bring him back to me, unless you are surrounded.' And when they had given him their solemn pledge, he said, 'Allah is a Witness over what we say.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of keeping promises and upholding trust. It teaches that when entrusting someone with a responsibility, it is permissible to seek a binding pledge or guarantee, as long as it is done with sincere intentions and not out of mistrust or suspicion. The verse also highlights Allah's watchfulness over our words and actions, reminding us to be truthful and fulfill our commitments.
orig: قال لن أرسله معكم حتى تؤتون موثقا من الله لتأتنني به إلا أن يحاط بكم فلما آتوه موثقهم قال الله على ما نقول وكيل

translation: And he said: 'O my sons! Do not enter by one gate, but enter by different gates. And I cannot avail you against Allah at all. The decision is only for Allah. Upon Him I have relied, and upon Him let those who would rely, rely.'
interpretation: This verse is instructing Prophet Yaqub's (Jacob's) sons to enter a town through different gates, rather than all together through one gate. This was likely a precautionary measure to avoid drawing unwanted attention or suspicion. The verse also emphasizes that all power and control ultimately lies with Allah alone, and that one should place their trust and reliance solely upon Him.
orig: وقال يا بني لا تدخلوا من باب واحد وادخلوا من أبواب متفرقة وما أغني عنكم من الله من شيء إن الحكم إلا لله عليه توكلت وعليه فليتوكل المتوكلون

translation: And when they entered in the manner which their father had enjoined, it would not avail them against Allah at all except (it satisfied) a need of Jacob's inner self which he discharged. And verily, he was endowed with knowledge because We had taught him, but most of mankind know not.
interpretation: Allah est soulignant que lorsque les fils de Jacob ont suivi les instructions de leur père d'entrer séparément par différentes portes, cela n'a eu aucun effet sur le décret d'Allah. Leur père Jacob avait simplement une préoccupation intérieure qu'il cherchait à satisfaire par cette action, car il avait été béni de la connaissance par Allah. Cependant, la plupart des gens ne comprennent pas les sagesses derrière de tels actes.
orig: ولما دخلوا من حيث أمرهم أبوهم ما كان يغني عنهم من الله من شيء إلا حاجة في نفس يعقوب قضاها وإنه لذو علم لما علمناه ولكن أكثر الناس لا يعلمون

translation: And when they entered upon Joseph, he drew his brother closer and said, "Indeed, I am your brother, so do not despair over what they used to do."
interpretation: This verse describes the emotional reunion between Prophet Joseph and his brother Benjamin. After years of separation and hardship, Joseph revealed his true identity to his brother, reassuring him not to grieve over the past difficulties they had faced. The interpretation highlights Joseph's compassion, forgiveness, and desire to comfort his brother, emphasizing the importance of strong family bonds and letting go of past sorrows.
orig: ولما دخلوا على يوسف آوى إليه أخاه قال إني أنا أخوك فلا تبتئس بما كانوا يعملون

translation: So when he furnished them with their provisions, he put the drinking cup into his brother's saddle-bag, then a crier cried out: 'O you people of the caravan! You are indeed thieves.'
interpretation: This verse describes the strategy employed by Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) to detain his brother Binyamin (Benjamin) in Egypt. After providing provisions for his brothers' journey, he secretly placed a valuable drinking cup in Binyamin's bag as a pretext to accuse them of theft and keep Binyamin with him. The crier's declaration of them being thieves was a planned move to create a situation where Binyamin would be held back, fulfilling Yusuf's desire to have his brother stay with him.
orig: فلما جهزهم بجهازهم جعل السقاية في رحل أخيه ثم أذن مؤذن أيتها العير إنكم لسارقون

translation: They said, and turned to them, 'What is it that you are missing?'
interpretation: This verse suggests that the people being addressed were questioned about something they were lacking or missing. The interpretation could be that they were being asked to identify a need or deficiency they had, so that it could be addressed or fulfilled.
orig: قالوا وأقبلوا عليهم ماذا تفقدون

translation: They said: 'We miss the king's drinking cup, and for him who produces it, is (the reward of) a camel load; and I am bound by this (reward)'.
interpretation: This verse refers to an incident when the brothers of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) were accused of stealing the king's drinking cup. The interpretation is that the officials announced a reward of a camel's load for whoever could produce the missing cup. This was a test for Yusuf's brothers, and it ultimately led to the truth being revealed about Yusuf's innocence and the reuniting of the family.
orig: قالوا نفقد صواع الملك ولمن جاء به حمل بعير وأنا به زعيم

translation: They said: 'By Allah, you certainly know that we did not come to commit mischief in the land, and we are not thieves.'
interpretation: This verse suggests that the brothers of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) were denying any wrongdoing or intention to cause harm when they were accused of theft. They swore by Allah that their purpose was not to spread corruption or engage in criminal activities like stealing. This emphasizes their claim of innocence and their attempt to clear their names from the allegations made against them.
orig: قالوا تالله لقد علمتم ما جئنا لنفسد في الأرض وما كنا سارقين

translation: They said, 'Then what would be the penalty for him if you are among the liars?'
interpretation: This verse is questioning the consequence or punishment that should be given if the claim made by the speaker is proven to be false. It implies a challenge to the truthfulness of the speaker's statement and demands accountability if they are found to be lying.
orig: قالوا فما جزاؤه إن كنتم كاذبين

translation: They said: 'The penalty for this, if he is proved guilty, is that the person in whose bag it is found shall receive the penalty prescribed. Thus do we punish the wrongdoers.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident when Prophet Yusuf's (Joseph's) brothers accused him of theft by planting the king's drinking cup in his bag. The interpretation is that they proposed a punishment for theft, which was to enslave the person in whose belongings the stolen item was found. This was their way of punishing the wrongdoers or those who committed crimes like theft.
orig: قالوا جزاؤه من وجد في رحله فهو جزاؤه كذلك نجزي الظالمين

translation: So he began with their bags before the bag of his brother, then he extracted it from the bag of his brother. Thus did We plan for Joseph. He could not have taken his brother within the religion of the king except that Allah willed. We raise in degrees whom We will, but over every possessor of knowledge is one [more] knowing.
interpretation: Allah enabled Joseph to plant the king's cup in his brother's bag as part of His plan to keep Benjamin with Joseph. Joseph could not have detained his brother according to the king's law unless Allah willed it. Allah elevates whom He wills in ranks and status. Above every knowledgeable person is the One who is more knowledgeable, referring to Allah's perfect and absolute knowledge.
orig: فبدأ بأوعيتهم قبل وعاء أخيه ثم استخرجها من وعاء أخيه كذلك كدنا ليوسف ما كان ليأخذ أخاه في دين الملك إلا أن يشاء الله نرفع درجات من نشاء وفوق كل ذي علم عليم

translation: They said, 'If he steals - a brother of his has stolen before.' But Joseph kept it secret within himself and did not reveal it to them. He said, 'You are in a worse position, and Allah is most knowing of what you describe.'
interpretation: The interpretation is that Joseph's brothers accused Benjamin of stealing, referring to their previous false accusation against Joseph himself of stealing. Joseph kept his knowledge of their past crime secret and did not reveal it to them. Instead, he pointed out that they were in a worse position by falsely accusing Benjamin, and that Allah knew the truth about what they were describing.
orig: قالوا إن يسرق فقد سرق أخ له من قبل فأسرها يوسف في نفسه ولم يبدها لهم قال أنتم شر مكانا والله أعلم بما تصفون

translation: They said: "O exalted one, he has a very old father, so take one of us in his place. Indeed, we see you as a doer of good."
interpretation: The brothers of Joseph pleaded with the ruler of Egypt to take one of them as a prisoner in place of Benjamin, as they knew that their aged father would be deeply grieved if Benjamin did not return. They appealed to the ruler's sense of kindness and justice, recognizing him as a "doer of good."
orig: قالوا يا أيها العزيز إن له أبا شيخا كبيرا فخذ أحدنا مكانه إنا نراك من المحسنين

translation: Mu'adh said, 'Allah forbid that we should take anything but what we find our goods with, for then indeed we should be wrongdoers.'
interpretation: Mu'adh was emphasizing the importance of honesty and integrity. He declared that it would be wrong for them to take anything that did not belong to them, even if they found their own belongings with someone else. Taking what is not rightfully theirs would make them wrongdoers or oppressors. This verse highlights the Islamic values of truthfulness, justice, and respecting the property rights of others.
orig: قال معاذ الله أن نأخذ إلا من وجدنا متاعنا عنده إنا إذا لظالمون

translation: So when they despaired of him, they went in private for consultation. The eldest among them said: "Do you not know that your father took from you a solemn pledge in Allah's Name? And aforetime you failed in your duty with Yusuf (Joseph). Therefore I will not leave this land until my father permits me, or Allah commands me. And He is the Best of judges.
interpretation: The eldest brother reminds them of their father's covenant with them regarding Joseph, and that they had failed to keep their promise before. He declares that he will not leave the land until their father allows him or Allah commands him, as Allah is the best judge of their situation.
orig: فلما استيأسوا منه خلصوا نجيا قال كبيرهم ألم تعلموا أن أباكم قد أخذ عليكم موثقا من الله ومن قبل ما فرطتم في يوسف فلن أبرح الأرض حتى يأذن لي أبي أو يحكم الله لي وهو خير الحاكمين

translation: Go back to your father and say, 'O our father! Indeed, your son has stolen, and we did not testify except to what we knew. And we were not guardians of the unseen.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident where the brothers of Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) accused him of stealing, even though they knew he was innocent. The interpretation is that one should speak the truth and not bear false witness, even against a close relative. It also highlights the limitations of human knowledge, as the brothers could not know the unseen reality behind the incident.
orig: ارجعوا إلى أبيكم فقولوا يا أبانا إن ابنك سرق وما شهدنا إلا بما علمنا وما كنا للغيب حافظين

translation: And ask the town where we have been and the caravan in which we traveled and indeed, we are truthful
interpretation: This verse instructs the Prophet Muhammad to inquire from the people of the town where the incident involving Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) took place, as well as the caravan that brought his brothers to Egypt. By doing so, the truthfulness of their story would be confirmed, as it was a well-known event in that region. The phrase "we are truthful" emphasizes the sincerity and honesty of the narrators, assuring the authenticity of the account.
orig: واسأل القرية التي كنا فيها والعير التي أقبلنا فيها وإنا لصادقون

translation: He said, "Nay, but your souls have enticed you to something. So (for me) patience is most fitting. It may be that Allah will bring them to me all together. Truly He! Only He is the All-Knowing, the All-Wise."
interpretation: This verse encourages patience and trust in Allah during difficult times. It suggests that one's soul or desires may lead them astray, but the proper response is to exercise patience and have faith that Allah, in His wisdom and knowledge, will ultimately guide one to the right path and resolve any difficulties.
orig: قال بل سولت لكم أنفسكم أمرا فصبر جميل عسى الله أن يأتيني بهم جميعا إنه هو العليم الحكيم

translation: And he turned away from them and said, 'Oh, my sorrow over Joseph,' and his eyes became white from grief, for he was a suppressor [of grief].
interpretation: This verse describes the deep sorrow and grief that Prophet Jacob felt over the loss of his son Joseph. Despite the intense pain, he suppressed his emotions and did not openly express his anguish. The phrase "his eyes became white from grief" is a metaphorical expression conveying the intensity of his sadness, to the point where his eyes lost their luster and became pale from constant weeping.
orig: وتولى عنهم وقال يا أسفى على يوسف وابيضت عيناه من الحزن فهو كظيم

translation: They said: 'By Allah, you will never cease remembering Yusuf until you become fatally ill or become of those who perish.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the deep grief and sorrow that Ya'qub (Jacob) felt over the loss of his son Yusuf (Joseph). His family members are criticizing him for being consumed by this grief, to the point where they fear it may lead to his demise or mental breakdown. The verse highlights the intensity of a father's love for his child and the profound impact that loss can have on one's emotional and psychological state.
orig: قالوا تالله تفتأ تذكر يوسف حتى تكون حرضا أو تكون من الهالكين

translation: He said, "I only complain of my suffering and my grief to Allah, and I know from Allah that which you do not know."
interpretation: This verse suggests that when faced with difficulties or hardships, one should turn to Allah and complain to Him alone, as He is the only One who truly knows what is in a person's heart and mind. It also implies that there are aspects of divine knowledge that humans are unaware of, and that we should trust in Allah's wisdom and plan.
orig: قال إنما أشكو بثي وحزني إلى الله وأعلم من الله ما لا تعلمون

translation: O my sons, go and find out about Joseph and his brother, and do not despair of relief from Allah. Indeed, no one despairs of relief from Allah except the disbelieving people.
interpretation: This verse encourages the believers to maintain hope and trust in Allah's mercy and relief, even in the most difficult circumstances. It advises Jacob's sons not to lose hope in finding Joseph and his brother, as despair is a trait of disbelievers who lack faith in Allah's power and wisdom. The verse reminds us that no matter how bleak the situation may seem, Allah's help and relief are always possible for those who have faith and perseverance.
orig: يا بني اذهبوا فتحسسوا من يوسف وأخيه ولا تيأسوا من روح الله إنه لا ييأس من روح الله إلا القوم الكافرون

translation: So when they came to him, they said, 'O 'Aziz, adversity has touched us and our family, and we have come with scant merchandise. But give us full measure and be charitable to us. Indeed, Allah rewards the charitable.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of being charitable and generous towards others, especially those in need. The brothers of Joseph, who had previously wronged him, are now facing hardship and adversity themselves. They approach Joseph, whom they do not recognize, and appeal to his sense of compassion and generosity. Despite their past actions, they seek kindness and charity from him, acknowledging that Allah rewards those who are charitable. The verse teaches us to be forgiving, compassionate, and to help those in need, even if they have wronged us in the past.
orig: فلما دخلوا عليه قالوا يا أيها العزيز مسنا وأهلنا الضر وجئنا ببضاعة مزجاة فأوف لنا الكيل وتصدق علينا إن الله يجزي المتصدقين

translation: He said: 'Do you know what you did with Joseph and his brother when you were ignorant?'
interpretation: This verse is referring to the incident when Joseph's brothers plotted against him and threw him into a well out of jealousy. The interpretation is that Allah is reminding them of their ignorant actions in the past, when they wronged their brother Joseph due to their lack of understanding and spiritual guidance.
orig: قال هل علمتم ما فعلتم بيوسف وأخيه إذ أنتم جاهلون

translation: They said: 'Are you indeed Yusuf?' He said: 'I am Yusuf, and this is my brother. Allah has indeed been gracious to us. Verily, whosoever fears Allah and is patient, then Allah does not waste the reward of the good-doers.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of patience, gratitude, and trust in God. Despite the trials and difficulties that Yusuf and his brother faced, they remained steadfast in their faith and righteousness. The interpretation emphasizes that those who fear God and persevere with patience will be rewarded by Him, as He does not neglect the efforts of the virtuous.
orig: قالوا أإنك لأنت يوسف قال أنا يوسف وهذا أخي قد من الله علينا إنه من يتق ويصبر فإن الله لا يضيع أجر المحسنين

translation: They said: 'By Allah, indeed Allah has preferred you over us, and we were certainly sinners.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the moment when Prophet Yusuf's (Joseph) brothers realized their mistake and acknowledged that Allah had favored him over them due to his piety and righteousness. They admitted that they had wronged him out of jealousy and sinfulness. The interpretation highlights the importance of repentance, humility, and recognizing one's faults before Allah.
orig: قالوا تالله لقد آثرك الله علينا وإن كنا لخاطئين

translation: He (Allah) will say: 'No reproach this day shall be on you, and Allah will forgive you, and He is the most Merciful of the merciful.'
interpretation: This verse indicates that on the Day of Judgment, Allah will forgive the believers for their sins and mistakes, and there will be no blame or reproach upon them. It highlights Allah's infinite mercy and compassion towards His servants who believed in Him and sought His forgiveness.
orig: قال لا تثريب عليكم اليوم يغفر الله لكم وهو أرحم الراحمين

translation: Go with this shirt of mine and cast it over the face of my father; he will become seeing. And bring me your family all together
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that Prophet Yusuf (Joseph) instructed his brothers to take his shirt and place it over the face of their father, Prophet Ya'qub (Jacob), who had become blind from excessive grief over the loss of his son. By doing so, his sight would be restored by the will of Allah. Yusuf also asked his brothers to bring their entire family to him, indicating his desire for reunification after the long period of separation.
orig: اذهبوا بقميصي هذا فألقوه على وجه أبي يأت بصيرا وأتوني بأهلكم أجمعين

translation: And when the caravan departed, their father said: 'I do indeed sense the presence of Joseph, were it not that you think me doting'
interpretation: This verse refers to a moment when Jacob (peace be upon him), the father of Joseph, sensed the presence or scent of his long-lost son Joseph, even though the caravan carrying Joseph had already departed. Jacob's statement suggests his strong intuition and deep connection with his son, despite the physical distance between them. It also highlights Jacob's unwavering faith and trust in God's plan, as he held onto the hope of reuniting with Joseph, despite the difficulties and doubts expressed by those around him.
orig: ولما فصلت العير قال أبوهم إني لأجد ريح يوسف لولا أن تفندون

translation: They said, 'By Allah, you are surely persisting in your old error.'
interpretation: This verse suggests that the disbelievers accused the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) of persisting in his old ways or beliefs, which they considered misguided or erroneous. They were mocking his message and accusing him of stubbornly clinging to his "old error," referring to his preaching of monotheism and rejection of idolatry. This verse highlights the opposition and ridicule faced by the Prophet from the disbelievers, who refused to accept his teachings and accused him of being misguided.
orig: قالوا تالله إنك لفي ضلالك القديم

translation: Then when the bearer of good tidings arrived, he cast it on his face, and his vision returned. He said, "Did I not tell you that I know from Allah what you do not know?"
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Jacob and his son Joseph. When Jacob received the good news that his son Joseph was alive, he regained his vision which he had lost due to excessive grief. Jacob's statement "Did I not tell you that I know from Allah what you do not know?" indicates his firm belief and trust in Allah's wisdom, even during difficult times.
orig: فلما أن جاء البشير ألقاه على وجهه فارتد بصيرا قال ألم أقل لكم إني أعلم من الله ما لا تعلمون

translation: They said: 'O our father! Ask forgiveness for us for our sins, indeed we have been sinners.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the sons of Prophet Ya'qub (Jacob) confessing their wrongdoing to their father and asking for his forgiveness. It highlights the importance of repentance, seeking forgiveness from Allah and from those we have wronged, and the significance of maintaining good family relations and respect for parents.
orig: قالوا يا أبانا استغفر لنا ذنوبنا إنا كنا خاطئين

translation: He said, 'I will ask forgiveness for you from my Lord. Indeed, it is He who is the Forgiving, the Merciful.'
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that the speaker, whose identity is not specified, promises to seek forgiveness from God on behalf of others. The verse highlights two of God's attributes: al-Ghafoor (the Forgiving) and al-Raheem (the Merciful). This emphasizes God's willingness to forgive those who sincerely repent and seek His forgiveness, as well as His infinite mercy towards His creation.
orig: قال سوف أستغفر لكم ربي إنه هو الغفور الرحيم

translation: And when they entered upon Joseph, he embraced his parents and said, "Enter Egypt, God willing, safe [and secure]."
interpretation: This verse refers to the emotional reunion of Prophet Joseph with his parents after many years of separation. Joseph embraced his parents with love and affection, welcoming them to Egypt and assuring them that they would be safe and secure there by God's will. The interpretation highlights Joseph's gratitude, compassion, and trust in God's protection.
orig: فلما دخلوا على يوسف آوى إليه أبويه وقال ادخلوا مصر إن شاء الله آمنين

translation: And he raised his parents upon the throne, and they bowed to him in prostration. And he said: 'O my father, this is the interpretation of my dream of old. My Lord has made it true, and He was indeed good to me when He took me out of the prison and brought you from the desert after the Shaytan had incited discord between me and my brothers. Truly, my Lord is Most Courteous to what He wills. Verily, He Alone is the All-Knowing, the All-Wise.'
interpretation: This verse describes the fulfillment of Prophet Yusuf's dream, in which he saw his parents and brothers prostrating before him. It shows the high status and honor that Allah bestowed upon Yusuf after his trials and tribulations. It also highlights Allah's wisdom, knowledge, and ability to turn adverse circumstances into favorable ones for those who remain patient and steadfast in their faith.
orig: ورفع أبويه على العرش وخروا له سجدا وقال يا أبت هذا تأويل رؤياي من قبل قد جعلها ربي حقا وقد أحسن بي إذ أخرجني من السجن وجاء بكم من البدو من بعد أن نزغ الشيطان بيني وبين إخوتي إن ربي لطيف لما يشاء إنه هو العليم الحكيم

translation: My Lord, You have given me some of the sovereignty and taught me the interpretation of dreams. O Creator of the heavens and the earth, You are my Protector in this world and the Hereafter. Cause me to die a Muslim and join me with the righteous.
interpretation: This verse expresses gratitude to Allah for the blessings He has bestowed, including sovereignty and the ability to interpret dreams. It also acknowledges Allah as the Creator and Protector, and humbly asks Him to grant a Muslim death and entry into Paradise among the righteous believers. The speaker recognizes Allah's power and mercy, and submits to His will in both this life and the Hereafter.
orig: رب قد آتيتني من الملك وعلمتني من تأويل الأحاديث فاطر السماوات والأرض أنت وليي في الدنيا والآخرة توفني مسلما وألحقني بالصالحين

translation: That is from the news of the unseen which We reveal to you, [O Muhammad]. And you were not with them when they cast their pens as to which of them should be entrusted with Mary and you were not with them when they disputed.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the story of Mary and her miraculous conception of Jesus is part of the unseen knowledge that Allah revealed to the Prophet Muhammad. He was not present when the priests cast lots to decide who would be entrusted with raising Mary, nor when they disputed over that matter. This shows that the Qur'an contains true information that could only come from divine revelation.
orig: ذلك من أنباء الغيب نوحيه إليك وما كنت لديهم إذ أجمعوا أمرهم وهم يمكرون

translation: And most of the people, although you strive [for it], are not believers.
interpretation: This verse indicates that despite the efforts and sincere attempts of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to guide people to the right path, most people will not embrace faith or believe in the message of Islam. It implies that disbelief and rejection of the truth are prevalent among the majority of people, even when presented with clear evidence and guidance. The verse suggests that the Prophet should not be disheartened by this reality, as it is a natural consequence of people's inclinations and the test of faith.
orig: وما أكثر الناس ولو حرصت بمؤمنين

translation: And you do not ask them for a reward for it. It is not except a reminder for the worlds.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) did not demand any payment or compensation from people for conveying the message of Islam. His mission was solely to remind and guide humanity, as the Qur'an is a reminder and source of guidance for all people and nations.
orig: وما تسألهم عليه من أجر إن هو إلا ذكر للعالمين

translation: And how many a sign within the heavens and earth do they pass over while they are turning away from it.
interpretation: This verse highlights the heedlessness of mankind towards the countless signs and proofs of Allah's existence and power that are present in the heavens and earth. Despite being surrounded by these clear evidences, many people remain oblivious or turn away from reflecting upon them and recognizing their Creator.
orig: وكأين من آية في السماوات والأرض يمرون عليها وهم عنها معرضون

translation: But most of them do not believe in Allah except while they associate others with Him.
interpretation: This verse criticizes the polytheists who claim to believe in Allah but associate partners with Him in worship. Their belief is tainted by their association of others with Allah, which contradicts the pure monotheism taught in Islam. The verse highlights the incoherence and inconsistency of their beliefs and practices.
orig: وما يؤمن أكثرهم بالله إلا وهم مشركون

translation: Have they become secure that the overwhelming punishment of Allah will not come upon them or that the Hour will not come upon them suddenly while they do not perceive?
interpretation: This verse questions the disbelievers' false sense of security and warns them against being heedless of Allah's punishment and the coming of the Day of Resurrection unexpectedly. It implies that their arrogance and rejection of faith should not make them feel safe from Allah's wrath, which can strike them at any time without warning.
orig: أفأمنوا أن تأتيهم غاشية من عذاب الله أو تأتيهم الساعة بغتة وهم لا يشعرون

translation: Say, 'This is my way; I invite to Allah with insight, I and whoever follows me. And exalted is Allah; and I am not of those who associate others with Him.'
interpretation: This verse instructs the Prophet Muhammad to declare that his way and method of calling people to Allah is based on clear insight, knowledge, and certainty, not mere conjecture or imitation. He and his followers invite others to the worship of Allah alone, without associating any partners with Him. The verse also affirms the transcendence and perfection of Allah, declaring that the Prophet is not among those who commit shirk (associating others with Allah).
orig: قل هذه سبيلي أدعو إلى الله على بصيرة أنا ومن اتبعني وسبحان الله وما أنا من المشركين

translation: And We sent not before you except men to whom We revealed from among the people of cities. So have they not traveled through the earth and observed how was the end of those before them? And the home of the Hereafter is best for those who fear Allah; then will you not reason?
interpretation: الله تعالى يخبر أنه لم يرسل قبل نبيه محمد صلى الله عليه وسلم إلا رجالاً من البشر، يوحي إليهم من أهل القرى والمدن، فلم يتأمل هؤلاء المشركون في مصير الأمم السابقة التي كذبت رسلها وكيف كان عاقبتهم الدمار والهلاك؟ وإن دار الآخرة هي الخير الحقيقي والنعيم المقيم للذين اتقوا الله واتبعوا رسله، أفلا يستعملون عقولهم ويتدبرون؟
orig: وما أرسلنا من قبلك إلا رجالا نوحي إليهم من أهل القرى أفلم يسيروا في الأرض فينظروا كيف كان عاقبة الذين من قبلهم ولدار الآخرة خير للذين اتقوا أفلا تعقلون

translation: Until, when the messengers gave up hope and thought that they were denied, Our victory came to them, and We saved whom We willed, but Our punishment cannot be averted from the people who are criminals.
interpretation: Allah is telling us that when the messengers lost hope and thought that their people would never believe in the message, Allah's help and victory came to them. He saved whomever He willed from among the believers, but His punishment is inevitable for those who persist in disbelief and disobedience.
orig: حتى إذا استيأس الرسل وظنوا أنهم قد كذبوا جاءهم نصرنا فنجي من نشاء ولا يرد بأسنا عن القوم المجرمين

translation: Indeed in their stories, there is a lesson for men of understanding. It (the Qur'an) is not a forged statement but a confirmation of the existing Scripture and a detailed explanation of everything, and a guidance and mercy for the people who believe.
interpretation: The stories of the previous prophets mentioned in the Qur'an contain valuable lessons for those who reflect and use their intellect. The Qur'an is not a fabricated book, but rather it confirms the divine scriptures that came before it and provides a detailed explanation of all religious and worldly matters. It serves as a guide and a mercy for those who have faith.
orig: لقد كان في قصصهم عبرة لأولي الألباب ما كان حديثا يفترى ولكن تصديق الذي بين يديه وتفصيل كل شيء وهدى ورحمة لقوم يؤمنون

translation: These are Verses of the Book, and that which has been revealed unto you from your Lord is the Truth, but most people do not believe.
interpretation: This verse affirms the truth and divine origin of the Qur'an, which has been revealed by Allah to the Prophet Muhammad. However, it also highlights the unfortunate reality that most people reject or disbelieve in this divine revelation, despite its clear and undeniable truth.
orig: المر تلك آيات الكتاب والذي أنزل إليك من ربك الحق ولكن أكثر الناس لا يؤمنون

translation: Allah is He Who raised the heavens without any pillars that you can see. Then He settled Himself on the Throne. And He has subjected the sun and the moon, each running for an appointed term. He manages all affairs, explaining the signs in detail, that you may be certain of meeting your Lord.
interpretation: This verse highlights Allah's absolute power and sovereignty over the entire universe. The raising of the heavens without visible pillars is a sign of His might. His settling on the Throne symbolizes His authority and control. The subjection of the sun and moon to their precise orbits for a fixed term demonstrates His meticulous planning. He governs all affairs with wisdom, revealing signs for those who reflect, so that they may be convinced of the inevitability of meeting Him on the Day of Judgment.
orig: الله الذي رفع السماوات بغير عمد ترونها ثم استوى على العرش وسخر الشمس والقمر كل يجري لأجل مسمى يدبر الأمر يفصل الآيات لعلكم بلقاء ربكم توقنون

translation: And it is He who spread out the earth and placed therein firm mountains and rivers and from all of the fruits He made therein two mates. He causes the night to cover the day. Indeed in that are signs for a people who give thought.
interpretation: This verse highlights Allah's power as the Creator and Sustainer of the universe. It describes how He spread out the earth, established firm mountains and rivers, and created pairs of fruits. The alternation of night and day is also mentioned as a sign of His might. The verse invites people to contemplate these signs and recognize the greatness of the Creator.
orig: وهو الذي مد الأرض وجعل فيها رواسي وأنهارا ومن كل الثمرات جعل فيها زوجين اثنين يغشي الليل النهار إن في ذلك لآيات لقوم يتفكرون

translation: And in the earth are neighboring parcels and gardens of grapevines and green crops and date palms, sharing one root system and separate root systems, watered by the same water; but We have made some of them exceed others in [quality of] fruit. Indeed in that are signs for a people who reason.
interpretation: Cette verse souligne la sagesse et la puissance de Dieu dans la création de la diversité dans la nature. Bien que toutes les plantes soient nourries par la même eau, elles diffèrent en qualité et en saveur des fruits qu'elles produisent. Cela montre que Dieu est le Créateur suprême qui contrôle tout selon Sa volonté et Sa sagesse. Cette diversité dans la création est un signe pour ceux qui réfléchissent et reconnaissent la grandeur de Dieu.
orig: وفي الأرض قطع متجاورات وجنات من أعناب وزرع ونخيل صنوان وغير صنوان يسقى بماء واحد ونفضل بعضها على بعض في الأكل إن في ذلك لآيات لقوم يعقلون

translation: And if you are astonished, [O Muhammad] - then amazing is their saying, 'When we are dust, will we indeed be [brought] into a new creation?' Those are the ones who have disbelieved in their Lord, and those will have shackles upon their necks, and those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally.
interpretation: This verse addresses the incredulity of the disbelievers towards the concept of resurrection after death. It states that if the Prophet Muhammad is amazed by their rejection of this belief, their statement questioning how they could be brought back to life after turning to dust is even more astonishing. It then declares that those who deny their Lord and reject the belief in resurrection will be shackled and will be the dwellers of Hellfire, where they will abide forever as a punishment for their disbelief.
orig: وإن تعجب فعجب قولهم أإذا كنا ترابا أإنا لفي خلق جديد أولئك الذين كفروا بربهم وأولئك الأغلال في أعناقهم وأولئك أصحاب النار هم فيها خالدون

translation: And they ask you to hasten on the punishment before the good, while there have already occurred before them similar punishments. And indeed, your Lord is the possessor of forgiveness for the people despite their wrongdoing. And indeed, your Lord is severe in penalty.
interpretation: This verse is addressing the disbelievers who mockingly demanded that the punishment be hastened upon them before any good befalls them. It reminds them that previous nations were also punished for their disbelief and wrongdoing. However, it also highlights that Allah is Forgiving towards people despite their transgressions, giving them opportunities to repent. At the same time, it warns that Allah is severe in punishing those who persist in disbelief and wrongdoing.
orig: ويستعجلونك بالسيئة قبل الحسنة وقد خلت من قبلهم المثلات وإن ربك لذو مغفرة للناس على ظلمهم وإن ربك لشديد العقاب

translation: And those who disbelieve say, 'Why has a sign not been sent down to him from his Lord?' You are only a warner, and for every people is a guide.
interpretation: This verse addresses the disbelievers who demand a miracle from the Prophet Muhammad as proof of his prophethood. The interpretation is: "The disbelievers demand that a sign or miracle be sent down to the Prophet from his Lord as evidence, but his role is only to warn people and guide them to the truth. Every nation has been sent a guide or messenger to show them the right path."
orig: ويقول الذين كفروا لولا أنزل عليه آية من ربه إنما أنت منذر ولكل قوم هاد

translation: Allah knows what every female carries and what the wombs lose or gain. And everything with Him is by due measure.
interpretation: This verse highlights Allah's perfect knowledge and wisdom. He knows the condition of every pregnant female, whether human or animal, and what is happening in their wombs. He knows if a pregnancy will result in a miscarriage or a successful birth, and if the child will be male or female. Nothing is hidden from His knowledge, and everything happens according to His precise plan and wisdom.
orig: الله يعلم ما تحمل كل أنثى وما تغيض الأرحام وما تزداد وكل شيء عنده بمقدار

translation: The Knower of the unseen and the witnessed, the Most Great, the Most High
interpretation: This verse describes Allah as the One who has complete knowledge of everything, both the unseen and the witnessed realms. He is the Greatest and Most Exalted, transcending all limitations and imperfections.
orig: عالم الغيب والشهادة الكبير المتعال

translation: Whether among you is he who conceals his speech, and he who speaks aloud, and he who hides himself by night and goes forth by day.
interpretation: This verse refers to Allah's all-encompassing knowledge and power. It indicates that whether one speaks secretly or openly, hides at night or moves about during the day, Allah is fully aware of all actions and intentions. No one can conceal anything from the Divine knowledge and authority. It serves as a reminder of accountability before Allah and the futility of attempting to hide from the All-Seeing and All-Knowing.
orig: سواء منكم من أسر القول ومن جهر به ومن هو مستخف بالليل وسارب بالنهار

translation: For him are angels in succession, before him and behind him, who guard him by Allah's command. Indeed, Allah does not change the condition of a people until they change what is within themselves. And when Allah intends for a people ill, there is no repelling it. And there is for them no protector other than Him.
interpretation: Cette interprétation souligne que Dieu a assigné des anges pour protéger chaque personne, mais que le changement positif ou négatif dans la vie d'une personne ou d'une communauté dépend de leurs propres actions et intentions. Dieu ne changera pas la condition d'un peuple tant qu'ils ne changeront pas ce qui est en eux-mêmes. S'ils font le mal, Dieu leur enverra des difficultés, et personne d'autre que Lui ne pourra les protéger. Cela met l'accent sur la responsabilité humaine et le libre arbitre, tout en affirmant que Dieu est l'Arbitre suprême.
orig: له معقبات من بين يديه ومن خلفه يحفظونه من أمر الله إن الله لا يغير ما بقوم حتى يغيروا ما بأنفسهم وإذا أراد الله بقوم سوءا فلا مرد له وما لهم من دونه من وال

translation: It is He who shows you the lightning, [causing] fear and aspiration, and generates the heavy clouds.
interpretation: This verse highlights Allah's power and majesty, as He is the One who creates the awe-inspiring phenomenon of lightning, which instills both fear and hope in people's hearts. The lightning serves as a reminder of Allah's might and a sign of His impending rain, which brings relief and sustenance. Additionally, Allah is the One who forms the dense clouds, carrying the precious rain that nourishes the earth and sustains life.
orig: هو الذي يريكم البرق خوفا وطمعا وينشئ السحاب الثقال

translation: And the thunder glorifies His praise, and the angels [too] from awe of Him. And He sends thunderbolts and strikes with them whomever He wills. Yet they dispute concerning Allah, though He is tremendous in might.
interpretation: This verse highlights Allah's power and majesty. The thunder and angels glorify Him out of awe and reverence. He sends thunderbolts to strike whomever He wills as a sign of His might. Yet, some people stubbornly dispute and deny Allah's existence despite the clear proofs of His power and control over the universe.
orig: ويسبح الرعد بحمده والملائكة من خيفته ويرسل الصواعق فيصيب بها من يشاء وهم يجادلون في الله وهو شديد المحال

translation: To Him belongs the supplication of truth, and those they call upon besides Him do not respond to them with anything, except like one who stretches his hands towards water so that it may reach his mouth, but it does not reach it. And the supplication of the disbelievers is only in vain.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that true supplication and worship belongs solely to Allah. Those who supplicate to others besides Allah, their supplications are futile and will not be answered, just like someone desperately trying to drink water by stretching out their hands but unable to reach it. The supplications of the disbelievers who reject Allah are misguided and in vain.
orig: له دعوة الحق والذين يدعون من دونه لا يستجيبون لهم بشيء إلا كباسط كفيه إلى الماء ليبلغ فاه وما هو ببالغه وما دعاء الكافرين إلا في ضلال

translation: And to Allah prostrates whatever is in the heavens and the earth, willingly or unwillingly, and their shadows in the mornings and the afternoons.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the absolute sovereignty and dominion of Allah over all of creation. Everything in the heavens and on earth, whether willingly or unwillingly, submits to Allah's command and prostrates before Him. Even their shadows, which are a manifestation of their existence, prostrate to Allah in the mornings and evenings, symbolizing the continuous and unwavering submission of all things to the Divine Will.
orig: ولله يسجد من في السماوات والأرض طوعا وكرها وظلالهم بالغدو والآصال

translation: Say, 'Who is the Lord of the heavens and the earth?' Say, 'Allah.' Say, 'Have you then taken protectors besides Him, who have no power to profit or harm even themselves?' Say, 'Are the blind and the seeing equal? Or are the darkness and light equal?' Have they ascribed to Allah partners who created the like of His creation, so that the creation seemed alike to them? Say, 'Allah is the Creator of all things, and He is the One, the Prevailing.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the Oneness and Uniqueness of Allah as the Lord and Creator of the heavens and the earth. It condemns the practice of associating partners with Allah, as these so-called partners have no power to benefit or harm anyone. The verse draws a comparison between the blind and the seeing, and between darkness and light, to highlight the stark contrast between truth and falsehood, guidance and misguidance. It questions how the polytheists can ascribe partners to Allah who create like His creation, when Allah alone is the Creator of all things, the One and the Irresistible.
orig: قل من رب السماوات والأرض قل الله قل أفاتخذتم من دونه أولياء لا يملكون لأنفسهم نفعا ولا ضرا قل هل يستوي الأعمى والبصير أم هل تستوي الظلمات والنور أم جعلوا لله شركاء خلقوا كخلقه فتشابه الخلق عليهم قل الله خالق كل شيء وهو الواحد القهار

translation: He sends down water from the sky, and the valleys flow according to their measure, and the torrent carries a rising foam. And from that [ore] which they heat in the fire, desiring to make ornaments or utensils, is a froth like it. Thus does Allah describe truth and falsehood. As for the froth, it will pass away, being cast off, but what benefits people remains on the earth. Thus does Allah present examples.
interpretation: This verse uses the metaphor of water and foam to illustrate the distinction between truth and falsehood. The water represents truth that is beneficial and lasting, while the foam represents falsehood that is temporary and ultimately worthless. The foam rises high but soon dissipates, just as falsehood may appear attractive initially but will eventually vanish. In contrast, the water that remains on the earth nourishes life, just as the truth benefits people and endures. Through this vivid imagery, Allah emphasizes the importance of discerning and holding fast to the truth, and rejecting that which is false and fleeting.
orig: أنزل من السماء ماء فسالت أودية بقدرها فاحتمل السيل زبدا رابيا ومما يوقدون عليه في النار ابتغاء حلية أو متاع زبد مثله كذلك يضرب الله الحق والباطل فأما الزبد فيذهب جفاء وأما ما ينفع الناس فيمكث في الأرض كذلك يضرب الله الأمثال

translation: For those who responded to their Lord is the best [reward]. But those who did not respond to Him - if they had all that is in the earth entirely and the like of it with it, they would [attempt to] ransom themselves thereby. Those will have the worst account, and their refuge is Hell, and wretched is the resting place.
interpretation: This verse contrasts the reward for those who answered the call of Allah and believed in Him, with the punishment for those who disbelieved. The believers will receive the best reward from Allah. As for the disbelievers, even if they possessed all the wealth in the world and twice as much, they would gladly give it all as a ransom to save themselves from the punishment on the Day of Judgment. However, no ransom will be accepted from them. They will suffer a terrible reckoning and their final abode will be Hell - a dreadful resting place.
orig: للذين استجابوا لربهم الحسنى والذين لم يستجيبوا له لو أن لهم ما في الأرض جميعا ومثله معه لافتدوا به أولئك لهم سوء الحساب ومأواهم جهنم وبئس المهاد

translation: Is one who knows that what has been revealed to you from your Lord is the truth like one who is blind? Only those of understanding receive admonition.
interpretation: This verse draws a distinction between those who recognize and accept the truth revealed by God, and those who are blind to it. It implies that true understanding and wisdom lies in acknowledging the divine revelations, while those who reject or ignore them are likened to the spiritually blind. The verse emphasizes that only people of sound intellect and contemplation can truly benefit from God's guidance and admonition.
orig: أفمن يعلم أنما أنزل إليك من ربك الحق كمن هو أعمى إنما يتذكر أولو الألباب

translation: Those who fulfill the Covenant of Allah and do not break the Covenant
interpretation: This verse refers to the believers who uphold their promises and covenants made with Allah. They fulfill the obligations set forth in the Qur'an and the teachings of Islam, and they do not violate or break the sacred covenant they have made with their Lord. It emphasizes the importance of being truthful, trustworthy, and steadfast in one's faith and commitments.
orig: الذين يوفون بعهد الله ولا ينقضون الميثاق

translation: And those who keep the covenant of Allah and do not break the covenant,
interpretation: This verse refers to those who honor their commitments and fulfill their obligations commanded by Allah, fearing His punishment and the severe reckoning on the Day of Judgment. It emphasizes the importance of being faithful to one's promises and duties, and having a profound reverence for Allah and accountability before Him.
orig: والذين يصلون ما أمر الله به أن يوصل ويخشون ربهم ويخافون سوء الحساب

translation: And those who patiently endure, seeking the Countenance of their Lord, and establish the prayer, and spend from what We have provided them secretly and openly, and repel evil with good - it is those for whom is the final attainment of the [eternal] home.
interpretation: This verse describes the qualities of the pious believers who will attain Paradise. It praises those who exercise patience and perseverance while seeking the pleasure of Allah, establish regular prayer, spend in charity both privately and publicly, and respond to harm with kindness and forgiveness. These virtuous actions lead them to the ultimate reward of the everlasting abode in the Hereafter.
orig: والذين صبروا ابتغاء وجه ربهم وأقاموا الصلاة وأنفقوا مما رزقناهم سرا وعلانية ويدرءون بالحسنة السيئة أولئك لهم عقبى الدار

translation: Gardens of perpetual residence; they will enter them with whoever was righteous among their fathers, their spouses, and their descendants. And the angels will enter upon them from every gate,
interpretation: This verse describes the reward that awaits the righteous believers in Paradise. They will be admitted to the eternal Gardens of Eden, along with their righteous family members, including parents, spouses, and children. Additionally, angels will welcome them from every entrance, signifying the honor and respect they will receive in the Hereafter for their faith and good deeds.
orig: جنات عدن يدخلونها ومن صلح من آبائهم وأزواجهم وذرياتهم والملائكة يدخلون عليهم من كل باب

translation: Peace be upon you for what you patiently endured. Excellent indeed is the final home.
interpretation: This verse is a greeting of peace and congratulations for those who patiently endured difficulties and trials in this life. It promises that the reward for their patience is an excellent and everlasting abode in the Hereafter. The interpretation highlights the virtue of patience and steadfastness in the face of hardships, as it leads to the ultimate reward of Paradise.
orig: سلام عليكم بما صبرتم فنعم عقبى الدار

translation: And those who break the covenant of Allah after its ratification, and sever what Allah has commanded to be joined, and spread corruption on earth - for them is the curse, and they will have the worst home.
interpretation: This verse refers to those who break their covenants with Allah after affirming them. They disobey Allah's commands to maintain ties of kinship and other relationships that Allah has ordained. They spread corruption, oppression and evil on earth. For such people, there is a curse in this life and an evil abode in the Hereafter.
orig: والذين ينقضون عهد الله من بعد ميثاقه ويقطعون ما أمر الله به أن يوصل ويفسدون في الأرض أولئك لهم اللعنة ولهم سوء الدار

translation: Allah expands the provision for whom He wills and restricts [it]. And they rejoice in the worldly life, while the worldly life compared to the Hereafter is not but a brief enjoyment.
interpretation: "Allah has complete control over sustenance and provisions. He grants abundance to whomever He wills and restricts it for others according to His wisdom. However, those who rejoice excessively in the temporary pleasures of this worldly life fail to recognize that it is fleeting and insignificant compared to the everlasting bliss of the Hereafter. The worldly life is merely a transient enjoyment, while the true and eternal happiness lies in the Hereafter."
orig: الله يبسط الرزق لمن يشاء ويقدر وفرحوا بالحياة الدنيا وما الحياة الدنيا في الآخرة إلا متاع

translation: And those who disbelieve say, 'Why has a sign not been sent down to him from his Lord?' Say, 'Indeed, Allah leaves astray whom He wills and guides to Himself whoever turns back [to Him].'
interpretation: This verse addresses the demand of the disbelievers for a miraculous sign from the Prophet Muhammad. It emphasizes that Allah guides whom He wills to the truth, and leaves astray those who stubbornly reject faith. The guidance or misguidance depends on one's willingness to turn towards Allah and accept the truth.
orig: ويقول الذين كفروا لولا أنزل عليه آية من ربه قل إن الله يضل من يشاء ويهدي إليه من أناب

translation: Those who have believed and whose hearts find peace in the remembrance of Allah. Surely, in the remembrance of Allah do hearts find peace.
interpretation: This verse highlights the spiritual tranquility and contentment that believers attain through remembering and being mindful of Allah. It emphasizes that the true source of peace and serenity for the heart lies in constantly turning one's thoughts and attention towards Allah through various acts of worship and contemplation. The remembrance of Allah serves as a remedy and solace for the restless human soul, providing a sense of inner calm, reassurance, and closeness to the Divine.
orig: الذين آمنوا وتطمئن قلوبهم بذكر الله ألا بذكر الله تطمئن القلوب

translation: Those who believe and do righteous deeds, for them is bliss and a beautiful place of return.
interpretation: This verse promises eternal bliss and a wonderful final abode in Paradise for those who have faith and perform good deeds. It highlights that genuine belief must be accompanied by righteous actions to attain the ultimate reward in the Hereafter.
orig: الذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات طوبى لهم وحسن مآب

translation: Thus We have sent you to a community before which other communities have passed on so you might recite to them that which We revealed to you, while they disbelieved in the Most Merciful. Say, "He is my Lord; there is no deity except Him. Upon Him I rely, and to Him is my return."
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the role of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) as a messenger sent to recite and convey the divine revelation to his community, just as messengers before him were sent to their respective nations. It highlights the rejection of the disbelievers towards the concept of the "Most Merciful" (Allah). The Prophet is instructed to declare his unwavering belief in the Oneness of Allah, his reliance upon Him, and his ultimate return to Him.
orig: كذلك أرسلناك في أمة قد خلت من قبلها أمم لتتلو عليهم الذي أوحينا إليك وهم يكفرون بالرحمن قل هو ربي لا إله إلا هو عليه توكلت وإليه متاب

translation: And if a Qur'an by which mountains could be moved, or the earth could be torn apart, or the dead could be made to speak [was sent down], but to Allah belongs the command entirely. Have those who believed not realized that if Allah had willed, He could have guided all humanity? And those who disbelieve will not cease to be struck by disaster because of what they have done, or it will descend near their home until the promise of Allah comes. Indeed, Allah does not fail in His promise.
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that the Qur'an is a mighty miracle from Allah, but its purpose is not to physically move mountains or tear apart the earth. Rather, its true miracle is in guiding humanity to the truth. However, Allah has given people free will to choose whether to believe or not. Those who disbelieve will face consequences for their actions, either in the form of disasters or punishments that will befall them, until the Day of Judgment arrives, for Allah's promise is true and will be fulfilled.
orig: ولو أن قرآنا سيرت به الجبال أو قطعت به الأرض أو كلم به الموتى بل لله الأمر جميعا أفلم ييأس الذين آمنوا أن لو يشاء الله لهدى الناس جميعا ولا يزال الذين كفروا تصيبهم بما صنعوا قارعة أو تحل قريبا من دارهم حتى يأتي وعد الله إن الله لا يخلف الميعاد

translation: And certainly were messengers ridiculed before you, but I prolonged for those who disbelieved their enjoyment; then I seized them, and how [severe] was My penalty.
interpretation: This verse reminds us that mocking and rejecting God's messengers is not a new phenomenon. Previous messengers were also ridiculed by their people, but Allah gave those disbelievers a respite and prolonged their enjoyment of worldly pleasures for a time. However, eventually, Allah seized them with His punishment, which was severe and inescapable. This serves as a warning against arrogance and disbelief, as Allah's justice will ultimately prevail.
orig: ولقد استهزئ برسل من قبلك فأمليت للذين كفروا ثم أخذتهم فكيف كان عقاب

translation: Is then one who is upright, and follows the right way, equal to him who is rebellious? Surely, Allah does not guide him who acts wrongfully, and has no helper.
interpretation: هذه الآية تقارن بين من يتبع الهدى ويسلك طريق الحق، وبين من يتمرد ويكفر بالله ويشرك به. فالمؤمن المتقي الذي يعمل الصالحات ليس كالكافر الضال الذي يشرك بالله ويعبد غيره. والله لا يهدي من يضل عن طريق الحق ويكفر به، فلا ناصر له ولا معين.
orig: أفمن هو قائم على كل نفس بما كسبت وجعلوا لله شركاء قل سموهم أم تنبئونه بما لا يعلم في الأرض أم بظاهر من القول بل زين للذين كفروا مكرهم وصدوا عن السبيل ومن يضلل الله فما له من هاد

translation: For them is a punishment in the life of this world, and the punishment of the Hereafter is more severe. And they will have no protector against Allah.
interpretation: "This verse emphasizes the severe consequences for those who reject faith and disobey God. They will face punishment in this worldly life through various difficulties and hardships, but the punishment in the Hereafter will be far more severe and unbearable. Moreover, they will have no one to protect or shield them from the wrath of God on the Day of Judgment."
orig: لهم عذاب في الحياة الدنيا ولعذاب الآخرة أشق وما لهم من الله من واق

translation: The example of the Garden which the pious have been promised, underneath which rivers flow, its produce is eternal and so is its shade. That is the reward for those who were conscious of Allah, while the reward of the disbelievers is the Fire.
interpretation: This verse presents a vivid metaphor contrasting the eternal bliss of Paradise promised to the righteous with the torment of Hellfire for the disbelievers. The "Garden" symbolizes the heavenly abode, nourished by rivers representing the unending bounties therein. Its everlasting fruits and shade signify the perpetual delight and tranquility enjoyed by the God-conscious. In contrast, the disbelievers' "reward" is the agonizing Hellfire, a stark warning against rejecting faith.
orig: مثل الجنة التي وعد المتقون تجري من تحتها الأنهار أكلها دائم وظلها تلك عقبى الذين اتقوا وعقبى الكافرين النار

translation: And those to whom We have given the Scripture rejoice in what has been revealed to you, and among the factions are some who deny a part of it. Say, "I am only commanded to worship Allah and not associate anything with Him. To Him I invite, and to Him is my return,"
interpretation: This verse addresses the different reactions to the revelation of the Qur'an. The People of the Book, who received previous scriptures, rejoice in the Qur'an's revelation as it confirms their beliefs. However, some factions reject parts of it due to their biases. The Prophet is commanded to worship Allah alone, associate no partners with Him, and invite others to this pure monotheism, for to Allah is the final return and accountability.
orig: والذين آتيناهم الكتاب يفرحون بما أنزل إليك ومن الأحزاب من ينكر بعضه قل إنما أمرت أن أعبد الله ولا أشرك به إليه أدعو وإليه مآب

translation: And thus We have sent it down as an Arabic Quran. And if you should follow their inclinations after what has come to you of knowledge, you would not have against Allah any ally or any protector.
interpretation: Allah is instructing the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to follow the Qur'an, which was revealed in the Arabic language. He warns that if the Prophet follows the desires and whims of the disbelievers after receiving the divine knowledge and guidance of the Qur'an, he will have no supporter or protector against Allah's punishment.
orig: وكذلك أنزلناه حكما عربيا ولئن اتبعت أهواءهم بعدما جاءك من العلم ما لك من الله من ولي ولا واق

translation: And We have certainly sent messengers before you and assigned to them wives and descendants. And it was not for any messenger to come with a sign except by permission of Allah. For every term is a decree.
interpretation: This verse highlights several key points: 1) Allah has sent many messengers before Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him. 2) These messengers had wives and children, indicating that they lived normal human lives. 3) No messenger can perform miracles or bring signs except by Allah's permission. 4) There is a predetermined time and decree for everything to occur, set by Allah's wisdom.
orig: ولقد أرسلنا رسلا من قبلك وجعلنا لهم أزواجا وذرية وما كان لرسول أن يأتي بآية إلا بإذن الله لكل أجل كتاب

translation: Allah eliminates what He wills and affirms [what He wills]. And with Him is the Mother of the Book.
interpretation: This verse highlights Allah's absolute power and authority over all creation. He has the ability to eliminate or remove whatever He wills from existence, and to affirm or establish whatever He desires. The "Mother of the Book" refers to the Preserved Tablet (Al-Lawh Al-Mahfudh), which contains the original and complete record of Allah's decrees and the destiny of all things. This emphasizes that Allah's knowledge and wisdom encompass everything, and nothing happens except by His will and command.
orig: يمحو الله ما يشاء ويثبت وعنده أم الكتاب

translation: And if We show you some of what We have promised them, or cause you to die [before its realization], then upon you is only the [duty of] notification, and upon Us is the account.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that the Prophet's responsibility is solely to convey the message, not to force people to believe or ensure its fulfillment. The realization of Allah's promises is up to Him, whether the Prophet witnesses it or not. His duty is to deliver the message faithfully, while accountability for people's deeds rests with Allah.
orig: وإن ما نرينك بعض الذي نعدهم أو نتوفينك فإنما عليك البلاغ وعلينا الحساب

translation: Do they not see that We are coming to the land, diminishing it from its outskirts? And Allah commands; there is no adjuster of His command. And He is swift in reckoning.
interpretation: This verse implies that Allah is All-Powerful and in complete control of the universe. The diminishing of the land from its outskirts is a sign of Allah's might and a reminder of the impermanence of this world. It serves as a warning that one day, this world will come to an end, and all will return to Allah for judgment. The verse emphasizes that Allah's command is final and cannot be overruled, and that He is swift in reckoning, implying the inevitability of accountability on the Day of Judgment.
orig: أولم يروا أنا نأتي الأرض ننقصها من أطرافها والله يحكم لا معقب لحكمه وهو سريع الحساب

translation: And those who were before them had plotted, but to Allah belongs all plotting. He knows what every soul earns, and the disbelievers will know who gets the good end.
interpretation: This verse warns against plotting and scheming against the truth. It reminds that although the disbelievers may devise plots, Allah has complete knowledge and control over all plots. He is aware of everyone's deeds and intentions. Ultimately, the disbelievers will come to know who attains the favorable outcome and eternal abode.
orig: وقد مكر الذين من قبلهم فلله المكر جميعا يعلم ما تكسب كل نفس وسيعلم الكفار لمن عقبى الدار

translation: And those who disbelieve say, 'You are not a messenger.' Say, 'Sufficient is Allah as Witness between me and you, and whoever has knowledge of the Scripture.'
interpretation: This verse addresses the denial of the disbelievers towards the Prophethood of Muhammad ﷺ. Allah instructs the Prophet to respond by affirming that Allah's testimony is sufficient, as He is fully aware of the truth. The verse also implies that those who truly understand the previous Scriptures would recognize the Prophet's mission as foretold.
orig: ويقول الذين كفروا لست مرسلا قل كفى بالله شهيدا بيني وبينكم ومن عنده علم الكتاب

translation: Alif, Lam, Ra. [This is] a Book which We have revealed to you, [O Muhammad], that you might bring mankind out of darknesses into the light by permission of their Lord - to the path of the Exalted in Might, the Praiseworthy.
interpretation: "This verse introduces the Qur'an as a divine revelation sent to guide humanity from the darkness of ignorance, disbelief, and misguidance towards the light of faith, knowledge, and righteousness. It emphasizes that the Qur'an is a means for spiritual enlightenment, guiding people to the straight path that leads to Allah, Who is Exalted in Might and deserving of all praise."
orig: الر كتاب أنزلناه إليك لتخرج الناس من الظلمات إلى النور بإذن ربهم إلى صراط العزيز الحميد

translation: Allah, to Whom belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. And woe to the disbelievers from a severe punishment.
interpretation: This verse affirms Allah's absolute sovereignty and ownership over all that exists in the heavens and the earth. It also serves as a stern warning to those who reject faith and disbelieve in Allah, that they will face a severe punishment for their disbelief.
orig: الله الذي له ما في السماوات وما في الأرض وويل للكافرين من عذاب شديد

translation: Those who prefer the life of this world over the Hereafter, and repel [people] from the way of Allah, and seek to make it crooked - those are in extreme error.
interpretation: This verse criticizes those who give preference to the temporary pleasures and material gains of this worldly life over the everlasting rewards of the Hereafter. It condemns those who actively discourage others from following the path of Allah and try to distort and misrepresent it. Such people are described as being in "extreme error," meaning they have strayed far from the straight path of truth and guidance.
orig: الذين يستحبون الحياة الدنيا على الآخرة ويصدون عن سبيل الله ويبغونها عوجا أولئك في ضلال بعيد

translation: And We did not send any messenger except [speaking] in the language of his people to state clearly for them, and Allah sends astray [thereby] whom He wills and guides whom He wills. And He is the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
interpretation: This verse highlights the divine wisdom in sending messengers who speak the language of their people, making the message clear and understandable. However, guidance ultimately comes from Allah, Who allows some to be misguided and others to be guided according to His wisdom and decree. This emphasizes Allah's absolute sovereignty, might, and wisdom in dealing with His creation.
orig: وما أرسلنا من رسول إلا بلسان قومه ليبين لهم فيضل الله من يشاء ويهدي من يشاء وهو العزيز الحكيم

translation: And We certainly sent Moses with Our signs, [saying], 'Bring out your people from darknesses into the light and remind them of the days of Allah .' Indeed in that are signs for everyone patient and grateful.
interpretation: This verse refers to Allah sending Prophet Moses with clear signs and miracles to deliver his people from the spiritual darkness of ignorance and oppression into the enlightenment of faith and freedom. Moses is commanded to remind his people of the favors and blessings that Allah has bestowed upon them throughout history, as a reminder of Allah's mercy and power. These signs and reminders are lessons for those who are patient in adversity and grateful for Allah's bounties.
orig: ولقد أرسلنا موسى بآياتنا أن أخرج قومك من الظلمات إلى النور وذكرهم بأيام الله إن في ذلك لآيات لكل صبار شكور

translation: And [recall] when Moses said to his people, "Remember the favor of Allah upon you when He saved you from the people of Pharaoh, who were afflicting you with terrible torment and slaughtering your [newborn] sons while keeping your women alive. And in that was a great trial from your Lord."
interpretation: This verse reminds the believers to be grateful for Allah's favors upon them, specifically when He saved them from the oppression and persecution of Pharaoh and his people. The verse describes the severe torment inflicted by Pharaoh, including killing the newborn sons and sparing the women, which was a great trial from Allah. The interpretation emphasizes the importance of recognizing and appreciating Allah's blessings, especially in times of difficulty and hardship.
orig: وإذ قال موسى لقومه اذكروا نعمة الله عليكم إذ أنجاكم من آل فرعون يسومونكم سوء العذاب ويذبحون أبناءكم ويستحيون نساءكم وفي ذلكم بلاء من ربكم عظيم

translation: And [recall] when your Lord proclaimed, 'If you are grateful, I will surely increase you [in favor]; but if you deny, indeed, My punishment is severe.'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of gratitude towards Allah's blessings and favors. It serves as a reminder that if we are thankful for the countless blessings bestowed upon us, Allah will increase us in His favors and grant us more. However, if we are ungrateful and deny His blessings, we will face a severe punishment from Him. The verse encourages us to adopt an attitude of gratitude and appreciate the countless favors of Allah in our lives.
orig: وإذ تأذن ربكم لئن شكرتم لأزيدنكم ولئن كفرتم إن عذابي لشديد

translation: And Moses said: 'If you should disbelieve, you and whoever is on the earth entirely - indeed, Allah is Free of need and Praiseworthy.'
interpretation: This verse highlights Allah's independence and self-sufficiency. Even if all of humanity were to disbelieve, it would not diminish Allah's greatness or cause Him any harm, for He is Free of need from His creation and Praiseworthy in His perfect Attributes and Actions. The verse emphasizes that human belief or disbelief does not affect Allah's Majesty and Perfection.
orig: وقال موسى إن تكفروا أنتم ومن في الأرض جميعا فإن الله لغني حميد

translation: Has there not reached you the news of those before you - the people of Noah and 'Aad and Thamud? And those after them? No one knows them but Allah. Their messengers came to them with clear proofs, but they put their hands over their mouths and said, "Indeed, we disbelieve in that with which you have been sent, and indeed we are, about that to which you invite us, in disquieting doubt."
interpretation: The interpretation is that Allah is reminding the disbelievers of previous nations who rejected the messengers sent to them with clear signs and proofs. Despite the clear evidence, they stubbornly rejected the message and expressed doubts about the truthfulness of what the messengers called them to. This verse serves as a warning to the disbelievers of the Prophet Muhammad's time, urging them not to follow in the footsteps of those who denied the truth before them.
orig: ألم يأتكم نبأ الذين من قبلكم قوم نوح وعاد وثمود والذين من بعدهم لا يعلمهم إلا الله جاءتهم رسلهم بالبينات فردوا أيديهم في أفواههم وقالوا إنا كفرنا بما أرسلتم به وإنا لفي شك مما تدعوننا إليه مريب

translation: Their messengers said, "Is there any doubt about Allah, the Originator of the heavens and the earth? He invites you to forgive you of your sins and delay you for a specified term." They said, "You are only men like us who want to turn us away from what our forefathers worshipped, so bring us a clear authority."
interpretation: The interpretation is that the messengers of Allah were calling their people to believe in the Oneness of Allah, the Creator of the heavens and the earth, and to seek forgiveness from Him. However, the people rejected the message, accusing the messengers of being mere humans like themselves, trying to mislead them from the religion of their forefathers. They demanded clear proof or authority from the messengers to support their claims.
orig: قالت رسلهم أفي الله شك فاطر السماوات والأرض يدعوكم ليغفر لكم من ذنوبكم ويؤخركم إلى أجل مسمى قالوا إن أنتم إلا بشر مثلنا تريدون أن تصدونا عما كان يعبد آباؤنا فأتونا بسلطان مبين

translation: Their messengers said to them, "We are only human beings like you, but Allah confers favor upon whom He wills of His servants. It was not for us to bring you an authority except by permission of Allah. And upon Allah let the believers put their trust."
interpretation: The messengers were reminding their people that they were mere human beings, chosen by Allah to deliver His message. They had no special powers or authority except what Allah had granted them. Their role was to convey the truth, but it was up to the people to have faith and trust in Allah's wisdom and plan.
orig: قالت لهم رسلهم إن نحن إلا بشر مثلكم ولكن الله يمن على من يشاء من عباده وما كان لنا أن نأتيكم بسلطان إلا بإذن الله وعلى الله فليتوكل المؤمنون

translation: And why should we not put our trust in Allah when He has guided us in our ways? And we will certainly endure whatever hurt you inflict upon us. And those who trust should put their trust in Allah.
interpretation: The interpretation is that believers should have complete trust and reliance in Allah, as He has guided them to the straight path. They should be patient and steadfast in the face of harm or persecution from others. True believers put their trust solely in Allah, not in anyone or anything else.
orig: وما لنا ألا نتوكل على الله وقد هدانا سبلنا ولنصبرن على ما آذيتمونا وعلى الله فليتوكل المتوكلون

translation: And those who disbelieved said to their messengers, 'We will surely drive you out of our land, or you must return to our religion.' So their Lord inspired to them, 'We will surely destroy the wrongdoers.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the arrogant rejection of the disbelievers towards the messengers sent to them by Allah. They threatened to expel the messengers from their land or force them to revert to the disbelievers' religion. However, Allah inspired the messengers that He would ultimately destroy the wrongdoers who oppressed and rejected the truth.
orig: وقال الذين كفروا لرسلهم لنخرجنكم من أرضنا أو لتعودن في ملتنا فأوحى إليهم ربهم لنهلكن الظالمين

translation: And We will grant inheritance of the land to those after them, to those who fear My station and fear My threat.
interpretation: Allah promises to grant authority and control over the land to the righteous believers who fear Him, His punishment, and standing before Him on the Day of Judgment. This verse gives hope to the oppressed that they will eventually prevail and inherit the land from the oppressors, if they remain steadfast in their faith and righteousness.
orig: ولنسكننكم الأرض من بعدهم ذلك لمن خاف مقامي وخاف وعيد

translation: And they sought victory and disappointed was every obstinate tyrant.
interpretation: This verse suggests that those who sought victory against the truth were ultimately disappointed and failed, no matter how arrogant or stubborn they were. It emphasizes that arrogance and stubbornness cannot prevail against the truth and those who stand for it.
orig: واستفتحوا وخاب كل جبار عنيد

translation: In front of him is Hell, and he will be given putrid water to drink
interpretation: This verse warns of the severe punishment that awaits the disbelievers and wrongdoers in the Hereafter. The phrase "In front of him is Hell" implies that Hell is awaiting him as his ultimate destination, where he will face eternal torment. The mention of being given "putrid water to drink" signifies the intense thirst and unbearable suffering he will endure, as putrid water is extremely foul and undrinkable. This vivid description serves as a deterrent, emphasizing the grave consequences of rejecting faith and engaging in evil deeds.
orig: من ورائه جهنم ويسقى من ماء صديد

translation: He will sip it unwillingly, and he will find a great difficulty in swallowing it. And death will come to him from every side, but he will not die; and there will be a severe torment behind him.
interpretation: This verse describes the excruciating punishment that the disbelievers will face in the Hereafter.
