The extended duration symbolizes the preservation of their faith and steadfastness in the face of persecution and oppression.
orig: ولبثوا في كهفهم ثلاث مائة سنين وازدادوا تسعا

translation: Say, "Allah is most knowing of how long they remained. He has [knowledge of] the unseen [aspects] of the heavens and the earth. How Perceiving and Hearing He is! They have no protector apart from Him, and He shares His Legislation with no one."
interpretation: This verse affirms that Allah alone has complete knowledge of the unseen matters, including how long the Companions of the Cave remained in the cave. It highlights Allah's perfect attributes of being the All-Seer and All-Hearer. No one besides Allah can protect or guide anyone, and He does not share His authority of judgment and legislation with anyone.
orig: قل الله أعلم بما لبثوا له غيب السماوات والأرض أبصر به وأسمع ما لهم من دونه من ولي ولا يشرك في حكمه أحدا

translation: And recite what has been revealed to you of the Book of your Lord. There is no changing His words, and you will never find any refuge other than Him.
interpretation: This verse instructs the Prophet Muhammad to recite and convey the Qur'an revealed to him by Allah, as its words are immutable and cannot be altered or changed. It emphasizes that there is no refuge or protection other than Allah, and one should seek guidance and salvation solely from Him.
orig: واتل ما أوحي إليك من كتاب ربك لا مبدل لكلماته ولن تجد من دونه ملتحدا

translation: And keep yourself patient [by being] with those who call upon their Lord in the morning and the evening, seeking His countenance. And let not your eyes pass beyond them, desiring adornments of the worldly life, and do not obey one whose heart We have made heedless of Our remembrance and who follows his desire and whose affair is ever [in] neglect.
interpretation: This verse instructs the believers to be patient and keep the company of those who sincerely worship and remember Allah morning and evening, seeking only His pleasure. It warns against being distracted by the temporary adornments of this worldly life, and against obeying those whose hearts are heedless of Allah's remembrance and who blindly follow their own desires, leading to neglect and ruin.
orig: واصبر نفسك مع الذين يدعون ربهم بالغداة والعشي يريدون وجهه ولا تعد عيناك عنهم تريد زينة الحياة الدنيا ولا تطع من أغفلنا قلبه عن ذكرنا واتبع هواه وكان أمره فرطا

translation: And say, 'The truth is from your Lord, so whoever wills - let him believe; and whoever wills - let him disbelieve.' Indeed, We have prepared for the wrongdoers a fire whose walls will surround them. And if they call for relief, they will be relieved with water like molten brass, which scalds their faces. Wretched is the drink, and evil is the resting place.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the freedom of choice given to humanity regarding belief or disbelief. It warns those who choose disbelief and oppression that a severe punishment awaits them in the form of a raging fire that will engulf them completely. Even if they seek relief, they will be given a drink that resembles molten metal, scalding their faces. This punishment is described as a wretched state, emphasizing the grave consequences of rejecting the truth and engaging in wrongdoing.
orig: وقل الحق من ربكم فمن شاء فليؤمن ومن شاء فليكفر إنا أعتدنا للظالمين نارا أحاط بهم سرادقها وإن يستغيثوا يغاثوا بماء كالمهل يشوي الوجوه بئس الشراب وساءت مرتفقا

translation: Indeed, those who have believed and done righteous deeds - indeed, We will not allow to be lost the reward of any who did well in deeds
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that Allah will certainly reward those who have faith and perform good deeds. It promises that the efforts and good actions of the believers will not go unrewarded or unrecognized by Allah. Their reward will be preserved and given to them in full, as Allah does not neglect or undervalue the good deeds of those who strive to please Him.
orig: إن الذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات إنا لا نضيع أجر من أحسن عملا

translation: Those will have gardens of perpetual residence; beneath them rivers will flow. They will be adorned therein with bracelets of gold and will wear green garments of fine silk and brocade, reclining upon thrones. Excellent is the reward, and best is the resting place.
interpretation: This verse describes the rewards that the righteous believers will receive in Paradise. It portrays a lush garden beneath which rivers flow, where the inhabitants will be adorned with golden bracelets and wear luxurious green garments made of fine silk and brocade. They will recline on thrones in a state of complete comfort and bliss. The verse emphasizes that this is an excellent reward and a most excellent resting place, indicating the ultimate pleasure and satisfaction that awaits the righteous in the Hereafter.
orig: أولئك لهم جنات عدن تجري من تحتهم الأنهار يحلون فيها من أساور من ذهب ويلبسون ثيابا خضرا من سندس وإستبرق متكئين فيها على الأرائك نعم الثواب وحسنت مرتفقا

translation: And present to them the example of two men: We granted to one of them two gardens of grapevines, and We surrounded both with palm trees and placed between them a crop.
interpretation: This verse presents an example of two men, one of whom was granted two lush gardens of grapevines surrounded by palm trees, with cultivated land between them. It serves as a metaphor for the blessings bestowed upon some people in this life, which can lead to arrogance and ingratitude if not accompanied by gratitude and humility towards Allah.
orig: واضرب لهم مثلا رجلين جعلنا لأحدهما جنتين من أعناب وحففناهما بنخل وجعلنا بينهما زرعا

translation: Each of the two gardens brought forth its produce, and did not fail in anything. And We caused a river to gush forth in their midst.
interpretation: "This verse describes the bountiful blessings Allah bestowed upon the two gardens, where each garden yielded its fruits in abundance without any deficiency. Additionally, Allah caused a river to flow between them, further enhancing their fertility and beauty. This portrays the generosity of Allah in providing abundant sustenance and favors to those who are grateful and obedient."
orig: كلتا الجنتين آتت أكلها ولم تظلم منه شيئا وفجرنا خلالهما نهرا

translation: And he had fruit, so he said to his companion while conversing with him, 'I am greater than you in wealth and mightier in attendants.'
interpretation: This verse alludes to the arrogance and ingratitude of the wealthy man towards his Lord. He boasts about his wealth and possessions, considering them a result of his own efforts rather than blessings from Allah. His arrogance stems from his attachment to worldly gains, causing him to become haughty and forget the true source of his provisions.
orig: وكان له ثمر فقال لصاحبه وهو يحاوره أنا أكثر منك مالا وأعز نفرا

translation: And he went into his garden while he was unjust to himself. He said, 'I do not think that this will ever perish.'
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as a critique of arrogance and ingratitude towards God's blessings. The person in question was unjust to himself by being arrogant and ungrateful for the garden he possessed, thinking that it would never perish. This shows his lack of humility and his failure to recognize that all blessings come from God and can be taken away. The verse serves as a warning against such arrogance and ingratitude.
orig: ودخل جنته وهو ظالم لنفسه قال ما أظن أن تبيد هذه أبدا

translation: And I do not think the Hour will ever come, and if I am returned to my Lord, I will surely find a resort far better than this.
interpretation: The speaker is expressing his disbelief in the coming of the Day of Resurrection. He thinks that even if he returns to his Lord, he will find a better abode than the one he currently has. This shows his arrogance and lack of faith in the Hereafter.
orig: وما أظن الساعة قائمة ولئن رددت إلى ربي لأجدن خيرا منها منقلبا

translation: His companion said to him while he was conversing with him, 'Do you disbelieve in the One Who created you from dust, then from a drop of semen, and then fashioned you as a man?'
interpretation: This verse highlights the folly of disbelief in Allah, the Creator. It reminds us of the miraculous process of human creation, starting from dust (referring to the origin of the human body from earthly elements), then a drop of semen, and finally being fashioned into a complete human being. The rhetorical question posed challenges the disbeliever's denial of the One Who brought about this remarkable process of creation, emphasizing the irrationality of rejecting the existence and power of the Creator.
orig: قال له صاحبه وهو يحاوره أكفرت بالذي خلقك من تراب ثم من نطفة ثم سواك رجلا

translation: But indeed, He is Allah, my Lord, and I do not associate with my Lord anyone.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the oneness of Allah and the rejection of associating any partners with Him. The speaker affirms their belief in Allah as the sole Lord and declares that they do not commit shirk, which is the gravest sin in Islam by associating others with Allah in worship or divinity. It is a profound statement of monotheism (tawheed) and a rejection of polytheism or idolatry.
orig: لكنا هو الله ربي ولا أشرك بربي أحدا

translation: But why did you not say when you entered your garden, 'Whatever Allah wills [will occur]; there is no power except in Allah'? Although you see me less than you in wealth and children,
interpretation: This verse reminds us to maintain humility and recognize that all blessings come from Allah. It advises against arrogance or pride in one's possessions or status, as these can be taken away at any time by the will of Allah. Instead, we should acknowledge Allah's power and attribute our successes to His grace and mercy.
orig: ولولا إذ دخلت جنتك قلت ما شاء الله لا قوة إلا بالله إن ترن أنا أقل منك مالا وولدا

translation: But it may be that my Lord will give me something better than your garden, and will send on it a thunderbolt from the sky so that it becomes a bare, slippery ground.
interpretation: The interpretation is that the believer should not feel inferior or envy the wealth of the disbelievers. Instead, one should have faith that Allah can bestow better blessings than the worldly possessions of the disbelievers. The verse suggests that the disbeliever's garden could be destroyed by a thunderbolt from the sky, rendering it barren and slippery. This symbolizes the temporary nature of worldly possessions and the ultimate triumph of faith over disbelief.
orig: فعسى ربي أن يؤتين خيرا من جنتك ويرسل عليها حسبانا من السماء فتصبح صعيدا زلقا

translation: Or its water will become sunken and lost, in which case you will not be able to seek it out.
interpretation: This verse suggests that if the water becomes depleted or lost, one will not be able to find or retrieve it, indicating the importance of preserving and valuing water resources. It serves as a reminder of the fragility and scarcity of water, and the need to use it wisely and sustainably.
orig: أو يصبح ماؤها غورا فلن تستطيع له طلبا

translation: And his fruits were encompassed [by ruin], so he began wringing his hands over what he had spent on it while it had collapsed upon its trellises, and said, 'Oh, I wish I had not associated with my Lord anyone!'
interpretation: This verse describes the regret of a disbeliever who had spent his wealth on worldly pleasures and disobeyed Allah, but when his wealth was destroyed, he realized his mistake of associating partners with Allah. The interpretation is that one should not be deceived by the temporary pleasures of this world and should worship Allah alone, for all blessings are from Him.
orig: وأحيط بثمره فأصبح يقلب كفيه على ما أنفق فيها وهي خاوية على عروشها ويقول يا ليتني لم أشرك بربي أحدا

translation: And there was no group of people to help him besides Allah, nor was he helped.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the complete reliance of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) on Allah alone for support and assistance. It highlights that he did not have any powerful group or army to aid him, nor was he aided by anyone other than Allah. This underscores the divine nature of his mission and the miraculous success he achieved through the help and guidance of Allah.
orig: ولم تكن له فئة ينصرونه من دون الله وما كان منتصرا

translation: True authority belongs to Allah, He is the best to reward and the best to determine the ultimate end.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that true and absolute authority belongs to Allah alone. He is the most generous in rewarding those who obey Him and follow His guidance. Additionally, He is the best to determine the ultimate outcome or consequence of one's actions in the Hereafter. This highlights the importance of submitting to Allah's authority, obeying His commands, and trusting in His wisdom and justice regarding the rewards and consequences in this life and the next.
orig: هنالك الولاية لله الحق هو خير ثوابا وخير عقبا

translation: And present to them the example of the life of this world, like rain which We have sent down from the sky, and the vegetation of the earth mingles with it and [then] it becomes dry remnants, scattered by the winds. And Allah is ever Perfect in Ability over all things.
interpretation: This verse uses the metaphor of rain and vegetation to illustrate the temporary and fleeting nature of this worldly life. Just as rain causes plants to grow and flourish, only to wither and be scattered by the winds, so too is the life of this world - it appears vibrant and alluring, but ultimately fades and perishes. The verse reminds us that true power and control belong to Allah alone, and that we should not be deceived by the transient pleasures of this world.
orig: واضرب لهم مثل الحياة الدنيا كماء أنزلناه من السماء فاختلط به نبات الأرض فأصبح هشيما تذروه الرياح وكان الله على كل شيء مقتدرا

translation: Wealth and children are the adornment of the worldly life, but the enduring good deeds are better with your Lord for reward and better for hope.
interpretation: This verse highlights the temporary nature of worldly possessions like wealth and children, which are mere adornments of this life. True and lasting rewards come from righteous deeds performed solely for the pleasure of Allah. Such good deeds are superior in the sight of Allah and hold greater hope for reward in the Hereafter.
orig: المال والبنون زينة الحياة الدنيا والباقيات الصالحات خير عند ربك ثوابا وخير أملا

translation: And [mention] the Day when We will remove the mountains and you will see the earth protruding, and We will gather them and not leave behind from them anyone.
interpretation: This verse refers to the events of the Day of Resurrection. The "removal of the mountains" symbolizes the complete upheaval and transformation of the earth, indicating the immense power of Allah. The "earth protruding" suggests that all creatures will be gathered on a vast, open plain before Allah for judgment. The phrase "We will gather them and not leave behind from them anyone" emphasizes that every single soul will be resurrected and held accountable, leaving no one behind, regardless of their status or deeds in this world.
orig: ويوم نسير الجبال وترى الأرض بارزة وحشرناهم فلم نغادر منهم أحدا

translation: And they will be presented before your Lord in rows, [and He will say], "You have certainly come to Us just as We created you the first time. But you claimed that We would never make for you an appointment."
interpretation: This verse highlights the accountability of human beings on the Day of Judgment. They will be presented before Allah in rows, just as they were created in this world. Despite their denial of the Resurrection, they will be resurrected and held accountable for their actions. The verse emphasizes that Allah's promise of the Day of Judgment is true, and that humans will have to face the consequences of their beliefs and deeds.
orig: وعرضوا على ربك صفا لقد جئتمونا كما خلقناكم أول مرة بل زعمتم ألن نجعل لكم موعدا

translation: And the Book will be placed, and you will see the criminals fearful of what is in it, and they will say, 'Oh, woe to us! What is this book that leaves nothing small or great except that it has enumerated it?' And they will find whatever they did present, and your Lord will not wrong anyone.
interpretation: This verse describes the terrifying scene on the Day of Judgment when the record of deeds is presented. The sinners will be filled with dread upon seeing their complete record, realizing that nothing they did, no matter how small or large, has been left out. They will find all their deeds accounted for, and they will not be wronged in the least by God, Who is perfectly just.
orig: ووضع الكتاب فترى المجرمين مشفقين مما فيه ويقولون يا ويلتنا مال هذا الكتاب لا يغادر صغيرة ولا كبيرة إلا أحصاها ووجدوا ما عملوا حاضرا ولا يظلم ربك أحدا

translation: And [mention, O Muhammad], when We said to the angels, 'Prostrate before Adam,' and they prostrated, except for Iblees. He was of the jinn and departed from the command of his Lord. Then will you take him and his descendants as allies other than Me while they are enemies to you? Wretched it is for the wrongdoers as an exchange.
interpretation: This verse reminds us of the story of Satan's disobedience when he refused to prostrate before Adam, despite Allah's command. It warns against taking Satan and his followers as allies, as they are sworn enemies of humankind. The verse emphasizes that choosing to ally with evil forces is a wretched exchange for the wrongdoers.
orig: وإذ قلنا للملائكة اسجدوا لآدم فسجدوا إلا إبليس كان من الجن ففسق عن أمر ربه أفتتخذونه وذريته أولياء من دوني وهم لكم عدو بئس للظالمين بدلا

translation: I did not make them witnesses to the creation of the heavens and the earth, nor to their own creation. Nor do I take the misguiders for assistants.
interpretation: Allah is saying that He did not call the idolaters as witnesses when He created the heavens and the earth, nor when He created them. He also affirms that He does not take the misguided people, who call others to falsehood, as helpers or supporters.
orig: ما أشهدتهم خلق السماوات والأرض ولا خلق أنفسهم وما كنت متخذ المضلين عضدا

translation: And the Day when He will say, "Call 'My partners' whom you claimed," then they will call upon them, but they will not respond to them, and We will put between them a place of annihilation.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Day of Judgment when Allah will command the idolaters to call upon those partners they associated with Him, but their calls will go unanswered. Allah will create a barrier of destruction between them and their false deities, symbolizing the futility of their belief and the severance of any supposed relationship they had with their idols.
orig: ويوم يقول نادوا شركائي الذين زعمتم فدعوهم فلم يستجيبوا لهم وجعلنا بينهم موبقا

translation: And the criminals will see the Fire and think that they are to fall therein, and they will find no way of escape from it.
interpretation: This verse describes the state of the disbelievers on the Day of Judgment. They will see the blazing Fire of Hell and realize with certainty that they are about to be thrown into it as a punishment for their sins and rejection of faith. However, they will find no way to avoid or escape this terrifying fate, as it is the ultimate consequence of their wrongdoings in this world.
orig: ورأى المجرمون النار فظنوا أنهم مواقعوها ولم يجدوا عنها مصرفا

translation: And We have certainly diversified in this Qur'an for the people from every kind of example, but man has ever been the most argumentative of things.
interpretation: Allah has provided numerous examples, parables, and lessons in the Qur'an to guide humanity. However, human beings are prone to excessive argumentation and disputation, often rejecting the clear signs and guidance presented in the Qur'an due to their stubborn nature.
orig: ولقد صرفنا في هذا القرآن للناس من كل مثل وكان الإنسان أكثر شيء جدلا

translation: And what prevented the people from believing when guidance came to them and asking forgiveness of their Lord except that they awaited the way of the former peoples to overtake them, or that the punishment should come upon them face to face?
interpretation: "This verse questions why people refuse to believe in the guidance sent by Allah and seek His forgiveness, unless they wish to meet the same fate as the previous nations who were destroyed for their disbelief, or they desire to witness the punishment of Allah firsthand."
orig: وما منع الناس أن يؤمنوا إذ جاءهم الهدى ويستغفروا ربهم إلا أن تأتيهم سنة الأولين أو يأتيهم العذاب قبلا

translation: And We send not the messengers except as bearers of good tidings and warners. But those who disbelieved dispute with falsehood to refute thereby the truth, and they take My verses and that whereof they are warned as a mockery.
interpretation: This verse highlights the primary role of Messengers sent by Allah: to convey glad tidings to the believers and warn the disbelievers of the consequences of rejecting faith. However, the disbelievers stubbornly argue with falsehood in an attempt to invalidate the truth brought by the Messengers. They mock and make a jest of Allah's revelations and warnings, displaying a disrespectful and arrogant attitude towards divine guidance.
orig: وما نرسل المرسلين إلا مبشرين ومنذرين ويجادل الذين كفروا بالباطل ليدحضوا به الحق واتخذوا آياتي وما أنذروا هزوا

translation: And who is more unjust than one who is reminded of the verses of his Lord but turns away from them and forgets what his hands have put forth? Indeed, We have placed over their hearts coverings, lest they understand it, and in their ears deafness. And if you invite them to guidance, they will never be guided, then - ever.
interpretation: This verse condemns those who turn away from Allah's signs and revelations, forgetting the good deeds they have done in the past. It states that Allah has placed coverings over their hearts, preventing them from understanding the truth, and deafness in their ears, making them unable to hear the guidance. If they are invited to the right path, they will never be guided because of their willful rejection and arrogance.
orig: ومن أظلم ممن ذكر بآيات ربه فأعرض عنها ونسي ما قدمت يداه إنا جعلنا على قلوبهم أكنة أن يفقهوه وفي آذانهم وقرا وإن تدعهم إلى الهدى فلن يهتدوا إذا أبدا

translation: But your Lord is the Forgiving One, the Possessor of mercy. If He were to take them to task for what they have earned, He would have hastened the punishment for them. But for them is an appointed time from which they will find no refuge.
interpretation: Allah is Most Forgiving and Merciful. If He were to punish people for their sins immediately, He would have hastened their punishment. However, He gives them respite and delays their reckoning until an appointed time. On that Day, they will have no refuge or escape from Allah's judgment.
orig: وربك الغفور ذو الرحمة لو يؤاخذهم بما كسبوا لعجل لهم العذاب بل لهم موعد لن يجدوا من دونه موئلا

translation: And those towns - We destroyed them when they wronged, and We made for their destruction an appointed time.
interpretation: Allah is stating that He destroyed those nations and towns because of their persistent wrongdoing, disbelief, and rejection of the messengers sent to them. Their destruction did not come suddenly, but rather Allah gave them respite and appointed a time for their annihilation after they had exceeded all limits in sin and transgression.
orig: وتلك القرى أهلكناهم لما ظلموا وجعلنا لمهلكهم موعدا

translation: And when Moses said to his attendant, 'I will not cease until I reach the junction of the two seas, though I go on for ages.'
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as referring to the journey of Prophet Moses and his servant in search of knowledge. The "junction of the two seas" is understood metaphorically as the meeting point of the two bodies of knowledge, the spiritual and the worldly. Moses' determination to continue the journey until he reaches this point, even if it takes a long time ("ages"), signifies the importance of seeking knowledge and understanding the unity of all knowledge under divine guidance.
orig: وإذ قال موسى لفتاه لا أبرح حتى أبلغ مجمع البحرين أو أمضي حقبا

translation: But when they reached the junction between the two [rivers], they forgot their fish, and it took its course into the sea, burrowing through.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Moses and his companion, who forgot their fish at the junction where two rivers or seas met. The fish miraculously came back to life and swam away, leaving behind a path in the water. This event marked the place where Moses was to meet the wise man (al-Khidr) from whom he sought knowledge. The forgetting of the fish was a sign from God, indicating that Moses had reached the appointed place.
orig: فلما بلغا مجمع بينهما نسيا حوتهما فاتخذ سبيله في البحر سربا

translation: So when they had gone on, he said to his boy: 'Bring us our morning meal, we have certainly encountered fatigue from this journey of ours.'
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as referring to the journey of Prophet Moses and his young servant. After traveling for some distance, Moses felt tired and asked his servant to bring their food, acknowledging the fatigue they had experienced on their journey.
orig: فلما جاوزا قال لفتاه آتنا غداءنا لقد لقينا من سفرنا هذا نصبا

translation: He said, "Did you see when we betook ourselves to the rock? Indeed, I forgot the fish, and nothing made me forget to mention it except Satan. And it took its course into the sea in an amazing way."
interpretation: This verse refers to an incident where Prophet Moses and his servant were traveling and stopped at a rock. Moses forgot about the fish they had caught, and he attributed this forgetfulness to Satan's whispers. The fish then miraculously came back to life and made its way back into the sea, which was an amazing event that caught Moses' attention.
orig: قال أرأيت إذ أوينا إلى الصخرة فإني نسيت الحوت وما أنسانيه إلا الشيطان أن أذكره واتخذ سبيله في البحر عجبا

translation: He said, 'That is what we were seeking.' So they went back retracing their footsteps.
interpretation: This verse suggests that the two individuals were on a journey or quest, and after encountering a particular situation or event, they realized that it was precisely what they had been seeking or looking for. As a result, they decided to retrace their steps and return from where they had come, perhaps to reflect on their experience or share their findings with others.
orig: قال ذلك ما كنا نبغ فارتدا على آثارهما قصصا

translation: And they found one of Our servants to whom We had granted mercy from Us and had taught him knowledge from Ourselves.
interpretation: This verse refers to the encounter between Moses and al-Khidr, a wise and knowledgeable man whom Allah had granted special knowledge and wisdom directly from Him. The interpretation is that Allah bestows His mercy and knowledge upon whomever He wills from among His servants, even if they are not prophets or messengers.
orig: فوجدا عبدا من عبادنا آتيناه رحمة من عندنا وعلمناه من لدنا علما

translation: Moses said to him, 'May I follow you on [the condition] that you teach me from what you have been taught of sound judgement?'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Moses and a servant of Allah known as al-Khidr. Moses asked to accompany al-Khidr so that he could learn from the wisdom and knowledge that Allah had bestowed upon him. The verse highlights Moses' humility and eagerness to learn from someone who possessed divine knowledge and "sound judgement" (rushd) that he did not have access to.
orig: قال له موسى هل أتبعك على أن تعلمن مما علمت رشدا

translation: He said, 'Indeed, you will never be able to have patience with me.'
interpretation: This verse suggests that the person being addressed lacks the patience or perseverance to accompany or follow the speaker. It implies that the speaker has knowledge or experiences that the other person may find difficult to endure or comprehend. The interpretation highlights the idea that certain paths or journeys require a significant level of patience and resilience that not everyone possesses.
orig: قال إنك لن تستطيع معي صبرا

translation: And how can you be patient over what you do not have any knowledge about?
interpretation: This verse questions how one can be patient and persevere regarding matters that they have no knowledge or awareness about. It emphasizes the importance of having understanding and insight before exercising patience, as patience without knowledge can lead to misguidance or misguided perseverance.
orig: وكيف تصبر على ما لم تحط به خبرا

translation: He said, 'You will find me, God willing, patient, and I will not disobey you in any matter.'
interpretation: This verse conveys the idea of unwavering obedience and patience in the face of adversity. It emphasizes the importance of having a strong faith in God's will and the willingness to endure challenges without disobeying divine commands. The speaker expresses their determination to remain steadfast and compliant, seeking God's aid in their endeavors.
orig: قال ستجدني إن شاء الله صابرا ولا أعصي لك أمرا

translation: He said, 'If you follow me, then do not ask me about anything until I make mention of it to you.'
interpretation: This verse suggests that the Prophet was instructed by God not to reveal certain matters or knowledge to his followers until the appropriate time. It implies that some information should be conveyed gradually and at the right moment, rather than all at once. The interpretation emphasizes the importance of wisdom, patience, and following divine guidance in the dissemination of knowledge.
orig: قال فإن اتبعتني فلا تسألني عن شيء حتى أحدث لك منه ذكرا

translation: So they set out, until when they had embarked upon the ship, al-Khidhr tore it open. [Moses] said, 'Have you torn it open to drown its people? You have certainly done a grave thing.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident where the Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) accompanied al-Khidhr, a wise man granted knowledge by Allah. When they embarked on a ship, al-Khidhr intentionally damaged it, which seemed unjustified to Moses. However, al-Khidhr's actions had a higher wisdom that was not immediately apparent to Moses. This teaches us to have patience and trust in Allah's plan, even when things seem inexplicable at first.
orig: فانطلقا حتى إذا ركبا في السفينة خرقها قال أخرقتها لتغرق أهلها لقد جئت شيئا إمرا

translation: He said, 'Did I not tell you that you would never be able to have patience with me?'
interpretation: This verse implies that the person being addressed was previously warned that they would not have the patience or perseverance to accompany the speaker on a certain matter or journey. It suggests that the speaker had anticipated the lack of patience from the other party, and is reminding them of that forewarning.
orig: قال ألم أقل إنك لن تستطيع معي صبرا

translation: He said, 'Do not blame me for what I forgot or overwhelm me in my matter with difficulty.'
interpretation: This verse refers to a supplication made by Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) to Allah. He asks Allah not to hold him accountable for any forgetfulness or mistakes on his part, and not to burden him with difficulties that he cannot bear in his mission. It reflects Moses' humility and reliance on Allah's guidance and mercy.
orig: قال لا تؤاخذني بما نسيت ولا ترهقني من أمري عسرا

translation: So they went on until, when they met a boy, he killed him. He said, "Have you killed a pure soul for no reason? You have certainly done a terrible thing."
interpretation: This verse is part of the story of Prophet Moses and his companion, al-Khidr. The killing of the boy seems unjustified from the apparent perspective, but al-Khidr had a deeper wisdom that was not immediately clear to Moses. It teaches us to have patience and trust in Allah's plan, even when faced with situations that seem inexplicable or difficult to comprehend at first glance.
orig: فانطلقا حتى إذا لقيا غلاما فقتله قال أقتلت نفسا زكية بغير نفس لقد جئت شيئا نكرا

translation: He said, 'Did I not tell you that you would never be able to have patience with me?'
interpretation: This verse refers to a conversation between Prophet Moses and his servant, in which Moses reminds his servant that he had warned him earlier that he would not be able to remain patient with Moses' actions, which were based on a higher knowledge granted to Moses by Allah. The verse highlights the idea that true knowledge and wisdom come from Allah, and that human beings, no matter how learned or patient they may be, have limited understanding compared to the knowledge bestowed upon the Prophets by Allah.
orig: قال ألم أقل لك إنك لن تستطيع معي صبرا

translation: He said, 'If you ask me about anything after this, then do not keep me as a companion. You have received an excuse from me.'
interpretation: This verse indicates that the speaker has given a final warning or ultimatum. If the listener continues to ask questions or make demands after this point, the speaker will terminate their companionship or relationship. The speaker feels they have provided sufficient justification or "excuse" for their stance, and any further inquiries would cross a line.
orig: قال إن سألتك عن شيء بعدها فلا تصاحبني قد بلغت من لدني عذرا

translation: Then they set out, until when they came unto the people of a township, they asked its people for food, but they refused to make them guests. And they found therein a wall which was about to fall down, and he restored it. [Al-Kahf] said: If thou hadst wished, thou couldst have taken payment for it.
interpretation: The interpretation is that the verse refers to a journey taken by Moses and his companion, al-Khidr. When they came to a town and asked for food, the people refused to host them. They then found a wall that was about to collapse, and al-Khidr repaired it without taking any payment, despite Moses suggesting that he could have charged for the work.
orig: فانطلقا حتى إذا أتيا أهل قرية استطعما أهلها فأبوا أن يضيفوهما فوجدا فيها جدارا يريد أن ينقض فأقامه قال لو شئت لاتخذت عليه أجرا

translation: He said: "This is a parting between me and you. I will inform you of the interpretation of that which you were unable to have patience for."
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Joseph (Yusuf) when he was in prison. He interpreted the dreams of his two fellow prisoners, one of whom would be released and the other executed. Joseph asked the one who would be released to mention him to the king so that he could be freed from prison. However, the released man forgot to mention Joseph to the king. After some years, the king himself had a dream which no one could interpret, and the released man remembered Joseph and mentioned him to the king. Joseph was then brought from the prison to interpret the king's dream. This verse indicates that Joseph was patient in bearing the difficulties of imprisonment, and now he would reveal the interpretation of the dream that the released man was unable to be patient about.
orig: قال هذا فراق بيني وبينك سأنبئك بتأويل ما لم تستطع عليه صبرا

translation: As for the ship, it belonged to poor people working at sea. So I intended to cause defect in it as there was a king after them who seized every ship by force.
interpretation: The verse refers to the incident when the Prophet Musa (Moses) and his companion were traveling and came across a ship belonging to poor sailors. His companion damaged the ship intentionally, which seemed unjustified at the time. However, the wisdom behind this action was revealed later - there was a tyrannical king ahead who was seizing every serviceable ship by force, so damaging the ship saved it from being taken away from its poor owners.
orig: أما السفينة فكانت لمساكين يعملون في البحر فأردت أن أعيبها وكان وراءهم ملك يأخذ كل سفينة غصبا

translation: And as for the boy, his parents were believers, and we feared that he would oppress them by rebellion and disbelief.
interpretation: Allah is explaining the wisdom behind the actions of the righteous servant (Prophet Khidr). The boy who was killed had believing parents, but it was feared that he would become rebellious and disbelieving as he grew older, causing immense grief and hardship for his parents who were believers. Therefore, Allah willed that he die as a young believer to prevent this future affliction upon his parents.
orig: وأما الغلام فكان أبواه مؤمنين فخشينا أن يرهقهما طغيانا وكفرا

translation: So We intended that their Lord should substitute for them one better than him in purity and nearer to mercy.
interpretation: Allah intended to replace the deceased child with another child who would be better in purity, righteousness, and closeness to His mercy. This verse emphasizes Allah's wisdom and mercy in compensating the believers for their losses with something better.
orig: فأردنا أن يبدلهما ربهما خيرا منه زكاة وأقرب رحما

translation: As for the wall, it belonged to two orphan boys in the town, and beneath it was a treasure belonging to them, and their father was a righteous man. So your Lord intended that they should attain their age of full strength and extract their treasure, as a mercy from your Lord. And I did it not of my own accord. That is the interpretation of that which you could not bear with patience.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Moses and his companion, al-Khidr. The wall that al-Khidr rebuilt belonged to two orphan boys in the town, and beneath it was a treasure that belonged to them. Their father was a righteous man, and God intended that the boys should reach maturity and be able to extract their treasure, which was an act of mercy from God. Al-Khidr's actions, which seemed strange to Moses, were done not of his own accord but by God's command. This interpretation explains the wisdom behind al-Khidr's actions, which initially appeared incomprehensible to Moses.
orig: وأما الجدار فكان لغلامين يتيمين في المدينة وكان تحته كنز لهما وكان أبوهما صالحا فأراد ربك أن يبلغا أشدهما ويستخرجا كنزهما رحمة من ربك وما فعلته عن أمري ذلك تأويل ما لم تسطع عليه صبرا

translation: And they ask you, [O Muhammad], about Dhul-Qarnayn. Say, 'I will recite to you about him a report.'
interpretation: This verse introduces the story of Dhul-Qarnayn, a powerful ruler blessed by Allah. The interpretation is that Allah is instructing Prophet Muhammad to recite and relate the account of Dhul-Qarnayn, who had great authority and traveled extensively. This story highlights Allah's power and wisdom in granting dominion to whom He wills.
orig: ويسألونك عن ذي القرنين قل سأتلو عليكم منه ذكرا

translation: Indeed, We established him upon the earth, and We gave him the means of all things.
interpretation: This verse refers to how Allah has granted human beings authority and control over the earth and provided them with the resources and means to sustain themselves and thrive. It highlights Allah's favor upon humankind by giving them the ability to utilize the earth's provisions and blessings for their benefit and survival. The verse encourages gratitude towards Allah for these blessings and a sense of responsibility in utilizing them appropriately.
orig: إنا مكنا له في الأرض وآتيناه من كل شيء سببا

translation: So follow a way
interpretation: This verse encourages the believer to follow a path or course of action that leads to righteousness and the pleasure of Allah. It implies that one should seek guidance from the Qur'an and the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to find the straight path and adhere to it steadfastly.
orig: فأتبع سببا

translation: Until, when he reached the setting place of the sun, he found it setting in a spring of black muddy (or hot) water. And he found near it a people. We (Allah) said (by inspiration): 'O Dhul-Qarnain! Either you punish them, or treat them with kindness.'
interpretation: Allah is describing the journey of Dhul-Qarnain, a righteous servant, until he reached the setting place of the sun. There he found it setting in a spring of black muddy or hot water, and a people living nearby. Allah then gave him a choice, either to punish them for their disbelief and sins, or to treat them with kindness and call them to the truth with wisdom and fair preaching.
orig: حتى إذا بلغ مغرب الشمس وجدها تغرب في عين حمئة ووجد عندها قوما قلنا يا ذا القرنين إما أن تعذب وإما أن تتخذ فيهم حسنا

translation: He (Allah) says: "As for him who does wrong, We shall punish him; then he will be brought back to his Lord, and He will punish him with a terrible punishment."
interpretation: This verse warns about the severe punishment that awaits those who commit wrongdoing and oppression. It indicates that Allah will first punish them in this world, and then they will be returned to Him on the Day of Judgment, where He will subject them to a horrific and unbearable punishment for their transgressions.
orig: قال أما من ظلم فسوف نعذبه ثم يرد إلى ربه فيعذبه عذابا نكرا

translation: But as for him who believes and does righteous deeds, he will have a reward never ending, and We will command him with ease from Our command.
interpretation: This verse promises a great reward for those who have faith and perform good deeds. They will receive an endless reward in the Hereafter, and Allah will make their affairs easy for them in this life. It emphasizes that belief and righteous actions are essential for attaining Allah's pleasure and blessings.
orig: وأما من آمن وعمل صالحا فله جزاء الحسنى وسنقول له من أمرنا يسرا

translation: Then he followed a way.
interpretation: This verse suggests that after being created and guided, the human being chose to follow a particular path or course of action. It implies that human beings have free will and the ability to make choices, whether good or bad, after receiving guidance from their Creator.
orig: ثم أتبع سببا

translation: Until, when he reached the rising place of the sun, he found it rising on a people for whom We had not made against it any shield.
interpretation: This verse refers to the journey of the righteous servant Dhul-Qarnayn, who traveled to the east until he reached the place where the sun rises. He found a people who had no shelter or protection from the intense heat of the sun. This could be interpreted as a metaphor for those who lack guidance and live in spiritual darkness, unprotected from the "heat" of misguidance and disbelief.
orig: حتى إذا بلغ مطلع الشمس وجدها تطلع على قوم لم نجعل لهم من دونها سترا

translation: And thus, We have encompassed what he had of information.
interpretation: هذه الآية تشير إلى علم الله المحيط بكل شيء، بما في ذلك ما كان لدى الشخص المذكور من معلومات وخبرات. فالله سبحانه وتعالى محيط بكل شيء، لا يخفى عليه شيء، وهو عالم بكل ما يحمله الإنسان من علم ومعرفة.
orig: كذلك وقد أحطنا بما لديه خبرا

translation: Then he followed a way.
interpretation: This verse suggests that after being guided to the truth, the person followed a path or course of action. The interpretation is that one should act upon the guidance received and strive to follow the right way in life.
orig: ثم أتبع سببا

translation: Until, when he reached [a pass] between two mountains, he found beside them a people who could hardly understand [any] speech.
interpretation: This verse refers to the journey of Dhul-Qarnayn, who traveled until he reached a narrow pass between two mountains, where he encountered a people who could barely communicate or understand speech due to their primitive language or isolation.
orig: حتى إذا بلغ بين السدين وجد من دونهما قوما لا يكادون يفقهون قولا

translation: They said, 'O Dhu'l-Qarnayn! Verily Ya'juj and Ma'juj (Gog and Magog) are creating mischief in the land. Shall we then pay you a tribute in order that you might set up a barrier between us and them?'
interpretation: This verse refers to a people who sought help from Dhu'l-Qarnayn, a righteous ruler, against the mischief and corruption caused by the tribes of Ya'juj and Ma'juj (Gog and Magog). They offered to pay him a tribute if he would build a barrier to protect them from these destructive people.
orig: قالوا يا ذا القرنين إن يأجوج ومأجوج مفسدون في الأرض فهل نجعل لك خرجا على أن تجعل بيننا وبينهم سدا

translation: He said, 'The power which my Lord has bestowed upon me is better (than your wealth), so help me with strength (of men), I will erect a barrier between you and them.'
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that Prophet Dhul-Qarnayn, who was granted power and authority by Allah, asked his people to assist him with manpower so that he could build a barrier to protect them from the mischievous acts of Ya'juj and Ma'juj (Gog and Magog). This barrier would serve as a fortification against their aggression and wrongdoing.
orig: قال ما مكني فيه ربي خير فأعينوني بقوة أجعل بينكم وبينهم ردما

translation: Bring me chunks of iron until, when he had filled the gap between the two mountains, he said: Blow. Until, when he had made it a fire, he said: Bring me molten copper to pour over it.
interpretation: This verse is referring to the story of Dhul-Qarnain, a righteous man who was given power and knowledge by Allah. He built a barrier between two mountains to protect people from the mischief of Gog and Magog. The verse describes how he gathered iron and melted it with fire, then poured molten copper over it to create an impenetrable barrier. This demonstrates Allah's power and wisdom in aiding His righteous servants.
orig: آتوني زبر الحديد حتى إذا ساوى بين الصدفين قال انفخوا حتى إذا جعله نارا قال آتوني أفرغ عليه قطرا

translation: But they were not able to subdue it, nor can they dig through the earth [to escape].
interpretation: This verse is emphasizing the inability of the disbelievers to overcome the truth and escape from the consequences of their rejection. They could not "subdue" or suppress the message of Islam, nor could they find a way to "dig through the earth" or find any means to flee from the divine truth and its consequences.
orig: فما اسطاعوا أن يظهروه وما استطاعوا له نقبا

translation: He said: "This is a mercy from my Lord, but when the promise of my Lord comes, He will level it level and the promise of my Lord is ever true."
interpretation: The interpretation is that Allah's mercy and blessings in this world are temporary, and when the Day of Judgment comes, everything will be destroyed and leveled. Allah's promise of the Hereafter and the Day of Resurrection is true and inevitable.
orig: قال هذا رحمة من ربي فإذا جاء وعد ربي جعله دكاء وكان وعد ربي حقا

translation: And We shall leave them, that day, to surge like waves on one another, and the Trumpet will be blown, and We shall collect them all together.
interpretation: This verse refers to the events of the Day of Resurrection. On that Day, people will be left surging against one another like waves in the sea, in a state of chaos and confusion. Then, the Trumpet will be blown, signaling the gathering of all people before God for judgment. The interpretation highlights the tumultuous nature of that Day and God's power to gather all of humanity together despite their dispersal.
orig: وتركنا بعضهم يومئذ يموج في بعض ونفخ في الصور فجمعناهم جمعا

translation: And We will present Hell that Day to the disbelievers, present
interpretation: This verse warns the disbelievers that on the Day of Judgment, Hell will be clearly displayed and presented to them as a consequence of their rejection of faith and righteous deeds. The repetition of the word "present" emphasizes the unavoidable reality they will face, leaving no doubt or ambiguity about the punishment that awaits them for their disbelief and disobedience.
orig: وعرضنا جهنم يومئذ للكافرين عرضا

translation: Those whose eyes were veiled from My remembrance, and could not bear to hear.
interpretation: This verse refers to those who turned away from Allah's guidance and reminders. Their hearts were veiled, preventing them from truly seeing and understanding the truth. They also could not bear to listen to the divine message, as they were unwilling to accept it. This describes the state of spiritual blindness and deafness of those who reject faith and Allah's signs.
orig: الذين كانت أعينهم في غطاء عن ذكري وكانوا لا يستطيعون سمعا

translation: Have those who disbelieved ever thought that they could take My servants instead of Me as allies? Verily, We have prepared Hell as a hospitable home for the disbelievers.
interpretation: This verse warns the disbelievers against taking anyone or anything as an ally besides Allah. It emphasizes that Hell has been prepared as an eternal abode for those who reject faith in the One True God. The implication is that associating partners with Allah or relying on false deities will only lead to a painful punishment in the Hereafter.
orig: أفحسب الذين كفروا أن يتخذوا عبادي من دوني أولياء إنا أعتدنا جهنم للكافرين نزلا

translation: Say, 'Shall We inform you of the greatest losers in respect to deeds?'
interpretation: This verse is prompting the Prophet Muhammad to ask the disbelievers a rhetorical question, "Shall We inform you of those whose deeds have rendered them the greatest losers?" This is referring to those who have strayed from the right path and rejected faith, whose efforts and actions in this life will be utterly wasted and unrewarded in the Hereafter.
orig: قل هل ننبئكم بالأخسرين أعمالا

translation: Those whose efforts have been wasted in this life while they thought that they were acquiring good by their deeds.
interpretation: This verse refers to those who are misguided and stray from the right path in their worldly life. Despite their efforts and deeds, they believe they are doing good, but in reality, their actions are misguided and futile because they lack true faith and guidance. Their efforts are wasted as they pursue worldly gains without considering the hereafter or pleasing Allah.
orig: الذين ضل سعيهم في الحياة الدنيا وهم يحسبون أنهم يحسنون صنعا

translation: Those are the ones who disbelieved in the signs of their Lord and in [their] meeting Him, so their deeds became worthless, and We will not assign to them on the Day of Resurrection any weight.
interpretation: This verse refers to those who reject the signs and revelations of Allah and deny the meeting with Him on the Day of Resurrection. Their deeds and efforts in this world will be rendered futile and worthless. On the Day of Judgment, they will not be given any value or consideration for their actions, as they lacked faith and rejected the truth.
orig: أولئك الذين كفروا بآيات ربهم ولقائه فحبطت أعمالهم فلا نقيم لهم يوم القيامة وزنا

translation: That is their recompense - Hell - for what they denied and made a mockery of My signs and messengers.
interpretation: This verse warns of the severe punishment awaiting those who reject faith and mock Allah's revelations and messengers. Their recompense for disbelief and mockery will be Hell, where they will face eternal torment. The verse emphasizes the grave consequences of denying the truth and ridiculing Allah's signs and messengers, which is a manifestation of their arrogance and ingratitude towards the Divine guidance.
orig: ذلك جزاؤهم جهنم بما كفروا واتخذوا آياتي ورسلي هزوا

translation: Indeed, those who have believed and done righteous deeds - they will have the Gardens of Paradise as a lodging,
interpretation: This verse promises Paradise as an eternal abode for those who have faith and perform good deeds. It highlights that true belief must be accompanied by righteous actions to attain the ultimate reward of Paradise, which is described as "Gardens of Paradise" to signify its beauty, tranquility, and everlasting bliss.
orig: إن الذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات كانت لهم جنات الفردوس نزلا

translation: Abiding forever therein, they will not desire from it any transfer.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the believers who enter Paradise will reside there eternally, without any desire to be transferred or moved elsewhere. Paradise is the ultimate and everlasting abode of bliss, fulfilling all desires, leaving no reason to seek a different place or state.
orig: خالدين فيها لا يبغون عنها حولا

translation: Say, 'If the ocean were ink for the words of my Lord, the ocean would be exhausted before the words of my Lord were exhausted, even if We brought the like of it as a supplement.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the infinite knowledge and words of Allah. It emphasizes that even if all the oceans were turned into ink to write down Allah's words, the ink would run out before Allah's words are exhausted. The boundless nature of Allah's knowledge and wisdom is beyond human comprehension, and no matter how much humans try, they cannot fully encompass or equal it.
orig: قل لو كان البحر مدادا لكلمات ربي لنفد البحر قبل أن تنفد كلمات ربي ولو جئنا بمثله مددا

translation: Say, "I am but a man like yourselves, to whom has been revealed that your god is one God. So whoever hopes for the meeting with his Lord - let him do righteous work and not associate anyone in the worship of his Lord."
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the concept of Tawheed (Oneness of God) and the importance of righteous deeds. It teaches that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was a human being like others, but he received revelation from the One True God. Those who desire to meet their Lord should perform good deeds and worship Allah alone, without associating any partners with Him.
orig: قل إنما أنا بشر مثلكم يوحى إلي أنما إلهكم إله واحد فمن كان يرجو لقاء ربه فليعمل عملا صالحا ولا يشرك بعبادة ربه أحدا

translation: Kaf, Ha, Ya, 'Ayn, Sad
interpretation: These are among the separated or disjointed letters that appear at the beginning of some chapters of the Qur'an. Their precise meaning is known only to Allah. However, scholars have offered various interpretations, such as: they are a sign of the miraculous nature of the Qur'an, a call to ponder over the Qur'an's inimitable language and style, or an allusion to certain divine names or attributes.
orig: كهيعص

translation: Mention the mercy of your Lord to His servant Zechariah.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Zechariah (peace be upon him) and how Allah bestowed His mercy upon him by answering his prayer and granting him a son, despite his old age and his wife's barrenness. It highlights Allah's power and mercy in fulfilling the desires of His pious servants who put their trust in Him.
orig: ذكر رحمت ربك عبده زكريا

translation: When he called upon his Lord with a hidden call,
interpretation: This verse refers to the Prophet Yunus (Jonah) when he called out to Allah in a state of humility and desperation while in the belly of the whale. Despite his dire situation, he turned to Allah in a sincere and private manner, seeking His help and forgiveness. The interpretation emphasizes the importance of turning to Allah with sincerity and humility, even in the most difficult circumstances.
orig: إذ نادى ربه نداء خفيا

translation: He said, 'My Lord, indeed my bones have weakened, and my head has filled with white hair, and never have I been in my supplication to You, my Lord, unhappy.'
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as a supplication of the Prophet Zakariya (Zechariah) to Allah. He expresses his old age, with weakened bones and gray hair, but affirms that despite his advanced years, he has never been disappointed or dissatisfied in his prayers and supplications to Allah. It reflects his unwavering faith and reliance on Allah, even in his old age.
orig: قال رب إني وهن العظم مني واشتعل الرأس شيبا ولم أكن بدعائك رب شقيا

translation: And indeed, I fear the successors after me, and my wife has been barren, so give me from Yourself an heir
interpretation: The Prophet Zakariya (peace be upon him) is expressing his fear of leaving his religious mission without a worthy successor after his death, since his wife was unable to bear children. He humbly asks Allah to bless him with a pious heir who can continue guiding people after him.
orig: وإني خفت الموالي من ورائي وكانت امرأتي عاقرا فهب لي من لدنك وليا

translation: He will inherit from me and inherit from the family of Jacob, and make him, my Lord, pleasing.
interpretation: This verse refers to Prophet Jesus (peace be upon him) inheriting prophethood and knowledge from Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and the previous prophets from the lineage of Prophet Jacob (peace be upon him). It also expresses the supplication of Prophet Muhammad to Allah to make Prophet Jesus pleasing and accepted in His sight.
orig: يرثني ويرث من آل يعقوب واجعله رب رضيا

translation: O Zakariya, indeed We give you good tidings of a boy whose name will be Yahya. We have not assigned to any before [this] name.
interpretation: This verse announces the glad tidings of the birth of a son to Prophet Zakariya, despite his and his wife's old age. The son is named Yahya, which means "he lives" or "the ever-living one", and this name was unique and had not been given to anyone before him. This child was a blessing from Allah, demonstrating His power to grant children even in seemingly impossible circumstances.
orig: يا زكريا إنا نبشرك بغلام اسمه يحيى لم نجعل له من قبل سميا

translation: He said, 'My Lord, how will I have a boy when my wife is barren and I have reached extreme old age?'
interpretation: This verse expresses the astonishment and disbelief of Prophet Zechariah when he was given the glad tidings of having a son despite his old age and his wife's barrenness. It highlights the power of Allah to grant children even in seemingly impossible circumstances, and tests the faith of believers in Allah's infinite might.
orig: قال رب أنى يكون لي غلام وكانت امرأتي عاقرا وقد بلغت من الكبر عتيا

translation: Thus has your Lord said: 'It is easy for Me - and indeed, I created you before, when you were nothing.'
interpretation: Allah is reminding us that just as He created us from nothing the first time, reviving us after death is an easy matter for Him. This verse emphasizes Allah's absolute power and ability to resurrect all creation after death, just as He originated their creation from nothingness. It serves as a reminder of the inevitability of the Resurrection and the need to prepare for the final accountability on that Day.
orig: قال كذلك قال ربك هو علي هين وقد خلقتك من قبل ولم تك شيئا

translation: He said, 'My Lord, appoint for me a sign.' He said, 'Your sign is that you will not speak to people for three nights, being sound.'
interpretation: Allah commanded Prophet Zakariya to remain silent and not speak to people for three nights as a sign of his thankfulness and patience. This was a test from Allah to strengthen Zakariya's faith and resolve.
orig: قال رب اجعل لي آية قال آيتك ألا تكلم الناس ثلاث ليال سويا

translation: So he came out to his people from the prayer chamber and signaled to them to exalt [Allah] in the morning and evening.
interpretation: This verse refers to the prophet Zakariya (Zechariah), who was granted a son named Yahya (John) in his old age, despite his wife's barrenness. When Zakariya emerged from the private chamber where he used to pray, he gestured to his people to glorify and praise God at the beginning and end of each day. This signifies the importance of remembering and worshipping God regularly, both in the morning and evening.
orig: فخرج على قومه من المحراب فأوحى إليهم أن سبحوا بكرة وعشيا

translation: O Yahya, take the Book with strength, and We gave him judgement while yet a child.
interpretation: "This verse refers to the Prophet Yahya (John the Baptist), who was given wisdom, understanding and prophethood from a young age. It highlights that Allah bestowed upon him the ability to comprehend and uphold the divine scriptures with firmness and strength, as well as the quality of sound judgement, even as a child. This serves as an example of Allah's power to grant knowledge and wisdom to whomever He wills, regardless of age or worldly status."
orig: يا يحيى خذ الكتاب بقوة وآتيناه الحكم صبيا

translation: And a mercy from Us and a purification and he was righteous.
interpretation: This verse refers to the gift of prophethood and divine revelation granted to Prophet Yahya (John the Baptist) by Allah. It highlights three key aspects: 1) "And a mercy from Us" - Yahya's prophethood was a mercy and blessing from Allah to guide people. 2) "And a purification" - Yahya was purified by Allah, both spiritually and morally, to undertake the noble task of preaching. 3) "And he was righteous" - Yahya was a deeply righteous and pious individual who adhered to the commands of Allah.
orig: وحنانا من لدنا وزكاة وكان تقيا

translation: And he was dutiful to his parents, and he was neither arrogant nor disobedient.
interpretation: This verse praises the Prophet Muhammad's character, highlighting his obedience and respect towards his parents, as well as his humility and lack of arrogance or disobedience. It emphasizes the importance of honoring one's parents and exhibiting good conduct in Islam.
orig: وبرا بوالديه ولم يكن جبارا عصيا

translation: And peace be upon him the day he was born, and the day he dies, and the day he is raised alive.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Prophet Jesus (peace be upon him). It sends peace and blessings upon him on three occasions: the day he was born, the day he dies, and the day he will be resurrected alive. It affirms Jesus' miraculous birth, his mortality like all humans, and his eventual resurrection on the Day of Judgment. The verse highlights Jesus' honored status as a prophet and messenger of God.
orig: وسلام عليه يوم ولد ويوم يموت ويوم يبعث حيا

translation: And mention, in the Book, Mary, when she withdrew from her family to a place toward the east.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Mary, the mother of Jesus. When she was pregnant with Jesus, she withdrew from her family to an isolated place towards the east, seeking privacy and seclusion for the birth of her miraculous child. This highlights Mary's piety, modesty, and trust in Allah's plan for her.
orig: واذكر في الكتاب مريم إذ انتبذت من أهلها مكانا شرقيا

translation: So she took a veil (to screen herself) from them; then We sent to her Our Ruh (angel), and he appeared before her in the form of a man in all respects.
interpretation: Allah is describing the event of the Annunciation to Mary, when the angel Gabriel appeared before her in the form of a man. Mary took a veil to seclude herself, as she was startled by the appearance of this man. However, the "man" was in fact the angel Gabriel, sent by Allah to give her the glad tidings of a son, Jesus, who would be born miraculously without a father.
orig: فاتخذت من دونهم حجابا فأرسلنا إليها روحنا فتمثل لها بشرا سويا

translation: She said: 'I seek refuge from you with the Most Merciful, [so leave me], if you should be fearing of Allah.'
interpretation: The verse refers to an incident involving the Prophet Musa (Moses) and a woman he encountered. When Musa approached her, she sought refuge in Allah from him, stating that she would only be safe from any harm if Musa truly feared Allah and was a pious person. The verse highlights the woman's faith in Allah's protection and her appeal to Musa's piety and righteousness.
orig: قالت إني أعوذ بالرحمن منك إن كنت تقيا

translation: He said: 'I am only a messenger from your Lord, to bestow upon you a pure son.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the glad tidings given by the angels to Zakariya (Zechariah) that he would be blessed with a son despite his old age and his wife's barrenness. The son mentioned here is Yahya (John the Baptist), who is described as being pure and righteous. This was a great blessing from God to Zakariya, who had been longing for a child to continue his legacy and prophethood.
orig: قال إنما أنا رسول ربك لأهب لك غلاما زكيا

translation: She said: 'How can I have a son when no man has touched me, nor have I been unchaste?'
interpretation: This verse refers to the conversation between the angel and the Virgin Mary when he informed her that she would give birth to a son, Jesus. Mary's response expresses her surprise and bewilderment at how she could conceive a child without a husband or any physical contact with a man, as she was a chaste woman who had not been unchaste. This highlights the miraculous nature of Jesus' birth, which defied the natural laws and served as a sign of God's power.
orig: قالت أنى يكون لي غلام ولم يمسسني بشر ولم أك بغيا

translation: He said, 'Thus has your Lord said: 'It is easy for Me, and We will make him a sign for the people and a mercy from Us. And it is a matter already decreed.'"
interpretation: Allah is stating that creating a child for the Virgin Mary is easy for Him, as He has absolute power over all things. This child (Jesus) will be a sign of Allah's might and a mercy from Him to humanity. This event was already decreed by Allah's wisdom and will.
orig: قال كذلك قال ربك هو علي هين ولنجعله آية للناس ورحمة منا وكان أمرا مقضيا

translation: So she conceived him, and she withdrew with him to a remote place.
interpretation: This verse refers to the miraculous conception and birth of Prophet Jesus by the virgin Mary. Despite being chaste and unmarried, Mary conceived Jesus through the divine will of Allah. Feeling distressed and fearing people's reactions, she withdrew to a remote place, away from her community, to give birth in seclusion.
orig: فحملته فانتبذت به مكانا قصيا

translation: And the pains of childbirth drove her to the trunk of a palm tree. She said, 'Oh, I wish I had died before this and was a thing forgotten.'
interpretation: This verse describes the difficult situation of Mary when she was about to give birth to Jesus. The intense labor pains caused her to lean against the trunk of a palm tree for support. In her anguish, she expressed a wish that she had died before this ordeal and been completely forgotten and unknown.
orig: فأجاءها المخاض إلى جذع النخلة قالت يا ليتني مت قبل هذا وكنت نسيا منسيا

translation: Then he called her from below her, 'Do not grieve; your Lord has provided a stream beneath you.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Mary (Maryam) when she gave birth to Jesus. It symbolizes that even in times of hardship and difficulty, Allah provides relief and sustenance. The "stream beneath" represents the provision and mercy of Allah that comes unexpectedly and alleviates suffering. It encourages having faith in Allah's wisdom and trusting in His plan, as He will provide a way out of difficulties for those who remain patient and steadfast.
orig: فناداها من تحتها ألا تحزني قد جعل ربك تحتك سريا

translation: And shake the trunk of the palm tree towards you, it will drop upon you ripe fresh dates.
interpretation: This verse refers to the miraculous birth of Jesus (peace be upon him). Allah commanded the Virgin Mary to shake the trunk of a palm tree, and fresh ripe dates would fall down for her to eat and regain her strength after giving birth. This was a sign from Allah to provide nourishment and comfort for Mary during her difficult time, as well as a miracle testifying to the miraculous birth of Jesus.
orig: وهزي إليك بجذع النخلة تساقط عليك رطبا جنيا

translation: So eat and drink and cool (thine) eye. And if thou dost see any man, say, 'I have vowed a fast to the Beneficent, and may not speak this day to any mortal.'
interpretation: This verse instructs Mary to eat, drink, and be at peace. If she encounters any person, she should indicate that she has taken a vow of silence and fasting to God, and thus cannot engage in conversation on that day.
orig: فكلي واشربي وقري عينا فإما ترين من البشر أحدا فقولي إني نذرت للرحمن صوما فلن أكلم اليوم إنسيا

translation: She brought him to her people, carrying him. They said, 'O Mary, you have certainly done a thing unprecedented.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the miraculous birth of Jesus by Mary. Despite being a virgin, she gave birth to Jesus in an extraordinary manner. The people were astonished and accused her of committing an unthinkable act, as it was inconceivable for a woman to bear a child without a husband at that time.
orig: فأتت به قومها تحمله قالوا يا مريم لقد جئت شيئا فريا

translation: O sister of Aaron! Your father was not a wicked man, nor was your mother an unchaste woman.
interpretation: This verse is addressing Mary, the mother of Jesus, and affirming her noble lineage. It refutes any accusations or doubts about her chastity or the righteousness of her parents. The verse emphasizes that she came from a pious and virtuous family, not one of wickedness or immorality. It serves to honor Mary and establish her pure origins.
orig: يا أخت هارون ما كان أبوك امرأ سوء وما كانت أمك بغيا

translation: But she pointed to the babe. They said: 'How can we talk to one who is a child in the cradle?'
interpretation: This verse refers to the miraculous event of the birth of Prophet Jesus (peace be upon him) to the Virgin Mary. When Mary brought the newborn baby to her people, they accused her of an immoral act. She pointed to the baby Jesus, who then miraculously spoke and declared his prophethood, defending his mother's honor. The verse highlights the divine power of Allah, who enabled a newborn infant to speak and bear witness to the truth.
orig: فأشارت إليه قالوا كيف نكلم من كان في المهد صبيا

translation: He said, 'Verily, I am a servant of Allah. He has given me the Scripture and made me a prophet.'
interpretation: This verse refers to Prophet Jesus (peace be upon him) affirming his status as a servant of God who was honored with divine revelation in the form of the Gospel, and was appointed as a prophet to guide people to the truth. It emphasizes Jesus' humility and submission to God, and his role as a messenger delivering God's message.
orig: قال إني عبد الله آتاني الكتاب وجعلني نبيا

translation: And He has made me blessed wherever I may be, and has enjoined upon me prayer and zakah as long as I remain alive.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah has bestowed blessings upon the Prophet Muhammad wherever he goes, and has commanded him to establish prayer and give zakah (obligatory charity) as long as he lives. The interpretation is that the Prophet is favored by Allah with blessings and guidance, and is required to perform acts of worship like prayer and charity to maintain a close connection with Allah and benefit others.
orig: وجعلني مباركا أين ما كنت وأوصاني بالصلاة والزكاة ما دمت حيا

translation: And He has made me kind to my mother, and not made me an arrogant wretched one.
interpretation: This verse highlights the virtues of being dutiful and kind to one's parents, especially the mother who endured hardship to nurture and raise the child. It condemns arrogance and ingratitude, which are seen as wretched qualities. The speaker is expressing gratitude to God for bestowing upon them the noble traits of kindness and humility towards their mother.
orig: وبرا بوالدتي ولم يجعلني جبارا شقيا

translation: And peace be upon me the day I was born, and the day I die, and the day I am raised alive.
interpretation: This verse is a prayer of Prophet Jesus, seeking peace and protection from Allah on three significant occasions: his birth, death, and resurrection. It reflects his submission to Allah's will and his trust in Allah's mercy and guidance throughout his life's journey.
orig: والسلام علي يوم ولدت ويوم أموت ويوم أبعث حيا

translation: That is Jesus, the son of Mary - the word of truth about which they are in dispute.
interpretation: This verse refers to Jesus as the "word of truth" which caused disputes and disagreements among people. It affirms the reality of Jesus as a prophet and messenger of God, and highlights the controversies surrounding his nature and status among different religious groups.
orig: ذلك عيسى ابن مريم قول الحق الذي فيه يمترون

translation: It is not befitting for Allah to take a son; exalted is He! When He decrees a matter, He only says to it, 'Be,' and it is.
interpretation: This verse affirms the transcendent nature of Allah and refutes the notion that He has a son or offspring. It emphasizes that Allah is far above such human characteristics and is free from any imperfections or needs. When Allah wills something to happen, He merely commands it to 'Be,' and it comes into existence instantaneously, without any difficulty or intermediary. This underscores Allah's absolute power, authority, and uniqueness as the sole Creator and Sustainer of all that exists.
orig: ما كان لله أن يتخذ من ولد سبحانه إذا قضى أمرا فإنما يقول له كن فيكون

translation: And indeed, Allah is my Lord and your Lord, so worship Him. This is a straight path.
interpretation: This verse affirms the Oneness of God (Allah) and His Lordship over all creation. It commands the worship of Allah alone, as He is the true Lord and Sustainer of all. The "straight path" mentioned here refers to the path of guidance, truth, and righteousness leading to Allah's pleasure and salvation in the Hereafter. It is a call to submit to Allah's will and follow His commandments without deviating from the right course.
orig: وإن الله ربي وربكم فاعبدوه هذا صراط مستقيم

translation: But the sects among them differed. So woe to those who disbelieved - from the scene of a tremendous Day.
interpretation: This verse highlights the disagreements and divisions that arose among different religious groups regarding the truth. It serves as a warning to those who rejected faith and disbelieved, for they will face a tremendous and horrific Day of Judgment.
orig: فاختلف الأحزاب من بينهم فويل للذين كفروا من مشهد يوم عظيم

translation: I hear them and see them on the Day they come to Us, but the wrongdoers are today in manifest error.
interpretation: This verse indicates that on the Day of Judgment, Allah will allow the disbelievers to hear and see the truth clearly, unlike in this world where they are in manifest misguidance and error due to their denial and rejection of the truth.
orig: أسمع بهم وأبصر يوم يأتوننا لكن الظالمون اليوم في ضلال مبين

translation: And warn them of the Day of Regret, when the matter will be decided while they are in heedlessness, and they do not believe.
interpretation: This verse warns the disbelievers about the Day of Resurrection, which is called the "Day of Regret" because on that day, they will deeply regret their rejection of faith and their sinful ways. It emphasizes that the final judgment will be passed while they are in a state of heedlessness, oblivious to the reality of the Hereafter, and persisting in their disbelief. The interpretation highlights the urgency of heeding the warning and embracing faith before it is too late.
orig: وأنذرهم يوم الحسرة إذ قضي الأمر وهم في غفلة وهم لا يؤمنون

translation: Indeed, it is We who will inherit the earth and whoever is on it, and to Us they will be returned.
interpretation: This verse affirms Allah's absolute ownership and sovereignty over the entire universe and all that exists within it. It emphasizes that everything in existence ultimately belongs to Allah, and that all creatures will return to Him on the Day of Resurrection. The verse serves as a reminder of Allah's ultimate authority and the temporary nature of our worldly existence. It encourages us to recognize our true purpose in life, which is to worship and submit to the One who will ultimately inherit all that exists.
orig: إنا نحن نرث الأرض ومن عليها وإلينا يرجعون

translation: And mention in the Book, Abraham. Indeed he was a man of truth, a prophet.
interpretation: This verse highlights the virtuous qualities of Prophet Abraham (peace be upon him). He is described as a 'siddiq' which means truthful and sincere, and a 'nabi' meaning prophet. This signifies that Allah chose Abraham for the noble task of prophethood due to his unwavering truthfulness and sincerity towards the divine message.
orig: واذكر في الكتاب إبراهيم إنه كان صديقا نبيا

translation: When he said to his father, "O my father, why do you worship that which does not hear and does not see and will never benefit you in anything?"
interpretation: "This verse refers to Prophet Ibrahim's questioning of his father's idolatry. It emphasizes the futility of worshipping inanimate objects that lack the faculties of hearing, sight, and providing any benefit. The verse highlights Ibrahim's call to his father to abandon the worship of idols and turn to the One True God."
orig: إذ قال لأبيه يا أبت لم تعبد ما لا يسمع ولا يبصر ولا يغني عنك شيئا

translation: O my father! There has come to me knowledge which has not come to you, so follow me; I will guide you to the straight path.
interpretation: This verse refers to the dialogue between Prophet Abraham and his father. Abraham is inviting his father to follow the true religion of worshipping One God, based on the knowledge and guidance he has received from Allah. He promises to guide his father to the "straight path", which represents the right way of life according to Islamic teachings.
orig: يا أبت إني قد جاءني من العلم ما لم يأتك فاتبعني أهدك صراطا سويا

translation: O my father, do not worship Satan. Indeed Satan has ever been, to the Most Merciful, disobedient.
interpretation: This verse is advising against worshipping Satan or following his evil ways, as he has disobeyed and rebelled against Allah, the Most Merciful. It emphasizes the importance of submitting only to Allah and avoiding the path of Satan, which leads to disobedience and defiance against the Creator.
orig: يا أبت لا تعبد الشيطان إن الشيطان كان للرحمن عصيا

translation: O my father, indeed I fear that there will strike you a punishment from the Most Merciful, so you would be a friend to Satan.
interpretation: The son is expressing his concern for his father's disbelief and warning him that if he persists in rejecting the truth, he may incur a punishment from Allah, the Most Merciful, and become an ally of Satan, who misguides people away from the right path.
orig: يا أبت إني أخاف أن يمسك عذاب من الرحمن فتكون للشيطان وليا

translation: He said: "Do you dislike my gods, O Abraham? If you do not desist, I will surely stone you, so avoid me for a long while."
interpretation: This verse refers to the confrontation between Prophet Abraham and his people who worshipped idols. When Abraham rejected their gods, they threatened to stone him and banish him from their land if he did not stop preaching against idolatry. The verse highlights Abraham's unwavering faith in the face of oppression and his willingness to sacrifice everything for the sake of monotheism.
orig: قال أراغب أنت عن آلهتي يا إبراهيم لئن لم تنته لأرجمنك واهجرني مليا

translation: He said, 'Peace be upon you; I will ask forgiveness for you from my Lord. Indeed, He is ever Gracious to me.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Abraham and his father, who was an idolater. Despite Abraham's efforts to guide his father to the true faith, his father remained stubborn. However, Abraham did not give up and promised to seek forgiveness for him from God, recognizing God's immense grace and mercy.
orig: قال سلام عليك سأستغفر لك ربي إنه كان بي حفيا

translation: And I have dissociated myself from you and whatever you worship besides Allah, and I worship my Lord, hoping that I shall not be unblessed in supplicating to my Lord.
interpretation: This verse expresses the firm stance of a believer in dissociating themselves from polytheism and idol worship. It signifies a complete rejection of anything associated with the worship of deities other than Allah. The believer declares their sole devotion to Allah, the One True God, and places their hope in supplicating to Him alone, seeking His blessings and protection from misguidance or wretchedness.
orig: وأعتزلكم وما تدعون من دون الله وأدعو ربي عسى ألا أكون بدعاء ربي شقيا
