translation: So when he turned away from them and from what they worshipped other than Allah, We bestowed upon him Isaac and Jacob, and each [of them] We made a prophet.
interpretation: Allah is indicating that when Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) dissociated himself from his people's worship of idols, and devoted himself solely to the worship of Allah, Allah blessed him with righteous offspring: Isaac and Jacob, and made both of them Prophets to guide people to the true religion of worshipping the One God.
orig: فلما اعتزلهم وما يعبدون من دون الله وهبنا له إسحاق ويعقوب وكلا جعلنا نبيا

translation: And We bestowed upon them out of Our mercy, and We assigned for them a tongue of truthfulness, most high.
interpretation: Allah bestowed His mercy upon the believers by granting them the ability to speak truthfully and eloquently. Their words were characterized by truthfulness and elevated status, reflecting their noble character and closeness to Allah.
orig: ووهبنا لهم من رحمتنا وجعلنا لهم لسان صدق عليا

translation: And mention in the Book, Moses. Indeed, he was chosen and he was a messenger and a prophet.
interpretation: This verse highlights the virtues of Prophet Moses. He is described as being 'chosen' by Allah, indicating his high status and nobility. He was also a 'messenger' who received divine revelation, and a 'prophet' who conveyed Allah's message to his people. The verse emphasizes Moses' role as a respected and honored prophet, reminding believers of his significance in the divine tradition.
orig: واذكر في الكتاب موسى إنه كان مخلصا وكان رسولا نبيا

translation: And We called him from the right side of the Mount and made him draw near to Us for mystic converse.
interpretation: This verse refers to the event when God called upon Prophet Moses from the right side of Mount Sinai (at-Toor al-Ayman) and brought him near for a close communion and to receive divine revelations. It signifies the honor and privilege bestowed upon Moses by God, who chose him as a Messenger and allowed him to directly communicate with the Divine.
orig: وناديناه من جانب الطور الأيمن وقربناه نجيا

translation: And We granted him, out of Our mercy, his brother Aaron as a prophet.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah bestowed His mercy upon Moses by appointing his brother Aaron as a prophet to assist and support him in conveying the message to Pharaoh and the Children of Israel. Having Aaron as a prophet alongside Moses was a great blessing, as it provided strength, support, and companionship in their mission of guiding the people towards the worship of the One True God.
orig: ووهبنا له من رحمتنا أخاه هارون نبيا

translation: And mention in the Book, Ismail. Indeed, he was true to his promise, and he was a messenger and a prophet.
interpretation: This verse highlights the virtues of Prophet Ismail (peace be upon him), who is described as being truthful in his promises and a messenger and prophet sent by Allah. It emphasizes his honesty, trustworthiness, and the honorable status bestowed upon him as a messenger conveying Allah's message and a prophet receiving divine revelation.
orig: واذكر في الكتاب إسماعيل إنه كان صادق الوعد وكان رسولا نبيا

translation: And he used to enjoin on his people prayer and zakah, and he was acceptable in the sight of his Lord.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) and highlights two of his key qualities: 1) He commanded his family and people to establish prayer and pay zakah, demonstrating his role as a leader and guide in promoting righteousness. 2) He was pleasing and accepted in the sight of Allah due to his obedience, sincerity, and devotion.
orig: وكان يأمر أهله بالصلاة والزكاة وكان عند ربه مرضيا

translation: And mention in the Book, Idrees. Indeed, he was a man of truth and a prophet.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Prophet Idrees (peace be upon him), who is mentioned with honor and praise. He was truthful in his words and actions, and he was a prophet sent by Allah to guide his people. The Qur'an highlights his status as a "siddeeq" (a man of truth) and a "nabi" (a prophet), indicating his high rank and closeness to Allah.
orig: واذكر في الكتاب إدريس إنه كان صديقا نبيا

translation: And We raised him to a high station.
interpretation: This verse refers to the great honor and elevated spiritual status bestowed upon Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) by Allah. It signifies that Allah raised the Prophet to a lofty and exalted position, granting him the highest rank among all prophets and messengers. The "high station" mentioned here represents the Prophet's proximity to Allah, his noble character, and his role as the final messenger and the seal of the prophets.
orig: ورفعناه مكانا عليا

translation: Those were the ones on whom Allah bestowed favor from among the prophets of the descendants of Adam and of those We carried [in the ship] with Noah, and of the descendants of Abraham and Israel, and of those whom We guided and chose. When the verses of the Most Merciful were recited to them, they fell in prostration and weeping.
interpretation: This verse highlights the honor and virtue of the Prophets and those who followed their guidance. It mentions that Allah bestowed His favor upon them, including the Prophets from the descendants of Adam, those who were with Prophet Noah in the ark, the descendants of Prophets Abraham and Israel (Jacob), and those whom Allah guided and chose. When the verses of the Qur'an were recited to them, they humbly prostrated and wept out of reverence, awe, and appreciation for Allah's words.
orig: أولئك الذين أنعم الله عليهم من النبيين من ذرية آدم وممن حملنا مع نوح ومن ذرية إبراهيم وإسرائيل وممن هدينا واجتبينا إذا تتلى عليهم آيات الرحمن خروا سجدا وبكيا

translation: Then there succeeded them a posterity who lost the prayer and followed lusts, so they will face Ghayya.
interpretation: This verse refers to the generations that came after the righteous predecessors. They neglected the obligatory prayers and indulged in their desires and sinful pleasures. As a result, they will encounter "Ghayya," which means misguidance, deviation, or a valley in Hell where they will be led astray and suffer the consequences of their actions.
orig: فخلف من بعدهم خلف أضاعوا الصلاة واتبعوا الشهوات فسوف يلقون غيا

translation: Except for those who repent, believe and do righteous deeds. For them there will be no fear, nor will they grieve.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of repentance, faith, and good deeds. It promises that those who sincerely repent from their sins, have faith in Allah, and perform righteous deeds will enter Paradise without any injustice or deprivation. The door of forgiveness is open to all who turn to Allah in sincere repentance and mend their ways through belief and good actions.
orig: إلا من تاب وآمن وعمل صالحا فأولئك يدخلون الجنة ولا يظلمون شيئا

translation: Gardens of perpetual residence which the Most Merciful has promised His servants in the unseen. Indeed, His promise has ever been coming.
interpretation: This verse describes the reward that Allah has promised to the believers in the Hereafter - Gardens of Paradise where they will dwell forever. It emphasizes that this promise is from the Most Merciful (Allah), and it is unseen by us in this world. However, Allah's promise is certain to be fulfilled, as His promise is always true and will inevitably come to pass.
orig: جنات عدن التي وعد الرحمن عباده بالغيب إنه كان وعده مأتيا

translation: They shall not hear therein ill speech or commission of sin, but only the saying of peace, and they will have their provision therein, morning and evening.
interpretation: The verse describes the blissful state of the righteous in Paradise. They will not hear any vain or sinful talk, but only greetings of peace. Their sustenance will be provided for them morning and evening without any effort on their part. This depicts the serenity, purity, and abundance they will enjoy as a reward for their good deeds in this world.
orig: لا يسمعون فيها لغوا إلا سلاما ولهم رزقهم فيها بكرة وعشيا

translation: That is the Paradise which We shall give as inheritance to those of Our servants who were ever God-revering.
interpretation: This verse promises Paradise as an inheritance for those who were pious and God-fearing in their lives. It emphasizes that the reward of Paradise is reserved for those who lived righteously and obeyed Allah's commands. The use of the word "inherit" suggests that Paradise is a permanent abode that the believers will enjoy eternally as a result of their good deeds and devotion to Allah.
orig: تلك الجنة التي نورث من عبادنا من كان تقيا

translation: And We do not descend except by the command of your Lord. To Him belongs whatever is before us and whatever is behind us and whatever is between that, and your Lord has never been forgetful.
interpretation: This verse affirms that the revelation of the Qur'an and the descent of the angels take place only by the command of Allah. It emphasizes that Allah has complete knowledge and control over everything that has happened, is happening, and will happen in the past, present, and future. Nothing escapes His knowledge or power. This reassures the Prophet Muhammad that the revelation he receives is from the All-Knowing and All-Powerful Lord, who does not forget anything.
orig: وما نتنزل إلا بأمر ربك له ما بين أيدينا وما خلفنا وما بين ذلك وما كان ربك نسيا

translation: Lord of the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them - so worship Him and have patience for His worship. Do you know of any similarity to Him?
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the Oneness and Uniqueness of Allah as the Lord and Creator of the heavens, the earth, and everything in between. It commands us to worship Him alone and be patient and steadfast in our worship, as He has no equal or partner. The rhetorical question at the end reinforces Allah's incomparability and affirms that there is nothing like unto Him.
orig: رب السماوات والأرض وما بينهما فاعبده واصطبر لعبادته هل تعلم له سميا

translation: And man says, "When I am dead, shall I be brought forth alive?"
interpretation: This verse refers to the denial of resurrection and life after death by disbelievers. It highlights the arrogance of man in questioning the power of Allah to resurrect him after death, considering it impossible or unlikely. The interpretation emphasizes the need for faith in Allah's ability to give life after death, as this is a fundamental belief in Islam.
orig: ويقول الإنسان أإذا ما مت لسوف أخرج حيا

translation: Does man not remember that We created him before, while he was nothing?
interpretation: This verse questions man's ingratitude and forgetfulness of his humble origins. It reminds him that before his existence, he was nothing, and it was Allah who created him from nothingness. The verse highlights man's arrogance in forgetting his Creator and the fact that he owes his very existence to Allah's power and will.
orig: أولا يذكر الإنسان أنا خلقناه من قبل ولم يك شيئا

translation: So, by your Lord, We will surely gather them and the devils together, then We will bring them assembled around Hell, on their knees.
interpretation: This verse indicates that on the Day of Judgment, Allah will gather all the disbelievers and the devils who misguided them, and bring them together surrounding Hell, humbled and on their knees. It highlights Allah's power and control over all creation, and that the disbelievers and devils will face a humiliating punishment for their rejection of faith and their misdeeds.
orig: فوربك لنحشرنهم والشياطين ثم لنحضرنهم حول جهنم جثيا

translation: Then We will surely extract from every sect those of them who were worst in obstinate rebellion against the Most Merciful.
interpretation: This verse implies that on the Day of Judgment, Allah will single out from every group or sect the individuals who were most arrogant and defiant towards Him. They will face severe punishment for their obstinate rejection of faith and disobedience to the Most Merciful. It serves as a warning against arrogance, rebellion, and disbelief in the face of Allah's signs and revelations.
orig: ثم لننزعن من كل شيعة أيهم أشد على الرحمن عتيا

translation: Then surely We know best those who are most worthy of being therein.
interpretation: According to this verse, Allah knows best who deserves to be in Paradise (Jannah) based on their faith, deeds, and sincerity. It implies that entry into Paradise is determined by Allah's wisdom and knowledge of people's true intentions and actions, not by outward appearances or claims. The interpretation emphasizes Allah's absolute authority in judging who is truly deserving of the eternal bliss of Paradise.
orig: ثم لنحن أعلم بالذين هم أولى بها صليا

translation: And there is none of you except he will come to it. This is upon your Lord an inevitability decreed.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that every single human being will inevitably face death and enter the Hellfire, as it is a decree from Allah that cannot be avoided. However, for the believers, their entry into Hellfire will only be temporary before they are admitted into Paradise due to Allah's mercy and their good deeds.
orig: وإن منكم إلا واردها كان على ربك حتما مقضيا

translation: Then We will save those who were mindful of Allah, and leave the wrongdoers in it, on their knees.
interpretation: This verse indicates that on the Day of Judgment, Allah will save the pious believers who feared Him and obeyed His commands. As for the wrongdoers who persisted in disbelief and disobedience, they will be left in a humiliating state, on their knees, unable to escape the punishment they deserve for their transgressions.
orig: ثم ننجي الذين اتقوا ونذر الظالمين فيها جثيا

translation: And when Our clear verses are recited to them, those who disbelieved say to those who believed, 'Which of the two parties is better in position and finer in assembly?'
interpretation: The disbelievers mocked the believers and questioned which group was superior and had a better way of life, thinking that their affluence and social status made them better than the believers.
orig: وإذا تتلى عليهم آياتنا بينات قال الذين كفروا للذين آمنوا أي الفريقين خير مقاما وأحسن نديا

translation: And how many a generation before them did We destroy, who were better in possessions and in appearance?
interpretation: This verse reminds us that Allah has destroyed many powerful nations before who were more affluent and impressive in their material possessions and outward appearances. It serves as a warning that worldly wealth and physical beauty are temporary and do not guarantee salvation. True success lies in faith, righteousness, and obedience to Allah.
orig: وكم أهلكنا قبلهم من قرن هم أحسن أثاثا ورئيا

translation: Say, "Whoever is in error - the Most Merciful will extend for him an extension until, when they see what they were promised - either the punishment or the Hour - they will come to know who is worst in position and weaker in soldiers."
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that those who persist in misguidance and disbelief will be granted a respite by Allah's mercy, until they face the consequences of their choices, either in the form of punishment in this world or on the Day of Resurrection. At that point, they will realize the gravity of their situation and the weakness of their stance against Allah's truth. It serves as a warning to reflect and embrace guidance before it's too late.
orig: قل من كان في الضلالة فليمدد له الرحمن مدا حتى إذا رأوا ما يوعدون إما العذاب وإما الساعة فسيعلمون من هو شر مكانا وأضعف جندا

translation: And those who are guided, He increases them in guidance, and gives them their righteousness.
interpretation: Allah increases the guidance and understanding of those who seek it sincerely. The righteous deeds that endure and benefit others are better in the sight of Allah and will earn a greater reward from Him.
orig: ويزيد الله الذين اهتدوا هدى والباقيات الصالحات خير عند ربك ثوابا وخير مردا

translation: Have you seen him who disbelieved in Our verses and said, 'I will surely be given wealth and children'?
interpretation: This verse refers to the arrogance and ingratitude of those who deny Allah's signs and revelations. They think that their wealth and offspring are a result of their own efforts, rather than blessings from Allah. They become deluded by their material possessions and fail to recognize the true source of all bounties.
orig: أفرأيت الذي كفر بآياتنا وقال لأوتين مالا وولدا

translation: Do I have knowledge of the unseen or have I taken a covenant with the Most Merciful?
interpretation: The Prophet is denying any claim of having knowledge of the unseen or any special covenant with Allah. He is affirming that he is a human messenger conveying the message revealed to him by Allah.
orig: أطلع الغيب أم اتخذ عند الرحمن عهدا

translation: Nay, We shall record what he says, and prolong for him a span of torment.
interpretation: This verse warns those who reject the truth and persist in disbelief that Allah will record their words and deeds, and they will be held accountable for them. Their punishment will be prolonged and intensified in the Hereafter as a result of their obstinacy and arrogance.
orig: كلا سنكتب ما يقول ونمد له من العذاب مدا

translation: And We shall inherit from him what he says, and he will come to Us alone.
interpretation: Allah says that He will preserve the words of the disbeliever, and record them as evidence against him on the Day of Judgment. The disbeliever will come before Allah alone, with no wealth, family or companions to aid him. He will be held accountable for his words and deeds.
orig: ونرثه ما يقول ويأتينا فردا

translation: And they have taken besides Allah [other] deities that they would be for them [a source of] honor.
interpretation: This verse criticizes the polytheists for worshipping idols and false gods besides Allah, thinking that these deities would bring them honor and status. However, the Qur'an emphasizes that true honor and dignity come only from worshipping the One True God, Allah.
orig: واتخذوا من دون الله آلهة ليكونوا لهم عزا

translation: Nay, but they will deny their worship, and will become opposers against them.
interpretation: This verse warns that the disbelievers will deny worshipping their false deities on the Day of Judgment, and those very deities will turn against them and become their opposers, testifying that the disbelievers had worshipped them instead of Allah.
orig: كلا سيكفرون بعبادتهم ويكونون عليهم ضدا

translation: Have you not seen that We have sent the devils upon the disbelievers, prodding them with a vigorous prodding?
interpretation: This verse warns the disbelievers that Allah has unleashed the devils upon them to continuously incite and provoke them towards evil deeds and disbelief. The devils persistently urge and tempt the disbelievers to stray further away from the truth and indulge in sinful acts, leading them towards their own destruction.
orig: ألم تر أنا أرسلنا الشياطين على الكافرين تؤزهم أزا

translation: So do not be impatient with them. We only count out to them a [limited] number.
interpretation: "This verse advises patience and forbids hastiness in dealing with the disbelievers. It indicates that Allah has predetermined a specific time for their punishment, and that this will inevitably come to pass. The believers should not rush or be anxious, as Allah's plan will unfold according to His wisdom."
orig: فلا تعجل عليهم إنما نعد لهم عدا

translation: The Day when We will gather the righteous to the Most Merciful as a delegation
interpretation: This verse refers to the Day of Resurrection when the pious and God-fearing people will be gathered together and escorted with honor and dignity to the presence of Allah, the Most Merciful. It highlights the special status and reward that the righteous will receive for their faith and good deeds.
orig: يوم نحشر المتقين إلى الرحمن وفدا

translation: And We shall drive the criminals to Hell, in thirst.
interpretation: This verse warns of the severe punishment that awaits the disobedient and wicked people in the Hereafter. Allah will gather them together and force them towards Hellfire, suffering from an intense thirst and burning desire that can never be quenched. It serves as a stern reminder of the grave consequences of rejecting faith and leading an immoral life devoid of obedience to Allah.
orig: ونسوق المجرمين إلى جهنم وردا

translation: None will have the power of intercession, except he who has made a covenant with the Most Merciful.
interpretation: Only those whom Allah has permitted can intercede on behalf of others on the Day of Judgment. This privilege is granted exclusively to those who have fulfilled their covenant with Allah by obeying His commands and avoiding His prohibitions.
orig: لا يملكون الشفاعة إلا من اتخذ عند الرحمن عهدا

translation: And they say, 'The Most Merciful has taken a son.'
interpretation: This verse refutes the false belief held by some that God has a son. It rejects the idea that the One True God, who is the Most Merciful, could have offspring, as this would contradict His Oneness and Absolute Perfection. The Qur'an emphasizes that God is far above such anthropomorphic concepts and is free from any notion of procreation or family relations.
orig: وقالوا اتخذ الرحمن ولدا

translation: You have certainly brought a grave thing
interpretation: This verse is expressing that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) has brought a serious and weighty matter or teaching that is difficult to accept or comprehend. It implies that the message of Islam was perceived as something grave or momentous by those who initially received it.
orig: لقد جئتم شيئا إدا

translation: The heavens are almost torn apart from it, and the earth is split asunder, and the mountains fall in ruins,
interpretation: This verse describes the tremendous magnitude and power of Allah's revelations and signs. The heavens, earth, and mountains are personified as being in awe and nearly breaking apart due to the grandeur of Allah's message. It emphasizes the importance of respecting and heeding Allah's revelations, as even the mightiest elements of creation tremble before them.
orig: تكاد السماوات يتفطرن منه وتنشق الأرض وتخر الجبال هدا

translation: That they ascribe a son to the Most Merciful
interpretation: This verse condemns the polytheistic belief of attributing a son to Allah, the Most Merciful. It rejects the notion that Allah could have offspring, as this contradicts His absolute Oneness and transcendent nature. The interpretation emphasizes Allah's transcendence above such human characteristics and the falsehood of ascribing partners or children to Him.
orig: أن دعوا للرحمن ولدا

translation: And it is not befitting for the Most Merciful to take a son.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the transcendence and uniqueness of Allah, the Most Merciful. It negates the notion that Allah would take a son or offspring, which would contradict His absolute Oneness and independence. This refutes the Christian belief in Jesus being the "Son of God" in a literal sense. The verse affirms that such a concept is incompatible with Allah's majesty and attributes.
orig: وما ينبغي للرحمن أن يتخذ ولدا

translation: Indeed, there is no one in the heavens and the earth but he comes to the Most Merciful as a servant.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the universal servitude of all creatures to Allah, the Most Merciful. It affirms that every being in the heavens and the earth, without exception, is a servant of Allah and will come to Him in submission and humility. This highlights the sovereignty and absolute dominion of Allah over His creation, and the recognition of His Lordship by all beings, whether willingly or unwillingly.
orig: إن كل من في السماوات والأرض إلا آتي الرحمن عبدا

translation: He has counted them and numbered them precisely.
interpretation: This verse suggests that Allah has complete knowledge and awareness of all His creations. He has enumerated and accounted for them with precision, leaving nothing uncounted or unaccounted for. It highlights Allah's perfect knowledge, power, and authority over all that exists.
orig: لقد أحصاهم وعدهم عدا

translation: And all of them are coming to Him on the Day of Resurrection alone.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the individual accountability of every person on the Day of Resurrection. On that Day, each person will stand alone before Allah, without any support or help from anyone else. It highlights the importance of preparing for that Day by living a righteous life and seeking Allah's forgiveness and mercy.
orig: وكلهم آتيه يوم القيامة فردا

translation: Indeed, those who have believed and done righteous deeds - the Most Merciful will appoint for them affection.
interpretation: This verse promises that Allah, the Most Merciful, will bestow a special love and affection upon those who have faith and perform righteous deeds. It implies a deep connection between the believers and their Lord, where they will experience His mercy, care, and closeness in a profound way.
orig: إن الذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات سيجعل لهم الرحمن ودا

translation: So indeed, We have made it easy in your tongue, only so that you may give good news thereby to the pious, and warn thereby a hostile people.
interpretation: Allah made the Qur'an easy to understand and memorize in the Arabic language, which was the Prophet's native tongue, so that he could convey its message of glad tidings to the righteous believers, and warn the stubborn disbelievers who were hostile to the truth.
orig: فإنما يسرناه بلسانك لتبشر به المتقين وتنذر به قوما لدا

translation: And how many a generation before them did We destroy? Do you perceive of them anyone or hear from them a sound?
interpretation: This verse is reminding us of the fate of past nations who rejected Allah's messengers and disobeyed His commands. Allah destroyed them completely, leaving no trace of their existence. It serves as a warning to the present generation to take heed and not follow in their footsteps, lest they meet the same end. The rhetorical questions "Do you perceive of them anyone or hear from them a sound?" emphasize the utter destruction and disappearance of those past nations, leaving no remnants behind.
orig: وكم أهلكنا قبلهم من قرن هل تحس منهم من أحد أو تسمع لهم ركزا

translation: Taa Haa.
interpretation: This is one of the unique letter combinations that begin some chapters of the Qur'an. Though the precise meaning is known only to Allah, these letters are believed to draw attention to the divine origin of the Qur'an and the miraculous nature of its language. They may also have symbolic meanings related to the names or attributes of Allah.
orig: طه

translation: We have not sent down the Qur'an to you to cause you distress
interpretation: Allah reassures the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, that the revelation of the Qur'an is not meant to be a burden or hardship upon him. Rather, it is a mercy and guidance, intended to bring ease and light to his heart and life.
orig: ما أنزلنا عليك القرآن لتشقى

translation: But only a reminder for he who fears [Allah]
interpretation: This verse suggests that the Qur'an serves as a reminder and guidance, but its message will only benefit those who have a sincere fear and reverence for Allah. It implies that true understanding and benefiting from the Qur'an requires a humble and God-fearing attitude.
orig: إلا تذكرة لمن يخشى

translation: A revelation from He who created the earth and the highest heavens.
interpretation: This verse affirms that the Qur'an is a divine revelation sent down by Allah, the Creator of the entire universe, including the earth and the highest celestial realms. It emphasizes the transcendent and supreme nature of Allah as the source of this sacred scripture, instilling a sense of reverence and awe towards its teachings.
orig: تنزيلا ممن خلق الأرض والسماوات العلى

translation: The Most Merciful has established Himself over the Throne.
interpretation: This verse affirms Allah's transcendence and sovereignty over His creation. The phrase "established Himself over the Throne" is a metaphorical expression that signifies Allah's absolute authority, power, and control over the entire universe. It does not imply any physical or anthropomorphic qualities, as Allah is beyond any likeness to His creation. The verse emphasizes Allah's majesty, grandeur, and supremacy as the sole Creator and Sustainer of all that exists.
orig: الرحمن على العرش استوى

translation: To Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth and whatever is between them and whatever is under the soil.
interpretation: This verse affirms Allah's absolute ownership and sovereignty over all of creation. It emphasizes that everything in the heavens, on the earth, in between them, and even beneath the soil belongs to Allah alone. This establishes His complete authority and control over the entire universe and all that exists within it. The verse serves as a reminder of our utter dependence on Allah and the need to submit to His will and commandments.
orig: له ما في السماوات وما في الأرض وما بينهما وما تحت الثرى

translation: And if you speak aloud - then indeed, He knows the secret and what is [even] more hidden.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah is All-Knowing and All-Aware. He knows what is spoken aloud as well as the secrets and most hidden thoughts within one's mind and heart. It serves as a reminder that nothing is hidden from Allah's knowledge, and one should be mindful of their words, thoughts, and actions, as Allah is fully aware of everything.
orig: وإن تجهر بالقول فإنه يعلم السر وأخفى

translation: Allah - there is no deity except Him, to Him belong the best names.
interpretation: This verse affirms the Oneness of Allah and that He alone is worthy of worship. It also highlights that Allah possesses the most beautiful names and attributes, which reflect His perfection and majesty. The "best names" refer to the sublime qualities that Allah has revealed about Himself in the Qur'an, such as "The Most Merciful," "The All-Knowing," and "The Sustainer." This verse reminds us to recognize and appreciate the greatness and perfection of Allah.
orig: الله لا إله إلا هو له الأسماء الحسنى

translation: And has the story of Moses reached you?
interpretation: This verse is introducing the story of Moses, peace be upon him, which is narrated in the following verses. It is drawing the listener's attention to this significant event and inviting them to ponder over the lessons and guidance contained within it.
orig: وهل أتاك حديث موسى

translation: When he saw a fire, he said to his family, "Stay here; indeed, I have perceived a fire. Perhaps I can bring you a torch or find at the fire some guidance."
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident when Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) saw a fire while traveling with his family. He perceived it as a sign of guidance or a source of warmth, so he decided to approach it, hoping to bring back a torch or find some directions. This marked the beginning of his divine encounter and the revelation he received from Allah.
orig: إذ رأى نارا فقال لأهله امكثوا إني آنست نارا لعلي آتيكم منها بقبس أو أجد على النار هدى

translation: And when he came to it, he was called, 'O Moses!'
interpretation: This verse refers to the moment when Prophet Moses reached the sacred valley and was called by Allah. It signifies the beginning of his divine mission and the revelation he was about to receive. The call "O Moses!" indicates Allah's direct address to him, marking the start of a profound spiritual journey and the communication of divine guidance.
orig: فلما أتاها نودي يا موسى

translation: Verily, I am your Lord! So take off your sandals; you are in the sacred valley, Tuwa.
interpretation: This verse refers to the divine calling of Prophet Moses when God spoke to him directly from the blessed valley of Tuwa. It signifies the sanctity and holiness of the place where God's words were revealed. By commanding Moses to remove his sandals, God emphasizes the need for utmost humility, respect, and preparedness when in the presence of the Divine. The verse underscores the transcendent nature of God's revelation and the profound spiritual experience Moses was about to undergo.
orig: إني أنا ربك فاخلع نعليك إنك بالواد المقدس طوى

translation: And I have chosen you, so listen to what is revealed.
interpretation: This verse is addressing the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him. It indicates that Allah has chosen and selected him to receive the divine revelation and guidance. Therefore, he must listen attentively and obey what is being revealed to him through the angel Gabriel.
orig: وأنا اخترتك فاستمع لما يوحى

translation: Indeed, I am Allah. There is no deity except Me, so worship Me and establish prayer for My remembrance.
interpretation: This verse affirms the Oneness of Allah and commands the believers to worship Him alone and establish regular prayer as a means of remembering and glorifying Him. It emphasizes that Allah is the only true God worthy of worship and obedience, and that prayer is a fundamental pillar of faith that keeps one connected to the Divine.
orig: إنني أنا الله لا إله إلا أنا فاعبدني وأقم الصلاة لذكري

translation: Indeed, the Hour is coming - I almost conceal it - so that every soul may be recompensed according to that for which it strives.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the certainty of the Day of Resurrection, which Allah has kept hidden so that people may strive according to their beliefs and intentions, and be held accountable for their deeds. It serves as a reminder to prepare for that inevitable Day by doing righteous deeds and avoiding sins.
orig: إن الساعة آتية أكاد أخفيها لتجزى كل نفس بما تسعى

translation: So do not be diverted from it by those who do not believe in it, and follow their desires, lest you perish.
interpretation: Allah is commanding the Prophet to adhere firmly to the Qur'an and not be misled by those who reject it and follow their own desires and whims. Doing so will lead to ruin and destruction in this life and the Hereafter.
orig: فلا يصدنك عنها من لا يؤمن بها واتبع هواه فتردى

translation: And what is that in your right hand, O Moses?
interpretation: This verse is questioning Moses about the staff or stick in his right hand. It implies that the staff had a special significance or purpose, which is revealed later in the story when Allah commands Moses to throw it down and it becomes a snake, demonstrating one of the miracles given to him.
orig: وما تلك بيمينك يا موسى

translation: He said: 'It is my staff; I lean on it, and I beat down leaves for my sheep, and in it I have other uses.'
interpretation: The verse refers to the staff of Prophet Moses, which had multiple functions beyond just being a walking stick. It was a tool he used for herding his sheep, as well as a means for achieving other objectives or "uses" that are not explicitly mentioned. This could allude to the miraculous powers that Allah later bestowed upon Moses' staff, allowing it to turn into a serpent and perform other wonders.
orig: قال هي عصاي أتوكأ عليها وأهش بها على غنمي ولي فيها مآرب أخرى

translation: He said: 'Cast it down, O Moses!'
interpretation: This verse refers to the moment when Allah commanded Moses to cast down his staff, which then miraculously turned into a serpent. This was one of the signs Allah granted Moses to prove his prophethood to Pharaoh and the Egyptians. The interpretation is that Allah has the power to transform ordinary objects into extraordinary phenomena, as a manifestation of His might and a test for those who witness such miracles.
orig: قال ألقها يا موسى

translation: So he threw it down, and behold, it was a serpent, moving swiftly.
interpretation: The verse is interpreted as an affirmation of the miracle granted to Prophet Moses, peace be upon him. When he cast down his staff by Allah's command, it transformed into a living, rapidly moving serpent. This served as a sign from Allah, demonstrating His power and validating Moses' prophethood.
orig: فألقاها فإذا هي حية تسعى

translation: He said, 'Take it and do not fear, We will restore it to its former state.'
interpretation: This verse refers to a miraculous event where Allah commanded Prophet Musa (Moses) to cast his staff onto the ground, and it turned into a snake. However, Allah reassured Musa not to fear, as the staff would return to its original form by Allah's command. This demonstrated Allah's power and Musa's prophethood.
orig: قال خذها ولا تخف سنعيدها سيرتها الأولى

translation: And draw your hand close to your side; it shall come forth white without disease - another sign.
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as a miracle given to Prophet Moses by Allah. When Moses was commanded to put his hand into his bosom and take it out, his hand came out shining white like light, but without any disease or defect. This was a sign from Allah to prove Moses' prophethood and support his message.
orig: واضمم يدك إلى جناحك تخرج بيضاء من غير سوء آية أخرى

translation: That We may show you (O Muhammad) some of Our greatest signs.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah will show the Prophet Muhammad some of His greatest signs and miracles as proof of His power and as a means of strengthening the Prophet's faith and that of his followers. The "greatest signs" could refer to various miracles and events that occurred during the Prophet's lifetime, such as the splitting of the moon or the miraculous victories in battles against the disbelievers, despite being outnumbered and outmatched. It could also refer to the revelation of the Qur'an itself, which is considered the greatest miracle given to the Prophet Muhammad.
orig: لنريك من آياتنا الكبرى

translation: Go to Pharaoh; indeed, he has transgressed.
interpretation: This verse commands Prophet Moses to confront Pharaoh, the tyrannical ruler of Egypt at the time, who had become arrogant and transgressed all bounds by claiming divinity and oppressing the Israelites. It signifies that no matter how powerful or oppressive a ruler may be, they must be stood up to and called to account for their injustices and tyranny.
orig: اذهب إلى فرعون إنه طغى

translation: He said, 'My Lord, expand for me my breast [with assurance]'
interpretation: The interpretation is that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) is asking Allah to grant him courage, confidence, and reassurance in his heart, so that he can fulfill his mission of conveying the message of Islam with ease and without any hesitation or fear.
orig: قال رب اشرح لي صدري

translation: And ease for me my task
interpretation: This verse is a supplication asking Allah to make one's affairs easy and remove any difficulties or obstacles. It recognizes that true ease and facilitation of matters comes from Allah alone, and one should turn to Him for assistance in overcoming challenges and fulfilling responsibilities.
orig: ويسر لي أمري

translation: And untie the knot from my tongue
interpretation: This verse is a supplication seeking Allah's help to remove any impediment or difficulty in speech and eloquence. It is a request for Allah to grant clarity, fluency, and eloquence in expressing oneself, and to remove any barriers or obstacles that may hinder effective communication.
orig: واحلل عقدة من لساني

translation: That they may understand my speech
interpretation: This verse implies that the Qur'an has been revealed in a clear and eloquent manner, using the Arabic language which was the native tongue of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and his people. The purpose is to make the message easily understandable and comprehensible to those who have knowledge of the Arabic language. It suggests that the Qur'an is not meant to be a complicated or ambiguous book, but rather a clear guide for humanity, conveyed in a language they can grasp and "understand".
orig: يفقهوا قولي

translation: And appoint for me a minister from my family
interpretation: In this verse, Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) is asking Allah to appoint a minister or assistant from his family to help him in his mission. This could be interpreted as a request for moral and practical support from a close and trusted relative who shares his values and beliefs. It highlights the importance of having reliable companions and helpers in fulfilling one's duties, especially in a position of leadership or responsibility.
orig: واجعل لي وزيرا من أهلي

translation: Aaron, my brother
interpretation: This verse refers to the close relationship between Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and Prophet Aaron, who was the brother of Prophet Moses. It highlights the bond of brotherhood and support that existed between the prophets of Allah.
orig: هارون أخي

translation: Strengthen me with him
interpretation: This verse is a supplication from Prophet Moses to Allah, asking Him to strengthen him with his brother Aaron. Moses is seeking support and assistance from his brother in carrying out the mission of conveying the message of Allah to Pharaoh and his people. It reflects the importance of seeking help and cooperation in fulfilling righteous tasks and goals.
orig: اشدد به أزري

translation: And associate him in my affair
interpretation: This verse suggests involving the person being addressed in one's affairs or decision-making process, seeking their counsel and partnership. It implies sharing responsibility and authority, rather than acting alone.
orig: وأشركه في أمري

translation: That we may glorify You much
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of constantly praising and glorifying Allah, the Almighty. It suggests that one of the purposes of our existence is to engage in the remembrance and exaltation of Allah through various acts of worship and obedience. The frequent glorification of Allah is a means of expressing gratitude, humility, and devotion to the Divine Creator.
orig: كي نسبحك كثيرا

translation: And we will remind you repeatedly
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah will continuously remind the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) of the Qur'anic teachings and guidance, so that he remains steadfast and does not forget or deviate from the path of truth. It emphasizes Allah's constant support and reinforcement for the Prophet in conveying the divine message.
orig: ونذكرك كثيرا

translation: Verily, You have been Ever Watchful over us
interpretation: This verse affirms that Allah has been constantly watchful and aware of the condition and deeds of His servants. It signifies that nothing escapes His knowledge and that He witnesses all our actions, whether good or bad. This awareness should instill a sense of accountability and consciousness of Allah in our hearts, motivating us to strive for righteousness and seek His pleasure.
orig: إنك كنت بنا بصيرا

translation: He said, 'You have been granted your request, O Moses.'
interpretation: This verse suggests that God granted Moses' request or prayer, indicating that God responds favorably to sincere supplications from His righteous servants.
orig: قال قد أوتيت سؤلك يا موسى

translation: And We have certainly conferred favor upon you, [O Muhammad], on another occasion.
interpretation: Allah reminds the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, of another favor He bestowed upon him. This could refer to various events in the Prophet's life where Allah guided and protected him, such as the night journey (Al-Isra') and ascension to the heavens (Al-Mi'raj), or the treaty of Hudaybiyyah which later led to the conquest of Makkah.
orig: ولقد مننا عليك مرة أخرى

translation: When We inspired to your mother what We inspired,
interpretation: This verse is referring to the divine revelation given to the mother of Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him. It implies that Allah revealed or inspired something to her, although the specific content of that revelation is not mentioned in this verse. The interpretation could be that Allah prepared and guided the mother of the Prophet, even before his birth, to nurture and raise him in a way that would make him ready for his great mission as the final Messenger of God.
orig: إذ أوحينا إلى أمك ما يوحى

translation: Cast him into the ark, and cast it into the river, then the river shall cast it on the shore, there shall take him up one who is an enemy to Me and an enemy to him. And I endowed you with love from Me, and that you may be brought up under My eye.
interpretation: Allah commanded Moses' mother to put him in a basket and cast it into the river Nile. The basket would be carried by the river to the shore, where Pharaoh, who was an enemy to Allah and to Moses, would find him. Allah assured Moses' mother that He would return Moses to her with His love and mercy, and that he would be raised under Allah's protection and care.
orig: أن اقذفيه في التابوت فاقذفيه في اليم فليلقه اليم بالساحل يأخذه عدو لي وعدو له وألقيت عليك محبة مني ولتصنع على عيني

translation: When your sister went and said, 'Shall I direct you to someone who will nurse him?' So We returned you to your mother that she might be content and not grieve. And you killed a man, but We saved you from great distress and tried you with a tremendous trial. Then you stayed for years among the people of Midian. Then you came [here] upon an occasion, O Moses.
interpretation: Cette verse fait référence à différents événements de la vie du prophète Moïse. Elle rappelle comment Dieu l'a sauvé et protégé à plusieurs reprises : lorsqu'il était bébé et que sa soeur a permis qu'il soit rendu à sa mère pour être nourri, lorsqu'il a tué un homme par accident et que Dieu l'a épargné, et lorsqu'il a dû fuir en Madyan où il a vécu pendant des années. La verse souligne la miséricorde et la protection divines envers Moïse tout au long de sa vie, malgré les épreuves traversées.
orig: إذ تمشي أختك فتقول هل أدلكم على من يكفله فرجعناك إلى أمك كي تقر عينها ولا تحزن وقتلت نفسا فنجيناك من الغم وفتناك فتونا فلبثت سنين في أهل مدين ثم جئت على قدر يا موسى

translation: And I have chosen you for Myself.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah has specially chosen and prepared the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) for a great purpose, to convey His message and guidance to humanity. It signifies the honor and distinction bestowed upon the Prophet by Allah, selecting him from among all people to receive divine revelation and prophethood. The interpretation emphasizes the unique and privileged position of the Prophet as the chosen messenger of Allah, destined to guide people to the straight path.
orig: واصطنعتك لنفسي

translation: Go, you and your brother, with My signs and do not slacken in My remembrance.
interpretation: This verse commands the Prophet Muhammad and his brother (referring to the believers) to convey the divine signs and proofs to the people, and to remain steadfast in worshipping and obeying Allah without any negligence or weakness.
orig: اذهب أنت وأخوك بآياتي ولا تنيا في ذكري

translation: Go, both of you, to Pharaoh. Indeed, he has transgressed.
interpretation: Allah commands Moses and Aaron to confront Pharaoh, who has exceeded all bounds in his arrogance, tyranny, and disbelief. This verse highlights Pharaoh's transgression against the truth and his oppression of the Children of Israel.
orig: اذهبا إلى فرعون إنه طغى

translation: So speak to him with gentle speech that perhaps he may be reminded or would fear [Allah].
interpretation: This verse instructs the believers to speak gently and with kindness to those who have gone astray or committed sins. By using a soft and compassionate approach, there is a greater chance that the person will be receptive, reflect upon their actions, and fear the consequences of disobeying Allah. The verse emphasizes the importance of dawah (calling others to Islam) through wisdom, beautiful preaching, and gentle persuasion rather than harshness or confrontation.
orig: فقولا له قولا لينا لعله يتذكر أو يخشى

translation: They said, 'Our Lord, indeed we fear that he might act oppressively toward us or transgress all bounds.'
interpretation: The interpretation is that the two angels expressed their concern to Allah about being assigned to guide a human being, fearing that the human might become arrogant or rebel against the guidance, which could lead them to sin by failing in their duty.
orig: قالا ربنا إننا نخاف أن يفرط علينا أو أن يطغى

translation: He (Allah) said, 'Fear not, indeed I am with you both; I hear and I see.'
interpretation: Allah reassures His Messengers, Moses and Aaron, not to fear their enemy (Pharaoh and his people) because He is with them, supporting and protecting them. He hears everything they say and sees all their actions. This verse instills courage and confidence in the believers that Allah is ever-present, All-Hearing, and All-Seeing, and He will aid those who put their trust in Him.
orig: قال لا تخافا إنني معكما أسمع وأرى

translation: So go to him and say, 'Indeed, we are messengers of your Lord, so send with us the Children of Israel and do not torment them. We have come to you with a sign from your Lord. And peace will be upon he who follows the guidance.'
interpretation: This verse is a command from Allah to Prophet Musa (Moses) and his brother Harun (Aaron) to approach Pharaoh and convey the message of Allah. They were instructed to demand the release of the Israelites from bondage and oppression, and to warn Pharaoh against tormenting them further. They were also instructed to inform Pharaoh that they have come with a clear sign or miracle from Allah, and that peace and security will be upon those who follow the guidance of Allah.
orig: فأتياه فقولا إنا رسولا ربك فأرسل معنا بني إسرائيل ولا تعذبهم قد جئناك بآية من ربك والسلام على من اتبع الهدى

translation: Indeed, it has been revealed to us that the punishment is upon whoever denies and turns away.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the divine warning that those who reject faith and turn away from the truth will face punishment. It serves as a reminder of the consequences of disbelief and disobedience to God's commands. The interpretation highlights the importance of accepting and following the guidance revealed by God to avoid His punishment.
orig: إنا قد أوحي إلينا أن العذاب على من كذب وتولى

translation: He (Pharaoh) said: 'Then what is the case, O Moses, with your Lord?'
interpretation: Pharaoh arrogantly questioned Moses about his Lord, implying that he did not believe in or acknowledge the existence of God. This shows Pharaoh's stubbornness and rejection of the truth that Moses was preaching.
orig: قال فمن ربكما يا موسى

translation: Our Lord has said, 'He Who gave everything its creation and then guided [it].'
interpretation: Allah is the Creator of all things, and He has given each creation its unique form, nature, and purpose. After creating everything, He has provided guidance for all His creations to fulfill their intended roles and functions in the universe. This verse affirms Allah's wisdom, power, and mercy in creating and sustaining the entire creation.
orig: قال ربنا الذي أعطى كل شيء خلقه ثم هدى

translation: He said: 'Then what is the case of the former generations?'
interpretation: This verse is questioning what happened to the previous nations and peoples who denied the message of the Prophets and messengers sent to them by Allah. It implies that they were destroyed or punished for their disbelief and rejection of the truth.
orig: قال فما بال القرون الأولى

translation: He said: 'The knowledge thereof is with my Lord in a Record. My Lord neither errs nor forgets.'
interpretation: This verse affirms that Allah is the source of all knowledge and that His knowledge is perfect and complete. It emphasizes that Allah does not make mistakes or forget anything, as His knowledge encompasses everything that exists. The "Record" mentioned in the verse refers to the Preserved Tablet (al-Lawh al-Mahfuz), where Allah's decree and knowledge of all things are eternally inscribed.
orig: قال علمها عند ربي في كتاب لا يضل ربي ولا ينسى

translation: It is He who has made the earth a resting place for you and has made pathways for you in it, and has sent down water from the sky. And We brought forth with it all kinds of vegetation.
interpretation: Allah is the One who created the earth as a suitable abode for human beings, providing them with a stable and comfortable dwelling. He also created paths and routes within the earth, allowing for travel and movement. Furthermore, He sends down rain from the sky, which enables the growth of diverse plants and vegetation that sustain life on earth. This verse highlights Allah's wisdom, power, and mercy in creating the perfect environment for human habitation and sustenance.
orig: الذي جعل لكم الأرض مهدا وسلك لكم فيها سبلا وأنزل من السماء ماء فأخرجنا به أزواجا من نبات شتى

translation: Eat and pasture your cattle. Verily, in this are signs for those of understanding.
interpretation: The verse encourages people to make use of the sustenance Allah has provided, such as animals for food and other benefits, as a sign of His mercy and wisdom. It reminds us to reflect on the blessings around us and be grateful to the Creator.
orig: كلوا وارعوا أنعامكم إن في ذلك لآيات لأولي النهى

translation: From the (earth) We created you, and into it We will return you, and from it We will extract you another time.
interpretation: This verse refers to the origin and ultimate return of human beings. It states that Allah created humans from the earth, meaning from its elements and substances. After death, humans will be returned to the earth through burial. However, the verse also indicates that there will be a second extraction or resurrection from the earth on the Day of Judgment, when all will be brought back to life to account for their deeds and receive their ultimate recompense.
orig: منها خلقناكم وفيها نعيدكم ومنها نخرجكم تارة أخرى

translation: And We did show him Our signs, all of them, but he denied and refused.
interpretation: This verse suggests that the person being referred to was shown clear proofs and signs from God, but he rejected them stubbornly and arrogantly, refusing to believe in them or be guided by them.
orig: ولقد أريناه آياتنا كلها فكذب وأبى

translation: They said: 'Have you come to us to drive us out from our land by your sorcery, O Musa?'
interpretation: The disbelievers accused Prophet Musa (Moses) of using sorcery or magic to try to expel them from their land. They saw his miracles as acts of sorcery rather than signs from Allah. This shows their arrogance, stubbornness, and rejection of the truth brought by the Prophet.
orig: قال أجئتنا لتخرجنا من أرضنا بسحرك يا موسى

translation: Then bring you a magic like it, and make between us and you an appointment which we shall not fail to keep - neither we nor you - in an even place.
interpretation: This verse is a challenge from Allah to those who deny the divine origin of the Qur'an. They are called upon to produce something similar to it if they believe it is not from God. However, the condition is set that it must be done collectively, not individually, and in a fair and impartial manner. The phrase "an even place" implies a level playing field, without any bias or unfair advantage. The verse emphasizes the inimitable nature of the Qur'an and its divine source.
orig: فلنأتينك بسحر مثله فاجعل بيننا وبينك موعدا لا نخلفه نحن ولا أنت مكانا سوى

translation: He said, 'Your appointed time is the Day of Adornment, and [at morning] the people will be gathered while it is daylight.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the Day of Resurrection when all people will be gathered before God. The phrase "Day of Adornment" could symbolize the grandeur and magnificence of that day, or it could refer to people being adorned with the results of their deeds. The gathering at daylight signifies the clarity and exposure of all matters on that momentous occasion.
orig: قال موعدكم يوم الزينة وأن يحشر الناس ضحى

translation: So Pharaoh turned away and gathered his plot, then came
interpretation: This verse is referring to Pharaoh's arrogant rejection of the message brought by Moses and his gathering of his advisors and forces to confront Moses and suppress his call to worship the One True God. It highlights Pharaoh's obstinacy and determination to maintain his tyrannical rule by plotting against the truth.
orig: فتولى فرعون فجمع كيده ثم أتى

translation: Moses said to them: 'Woe to you! Do not invent a lie against Allah, or He will destroy you with a punishment, and whoever invents a lie shall fail.'
interpretation: This verse warns against attributing falsehood to Allah. It emphasizes that inventing lies about Allah is a grave sin that will bring severe punishment from Him. The phrase "Woe to you!" expresses strong disapproval and admonition. The verse stresses that those who fabricate lies against Allah will ultimately fail and face destruction. It calls for truthfulness, sincerity, and reverence towards Allah.
orig: قال لهم موسى ويلكم لا تفتروا على الله كذبا فيسحتكم بعذاب وقد خاب من افترى

translation: But they disagreed among themselves and exchanged secret counsels.
interpretation: This verse refers to a disagreement or dispute that arose among a group of people. They engaged in secret consultations or private discussions, perhaps plotting or conspiring against something or someone. The verse implies a sense of disunity, conflict, and hidden agendas within the group.
orig: فتنازعوا أمرهم بينهم وأسروا النجوى

translation: They said, "Indeed, these two are sorcerers who want to drive you out of your land with their sorcery and do away with your most exemplary way of life."
interpretation: This verse refers to the opposition that Prophet Moses and his brother Aaron faced from the disbelievers when they conveyed Allah's message to Pharaoh and his people. The disbelievers accused Moses and Aaron of being sorcerers who wanted to expel them from their land and abolish their way of life through sorcery. This interpretation highlights the resistance and false accusations that Prophets often faced from those who rejected the truth out of arrogance and a desire to maintain their power and corrupt practices.
orig: قالوا إن هذان لساحران يريدان أن يخرجاكم من أرضكم بسحرهما ويذهبا بطريقتكم المثلى

translation: So resolve your plot and come [forward] in line. And whoever has transgressed against me - he has certainly succeeded today.
interpretation: Allah is challenging those who disbelieve to unite their efforts and put forth their utmost schemes against the Prophet Muhammad. However, their plots will ultimately fail, and it is the believers who will be victorious on this day by persevering in faith and obedience to Allah.
orig: فأجمعوا كيدكم ثم ائتوا صفا وقد أفلح اليوم من استعلى

translation: They said: 'O Moses! Either you throw first or we will be the first to throw.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the confrontation between Moses and the magicians of Pharaoh. The magicians challenged Moses to a contest of miracles, demanding that he either perform his miracle first or allow them to go first. This challenge was a test of faith for Moses and his followers, as they were outnumbered and facing the powerful sorcerers of the ruling regime. The verse highlights the arrogance and defiance of the magicians, who were confident in their abilities and sought to intimidate Moses.
orig: قالوا يا موسى إما أن تلقي وإما أن نكون أول من ألقى

translation: He said: "Nay, cast you down." Then behold! their ropes and their sticks, by their magic, appeared to him as though they moved fast.
interpretation: This verse describes the confrontation between Prophet Moses and the magicians of Pharaoh. When Moses threw down his staff, the magicians cast their ropes and sticks, which appeared to move like snakes due to their magic tricks, giving the illusion of movement. However, the true miracle of Moses overpowered their deception, as the Qur'an states in the following verse.
orig: قال بل ألقوا فإذا حبالهم وعصيهم يخيل إليه من سحرهم أنها تسعى

translation: Then he sensed within himself apprehension from Moses
interpretation: This verse suggests that the person (likely the magician) felt a sense of fear or apprehension towards Moses after witnessing the miracle he performed. The Arabic word "khifah" denotes a feeling of fear or apprehension, indicating that the person was intimidated or felt threatened by Moses' demonstration of divine power.
orig: فأوجس في نفسه خيفة موسى

translation: We said, "Fear not, for you are the superior one."
interpretation: "This verse is reassuring the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, that he should not fear or feel intimidated by the disbelievers and their opposition. It affirms his high status and superiority over them, as he is guided by divine revelation and supported by Allah."
orig: قلنا لا تخف إنك أنت الأعلى

translation: And throw that which is in your right hand! It will swallow up that which they have crafted. What they have crafted is only a magician's trick, and the magician will not succeed wherever he goes.
interpretation: This verse is instructing Prophet Moses to throw his staff onto the ground, which would then swallow up the tricks and illusions created by the magicians of Pharaoh's court. It emphasizes that the magicians' deceptions were merely tricks with no real power, and that their sorcery would ultimately fail against the truth and miracles of God.
orig: وألق ما في يمينك تلقف ما صنعوا إنما صنعوا كيد ساحر ولا يفلح الساحر حيث أتى

translation: So the magicians were thrown down in prostration. They said, "We have believed in the Lord of Aaron and Moses."
interpretation: This verse describes the event when the magicians witnessed the miracle performed by Moses, which was superior to their magic tricks. They realized the truth and submitted to the Lord, acknowledging their belief in the God of Aaron and Moses. Their prostration signified their humility and acceptance of the divine message brought by the prophets.
orig: فألقي السحرة سجدا قالوا آمنا برب هارون وموسى

translation: He said, "You believed in him before I gave you permission. Indeed, he is your leader who has taught you magic. So I will surely cut off your hands and feet on opposite sides, and I will surely crucify you on the trunks of palm trees, and you will surely know which of us is more severe in [giving] punishment and more enduring."
interpretation: This verse depicts the Pharaoh's arrogant and tyrannical response to the believers among his people who had accepted the message of Moses. He accuses them of believing in Moses without his permission, considering Moses their leader who taught them magic (referring to the miracles shown by Moses). The Pharaoh threatens to severely punish them by cutting off their hands and feet from opposite sides, crucifying them on palm trunks, and making them suffer a harsh and enduring punishment. This verse highlights the Pharaoh's cruelty, disbelief, and abuse of power against those who embraced the truth.
orig: قال آمنتم له قبل أن آذن لكم إنه لكبيركم الذي علمكم السحر فلأقطعن أيديكم وأرجلكم من خلاف ولأصلبنكم في جذوع النخل ولتعلمن أينا أشد عذابا وأبقى

translation: They said, 'We will never prefer you over the clear proofs that have come to us, and over He who created us, so decree whatever you will decree. You can only decree regarding this worldly life.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the rejection of the disbelievers towards the message of the Prophet. They declare that they will not abandon the clear signs and revelations that have come to them from their Lord, and the natural disposition (fitrah) with which they were created, in favor of following the Prophet. They challenge the Prophet to do whatever he wishes, as his authority is limited to this worldly life and does not extend to the Hereafter.
orig: قالوا لن نؤثرك على ما جاءنا من البينات والذي فطرنا فاقض ما أنت قاض إنما تقضي هذه الحياة الدنيا

translation: Indeed, we have believed in our Lord that He may forgive us our sins and what we were compelled to do of magic. And Allah is the Best and the Eternal.
interpretation: This verse expresses the belief and hope of those who previously practiced magic. They affirm their faith in Allah, seeking forgiveness for their past sins and the magic they were forced to practice. It highlights their trust in Allah's mercy and their recognition of His superiority and everlasting nature.
orig: إنا آمنا بربنا ليغفر لنا خطايانا وما أكرهتنا عليه من السحر والله خير وأبقى

translation: Indeed, whoever comes to his Lord as a criminal - indeed, for him is Hellfire; he will never die therein nor live.
interpretation: This verse warns that whoever meets Allah while persisting in disbelief and sin, without repentance, will be punished in Hellfire. Their torment will be eternal; they will neither die to be relieved of the punishment, nor will they truly live a life of comfort and peace.
orig: إنه من يأت ربه مجرما فإن له جهنم لا يموت فيها ولا يحيى

translation: But whoever comes to Him as a believer having done righteous deeds - for them will be the highest degrees.
interpretation: This verse promises the highest spiritual ranks and rewards in the Hereafter for those who come to Allah with true faith and have performed righteous deeds in this world. It emphasizes that genuine belief must be accompanied by good actions to attain the loftiest stations in Paradise. The "highest degrees" signify elevated levels of honor, bliss, and nearness to Allah, reserved for the most pious and virtuous believers.
orig: ومن يأته مؤمنا قد عمل الصالحات فأولئك لهم الدرجات العلى

translation: Gardens of perpetual residence; beneath them rivers will flow. They will abide therein forever. And that is the reward for whoever purifies himself.
interpretation: This verse describes the reward of Paradise that awaits those who purify themselves through faith and righteous deeds. The "Gardens of perpetual residence" refer to the eternal gardens of Paradise, where rivers flow beneath their lofty dwellings. The believers will abide therein forever as a reward for their piety and self-purification from sins and disobedience to Allah.
orig: جنات عدن تجري من تحتها الأنهار خالدين فيها وذلك جزاء من تزكى

translation: And We had certainly inspired to Moses, 'Travel by night with My servants and strike for them a dry path through the sea. You will not fear being overtaken [by Pharaoh] and will not fear [drowning].'
interpretation: This verse refers to the miraculous event of the parting of the Red Sea for Moses and the Israelites to cross safely while fleeing from Pharaoh and his army. Allah commanded Moses to lead his people during the night and strike the sea with his staff, causing it to split and form a dry path. This allowed them to cross without fear of being caught by Pharaoh or drowning. It demonstrates Allah's power and protection for those who have faith in Him.
orig: ولقد أوحينا إلى موسى أن أسر بعبادي فاضرب لهم طريقا في البحر يبسا لا تخاف دركا ولا تخشى

translation: Then Pharaoh pursued them with his soldiers, but the sea overwhelmed them, drowning them all.
interpretation: This verse describes the climactic moment when Pharaoh and his army pursued the Israelites after their exodus from Egypt. As they reached the sea, Allah commanded Moses to strike it with his staff, causing the waters to part and allowing the Israelites to cross safely. However, when Pharaoh and his soldiers followed, the sea closed in on them, drowning them all. This event demonstrated Allah's power and protection for the believers, while punishing the arrogant oppressors.
orig: فأتبعهم فرعون بجنوده فغشيهم من اليم ما غشيهم

translation: And Pharaoh led his people astray and did not guide them.
interpretation: This verse is a criticism of Pharaoh's arrogance and tyranny. He misguided his people by preventing them from believing in Allah and following the true religion. Instead of being a righteous leader who guides his subjects to the truth, he led them into disbelief and error through his oppressive policies and false claims of divinity.
orig: وأضل فرعون قومه وما هدى

translation: O Children of Israel! We delivered you from your enemy, and We made a covenant with you on the right side of Mount Tur, and We sent down to you manna and quails
interpretation: This verse is addressing the Children of Israel, reminding them of the favors that Allah bestowed upon them. It mentions that He saved them from their enemy, likely referring to Pharaoh and his people. Additionally, Allah made a covenant with them at the right side of Mount Tur, which is believed to be Mount Sinai where Moses received the Torah. Furthermore, Allah provided them with manna and quails as sustenance during their journey in the desert after their exodus from Egypt. The verse serves as a reminder of Allah's blessings and mercy upon the Children of Israel.
orig: يا بني إسرائيل قد أنجيناكم من عدوكم وواعدناكم جانب الطور الأيمن ونزلنا عليكم المن والسلوى

translation: Eat of the good things We have provided for you, and do not transgress therein, lest My anger should descend upon you, and whoever is subject to My anger has certainly fallen.
interpretation: "Do not go beyond the limits set by Allah in consuming the provisions He has granted you. Refrain from what is prohibited, such as consuming unlawful or impure substances, indulging in extravagance, or engaging in any form of transgression. If you exceed these boundaries, you will incur My wrath and punishment. Whoever invites My anger upon themselves has indeed fallen into misguidance and ruin."
orig: كلوا من طيبات ما رزقناكم ولا تطغوا فيه فيحل عليكم غضبي ومن يحلل عليه غضبي فقد هوى

translation: And indeed, I am the Perpetual Forgiver of whoever repents, believes, and does righteous deeds, and then remains guided.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes Allah's infinite mercy and forgiveness for those who sincerely repent, have faith, perform good deeds, and remain on the guided path. It highlights that no matter how grave one's sins may be, the door to Allah's forgiveness is always open for those who genuinely turn towards Him with sincere repentance, faith, righteous actions, and a commitment to staying guided.
orig: وإني لغفار لمن تاب وآمن وعمل صالحا ثم اهتدى

translation: And what made you hasten from your people, O Moses?
interpretation: This verse questions Moses' haste in leaving his people behind. It suggests that there was a sense of urgency or an important reason that compelled Moses to depart swiftly from his community. The interpretation could be that Moses had a divine calling or mission that required him to separate himself from his people temporarily or permanently.
orig: وما أعجلك عن قومك يا موسى

translation: He said, "They are close on my footsteps, and I hastened to You, my Lord, that You may be pleased."
interpretation: This verse refers to Prophet Moses' (peace be upon him) response when Allah asked him why he left his people behind in such a hurry. Moses explained that he rushed to meet Allah in order to please Him, and that his people were following closely behind him.
orig: قال هم أولاء على أثري وعجلت إليك رب لترضى

translation: He said: "Verily, We have tried your people in your absence, and As-Samiri has led them astray."
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident of the worship of the golden calf by the Children of Israel during the absence of Prophet Moses. God is informing Moses that his people were misled by As-Samiri, who fashioned a calf for them to worship. The verse highlights the ease with which people can deviate from the true path of God in the absence of proper guidance.
orig: قال فإنا قد فتنا قومك من بعدك وأضلهم السامري

translation: Then Moses returned to his people in a state of anger and grief. He said: 'O my people, did not your Lord make a handsome promise to you? Did then the covenant seem too long for you, or did you desire that wrath should descend from your Lord on you, and so you broke your promise to me?'
interpretation: This verse describes Moses' reaction upon returning to his people after receiving the revelation from God. He was angry and grieved to find them worshipping the calf idol, despite God's covenant with them. Moses rebukes them for breaking their promise to worship only God, and questions whether they desired God's wrath to descend upon them by their disobedience.
orig: فرجع موسى إلى قومه غضبان أسفا قال يا قوم ألم يعدكم ربكم وعدا حسنا أفطال عليكم العهد أم أردتم أن يحل عليكم غضب من ربكم فأخلفتم موعدي

translation: They said: 'We did not break our promise to you by our own will, but we were laden with burdens of ornaments of the people, so we threw them (into the fire), and so did the Samaritan throw (likewise)'
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident of the worship of the golden calf by the Israelites during the absence of Prophet Moses. The Israelites claim that they did not intentionally break their promise to Moses, but were burdened by the ornaments and wealth of the Egyptian people which they had taken with them. They melted these ornaments to make the golden calf, influenced by al-Samiri who initiated this act of idolatry. The verse highlights the weakness of faith and the tendency to be swayed by material temptations.
orig: قالوا ما أخلفنا موعدك بملكنا ولكنا حملنا أوزارا من زينة القوم فقذفناها فكذلك ألقى السامري

translation: Then he brought forth for them a calf, a body having a sound. So they said, 'This is your god and the god of Moses, but he forgot.'
interpretation: The verse refers to the incident when the Israelites, in the absence of Moses, demanded that a statue be made for them to worship. The calf statue was created by collecting their ornaments and casting them into a mould, resulting in a physical form that produced a sound. The Israelites mistakenly attributed divinity to this inanimate object, claiming it to be their god and the god of Moses, whom they accused of forgetting or neglecting them.
orig: فأخرج لهم عجلا جسدا له خوار فقالوا هذا إلهكم وإله موسى فنسي

translation: Do they not see that it cannot return speech to them, nor can it cause them any harm or benefit?
interpretation: This verse questions the idolaters' belief in powerless idols that cannot speak, harm, or benefit them in any way. It highlights the absurdity of worshipping inanimate objects that lack any divine qualities or abilities. The verse aims to make the idolaters reflect on the futility of their practices and recognize the oneness of God, who alone deserves worship and supplication.
orig: أفلا يرون ألا يرجع إليهم قولا ولا يملك لهم ضرا ولا نفعا

translation: And indeed, Harun had already said to them beforehand: 'O my people! You are only being tested by it, and indeed, your Lord is the Most Merciful, so follow me and obey my order.'
interpretation: In this verse, Aaron (Harun) is advising his people not to be misled by the worship of the calf idol, which was just a test from Allah. He reminds them that Allah is the Most Merciful, and that they should follow his guidance and obey his commands instead of succumbing to this trial.
orig: ولقد قال لهم هارون من قبل يا قوم إنما فتنتم به وإن ربكم الرحمن فاتبعوني وأطيعوا أمري

translation: They said, 'We will not cease being devoted to it until Moses returns to us.'
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that the Israelites were determined to continue worshipping the calf idol until Moses returned to them, despite his instructions to worship only Allah. This shows their stubbornness and lack of faith, as they quickly turned to idolatry in the absence of their prophet.
orig: قالوا لن نبرح عليه عاكفين حتى يرجع إلينا موسى

translation: He (Moses) said: 'O Aaron! What prevented you when you saw them going astray?'
interpretation: In this verse, Allah mentions the conversation between Prophet Moses and his brother Prophet Aaron regarding the worship of the calf by the Children of Israel in Moses' absence. Moses questions Aaron why he did not prevent them from this act of misguidance when he witnessed it.
orig: قال يا هارون ما منعك إذ رأيتهم ضلوا

translation: Have I not forbidden you from worshipping Satan? Verily, he is a plain misleading enemy to you.
interpretation: This verse is a rebuke from Allah to mankind for disobeying His command and following Satan, who is an open and clear enemy leading them astray. It emphasizes that worshipping or obeying Satan goes against Allah's explicit prohibition and will only lead to misguidance and enmity with Allah.
orig: ألا تتبعن أفعصيت أمري

translation: He said: 'O son of my mother! Do not seize me by my beard or my head. Indeed, I feared that you would say, 'You caused division among the Children of Israel, and did not observe my word.'
interpretation: This verse refers to a situation where Prophet Moses feared that his companion would accuse him of causing division among the Children of Israel by striking someone. Moses was concerned that his actions might be misunderstood and lead to disunity among his people. The verse highlights the importance of avoiding actions that could cause disunity and emphasizes the need for patience and wisdom in dealing with conflicts.
orig: قال يا ابن أم لا تأخذ بلحيتي ولا برأسي إني خشيت أن تقول فرقت بين بني إسرائيل ولم ترقب قولي

translation: He said: 'What then is the matter with you, O Samiri?'
interpretation: This verse is addressing Samiri, who had misled the Israelites into worshipping the golden calf during the absence of Prophet Moses. It is a rhetorical question, expressing disapproval and seeking an explanation for Samiri's unacceptable behavior in leading people astray from the true path of worshipping Allah alone.
orig: قال فما خطبك يا سامري

translation: He said, 'I have seen what they have not seen, so I took a handful from the traces of the Messenger and cast it away, and thus my soul enticed me.'
interpretation: This verse could be interpreted as someone claiming to have gained spiritual insight or knowledge that others have not attained. However, instead of preserving and cherishing this knowledge, they rejected and discarded it, allowing their ego or desires to lead them astray. The phrase "traces of the Messenger" suggests a connection to the teachings or legacy of a religious figure, which the person initially embraced but then abandoned due to their own temptations or self-deception.
orig: قال بصرت بما لم يبصروا به فقبضت قبضة من أثر الرسول فنبذتها وكذلك سولت لي نفسي

translation: He (Allah) said: "Go, and indeed for you in life is to say, 'No touch!' And indeed, you will have an appointment you will not fail to keep. And look at your 'god' to which you remained obedient. We will surely burn it and blow it into the sea with a complete blowing."
interpretation: This verse is a warning from Allah to Pharaoh, who had arrogantly claimed to be a god. Allah mocks Pharaoh's false claim to divinity and promises to completely destroy the idols and false objects of worship that Pharaoh had devoted himself to. The 'appointment' refers to the Day of Judgment when Pharaoh will face the consequences of his disbelief and arrogance.
orig: قال فاذهب فإن لك في الحياة أن تقول لا مساس وإن لك موعدا لن تخلفه وانظر إلى إلهك الذي ظلت عليه عاكفا لنحرقنه ثم لننسفنه في اليم نسفا

translation: Your God is but One God; there is no god but He, the All-Embracing, the All-Knowing.
interpretation: This verse affirms the Oneness and Uniqueness of God (Allah). It states that there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah, Who encompasses everything with His knowledge and power. This verse emphasizes the concept of Tawheed (Oneness of God), which is the foundation of Islamic belief. It rejects the notion of any partners or associates with Allah, and establishes that He alone is the sole object of worship and the source of all knowledge and authority.
