interpretation: This verse criticizes those who preach virtues but do not practice them in their own lives. It condemns hypocrisy and the contradiction between one's words and actions. The interpretation is that true faith requires consistency between one's beliefs and deeds, and that merely professing something without living by it is insincere and unacceptable.
orig: وأنهم يقولون ما لا يفعلون

translation: Except those who believe, do righteous deeds, remember Allah much, and defend themselves after they have been wronged. And those who do wrong will come to know what final return they will be returned to.
interpretation: This verse is an exception to the previous verses describing the state of disbelievers. It highlights the qualities of true believers: having faith, performing good deeds, frequent remembrance of Allah, and defending themselves against oppression without exceeding limits. It promises that the wrongdoers will ultimately face the consequences of their actions and return to Allah for judgment.
orig: إلا الذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات وذكروا الله كثيرا وانتصروا من بعد ما ظلموا وسيعلم الذين ظلموا أي منقلب ينقلبون

translation: Ṭā Sīn. These are the verses of the Qur'an and a clear Book.
interpretation: "This surah begins with the letters 'Ṭā Sīn', which are among the disjointed or separated letters that appear at the beginning of some chapters of the Qur'an. Their precise meaning is known only to Allah. However, they serve as an affirmation that the Qur'an is indeed the Word of Allah and a reminder of its inimitable linguistic and literary nature. The verse then declares that the verses that follow are from the Qur'an, which is a clear and enlightening Book, providing guidance and wisdom to humanity."
orig: طس تلك آيات القرآن وكتاب مبين

translation: A guidance and good tidings for the believers
interpretation: This verse indicates that the Qur'an serves as a guide and source of glad tidings for those who have faith and believe in Allah. It provides spiritual guidance, moral teachings, and the promise of reward and salvation for the believers.
orig: هدى وبشرى للمؤمنين

translation: Those who establish prayer and give zakah, and they are certain of the Hereafter.
interpretation: This verse refers to the true believers who fulfill the obligations of prayer and charity, and have firm faith in the Day of Judgment and the life after death. It emphasizes the importance of both spiritual and practical acts of worship, as well as unwavering belief in the ultimate accountability before God.
orig: الذين يقيمون الصلاة ويؤتون الزكاة وهم بالآخرة هم يوقنون

translation: Indeed, those who do not believe in the Hereafter - We have made pleasing to them their deeds, so they wander blindly.
interpretation: This verse refers to the disbelievers who deny the existence of the Hereafter and the Day of Judgment. Allah has made their evil deeds seem attractive and pleasing to them in this worldly life, so they continue to indulge in sin and disobedience without fear of consequences. Their disbelief has blinded them from the truth, causing them to wander aimlessly like someone lost in darkness, unable to find the right path.
orig: إن الذين لا يؤمنون بالآخرة زينا لهم أعمالهم فهم يعمهون

translation: Those are the ones for whom is the worst of punishment, and in the Hereafter they will be the greatest losers.
interpretation: This verse refers to those who reject faith and disobey Allah's commands. They will face a severe punishment in this life and the Hereafter, where they will be the ultimate losers, deprived of any reward or salvation. The interpretation emphasizes the grave consequences of disbelief and warns against prioritizing worldly gains over eternal bliss.
orig: أولئك الذين لهم سوء العذاب وهم في الآخرة هم الأخسرون

translation: And indeed, you receive the Qur'an from the presence of One Wise and Knowing.
interpretation: This verse affirms that the Qur'an is revealed by Allah, Who is All-Wise and All-Knowing. It highlights the divine origin and wisdom behind the Qur'anic revelations, indicating that they are not mere words of a human being, but rather the Word of God, the Sole Creator, who possesses absolute wisdom and knowledge.
orig: وإنك لتلقى القرآن من لدن حكيم عليم

translation: When Moses said to his family, 'Indeed, I have perceived a fire. I will bring you from there information or will bring you a burning torch that you may warm yourselves.'
interpretation: This verse describes the incident when Prophet Moses saw a fire while traveling with his family. He told them that he would go and investigate the fire, either to bring them news or a burning torch to warm themselves. The fire turned out to be a manifestation of God, who then spoke to Moses and appointed him as a prophet. This marked the beginning of Moses' mission to confront Pharaoh and deliver the Children of Israel from bondage.
orig: إذ قال موسى لأهله إني آنست نارا سآتيكم منها بخبر أو آتيكم بشهاب قبس لعلكم تصطلون

translation: But when it came to her, she was called: 'Blessed is whoever is in the Fire and whoever is about it. And exalted is Allah, Lord of the worlds.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident when the fire that Abraham was thrown into by Nimrod became a garden for him. The interpretation is that when the fire approached Mary (the mother of Jesus), it was addressed and told that it has been made a source of peace and blessing for those in it and around it, by the command of Allah, the Lord of the worlds.
orig: فلما جاءها نودي أن بورك من في النار ومن حولها وسبحان الله رب العالمين

translation: O Moses, indeed it is I - Allah, the Exalted in Might, the Wise.
interpretation: This verse is a direct address from Allah to Prophet Moses, affirming His absolute power and wisdom. It emphasizes Allah's might and authority, as well as His perfect wisdom in all matters. The interpretation highlights Allah's self-proclamation as the source of all might and wisdom, instilling reverence and submission in the listener.
orig: يا موسى إنه أنا الله العزيز الحكيم

translation: And throw down your staff. But when he saw it writhing as if it were a snake, he turned in flight and did not return. O Moses, fear not. Indeed, the messengers do not fear in My presence.
interpretation: This verse is instructing Prophet Moses to throw down his staff, which miraculously turned into a snake-like creature. This caused fear in Moses, prompting him to flee. However, God reassures Moses not to be afraid, as the Messengers of God have no reason to fear in His presence.
orig: وألق عصاك فلما رآها تهتز كأنها جان ولى مدبرا ولم يعقب يا موسى لا تخف إني لا يخاف لدي المرسلون

translation: Except for those who have wronged, and then changed their evil deed with a good one, then I am Oft-Forgiving, Most Merciful.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes Allah's infinite mercy and willingness to forgive those who repent and replace their wrongdoings with good deeds. It encourages people to seek forgiveness, rectify their mistakes, and strive to do good, as Allah is ever Forgiving and Merciful towards those who sincerely repent and reform themselves.
orig: إلا من ظلم ثم بدل حسنا بعد سوء فإني غفور رحيم

translation: And put your hand into your bosom, it will come forth white without hurt, among nine signs to Pharaoh and his people; surely they are a transgressing people.
interpretation: "This verse instructs Prophet Moses to perform a miracle by putting his hand into his bosom, and when he takes it out, it will shine with a brilliant white light without any defect or blemish. This is one of the nine signs given to Moses to present before Pharaoh and his people as proof of his prophethood. However, the verse also states that Pharaoh and his people were transgressors who had deviated from the path of truth and righteousness."
orig: وأدخل يدك في جيبك تخرج بيضاء من غير سوء في تسع آيات إلى فرعون وقومه إنهم كانوا قوما فاسقين

translation: But when Our clear verses came to them, they said, 'This is a clear magic.'
interpretation: The verse is referring to the rejection and denial of the disbelievers when they were presented with clear signs and miracles from Allah. Instead of accepting the truth, they stubbornly claimed that these signs were merely magic or sorcery, refusing to acknowledge the divine origin of the revelations.
orig: فلما جاءتهم آياتنا مبصرة قالوا هذا سحر مبين

translation: But they rejected it insolently, though their souls were convinced thereof. See then what was the end of those who acted corruptly.
interpretation: This verse refers to those who reject the truth and guidance from God, despite their inner selves being convinced of its veracity. It warns against arrogance and stubbornness in denying the truth, and highlights the ultimate consequence faced by those who spread corruption and mischief on earth. The phrase "See then what was the end of those who acted corruptly" serves as a reminder of the dire fate that befalls those who persistently reject God's signs and spread evil.
orig: وجحدوا بها واستيقنتها أنفسهم ظلما وعلوا فانظر كيف كان عاقبة المفسدين

translation: And We had certainly given to David and Solomon knowledge, and they said, "Praise [is due] to Allah, who has favored us over many of His believing servants."
interpretation: "This verse highlights the blessings of knowledge and wisdom bestowed upon the Prophets David and Solomon. It emphasizes their gratitude to Allah for favoring them with knowledge over many other believers. The interpretation is that true knowledge leads to recognizing Allah's favors and expressing gratitude, which should be the attitude of all those blessed with knowledge."
orig: ولقد آتينا داوود وسليمان علما وقالا الحمد لله الذي فضلنا على كثير من عباده المؤمنين

translation: And Solomon inherited from David and said: "O people! We have been taught the language of birds, and we have been given from all things. Indeed, this is evident bounty."
interpretation: "The verse indicates that Prophet Solomon inherited prophethood and wisdom from his father, Prophet David. It also highlights that God bestowed upon Solomon the unique ability to understand and communicate with birds, which was a manifestation of God's evident favor and grace upon him. This special knowledge was a sign of Solomon's high rank and status among the prophets."
orig: وورث سليمان داوود وقال يا أيها الناس علمنا منطق الطير وأوتينا من كل شيء إن هذا لهو الفضل المبين

translation: And gathered for Solomon were his soldiers of the jinn and men and birds, and they were set in battle order.
interpretation: This verse refers to the power and authority granted to Prophet Solomon over various creatures, including jinn, humans, and birds. It suggests that they were gathered and organized under his command, ready to carry out his orders. This could be interpreted as a metaphor for Solomon's wisdom, governance, and control over different realms and beings.
orig: وحشر لسليمان جنوده من الجن والإنس والطير فهم يوزعون

translation: Until, when they came upon the valley of the ants, an ant said: 'O ants! Enter your dwellings, lest Solomon and his hosts crush you while they are unaware.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the wisdom and understanding of even small creatures like ants, who recognized the power of Prophet Solomon and his army. It serves as a reminder of God's mercy towards all His creation, and the importance of being mindful and respectful towards others, even those seemingly weaker than us.
orig: حتى إذا أتوا على واد النمل قالت نملة يا أيها النمل ادخلوا مساكنكم لا يحطمنكم سليمان وجنوده وهم لا يشعرون

translation: Then he smiled, laughing at her words, and said, 'My Lord, inspire me to be grateful for Your favors which You have bestowed upon me and upon my parents, and to do good deeds that please You, and admit me, by Your mercy, among Your righteous servants.'
interpretation: This verse highlights Prophet Ibrahim's gratitude and humility towards Allah. He asks Allah to guide him to be thankful for the blessings bestowed upon him and his parents, and to enable him to perform righteous deeds that please Allah. He also prays to be admitted among the righteous servants of Allah through His mercy. The verse emphasizes the importance of gratitude, righteousness, and seeking Allah's guidance and mercy.
orig: فتبسم ضاحكا من قولها وقال رب أوزعني أن أشكر نعمتك التي أنعمت علي وعلى والدي وأن أعمل صالحا ترضاه وأدخلني برحمتك في عبادك الصالحين

translation: And he took a muster of the birds and said: 'What is the matter that I see not the hoopoe, or is he among the absentees?'
interpretation: This verse suggests that the Prophet Solomon was inspecting the birds under his command, and he noticed that the hoopoe bird was missing. It implies that Solomon had authority over the birds and expected them to be present and obedient to him. The verse highlights Solomon's keen observation and his expectation of accountability from those under his charge.
orig: وتفقد الطير فقال ما لي لا أرى الهدهد أم كان من الغائبين

translation: I will surely punish him with a severe punishment or slaughter him, unless he brings me a clear authority.
interpretation: This verse implies a warning and a threat from Allah to those who reject faith and deny the truth. The severe punishment or slaughter mentioned is a consequence for those who persist in disbelief and do not submit to Allah's authority. However, they are given a chance to bring a "clear authority" or evidence to justify their position, which is a way for them to avoid the punishment. The verse highlights Allah's justice and mercy, as He does not punish anyone without giving them a fair opportunity to embrace the truth.
orig: لأعذبنه عذابا شديدا أو لأذبحنه أو ليأتيني بسلطان مبين

translation: But he stayed not long, and said: 'I have grasped that which you have not grasped, and I have come to you from Sheba with sure tidings.'
interpretation: The interpretation is that the hoopoe bird, which was sent by Prophet Sulaiman (Solomon) to explore the land of Sheba, returned quickly with accurate information about the Queen of Sheba and her people worshipping the sun instead of Allah. The bird claimed to have understood something that even Sulaiman did not, referring to the specific details about the Queen and her kingdom.
orig: فمكث غير بعيد فقال أحطت بما لم تحط به وجئتك من سبإ بنبإ يقين

translation: Indeed, I found a woman ruling over them, and she has been given abundance of all things, and she has a great throne.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Queen of Sheba, also known as Bilqis. It suggests that she was a powerful and wealthy ruler who possessed great authority and resources, symbolized by her "great throne." The interpretation could be that the Qur'an acknowledges the existence of powerful female leaders and their right to rule, contrary to the cultural norms of that time.
orig: إني وجدت امرأة تملكهم وأوتيت من كل شيء ولها عرش عظيم

translation: And I found her and her people worshipping the sun instead of Allah, and Satan had made their deeds seem fair to them and had barred them from the Way, so they were not guided.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) when he encountered his people worshipping the sun instead of Allah. Satan had deceived them and made their idolatrous practices seem appealing, preventing them from following the true path of guidance and worship of the One True God.
orig: وجدتها وقومها يسجدون للشمس من دون الله وزين لهم الشيطان أعمالهم فصدهم عن السبيل فهم لا يهتدون

translation: Do they not prostrate to Allah, who brings forth the hidden in the heavens and the earth, and knows what you conceal and what you reveal?
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of submitting to Allah, the Almighty, who has perfect knowledge of all that is hidden and manifest in the heavens and the earth. It calls upon people to prostrate before Allah in recognition of His absolute power and omniscience. The verse implies that since Allah is aware of our innermost thoughts and actions, we should worship Him sincerely and with utmost humility.
orig: ألا يسجدوا لله الذي يخرج الخبء في السماوات والأرض ويعلم ما تخفون وما تعلنون

translation: Allah - there is no deity except Him, Lord of the Great Throne.
interpretation: This verse affirms the Oneness of Allah, declaring that there is no true deity worthy of worship except Him alone. It highlights His Lordship over the "Great Throne," which symbolizes His supreme authority, majesty, and sovereignty over the entire universe.
orig: الله لا إله إلا هو رب العرش العظيم

translation: He (Allah) said: "We will see whether you are truthful or you were one of the liars."
interpretation: This verse suggests that Allah will test the truthfulness of a person's claims or intentions through their actions and the outcome of events. It implies that the truth will eventually become evident, and those who are dishonest or deceitful will be exposed as liars.
orig: قال سننظر أصدقت أم كنت من الكاذبين

translation: Go, with this Book of Mine, and cast it towards them, then turn away from them and see what they will return.
interpretation: This verse is an instruction from Allah to the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him. It commands him to present the Qur'an to the disbelievers and then turn away from them, leaving them to ponder over its message without further argument or debate. The phrase "see what they will return" implies observing their response, whether they accept the truth or persist in rejection. This approach highlights the clarity of the Qur'anic message and leaves the choice of acceptance or denial to the people themselves.
orig: اذهب بكتابي هذا فألقه إليهم ثم تول عنهم فانظر ماذا يرجعون

translation: She said: 'O chiefs! Verily, there has been delivered to me a noble Book.'
interpretation: The Queen of Sheba is addressing her chiefs and informing them that she has received a noble and honorable Book (letter) from Prophet Sulayman, calling them to worship Allah alone. This shows her wisdom in consulting her advisors before making a decision, and her open-mindedness to consider the message rather than immediately rejecting it.
orig: قالت يا أيها الملأ إني ألقي إلي كتاب كريم

translation: It is from Solomon, and it is: 'In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful.'
interpretation: This verse suggests that the following message or wisdom is from the Prophet Solomon, and it begins with the Islamic expression of praising and seeking help from God, the Most Merciful and Most Compassionate. It implies that what follows is a profound teaching or guidance inspired by divine revelation.
orig: إنه من سليمان وإنه بسم الله الرحمن الرحيم

translation: Will you not then be Muslims?
interpretation: This verse is an invitation from Allah to humanity to submit to His will and embrace Islam as a way of life. It is a call to abandon disbelief, polytheism, and disobedience, and to instead accept the truth of Tawheed (Oneness of God) and follow the guidance revealed by Allah through His prophets and messengers.
orig: ألا تعلوا علي وأتوني مسلمين

translation: She said: 'O chiefs! Advise me in my affair. I would not decide a matter until you witness [for] me.'
interpretation: The Queen of Sheba is consulting her advisors and chiefs before making any decision regarding the letter she received from Prophet Sulaiman (peace be upon him). She values their counsel and does not want to take a unilateral decision on such an important matter without their input and presence.
orig: قالت يا أيها الملأ أفتوني في أمري ما كنت قاطعة أمرا حتى تشهدون

translation: They said, 'We are possessors of strength and possessors of great military might, but the command is yours, so see what you will command us.'
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as the leaders of the disbelievers boasting about their strength and military power, but acknowledging that the final decision rests with the Queen. They are essentially offering their services to carry out whatever she commands, even if it means using force against the believers.
orig: قالوا نحن أولو قوة وأولو بأس شديد والأمر إليك فانظري ماذا تأمرين

translation: She said: 'Kings, when they enter a township, ruin it and make the most honorable among its people the meanest. Thus do they behave.'
interpretation: The verse is interpreted as a criticism of the behavior of kings and rulers who, when they conquer a city or territory, tend to destroy and oppress its people, especially the honorable and respected members of society. This verse highlights the abuse of power and the oppressive nature of tyrannical rulers who subjugate and humiliate the people they rule over, rather than protecting and uplifting them.
orig: قالت إن الملوك إذا دخلوا قرية أفسدوها وجعلوا أعزة أهلها أذلة وكذلك يفعلون

translation: And indeed, I am going to send a present to them and see with what [answer] the messengers will return.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of the Queen of Sheba when she decided to send a gift to Prophet Sulayman (peace be upon him) to test his character and prophethood. The interpretation is that she wanted to observe how the Prophet would react to her gift, as this would reveal his true nature and whether he was truly a messenger of God or not.
orig: وإني مرسلة إليهم بهدية فناظرة بم يرجع المرسلون

translation: But when Solomon arrived, he said, "Would you furnish me with wealth? What Allah has given me is far better than what He has given you. No, you are the ones who rejoice in your gift."
interpretation: The verse suggests that true wealth and blessings come from Allah, and material possessions alone do not constitute real prosperity. Solomon, despite his great wealth and power, did not boast about it or consider it superior to the spiritual gifts bestowed by Allah. He recognized that the true gift from Allah was far more valuable than any worldly riches, which should not be a source of arrogance or pride.
orig: فلما جاء سليمان قال أتمدونن بمال فما آتاني الله خير مما آتاكم بل أنتم بهديتكم تفرحون

translation: Go back to them, for we will surely bring against them troops that they will have no power to face, and we will surely expel them from there in humiliation, and they will be utterly disgraced.
interpretation: This verse is a warning from Allah to the disbelievers who were opposing the Prophet Muhammad and the believers. Allah is commanding the Prophet to return to his people, and Allah promises to send forces against the disbelievers which they cannot withstand. Allah also promises to expel them from their land in a humiliating and disgraced state as a punishment for their arrogance and rejection of the truth.
orig: ارجع إليهم فلنأتينهم بجنود لا قبل لهم بها ولنخرجنهم منها أذلة وهم صاغرون

translation: He said: 'O chiefs! Which of you can bring me her throne before they come to me in submission?'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Solomon and the Queen of Sheba. Solomon is asking his chiefs and advisors to bring the throne of the Queen before she and her people embrace Islam and submit to Allah's command. This demonstrates Solomon's wisdom and authority, as well as his desire to guide the Queen towards the true religion.
orig: قال يا أيها الملأ أيكم يأتيني بعرشها قبل أن يأتوني مسلمين

translation: An 'Ifrit (strong one) from the jinns said: 'I will bring it to you before you rise from your place. And verily, I am indeed strong and trustworthy for such work.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Sulayman (peace be upon him) when he asked who could bring him the throne of the Queen of Saba before she and her people come to him as Muslims. One of the powerful jinns, described as an 'Ifrit, boastfully claimed that he could bring it swiftly, highlighting his strength and trustworthiness for the task.
orig: قال عفريت من الجن أنا آتيك به قبل أن تقوم من مقامك وإني عليه لقوي أمين

translation: He who had knowledge from the Scripture said: 'I will bring it to you before your glance returns to you.' And when he saw it placed before him, he said: 'This is by the Grace of my Lord - that He may test me whether I give thanks or am ungrateful. Whosoever gives thanks, he gives thanks but for (the good of) his own self. And whosoever is ungrateful, (he is ungrateful only for the loss of his own self). Certainly my Lord is Self-Sufficient, Bountiful.'
interpretation: This verse refers to an incident where a knowledgeable person from the People of the Book (possibly a Christian monk) promised to bring the throne of the Queen of Sheba before Prophet Sulayman could blink his eye. When he saw the throne miraculously brought before him, he acknowledged it as a test from Allah to see if he would be grateful or ungrateful. He recognized that gratitude benefits one's own self, while ingratitude harms no one but oneself, for Allah is Self-Sufficient and Generous.
orig: قال الذي عنده علم من الكتاب أنا آتيك به قبل أن يرتد إليك طرفك فلما رآه مستقرا عنده قال هذا من فضل ربي ليبلوني أأشكر أم أكفر ومن شكر فإنما يشكر لنفسه ومن كفر فإن ربي غني كريم

translation: He said: 'Disguise her throne for her that we may see whether she will go aright or be one of those who miss the way.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of the Queen of Sheba and Prophet Solomon. Solomon wanted to test the Queen's wisdom and discernment, so he ordered his servants to disguise her throne in order to see if she would recognize it or be misguided. The interpretation is that true wisdom and guidance come from God, and even those in positions of power and authority must be tested to see if they possess true understanding and follow the right path.
orig: قال نكروا لها عرشها ننظر أتهتدي أم تكون من الذين لا يهتدون

translation: But when she arrived, it was said [to her], 'Is your throne like this?' She said, 'It is as though it is the same, and we were given knowledge before it, and we were Muslims [submitting to Allah].'
interpretation: The verse refers to the story of the Queen of Sheba and her encounter with Prophet Solomon. When she saw the palace built for her, she recognized it as her own throne, indicating her wisdom and knowledge. However, she acknowledged that she and her people had been given knowledge even before this encounter, and that they were already Muslims, submitting to the will of Allah.
orig: فلما جاءت قيل أهكذا عرشك قالت كأنه هو وأوتينا العلم من قبلها وكنا مسلمين

translation: And he was averted from whatever besides Allah they worshipped. Indeed, she was from a disbelieving people.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the person being referred to (with the pronoun 'he') turned away from worshipping anything or anyone other than Allah. It emphasizes that the 'she' mentioned was from people who disbelieved in the Oneness of Allah and associated partners with Him in worship.
orig: وصدها ما كانت تعبد من دون الله إنها كانت من قوم كافرين

translation: It was said to her, 'Enter the palace.' But when she saw it, she thought it was a pool of water and uncovered her shins. He said, 'Indeed, it is a palace paved with glass.' She said, 'My Lord, indeed I have wronged myself, and I submit together with Solomon to Allah, Lord of the worlds.'
interpretation: This verse describes the story of the Queen of Sheba when she was invited to enter Solomon's palace. At first, she mistook the glass floor for a pool of water and uncovered her shins, thinking she had to wade through water. Solomon then clarified that it was a palace made of glass. The Queen realized her mistake and submitted herself to Allah, acknowledging that she had wronged herself by doubting Solomon's words. This story serves as a lesson in humility, recognizing one's faults, and submitting to the truth.
orig: قيل لها ادخلي الصرح فلما رأته حسبته لجة وكشفت عن ساقيها قال إنه صرح ممرد من قوارير قالت رب إني ظلمت نفسي وأسلمت مع سليمان لله رب العالمين

translation: And We certainly sent to Thamud their brother Salih, [saying], 'Worship Allah,' and at once they were two parties quarreling.
interpretation: "This verse refers to the story of the Prophet Salih, who was sent to the people of Thamud. He called them to worship Allah alone, but they split into two opposing groups: those who believed in his message, and those who rejected it and continued in their disbelief and idolatry. This division led to disputes and conflicts among them."
orig: ولقد أرسلنا إلى ثمود أخاهم صالحا أن اعبدوا الله فإذا هم فريقان يختصمون

translation: He said: 'O my people, why do you seek to hasten the evil before the good? Why do you not seek forgiveness from Allah so that you may receive mercy?'
interpretation: This verse encourages people to be patient and not hasten towards evil or wrongdoing. Instead, it advises them to seek forgiveness from Allah and strive for good deeds, as this is the path to receiving Allah's mercy and blessings.
orig: قال يا قوم لم تستعجلون بالسيئة قبل الحسنة لولا تستغفرون الله لعلكم ترحمون

translation: They said, 'We augur ill fortune from you and those with you.' He said, 'Your ill fortune is with Allah; rather, you are a people being tried.'
interpretation: This verse suggests that superstitions and ill omens have no basis in reality, and that trials and difficulties in life are a test from Allah to strengthen one's faith and character. The interpretation emphasizes the importance of trusting in Allah's wisdom and plan, rather than relying on baseless superstitions.
orig: قالوا اطيرنا بك وبمن معك قال طائركم عند الله بل أنتم قوم تفتنون

translation: And there were in the city nine persons who spread corruption on the earth and did not reform.
interpretation: This verse refers to a group of nine people who lived in a city and engaged in spreading corruption and mischief, without any inclination towards righteousness or reform. They disregarded moral values and principles, causing harm and disruption within their community. The verse condemns their actions and highlights their persistent rejection of righteous conduct and positive change.
orig: وكان في المدينة تسعة رهط يفسدون في الأرض ولا يصلحون

translation: They said, 'Swear by Allah that you will lie in wait for him and his family at night, then you will say to his guardian, 'We did not witness the destruction of his family, and we are indeed truthful.'
interpretation: This verse refers to a plot by some people against a prophet and his family. They conspired to lie in ambush at night and attack the prophet's household. Afterwards, they planned to falsely claim innocence to the prophet's guardian, denying any involvement in the destruction of his family, despite being deceitful.
orig: قالوا تقاسموا بالله لنبيتنه وأهله ثم لنقولن لوليه ما شهدنا مهلك أهله وإنا لصادقون

translation: And they plotted a plot, and We plotted a plot, while they perceived not.
interpretation: This verse refers to the plotting and scheming of the disbelievers against the Prophet Muhammad and the believers. However, Allah also had a plan to foil their plots and protect the believers. The disbelievers were unaware of Allah's plan and continued with their evil schemes, oblivious to the fact that their plots would ultimately fail against the will of Allah.
orig: ومكروا مكرا ومكرنا مكرا وهم لا يشعرون

translation: So observe how was the end of their plot; [for] indeed, We destroyed them and their people, all.
interpretation: This verse serves as a warning and a lesson from Allah about the consequences of plotting against His messengers and rejecting the truth. It refers to those who schemed and conspired against the prophets, such as the people of Noah or the Pharaoh and his followers who opposed Moses. Allah is reminding us that He ultimately destroys those who persist in disbelief and wickedness, no matter how powerful or arrogant they may seem. Their plots and schemes were futile, and they met a devastating end along with their people who followed them in falsehood. This verse encourages believers to reflect on the fate of previous nations who defied Allah's messengers, and to remain steadfast in faith and righteousness.
orig: فانظر كيف كان عاقبة مكرهم أنا دمرناهم وقومهم أجمعين

translation: Thus were their houses in utter ruin, for they persisted in wrongdoing. Verily in this is indeed a sign for people of knowledge.
interpretation: "This verse serves as a warning against oppression and wrongdoing. It describes the utter destruction and desolation that befell the dwellings of those who persisted in injustice and transgression against God's commands. Their ruined homes stand as a powerful sign and lesson for those who possess knowledge and insight, reminding them of the grave consequences of defying divine laws and indulging in oppressive behavior."
orig: فتلك بيوتهم خاوية بما ظلموا إن في ذلك لآية لقوم يعلمون

translation: And We delivered those who believed and were righteous.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah saved and rescued those who had faith and were mindful of Him, implying that belief and righteousness are key factors for attaining divine salvation and deliverance from hardships and calamities.
orig: وأنجينا الذين آمنوا وكانوا يتقون

translation: And (mention) Lut, when he said to his people: 'Do you commit the abomination while you see?'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Lut (Lot) who preached against the grave sin of homosexuality that was prevalent among his people. He condemned their act as a 'fahisha' (abomination or immoral deed) and questioned how they could indulge in such an act openly and shamelessly while being fully aware of its sinfulness and immorality.
orig: ولوطا إذ قال لقومه أتأتون الفاحشة وأنتم تبصرون

translation: Do you approach men with lust instead of women? Nay, you are an ignorant people.
interpretation: This verse condemns the practice of homosexuality, which was prevalent among some people at the time of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). It criticizes those who indulge in lustful desires with men instead of women, which is against the natural order established by God. The verse characterizes such behavior as a form of ignorance and deviation from the divine guidance.
orig: أئنكم لتأتون الرجال شهوة من دون النساء بل أنتم قوم تجهلون

translation: But the answer of his people was not except that they said, 'Expel the family of Lot from your city. Indeed, they are people who keep themselves pure.'
interpretation: The verse refers to the people of Prophet Lut (Lot) who rejected his call to worship Allah alone and accused him and his followers of being "pure" or "self-righteous" people. They demanded that Lut's family be expelled from their city because they disapproved of their moral values and perceived "purity".
orig: فما كان جواب قومه إلا أن قالوا أخرجوا آل لوط من قريتكم إنهم أناس يتطهرون

translation: So We saved him and his family, except his wife; We destined her to be of those who remained behind.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Lut (Lot) and how Allah saved him and his believing family members, except his wife who chose to remain with the disbelievers. Her fate was sealed as she was destined to be among those who were destroyed for their persistent rejection of faith and disobedience to Allah's commands.
orig: فأنجيناه وأهله إلا امرأته قدرناها من الغابرين

translation: And We rained upon them a rain [of stones]. And wretched is the rain of those who were warned.
interpretation: This verse refers to the punishment that Allah inflicted upon the people of Lut (Lot) for their grave sins of homosexuality and highway robbery. The "rain" mentioned here is a figurative expression for the shower of stones that Allah sent down upon them, destroying their entire community as a consequence of their persistent disobedience and rejection of the warnings conveyed by Prophet Lut. The interpretation highlights Allah's severe punishment for those who defy His commands and refuse to heed the advice of His messengers, despite being warned repeatedly.
orig: وأمطرنا عليهم مطرا فساء مطر المنذرين

translation: Say: Praise be to Allah and peace be upon His servants whom He has chosen. Is Allah better, or the partners they ascribe?
interpretation: This verse instructs the Prophet Muhammad to declare that all praise belongs to Allah alone, and to send greetings of peace upon those servants whom Allah has chosen and guided to the true faith. It then poses a rhetorical question: Is Allah, the One True God, better or the false deities that the idolaters associate with Him? The verse affirms Allah's absolute perfection and the falsehood of associating partners with Him.
orig: قل الحمد لله وسلام على عباده الذين اصطفى آلله خير أما يشركون

translation: Is He who created the heavens and the earth and sent down for you water from the sky, by which We caused to grow orchards full of splendid beauty - you could not cause their trees to grow? Is there a god besides Allah? Rather, they are a people who equate others with Him.
interpretation: هذه الآية تبين قدرة الله تعالى وعظمته في خلق السماوات والأرض وإنزال المطر الذي به تنبت الحدائق الجميلة، وتساءل الآية عن وجود إله آخر غير الله قادر على ذلك، ثم تصف الذين يشركون بالله بأنهم قوم يعدلون ويساوون بين الله وغيره من المخلوقات.
orig: أمن خلق السماوات والأرض وأنزل لكم من السماء ماء فأنبتنا به حدائق ذات بهجة ما كان لكم أن تنبتوا شجرها أإله مع الله بل هم قوم يعدلون

translation: Is He who made the earth a resting place, and made rivers through it, and made firm mountains for it, and placed a partition between the two seas? Is there any god besides Allah? Nay, but most of them know not.
interpretation: This verse is highlighting the uniqueness and power of Allah as the sole Creator. It describes various aspects of Allah's creation, such as the earth being a stable dwelling place, the presence of rivers, mountains, and the barrier between salt and fresh waters. These signs of Allah's might are then contrasted with the notion of any other deity besides Him, rejecting it outright and attributing such ignorance to most people's lack of knowledge.
orig: أمن جعل الأرض قرارا وجعل خلالها أنهارا وجعل لها رواسي وجعل بين البحرين حاجزا أإله مع الله بل أكثرهم لا يعلمون

translation: Or is He [not best] who responds to the distressed one when he calls upon Him and removes the evil and has made you successors upon the earth? Is there a deity with Allah? Little do you remember.
interpretation: Allah is questioning whether there is any other deity besides Him who responds to the distressed when they call upon Him, removes hardship and evil, and has granted humankind the honor of being successors on earth. The verse emphasizes Allah's uniqueness as the only true God worthy of worship and reminds people of their forgetfulness and lack of gratitude towards Him.
orig: أمن يجيب المضطر إذا دعاه ويكشف السوء ويجعلكم خلفاء الأرض أإله مع الله قليلا ما تذكرون

translation: Or who guides you through the depths of darkness on land and sea and who sends the winds as heralds of glad tidings, going before His mercy? Is there another god besides Allah? High is Allah exalted above whatever they associate with Him.
interpretation: This verse highlights Allah's power and control over the forces of nature, which guide and protect humanity. The interpretation is that no one other than Allah has the ability to guide people through the darkness of land and sea, or send favorable winds as a sign of His mercy. It emphasizes Allah's uniqueness and rejects the notion of any other deity besides Him.
orig: أمن يهديكم في ظلمات البر والبحر ومن يرسل الرياح بشرا بين يدي رحمته أإله مع الله تعالى الله عما يشركون

translation: Is He who begins the creation, then repeats it, and who provides for you from the heaven and the earth? Is there any god besides Allah? Say, 'Bring forth your proof if you are truthful.'
interpretation: This verse questions the polytheists' belief in multiple deities. It asks them who is the one that initiates creation, sustains it, and provides for all from the heavens and the earth. The rhetorical question implies that there is no other deity besides Allah who possesses such power and control over the universe. The verse challenges the polytheists to present evidence for their beliefs if they are truthful in their claims.
orig: أمن يبدأ الخلق ثم يعيده ومن يرزقكم من السماء والأرض أإله مع الله قل هاتوا برهانكم إن كنتم صادقين

translation: Say: None in the heavens and the earth knows the unseen except Allah, and they do not perceive when they shall be raised.
interpretation: No one in the heavens or on earth except Allah has knowledge of the unseen and the future events like the Day of Resurrection. The disbelievers are unaware of when they will be resurrected and brought back to life for judgement.
orig: قل لا يعلم من في السماوات والأرض الغيب إلا الله وما يشعرون أيان يبعثون

translation: Nay, but their knowledge stops short of the Hereafter; nay, they are in doubt concerning it; nay, they are blind to it.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the disbelievers have limited knowledge about the Hereafter and the reality of life after death. They are in doubt and uncertainty regarding its existence, and they are blind and unable to comprehend its true nature. Their denial stems from their ignorance and lack of faith.
orig: بل ادارك علمهم في الآخرة بل هم في شك منها بل هم منها عمون

translation: And those who disbelieved say, 'When we have become dust as well as our forefathers, will we indeed be brought forth [again]?'
interpretation: The disbelievers expressed their disbelief in the resurrection, questioning how they and their ancestors who have turned to dust could be brought back to life. This verse highlights their denial of the fundamental Islamic belief in the resurrection and accountability on the Day of Judgment.
orig: وقال الذين كفروا أإذا كنا ترابا وآباؤنا أئنا لمخرجون

translation: We have been promised this - we and our forefathers before - these are nothing but legends of the former peoples.
interpretation: This verse refers to the disbelievers' rejection of the concept of resurrection and life after death. They dismiss it as mere tales and fables inherited from previous generations, without any basis in reality. The interpretation highlights their arrogant denial of the truth and their stubborn adherence to the beliefs and traditions of their ancestors, even when presented with clear evidence and guidance.
orig: لقد وعدنا هذا نحن وآباؤنا من قبل إن هذا إلا أساطير الأولين

translation: Say, 'Travel through the land and observe how was the end of the criminals.'
interpretation: This verse encourages people to reflect on the consequences of wrongdoing by observing the fate of past nations who committed sins and crimes. It suggests that by exploring the world and studying history, one can learn valuable lessons about the inevitable punishment that befalls those who transgress against God's laws and engage in corruption and oppression. The verse implies that just as previous civilizations were destroyed due to their evil deeds, a similar fate awaits those who persist in immorality and disobedience.
orig: قل سيروا في الأرض فانظروا كيف كان عاقبة المجرمين

translation: And do not be grieved over them, nor be in distress because of what they plot.
interpretation: "Do not feel saddened or distressed by the disbelief and rejection of the truth by those who oppose you. Have trust in Allah and remain steadfast, for He will protect you from their evil schemes and plots."
orig: ولا تحزن عليهم ولا تكن في ضيق مما يمكرون

translation: And they say, 'When is this promise, if you should be truthful?'
interpretation: This verse refers to the disbelievers mocking and questioning the truthfulness of the Prophet Muhammad's warning about the Day of Resurrection and divine punishment. They are demanding proof and asking when this promised event will occur if the Prophet is indeed truthful in his message.
orig: ويقولون متى هذا الوعد إن كنتم صادقين

translation: Say, 'Perhaps that which you are impatient for is close behind you.'
interpretation: This verse suggests that the punishment or consequences that the disbelievers are hastening may actually be imminent and approaching them soon. It serves as a warning that what they are demanding out of mockery or impatience may manifest sooner than they expect, prompting them to be mindful and reconsider their stance.
orig: قل عسى أن يكون ردف لكم بعض الذي تستعجلون

translation: And indeed, your Lord is the possessor of bounty for the people, but most of them are not grateful.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that Allah bestows countless favors and blessings upon humanity, but unfortunately, most people do not recognize or appreciate them. They fail to express gratitude for Allah's generosity and bounties, which include life itself, sustenance, health, and innumerable other blessings. The verse serves as a reminder to be thankful and appreciative of Allah's favors, and not to be among the ungrateful majority.
orig: وإن ربك لذو فضل على الناس ولكن أكثرهم لا يشكرون

translation: And indeed, your Lord knows what their breasts conceal and what they reveal.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah has complete knowledge of what people conceal in their hearts, as well as what they openly express. It emphasizes Allah's all-encompassing knowledge and awareness of the innermost thoughts, intentions, and secrets of individuals. No matter how well one may attempt to hide something, Allah is fully aware of it. This serves as a reminder to have sincerity, truthfulness, and consciousness of Allah in one's heart and actions.
orig: وإن ربك ليعلم ما تكن صدورهم وما يعلنون

translation: And there is nothing hidden in the heaven and the earth but it is in a clear Book.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah's knowledge encompasses everything in the heavens and the earth, and that nothing is hidden from Him. All things, whether visible or unseen, are recorded and preserved in a "clear Book", which refers to the Preserved Tablet (al-Lawh al-Mahfudh). This affirms Allah's absolute knowledge, power, and authority over all creation.
orig: وما من غائبة في السماء والأرض إلا في كتاب مبين

translation: Verily, this Qur'an narrates to the Children of Israel most of that about which they differ.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the Qur'an provides guidance and clarification on many matters that were disputed among the Jews (Children of Israel). It aims to resolve their differences and disagreements by presenting the truth from Allah. The Qur'an serves as a reference point and a source of knowledge to address the various controversies and conflicting views they held regarding religious matters.
orig: إن هذا القرآن يقص على بني إسرائيل أكثر الذي هم فيه يختلفون

translation: And indeed, it (the Qur'an) is a guidance and mercy for the believers.
interpretation: This verse highlights two essential qualities of the Qur'an: it is a source of guidance that illuminates the straight path, and a manifestation of God's mercy, providing solace and forgiveness for those who have faith and follow its teachings. The Qur'an serves as a comprehensive guide for believers, offering them direction in all aspects of life, while simultaneously being a profound expression of divine compassion and benevolence towards those who embrace its message wholeheartedly.
orig: وإنه لهدى ورحمة للمؤمنين

translation: Indeed, your Lord will judge between them by His [wise] judgement. And He is the Exalted in Might, the All-Knowing.
interpretation: This verse implies that Allah, the Most High, is the ultimate Judge and Arbiter. He will settle disputes and judge between His servants with perfect justice and wisdom, for He is the Almighty and the All-Knowing, fully aware of all circumstances and intentions.
orig: إن ربك يقضي بينهم بحكمه وهو العزيز العليم

translation: So put your trust in Allah, for you are on the manifest truth.
interpretation: This verse instructs the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to place his complete trust and reliance in Allah alone, since he is following the clear and evident truth from Allah. It encourages having firm faith and conviction in Allah's guidance and support, especially in the face of opposition or adversity.
orig: فتوكل على الله إنك على الحق المبين

translation: Verily, you cannot make the dead hear, nor can you make the deaf hear the call when they turn away.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) cannot guide those who are spiritually dead or unwilling to listen to the truth. Just as a physically dead person cannot hear, and a deaf person cannot hear when turning away, similarly those who reject faith and turn away from guidance cannot benefit from the Prophet's message.
orig: إنك لا تسمع الموتى ولا تسمع الصم الدعاء إذا ولوا مدبرين

translation: And you are not a guide to the blind against their misguidance. You can only make hear him who believes in Our verses, so they are Muslims.
interpretation: Allah is telling the Prophet Muhammad that he cannot guide the spiritually blind who reject faith. His role is to convey the message, but guidance comes from Allah. Only those who have faith in Allah's revelations and submit to Him will benefit from the Prophet's teachings.
orig: وما أنت بهادي العمي عن ضلالتهم إن تسمع إلا من يؤمن بآياتنا فهم مسلمون

translation: And when the Word is fulfilled against them, We shall bring forth for them a creature from the earth which will speak to them because people did not believe in Our signs with certainty.
interpretation: This verse is referring to a miraculous event that will occur towards the end of times. A creature from the earth will emerge and speak to humans, bearing witness that they disbelieved in Allah's signs and revelations. This creature's speech is a sign from Allah, meant to awaken people to the truth they had rejected.
orig: وإذا وقع القول عليهم أخرجنا لهم دابة من الأرض تكلمهم أن الناس كانوا بآياتنا لا يوقنون

translation: And on the Day We will gather from every nation a group of those who denied Our signs, and they will be driven in rows.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Day of Judgment, when Allah will gather representatives from every nation or community who rejected and denied His signs and revelations. They will be driven and assembled in rows to face accountability for their disbelief and denial of the truth.
orig: ويوم نحشر من كل أمة فوجا ممن يكذب بآياتنا فهم يوزعون

translation: Until, when they come, He will say, 'Did you deny My signs while you encompassed them not in knowledge? Or what [deed] were you doing?'
interpretation: This verse warns those who reject the signs of Allah and follow their desires without knowledge or guidance. On the Day of Judgment, Allah will question them about denying His clear signs and revelations without truly understanding them. Their deeds based on ignorance and arrogance will be exposed, and they will have no excuse.
orig: حتى إذا جاءوا قال أكذبتم بآياتي ولم تحيطوا بها علما أماذا كنتم تعملون

translation: And the Word will be fulfilled against them for what they have wronged, and they will not be able to speak.
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that the punishment and decree of Allah will inevitably come upon those who persisted in wrongdoing and disbelief. They will be rendered speechless and unable to offer any excuses or pleas on the Day of Judgment for their injustices and rejection of the truth.
orig: ووقع القول عليهم بما ظلموا فهم لا ينطقون

translation: Do they not see that We have made the night for them to rest therein and the day giving sight? Verily, in this are indeed signs for a people who believe.
interpretation: "This verse highlights the wisdom and power of Allah in creating the night and day, each serving a distinct purpose for the benefit of humanity. The night is a time of rest and tranquility, allowing people to find repose and rejuvenation. Conversely, the day brings light, enabling vision and facilitating human activities. These natural phenomena are signs of Allah's existence and greatness, but only those who believe and reflect upon them can truly appreciate their significance."
orig: ألم يروا أنا جعلنا الليل ليسكنوا فيه والنهار مبصرا إن في ذلك لآيات لقوم يؤمنون

translation: And on the Day when the Trumpet will be blown, then whoever is in the heavens and whoever is on the earth will be terrified, except whom Allah wills. And all shall come unto Him, humbled.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Day of Resurrection when the Trumpet will be blown, striking terror in all creatures in the heavens and on earth, except those whom Allah wills to exempt. All beings will come before Allah in a state of humility and submission, having no choice but to face the ultimate reckoning.
orig: ويوم ينفخ في الصور ففزع من في السماوات ومن في الأرض إلا من شاء الله وكل أتوه داخرين

translation: And you see the mountains, thinking them rigid, while they pass like the passing of clouds - the work of Allah, who perfected everything. Indeed, He is Acquainted with what you do.
interpretation: The verse highlights Allah's perfect creation and His knowledge of all things. It compares the movement of mountains, which may seem motionless, to the passing of clouds, indicating that they are in constant motion by Allah's command. This emphasizes Allah's power and mastery over His creation, as He has perfected everything according to a precise plan. The verse also reminds us that Allah is fully aware of our actions and deeds.
orig: وترى الجبال تحسبها جامدة وهي تمر مر السحاب صنع الله الذي أتقن كل شيء إنه خبير بما تفعلون

translation: Whoever brings a good deed will have better than it, and they will be secure from terror on that Day.
interpretation: This verse promises a great reward for those who perform good deeds in this world. They will receive an even greater recompense from Allah than the deed itself. Moreover, on the Day of Judgment, they will be safe from fear and terror, enjoying security and peace.
orig: من جاء بالحسنة فله خير منها وهم من فزع يومئذ آمنون

translation: And whoever comes with an evil deed - their faces will be overturned into the Fire, [and it will be said], 'Are you receiving [anything] except what you used to do?'
interpretation: This verse warns that those who commit evil deeds will be punished in the Hereafter. Their faces will be thrown into the Fire of Hell, and they will be recompensed for their misdeeds. The rhetorical question "Are you receiving [anything] except what you used to do?" emphasizes that their punishment is a direct consequence of their own actions and choices in this world.
orig: ومن جاء بالسيئة فكبت وجوههم في النار هل تجزون إلا ما كنتم تعملون

translation: I have been commanded only to worship the Lord of this city, Who has sanctified it, and to Whom all things belong. And I have been commanded to be of those who submit [to Allah].
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the fundamental teachings of Islam: the worship of the One True God, the Lord of Makkah, and the submission to His Will. It highlights the sanctity of Makkah and affirms that all things belong to Allah, the Almighty. The verse also instructs the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to be among those who submit themselves completely to Allah's commands and guidance.
orig: إنما أمرت أن أعبد رب هذه البلدة الذي حرمها وله كل شيء وأمرت أن أكون من المسلمين

translation: And that I should recite the Quran, so whoever is guided is only guided for [the benefit of] himself; and whoever goes astray - then say, 'I am only one of the warners.'
interpretation: The interpretation is that the Prophet's role is to recite and convey the Qur'an, but guidance ultimately comes from Allah. Those who follow the guidance do so for their own benefit, while those who stray are simply warned by the Prophet, who is just a messenger and not responsible for their misguidance.
orig: وأن أتلو القرآن فمن اهتدى فإنما يهتدي لنفسه ومن ضل فقل إنما أنا من المنذرين

translation: And say, 'Praise be to Allah; He will show you His signs, and you shall recognize them. And your Lord is not unaware of what you do.'
interpretation: This verse encourages gratitude to Allah and affirms that He will reveal clear signs that will help people recognize the truth. It also reminds us that Allah is fully aware of all our actions and nothing is hidden from Him. The interpretation emphasizes having faith in Allah's signs, being mindful of our deeds, and acknowledging Allah's knowledge and awareness of everything we do.
orig: وقل الحمد لله سيريكم آياته فتعرفونها وما ربك بغافل عما تعملون

translation: Ta, Sin, Mim (These letters are one of the mystic letters in the beginning of some chapters of the Quran, and their meanings are known only to Allah).
interpretation: These mystic letters are among the Quranic mysteries whose meanings are known only to Allah. Some scholars suggest that they may represent divine names or symbols that only Allah knows their true significance. They serve as an affirmation that the Quran is the word of Allah, containing profound meanings that human beings cannot fully comprehend.
orig: طسم

translation: These are the verses of the enlightening Book.
interpretation: This verse affirms that the verses mentioned are from the Qur'an, which is described as "the enlightening Book." It highlights the clarity and guidance that the Qur'an provides, illuminating the path for humanity and dispelling doubts and uncertainties.
orig: تلك آيات الكتاب المبين

translation: We recite to you from the story of Moses and Pharaoh in truth, for a people who believe.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the Qur'an narrates the truthful story of Moses and Pharaoh as a lesson and guidance for those who have faith and are willing to believe. The story serves as a reminder of Allah's power, justice, and support for the oppressed against the tyranny of the arrogant rulers like Pharaoh.
orig: نتلو عليك من نبإ موسى وفرعون بالحق لقوم يؤمنون

translation: Indeed, Pharaoh exalted himself in the land and made its people into factions, oppressing a sector among them by slaughtering their [newborn] sons and keeping their females alive. Indeed, he was of the corrupters.
interpretation: This verse highlights Pharaoh's arrogance and oppression towards the Israelites. He divided the people into groups and subjugated one group, the Israelites, by killing their newborn sons to prevent them from growing in number and strength, while sparing the females, likely for enslavement. This cruel practice was an act of corruption and transgression against God's commands.
orig: إن فرعون علا في الأرض وجعل أهلها شيعا يستضعف طائفة منهم يذبح أبناءهم ويستحيي نساءهم إنه كان من المفسدين

translation: And We wished to confer favor upon those who were oppressed in the land, and to make them leaders and make them inheritors.
interpretation: This verse suggests that Allah intends to empower and honor those who have been oppressed and persecuted on earth. He plans to elevate their status, making them leaders and giving them authority and inheritance, as a way of favoring and rewarding them for their perseverance and steadfastness in the face of injustice and hardship.
orig: ونريد أن نمن على الذين استضعفوا في الأرض ونجعلهم أئمة ونجعلهم الوارثين

translation: And We established them in the land and showed Pharaoh and Haman and their hosts from them what they had been fearing.
interpretation: This verse suggests that Allah gave power and authority to the oppressed Children of Israel in the land, and made Pharaoh, Haman and their armies witness the very thing they feared - the rise and empowerment of those they had subjugated. It implies a reversal of fortunes, where the oppressed became victorious and the oppressors witnessed their own downfall.
orig: ونمكن لهم في الأرض ونري فرعون وهامان وجنودهما منهم ما كانوا يحذرون

translation: And We inspired the mother of Moses, saying: 'Suckle him, but when you fear for him, cast him into the river and do not fear and do not grieve. Indeed, We will return him to you and will make him one of the messengers.'
interpretation: "This verse refers to the divine inspiration given to the mother of Prophet Moses during the difficult circumstances surrounding his birth. God commanded her to nurse and nurture Moses, but when she feared for his safety due to the oppression of Pharaoh, she was instructed to place him in the river Nile. However, God reassured her not to fear or grieve, as He would ensure Moses' safe return to her and would appoint him as one of His messengers with a great mission."
orig: وأوحينا إلى أم موسى أن أرضعيه فإذا خفت عليه فألقيه في اليم ولا تخافي ولا تحزني إنا رادوه إليك وجاعلوه من المرسلين

translation: Then the family of Pharaoh picked him up, that he might become for them an enemy and a cause of grief. Certainly, Pharaoh and Haman and their soldiers were deliberate sinners.
interpretation: Allah allowed the baby Moses to be found and raised in Pharaoh's household, despite Pharaoh's intention to kill all newborn males among the Children of Israel. This was a divine plan to make Moses a source of enmity and grief for Pharaoh and his people, as Moses would eventually confront them and expose their wrongdoings. Pharaoh, Haman (his minister), and their soldiers were deliberately committing sins by oppressing and persecuting the Israelites.
orig: فالتقطه آل فرعون ليكون لهم عدوا وحزنا إن فرعون وهامان وجنودهما كانوا خاطئين

translation: And the wife of Pharaoh said, 'A comfort of the eye for me and for you. Do not kill him; perhaps he may benefit us, or we may adopt him as a son.' And they were not aware.
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that Pharaoh's wife was moved by the infant Moses and saw him as a potential source of joy and comfort for herself and Pharaoh. She pleaded with Pharaoh not to kill him, suggesting that they could adopt him as their own son, as she saw some good in him that could benefit them. However, they were unaware of the great destiny that Allah had planned for Moses as a Prophet and messenger.
orig: وقالت امرأت فرعون قرت عين لي ولك لا تقتلوه عسى أن ينفعنا أو نتخذه ولدا وهم لا يشعرون

translation: And the heart of Moses' mother became empty [of all else]. She was very nearly exposing him, had We not bound fast her heart that she might be of the believers.
interpretation: The interpretation is that Allah strengthened the heart of Moses' mother with faith and patience, enabling her to endure the difficult situation of putting her infant son in the river. Despite her intense motherly love and fear for her child's safety, Allah prevented her from exposing Moses' identity, which could have put him in harm's way. Her unwavering belief in Allah's plan allowed her to trust in His wisdom and protection.
orig: وأصبح فؤاد أم موسى فارغا إن كادت لتبدي به لولا أن ربطنا على قلبها لتكون من المؤمنين

translation: And she said to his sister, 'Follow him.' So she watched him from a distance while they were unaware.
interpretation: This verse refers to an incident involving the infant Moses and his sister. When Moses' mother placed him in a basket and set it afloat on the river to save him from being killed by Pharaoh's men, she instructed Moses' sister to follow the basket discreetly and observe where it would end up, without arousing suspicion from those who might harm the child. The sister obediently watched over the basket from a safe distance, unnoticed by others, allowing God's plan to unfold and protect Moses.
orig: وقالت لأخته قصيه فبصرت به عن جنب وهم لا يشعرون

translation: And We had already forbidden wet nurses for him before. So she said, 'Shall I direct you to a household that will be responsible for his upbringing for you, and they will be sincere advisers to him?'
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident when Prophet Moses' mother had to part ways with him due to the decree of Pharaoh. She was inspired by Allah to send him away, entrusting his care to a household that would raise him and guide him sincerely, without knowing that it was the household of Pharaoh himself.
orig: وحرمنا عليه المراضع من قبل فقالت هل أدلكم على أهل بيت يكفلونه لكم وهم له ناصحون

translation: So We returned him to his mother that she might be content and not grieve, and that she would know that the promise of Allah is true. But most of them do not know.
interpretation: Allah returned the child to his mother so that she may be comforted and not grieve over losing him. This was also to reassure her that Allah's promise of reuniting them is true. However, most people do not understand Allah's wisdom and plans.
orig: فرددناه إلى أمه كي تقر عينها ولا تحزن ولتعلم أن وعد الله حق ولكن أكثرهم لا يعلمون

translation: And when he attained his full strength and was perfect, We bestowed upon him wisdom and knowledge; for thus do We reward the doers of good.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Jesus, peace be upon him. It indicates that when he reached maturity and attained full physical and intellectual development, Allah bestowed upon him wisdom and knowledge as a reward for his righteousness and good deeds. This highlights Allah's mercy and justice in granting guidance and understanding to those who strive to do good.
orig: ولما بلغ أشده واستوى آتيناه حكما وعلما وكذلك نجزي المحسنين

translation: And he entered the city at a time of inattention by its people and found therein two men fighting - one from his faction and one from among his enemy. And the one from his faction called for help to him against the one from his enemy, so Moses struck him and [unintentionally] killed him. [Moses] said, "This is from the work of Satan. Indeed, he is a manifest, misguiding enemy."
interpretation: This verse describes an incident where Moses entered a city and found two men fighting, one from his own people and the other from his enemy's people. The one from his people called for Moses' help against the enemy. In trying to defend his man, Moses struck the enemy with such force that he ended up killing him unintentionally. Moses then realized that this act of violence was instigated by Satan, who is a clear enemy that misguides people.
orig: ودخل المدينة على حين غفلة من أهلها فوجد فيها رجلين يقتتلان هذا من شيعته وهذا من عدوه فاستغاثه الذي من شيعته على الذي من عدوه فوكزه موسى فقضى عليه قال هذا من عمل الشيطان إنه عدو مضل مبين

translation: He said, 'My Lord, I have wronged myself, so forgive me,' and He forgave him. Indeed, He is the Forgiving, the Merciful.
interpretation: This verse highlights the mercy and forgiveness of Allah. It teaches us that no matter how grave our sins, if we sincerely repent and ask for forgiveness from Allah, He will forgive us. It emphasizes the importance of acknowledging our mistakes, feeling remorseful, and turning back to Allah with a sincere heart. The verse also reminds us of the infinite mercy and compassion of Allah, who is always ready to forgive those who repent sincerely.
orig: قال رب إني ظلمت نفسي فاغفر لي فغفر له إنه هو الغفور الرحيم

translation: He said: 'O my Lord! For that wherewith Thou hast favoured me, I will surely not be a supporter of the guilty.'
interpretation: This verse refers to Prophet Ibrahim's (peace be upon him) statement expressing his firm resolve to never aid or support those who persist in disbelief and wrongdoing against Allah. He acknowledged the favors and blessings bestowed upon him by Allah and vowed to use them in the way of truth and righteousness, never lending a hand to the criminals who defy Allah's commands.
orig: قال رب بما أنعمت علي فلن أكون ظهيرا للمجرمين

translation: So he became afraid, anticipating [exposure] in the city, when suddenly the one who asked his help the previous day cried out to him [once again]. Moses said to him, "Indeed, you are an evident, [persisting] deviator."
interpretation: This verse describes the aftermath of Moses' unintentional killing of the Egyptian man. Moses became fearful and anxious, anticipating that his act would be exposed in the city. At that moment, the same Israelite who had sought Moses' help the previous day called out to him again, perhaps seeking further assistance. However, Moses rebuked him, calling him a "persisting deviator" or someone who persists in misguidance and error. This suggests that the Israelite's behavior or demands were inappropriate or misguided, leading Moses to recognize him as someone who consistently deviates from the right path.
orig: فأصبح في المدينة خائفا يترقب فإذا الذي استنصره بالأمس يستصرخه قال له موسى إنك لغوي مبين

translation: But when he intended to seize the one who was an enemy to both of them, he said, 'O Moses, do you intend to kill me as you killed someone yesterday? You only want to be a tyrant in the land, and you do not want to be among the reformers.'
interpretation: This verse refers to an incident where Moses encountered a man who was an enemy to him and another person. The man accused Moses of wanting to kill him, just as he had killed someone the previous day. He accused Moses of seeking to become a tyrant in the land and not wanting to be among those who reform and do good.
orig: فلما أن أراد أن يبطش بالذي هو عدو لهما قال يا موسى أتريد أن تقتلني كما قتلت نفسا بالأمس إن تريد إلا أن تكون جبارا في الأرض وما تريد أن تكون من المصلحين

translation: And a man came running from the farthest part of the city. He said: 'O Moses! The chiefs are conspiring against you to kill you, so leave; I am one of your well-wishers.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident where a man came rushing from the outskirts of the city to warn Moses that the chiefs and leaders were plotting to kill him after he had killed an Egyptian. The interpretation is that even when one is striving for justice and truth, there will be opposition and threats from those in power, but God sends help and guidance through well-wishers to protect the righteous.
orig: وجاء رجل من أقصى المدينة يسعى قال يا موسى إن الملأ يأتمرون بك ليقتلوك فاخرج إني لك من الناصحين

translation: So he went forth therefrom, fearing and awaiting. He said: My Lord! Save me from the wrongdoing people.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) after he fled from Egypt, fearing for his life after accidentally killing a man while trying to stop a fight between an Israelite and an Egyptian. He left Egypt in a state of fear and apprehension, seeking refuge in God and praying to be saved from the oppressive people who might harm him.
orig: فخرج منها خائفا يترقب قال رب نجني من القوم الظالمين

translation: And when he went towards Madyan, he said: 'I hope my Lord will guide me to the right way.'
interpretation: This verse refers to Prophet Moses' journey towards Madyan after fleeing from Egypt. He expresses his hope and trust in Allah to guide him to the right path, recognizing that true guidance comes from God alone.
orig: ولما توجه تلقاء مدين قال عسى ربي أن يهديني سواء السبيل

translation: And when he arrived at the water of Midian, he found there a community of people watering [their flocks], and he found aside from them two women driving back [their flocks]. He said, 'What is your circumstance?' They said, 'We do not water until the shepherds dispatch [their flocks]; and our father is an old man.'
interpretation: This verse describes the arrival of Prophet Moses in Midian after fleeing Egypt. He found a group of people watering their flocks, and two women waiting to water their animals after the shepherds had finished. The women explained that their elderly father could not water the animals himself, so they had to wait their turn. This situation revealed the difficulties faced by the weak and vulnerable in society, and foreshadowed Moses' subsequent assistance to the women.
orig: ولما ورد ماء مدين وجد عليه أمة من الناس يسقون ووجد من دونهم امرأتين تذودان قال ما خطبكما قالتا لا نسقي حتى يصدر الرعاء وأبونا شيخ كبير

translation: So he watered (their flocks) for them. Then he turned back to shade, and said: 'O my Lord! Truly, I am in need of whatever good that You bestow on me.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Musa (Moses) when he arrived in Madyan after fleeing from Egypt. He helped two women water their flocks, and then sought shade and supplicated to Allah, acknowledging his need for Allah's provision and bounties.
orig: فسقى لهما ثم تولى إلى الظل فقال رب إني لما أنزلت إلي من خير فقير

translation: Then there came to him one of the two women, walking with shyness. She said, 'Indeed, my father invites you that he may reward you for having watered for us.' So when he came to him and related to him the story, he said, 'Fear not. You have escaped from the wrongdoing people.'
interpretation: This verse narrates the story of Prophet Moses after he fled from Egypt. One of the two women he had helped by watering their flocks came to him shyly, inviting him to meet her father, who wanted to reward him for his kind act. When Moses met the father and told him what had happened, the father reassured him, saying he need not fear, for he had escaped from the oppressive people of Egypt.
orig: فجاءته إحداهما تمشي على استحياء قالت إن أبي يدعوك ليجزيك أجر ما سقيت لنا فلما جاءه وقص عليه القصص قال لا تخف نجوت من القوم الظالمين

translation: One of the two women said, 'O my father, hire him. Indeed, the best one you can hire is the strong and the trustworthy.'
interpretation: This verse highlights the importance of hiring capable and trustworthy individuals. The woman advises her father to hire the man (Moses) because he possesses the qualities of strength and trustworthiness, which are essential for carrying out tasks effectively and responsibly. The interpretation emphasizes the value of competence and integrity in any professional or personal endeavor.
orig: قالت إحداهما يا أبت استأجره إن خير من استأجرت القوي الأمين

translation: He said: 'I intend to wed one of these two daughters of mine to you, on condition that you serve me for eight years; but if you complete ten, it will be of your own free will. I do not wish to be hard on you, God willing, you will find me one of the righteous.'
interpretation: This verse relates to the story of Prophet Moses when he sought employment with a righteous man. The man offered to marry one of his daughters to Moses in return for serving him for eight years, or optionally ten years if Moses chose to do so voluntarily. The man reassured Moses that he did not wish to overburden him, and that God willing, Moses would find him to be a righteous person to work with.
orig: قال إني أريد أن أنكحك إحدى ابنتي هاتين على أن تأجرني ثماني حجج فإن أتممت عشرا فمن عندك وما أريد أن أشق عليك ستجدني إن شاء الله من الصالحين

translation: He said, 'This is between me and you. Whichever of the two terms I fulfill, there will be no injustice done to me, and Allah is a Witness over what we say.'
interpretation: This verse refers to a situation where two parties have agreed upon certain terms or conditions. The interpretation is that if either party fulfills their part of the agreement, the other party cannot accuse them of any wrongdoing or injustice. Additionally, it emphasizes that Allah is the Witness over their agreement and their words.
orig: قال ذلك بيني وبينك أيما الأجلين قضيت فلا عدوان علي والله على ما نقول وكيل

translation: So when Moses had completed the term and was traveling with his family, he perceived from the direction of the mount a fire. He said to his family, "Stay here; indeed, I have perceived a fire. Perhaps I can bring you from there some information or a burning wood from the fire that you may warm yourselves."
interpretation: This verse describes the beginning of Moses' encounter with God at the burning bush. After completing his term of service with his father-in-law, Moses was traveling with his family when he noticed a fire in the distance near Mount Sinai. He told his family to stay behind while he went to investigate the fire, hoping to bring back information or a burning ember to warm themselves. This marked the start of Moses' prophetic mission and his communication with God.
orig: فلما قضى موسى الأجل وسار بأهله آنس من جانب الطور نارا قال لأهله امكثوا إني آنست نارا لعلي آتيكم منها بخبر أو جذوة من النار لعلكم تصطلون

translation: Then when he came to it, he was called from the right side of the valley in the blessed ground, from the tree, 'O Moses, indeed I am Allah, Lord of the worlds.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the event when Prophet Moses encountered the burning bush on Mount Sinai. He was called by Allah from the right side of the valley, which is described as the "blessed ground." The voice came from the tree, addressing Moses and declaring that Allah is the Lord of the worlds. This event marked the beginning of Moses' prophethood and his mission to confront Pharaoh and deliver the Children of Israel from bondage.
orig: فلما أتاها نودي من شاطئ الواد الأيمن في البقعة المباركة من الشجرة أن يا موسى إني أنا الله رب العالمين

translation: "And throw your staff." So when he saw it writhing as if it were a snake, he turned in flight and did not return. "O Moses, come forward and do not fear. Indeed, you are of those who are secure."
interpretation: "This verse describes the encounter between Moses and God at the sacred valley of Tuwa. When Moses threw down his staff as commanded by God, it miraculously transformed into a slithering snake, causing Moses to flee in fear initially. However, God reassured him, calling him to approach without fear, as he was among those who were secure and protected by God."
orig: وأن ألق عصاك فلما رآها تهتز كأنها جان ولى مدبرا ولم يعقب يا موسى أقبل ولا تخف إنك من الآمنين

translation: Put your hand into your bosom, it will come forth white without disease, and draw your wing close to yourself (to still) your fear. These are two proofs from your Lord to Pharaoh and his chiefs. Truly, they are an evil-living people.
interpretation: This verse instructs Prophet Moses to perform two miracles as signs from God to Pharaoh and his people. The first is to insert his hand into his garment and then withdraw it, and it will come out shining white without any disease or blemish. The second is to draw his wing or arm close to his body to overcome his fear. These two miracles are evidence of Moses' prophethood from God to Pharaoh and his chiefs, who were transgressing people.
orig: اسلك يدك في جيبك تخرج بيضاء من غير سوء واضمم إليك جناحك من الرهب فذانك برهانان من ربك إلى فرعون وملئه إنهم كانوا قوما فاسقين

translation: He said: 'O my Lord! I have killed a person among them, and I fear that they will kill me.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the incident when Moses killed an Egyptian man who was fighting with an Israelite. Moses expresses his fear of being killed in retaliation by the Egyptians for this act. It highlights Moses' human vulnerability and his reliance on Allah's protection and guidance.
orig: قال رب إني قتلت منهم نفسا فأخاف أن يقتلون

translation: And my brother Aaron is more eloquent in speech than me, so send him with me as a helper to confirm me. Indeed, I fear that they will deny me.
interpretation: The interpretation is that Moses (peace be upon him) is asking Allah to send his brother Aaron with him as a support and helper in conveying the message to Pharaoh and the Egyptians. Moses fears that they may reject or deny his message, so he wants Aaron, who is more eloquent in speech, to accompany him and confirm what he says.
orig: وأخي هارون هو أفصح مني لسانا فأرسله معي ردءا يصدقني إني أخاف أن يكذبون

translation: He said, 'We will strengthen your arm through your brother and give you both power so they will not touch you because of Our signs; you two, and those who follow you, will prevail.'
interpretation: Allah is promising support, authority, and victory to Moses and his brother Aaron, as well as to those who follow their teachings and the signs of Allah. This verse gives reassurance that they will prevail over their enemies and those who oppose the message of Allah.
orig: قال سنشد عضدك بأخيك ونجعل لكما سلطانا فلا يصلون إليكما بآياتنا أنتما ومن اتبعكما الغالبون
