orig: فاعترفوا بذنبهم فسحقا لأصحاب السعير

translation: Indeed, those who fear their Lord unseen, for them is forgiveness and a great reward.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of having a sincere and profound reverence for Allah, even in private moments when no one is watching. Those who truly fear and respect their Lord in their hearts and minds, even when they are unseen by others, will be rewarded with forgiveness for their sins and a tremendous reward in the Hereafter. It highlights the value of developing a strong spiritual connection with Allah and maintaining piety and righteousness at all times, not just in public displays of religiosity.
orig: إن الذين يخشون ربهم بالغيب لهم مغفرة وأجر كبير

translation: And conceal your speech or make it public, indeed He is All-Knower of what is in the breasts.
interpretation: Allah is fully aware of our innermost thoughts and intentions, whether we conceal or reveal them. This verse reminds us that we cannot hide anything from Allah, and that He has complete knowledge of what is in our hearts and minds. It encourages sincerity and truthfulness in our words and actions, as Allah knows our true motives and nothing is hidden from Him.
orig: وأسروا قولكم أو اجهروا به إنه عليم بذات الصدور

translation: Does He who created not know, while He is the Subtle, the Acquainted?
interpretation: This verse emphasizes Allah's perfect knowledge and awareness of all things. He is the Creator of everything, so how could He not have complete knowledge of His creation? The attributes "Al-Lateef" (The Subtle) and "Al-Khabeer" (The Acquainted) highlight Allah's profound wisdom and intimate familiarity with the minutest details of His creation. This verse instills a sense of awe and reverence for the all-encompassing knowledge of the Divine.
orig: ألا يعلم من خلق وهو اللطيف الخبير

translation: It is He who has made the earth tame for you, so walk among its slopes and eat of His provision, and to Him is the resurrection.
interpretation: Allah has made the earth subservient and suitable for human habitation, allowing them to traverse its paths and benefit from its resources. It is from Allah's provision that humans obtain sustenance, and to Him alone will be the resurrection and return after death.
orig: هو الذي جعل لكم الأرض ذلولا فامشوا في مناكبها وكلوا من رزقه وإليه النشور

translation: Do you feel secure that He who is in the heaven will not cause the earth to swallow you when it shakes violently?
interpretation: This verse is a warning and a reminder of Allah's power and ability to punish those who disbelieve or disobey Him. It questions whether the people feel secure from Allah, who is in the heavens, causing the earth to swallow them when it shakes violently. The verse implies that no one is truly secure from Allah's punishment, and that they should fear Him and obey His commands.
orig: أأمنتم من في السماء أن يخسف بكم الأرض فإذا هي تمور

translation: Or do you feel secure that He who is in the heaven will not send upon you a storm of stones? But you will come to know how [terrible] was My warning.
interpretation: This verse is a warning from Allah to the disbelievers who denied His revelations and messengers. It questions their false sense of security, asking if they think they are safe from Allah sending down a punishment upon them from the heavens, such as a storm of stones. The verse emphasizes that they will come to realize the severity of Allah's warning when the punishment befalls them.
orig: أم أمنتم من في السماء أن يرسل عليكم حاصبا فستعلمون كيف نذير

translation: And verily, those before them denied, so how was My rejection?
interpretation: This verse reminds the disbelievers of the fate of those who rejected the truth before them. It warns them that just as Allah punished the previous nations who denied His messengers and signs, He will likewise reject and punish those who persist in disbelief and denial of the truth brought by the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). The rhetorical question "how was My rejection?" emphasizes the severity and inevitability of Allah's punishment for those who defy His commandments.
orig: ولقد كذب الذين من قبلهم فكيف كان نكير

translation: Do they not observe the birds above them, spreading their wings and folding them? None upholds them except the Most Merciful. Indeed, He is All-Seer of everything.
interpretation: This verse encourages humans to reflect on the wonders of God's creation, specifically the birds flying above them. The birds' ability to spread and fold their wings, and to remain airborne, is sustained only by the power and mercy of God. It reminds us that God is All-Seeing and All-Aware of everything in His creation, emphasizing His omniscience and control over all things.
orig: أولم يروا إلى الطير فوقهم صافات ويقبضن ما يمسكهن إلا الرحمن إنه بكل شيء بصير

translation: Is this the one who is an army for you to help you besides the Most Merciful? The disbelievers are not but in delusion.
interpretation: Allah is questioning the disbelievers mockingly: "Is this idol that you worship an army that can help you against Allah's punishment? The disbelievers are deluded in their belief that these idols can benefit or protect them."
orig: أمن هذا الذي هو جند لكم ينصركم من دون الرحمن إن الكافرون إلا في غرور

translation: Is it this that provides for you if He withholds His provision? Nay, but they persist in insolence and aversion.
interpretation: Allah is questioning the disbelievers: "Is there anyone other than Allah who can provide for you if He withholds His provision from you?" The implied answer is that there is no one else who can provide for them. However, they persist in their arrogance and aversion to the truth.
orig: أمن هذا الذي يرزقكم إن أمسك رزقه بل لجوا في عتو ونفور

translation: Is one who walks prone on his face better guided, or one who walks upright on a straight path?
interpretation: This verse is contrasting those who blindly follow misguidance, represented by walking prone on one's face, with those who follow the straight path of truth and guidance. It emphasizes that true guidance comes from following the straight path ordained by God, rather than being misguided and stumbling blindly through life.
orig: أفمن يمشي مكبا على وجهه أهدى أمن يمشي سويا على صراط مستقيم

translation: Say, 'He is the One who created you and made for you hearing, vision and hearts - little is what you give thanks.'
interpretation: This verse reminds us that Allah is the sole Creator of all human beings, and He has blessed us with the faculties of hearing, sight, and intellect. However, most people fail to appreciate these blessings and do not express gratitude to Allah for them. The verse encourages us to reflect on Allah's favors upon us and to be thankful to Him.
orig: قل هو الذي أنشأكم وجعل لكم السمع والأبصار والأفئدة قليلا ما تشكرون

translation: Say, 'It is He who has dispersed you throughout the earth, and to Him you will be gathered.'
interpretation: This verse affirms that Allah is the One who created and dispersed human beings across the earth. It also reminds us that ultimately, we will all be gathered back to Allah on the Day of Resurrection to account for our deeds and beliefs. The verse highlights Allah's power as the Creator and Gatherer of all humanity, emphasizing our accountability to Him.
orig: قل هو الذي ذرأكم في الأرض وإليه تحشرون

translation: And they say, 'When is this promise, if you should be truthful?'
interpretation: This verse refers to the disbelievers who mockingly ask about the fulfillment of Allah's promise of punishment or the Day of Resurrection. They challenge the truthfulness of the Prophet and the believers, demanding to know when this promised event will occur if they are indeed truthful in their claims. The verse highlights the attitude of denial and skepticism displayed by the disbelievers towards the divine warnings and the inevitability of the final accounting.
orig: ويقولون متى هذا الوعد إن كنتم صادقين

translation: Say, "The knowledge is only with Allah, and I am only a clear warner."
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that true and complete knowledge belongs solely to Allah. The Prophet Muhammad's role is to convey the divine message clearly as a "warner" without claiming any personal knowledge beyond what has been revealed to him. It highlights the limits of human understanding and the need to rely on Allah's guidance.
orig: قل إنما العلم عند الله وإنما أنا نذير مبين

translation: But when they saw it as a dense cloud approaching their valleys, they said, 'This is a cloud bringing us rain!' Rather, it is that for which you were impatient, a wind, therein is a painful punishment.
interpretation: "This verse refers to the punishment that befell the disbelieving people of Prophet Salih. When they saw the punishment approaching in the form of a dense cloud, they mistakenly thought it was a rain cloud that would bring them relief. However, it was the very punishment they had been impatiently challenging Salih to bring upon them. The 'painful punishment' was a mighty wind that destroyed them utterly."
orig: فلما رأوه زلفة سيئت وجوه الذين كفروا وقيل هذا الذي كنتم به تدعون

translation: Say, 'Have you considered: if Allah should cause me and those with me to perish or have mercy upon us, then who can protect the disbelievers from a painful punishment?'
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of faith in Allah and following His guidance. It challenges the disbelievers to consider what would happen if Allah decided to punish them or show mercy to the believers. The interpretation is that no one can protect the disbelievers from Allah's painful punishment if they reject His message and continue in disbelief. Only by accepting faith and submitting to Allah can one hope for His mercy and protection.
orig: قل أرأيتم إن أهلكني الله ومن معي أو رحمنا فمن يجير الكافرين من عذاب أليم

translation: Say, "He is the Most Merciful; we have believed in Him, and upon Him we have relied. And you will [come to] know who it is that is in clear error."
interpretation: This verse commands the Prophet Muhammad to declare that Allah is the Most Merciful, and that the believers have put their faith and trust in Him alone. It also warns the disbelievers that they will eventually realize who is truly misguided and astray from the right path.
orig: قل هو الرحمن آمنا به وعليه توكلنا فستعلمون من هو في ضلال مبين

translation: Say, 'Have you considered: if your water were to become sunken [into the earth], then who could bring you flowing water?'
interpretation: This verse prompts the disbelievers to reflect on the possibility of their water sources drying up and disappearing into the earth. It then questions who, other than Allah, could provide them with fresh, flowing water in such a situation. The implication is that no one but Allah has the power to sustain life by providing water, a vital resource. It serves as a reminder of human dependence on Allah's mercy and blessings.
orig: قل أرأيتم إن أصبح ماؤكم غورا فمن يأتيكم بماء معين

translation: Nun, By the pen and what they inscribe,
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as an oath sworn by Allah, emphasizing the importance of the pen, writing, and knowledge. It highlights the significance of recording knowledge and the act of writing, which preserves and transmits wisdom and understanding. The pen symbolizes the means by which divine revelations, teachings, and human knowledge are recorded and disseminated.
orig: ن والقلم وما يسطرون

translation: By the grace of your Lord, you are not a madman.
interpretation: This verse is affirming that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) is not insane or possessed, as some of his opponents claimed. Rather, it states that by the grace and mercy of Allah, he is sound of mind and receiving divine revelation. This verse reassures the Prophet and establishes the truth of his prophethood.
orig: ما أنت بنعمة ربك بمجنون

translation: And indeed, for you is a reward never to be cut off
interpretation: This verse promises the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, an everlasting and continuous reward from Allah for his efforts in conveying the message of Islam. The word "ghair mamnoon" means "never to be cut off" or "never ending", indicating that the reward awaiting him in the Hereafter will be eternal and uninterrupted. This reward is a recognition and appreciation from Allah for the Prophet's unwavering dedication, sacrifices, and struggles in preaching the truth and guiding humanity towards the right path.
orig: وإن لك لأجرا غير ممنون

translation: And verily, you are on an exalted standard of character.
interpretation: This verse praises the Prophet Muhammad's exemplary moral character and conduct. It affirms that he possessed the highest and noblest qualities, making him a perfect role model for humanity to follow. His exceptional character was a manifestation of his close relationship with God and a sign of his truthfulness as a Messenger.
orig: وإنك لعلى خلق عظيم

translation: Soon you will see, and they will see
interpretation: This verse suggests that the truth will eventually become clear to everyone, both the believers and the disbelievers. It implies that the signs and evidence of God's existence and the truthfulness of the Prophet's message will manifest themselves, removing any doubts or misconceptions. The believers will see the realization of God's promises, while the disbelievers will witness the consequences of their rejection and denial.
orig: فستبصر ويبصرون

translation: Which of you is afflicted with madness?
interpretation: This verse questions the sanity of those who reject the message of the Qur'an and accuse the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) of being mad or possessed. It implies that it is actually they who are afflicted with madness or misguidance for denying the clear signs and revelations from Allah.
orig: بأييكم المفتون

translation: Indeed, it is your Lord who is most knowing of who has gone astray from His way, and He is most knowing of those who are guided.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah alone has perfect knowledge of who deviates from the straight path and who follows guidance. He knows the intentions, beliefs, and actions of all people, and He will judge them accordingly on the Day of Judgment. The emphasis is on Allah's perfect knowledge and wisdom in distinguishing between those who are rightly guided and those who have gone astray, despite outward appearances.
orig: إن ربك هو أعلم بمن ضل عن سبيله وهو أعلم بالمهتدين

translation: So do not obey the deniers.
interpretation: This verse instructs the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) not to obey or follow those who deny the truth and reject Allah's message. It is a command to remain steadfast in conveying the divine message, despite the opposition and rejection from the disbelievers. The interpretation emphasizes the importance of adhering to the truth and not compromising one's principles in the face of denial or opposition.
orig: فلا تطع المكذبين

translation: They wish that you would compromise, so they too could compromise.
interpretation: This verse refers to the hypocrites and disbelievers who wanted the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to make concessions in his faith and teachings, so that they could also relax their stance and not fully embrace Islam. It highlights their insincere attitude and unwillingness to accept the truth wholeheartedly. The interpretation emphasizes their desire for the Prophet to "soften" his stance, which would allow them to follow suit and avoid fully committing to the faith.
orig: ودوا لو تدهن فيدهنون

translation: And obey not every swearer of oaths, a scorner
interpretation: This verse advises against obeying or following those who frequently swear oaths and insult others. It warns against being influenced by arrogant and disrespectful individuals who may try to lead one astray through their false oaths and mocking behavior.
orig: ولا تطع كل حلاف مهين

translation: A defaming slanderer, going about with malicious gossip
interpretation: This verse refers to a person who habitually engages in slandering and defaming others by spreading malicious rumors and gossip. It condemns the act of backbiting and describes such a person as someone who goes about spreading lies and false information to harm others' reputations. The Qur'an strongly prohibits this unethical behavior and warns against causing harm through one's speech.
orig: هماز مشاء بنميم

translation: A preventer of good, transgressing, sinful.
interpretation: This verse describes the characteristics of a wicked person who prevents others from doing good deeds, transgresses the limits set by Allah, and indulges in sinful acts. It condemns those who hinder the spread of righteousness and engage in immoral behavior that violates divine commandments.
orig: مناع للخير معتد أثيم

translation: Then Zanaym was blunted.
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as referring to the weakening or diminishing of Zanaym's power, influence or effectiveness after a period of strength or dominance. The word "blunted" suggests that Zanaym's sharp edge or potency was dulled or reduced, potentially due to changing circumstances or the passage of time.
orig: عتل بعد ذلك زنيم

translation: If he was a man of wealth and children
interpretation: This verse is referring to a person who possesses material wealth and has offspring. It suggests that even if one has worldly riches and progeny, it does not guarantee salvation or happiness in the Hereafter. The true measure of a person's worth lies in their faith, righteousness, and submission to God's commands.
orig: أن كان ذا مال وبنين

translation: And when Our verses are recited to him, he says, 'Legends of the former peoples.'
interpretation: This verse refers to those who reject the divine revelations and dismiss them as mere stories or fables from ancient times. It highlights the arrogance and stubbornness of those who refuse to acknowledge the truth, even when presented with clear signs and evidence. Their dismissal stems from a lack of understanding or willingness to accept the profound wisdom contained within the revealed verses.
orig: إذا تتلى عليه آياتنا قال أساطير الأولين

translation: We will brand him on the snout
interpretation: This verse implies a stern punishment for those who persistently reject the truth and engage in arrogant behavior. The phrase "branding on the snout" is a metaphorical expression suggesting a humiliating and painful consequence for their defiance and obstinacy. It serves as a warning against pride, disbelief, and a stubborn rejection of divine guidance.
orig: سنسمه على الخرطوم

translation: Indeed, We tried them as We tried the companions of the garden, when they swore to pluck its fruit in the morning,
interpretation: This verse refers to a test or trial that Allah put the disbelievers through, similar to the test He put the owners of a garden through. The owners swore to harvest all the fruits of their garden early in the morning, without leaving any for the poor and needy, showing their greed and lack of gratitude to Allah's blessings. The verse implies that just as the owners were tested with wealth and property, the disbelievers were tested with various favors from Allah to see if they would be grateful or ungrateful.
orig: إنا بلوناهم كما بلونا أصحاب الجنة إذ أقسموا ليصرمنها مصبحين

translation: And they do not make exception
interpretation: This verse suggests that the disbelievers do not make any exceptions or exemptions in their rejection of faith and their opposition to the truth. They reject it completely and without any reservations or conditions.
orig: ولا يستثنون

translation: Then there passed over it a visitation from your Lord while they were asleep.
interpretation: This verse refers to a miraculous event that occurred to the Companions of the Cave (Ashaab al-Kahf) mentioned in the Qur'an. While they were asleep in the cave for many years, Allah sent a "visitation" or blessing upon them, preserving their lives and protecting them from harm during their long slumber. This "visitation" is a manifestation of Allah's power and mercy towards those who have faith in Him and seek refuge in Him.
orig: فطاف عليها طائف من ربك وهم نائمون

translation: So I became like a decayed plant stem.
interpretation: This verse is a metaphor describing the speaker's state of utter despair and desolation. The image of a decayed plant stem conveys a sense of lifelessness, withering, and being cut off from any source of sustenance or vitality. The interpretation is that the speaker feels drained of all hope, joy, and purpose, left as a mere husk or remnant of their former self.
orig: فأصبحت كالصريم

translation: So they called out one to another in the morning,
interpretation: This verse refers to the situation when the owners of the garden realized that their garden had been destroyed overnight. They called out to one another in the morning, expressing their regret and dismay at the loss of their prized possession. The interpretation highlights the sudden and unexpected nature of the calamity that befell them, and their sense of disbelief and grief at the sight of their ruined garden.
orig: فتنادوا مصبحين

translation: Go forth to your tilth when you will, but do acts for yourselves beforehand.
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as an allegory for sexual relations between spouses. It advises believers to approach their "tilth" (a metaphor for their wives) whenever they desire, but to "do acts for themselves beforehand", which is understood to mean performing acts of worship and righteousness before engaging in intimacy.
orig: أن اغدوا على حرثكم إن كنتم صارمين

translation: So they went forth, whispering:
interpretation: This verse suggests that the people mentioned went away from the scene, speaking secretly or whispering among themselves, perhaps discussing the matter at hand or plotting something. The word "يتخافتون" (yatakhafatun) implies a sense of secrecy or discretion in their conversation.
orig: فانطلقوا وهم يتخافتون

translation: That no indigent one will enter it today against you
interpretation: This verse suggests that on the Day of Judgment, the wealthy and privileged will not be able to use their status or wealth to prevent the poor and needy from entering Paradise. It emphasizes the equality of all people before God, regardless of their worldly circumstances.
orig: أن لا يدخلنها اليوم عليكم مسكين

translation: And in the morning they went forth, possessing the ability to prevent.
interpretation: This verse refers to a group of people who set out early in the morning with determination and capability to achieve their goals or defend themselves against potential threats or hardships. It highlights their preparedness, strength, and resolve to face challenges and overcome obstacles that may come their way.
orig: وغدوا على حرد قادرين

translation: But when they saw it, they said, 'Indeed, we are misguided,'
interpretation: This verse suggests that when the people witnessed a certain event or phenomenon, they realized that they had been mistaken or misguided in their previous beliefs or understanding. It implies a moment of realization and acknowledgment of their error or misguidance.
orig: فلما رأوها قالوا إنا لضالون

translation: Nay, we are deprived.
interpretation: This verse suggests that the disbelievers are acknowledging their deprivation and loss, perhaps in reference to being deprived of guidance, truth, or the rewards of the Hereafter due to their rejection of faith.
orig: بل نحن محرومون

translation: The most moderate among them said, 'Did I not tell you, why did you not exalt [Allah]?'
interpretation: This verse suggests that the moderate person among the group tried to advise them to glorify and praise Allah, but they did not listen to his advice. It implies the importance of heeding good counsel and being mindful of worshipping and praising the Creator.
orig: قال أوسطهم ألم أقل لكم لولا تسبحون

translation: They said: 'Glory to our Lord! Truly we were wrongdoers.'
interpretation: This verse indicates the remorse and repentance of the believers upon realizing their sins and mistakes. It highlights their acknowledgement of Allah's perfection and their own shortcomings as human beings. The phrase "Glory to our Lord" expresses their praise and exaltation of Allah, recognizing His supremacy and absolving Him of any imperfection or wrongdoing. By declaring "Truly we were wrongdoers," they admit their transgressions and take responsibility for their actions, seeking forgiveness and resolving to mend their ways.
orig: قالوا سبحان ربنا إنا كنا ظالمين

translation: Some of them drew near unto others, mutually questioning.
interpretation: This verse suggests that on the Day of Judgment, people will gather in groups and question one another about their actions and beliefs in the worldly life. It implies a sense of accountability and regret for those who neglected their duties or followed falsehood.
orig: فأقبل بعضهم على بعض يتلاومون

translation: They will say, 'Woe to us! We were indeed transgressors.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the remorse and regret that the disbelievers will feel on the Day of Judgment when they realize the gravity of their sins and disobedience. They will acknowledge their wrongdoing and express anguish over their transgression against Allah's commands. The phrase "Woe to us!" conveys their deep sorrow and distress at that moment.
orig: قالوا يا ويلنا إنا كنا طاغين

translation: It may be that our Lord will give us in exchange a better garden than this, for we indeed turn with longing to our Lord.
interpretation: This verse expresses the believers' hope and trust in Allah's mercy and bounties. Despite the loss of their garden, they remain optimistic that Allah will compensate them with something better in the Hereafter, as they eagerly seek His pleasure and Paradise. It highlights the virtues of patience, perseverance, and reliance on Allah in the face of adversity.
orig: عسى ربنا أن يبدلنا خيرا منها إنا إلى ربنا راغبون

translation: Such is the punishment, and the punishment of the Hereafter is certainly greater, if they only knew.
interpretation: "This worldly punishment is a glimpse of the severe punishment that awaits the disbelievers in the Hereafter. The torment of the Hereafter is far greater and more intense, but they are unaware of its severity due to their ignorance and disbelief."
orig: كذلك العذاب ولعذاب الآخرة أكبر لو كانوا يعلمون

translation: Indeed, for the righteous, with their Lord, are Gardens of Pleasure.
interpretation: This verse promises that those who are righteous and conscious of Allah, fearing Him and obeying His commands, will attain Gardens of eternal bliss and delight in the Hereafter. The "Gardens of Pleasure" refers to Paradise, a place of everlasting joy and contentment, reserved for the pious believers as a reward from their Lord for their faith and good deeds.
orig: إن للمتقين عند ربهم جنات النعيم

translation: Shall We treat the Muslims like the criminals?
interpretation: This verse is questioning the notion of treating Muslims, who have submitted themselves to God, in the same manner as criminals or wrongdoers. It implies that Muslims, by virtue of their faith and obedience to God, should not be equated with those who commit sins or engage in unlawful acts. The verse highlights the injustice of subjecting believers to the same treatment as transgressors, emphasizing the need to distinguish between those who follow the righteous path and those who stray from it.
orig: أفنجعل المسلمين كالمجرمين

translation: What is the matter with you? How do you judge?
interpretation: This verse questions the criteria and basis upon which people make judgments. It implies that their judgments are flawed or lack sound reasoning and evidence. The verse prompts self-reflection on one's thought processes and decision-making.
orig: ما لكم كيف تحكمون

translation: Or do you have a book in which you study?
interpretation: This verse questions the disbelievers about their source of knowledge or scripture that they rely upon, implying that they have no valid basis for their beliefs and actions other than conjecture and whims, unlike the believers who follow the guidance of the Qur'an revealed by Allah.
orig: أم لكم كتاب فيه تدرسون

translation: Indeed, for you in it is whatever you choose.
interpretation: This verse suggests that in the world, humans have the freedom to choose their path and pursue whatever they desire, whether it is righteous or sinful. However, they will be held accountable for their choices in the Hereafter.
orig: إن لكم فيه لما تخيرون

translation: Or do you have covenants binding on Us till the Day of Resurrection that you shall have whatever you judge?
interpretation: This verse questions the polytheists who associated partners with Allah, asking them if they have any binding covenants from Allah that would allow them to judge matters as they please until the Day of Resurrection. It implies that their beliefs and practices have no basis or divine sanction, and they will be held accountable for their false judgments and association of partners with Allah.
orig: أم لكم أيمان علينا بالغة إلى يوم القيامة إن لكم لما تحكمون

translation: Ask them, which of them will vouch for that.
interpretation: This verse questions the disbelievers and asks them to present someone who can guarantee or take responsibility for their false claims about the Qur'an and its teachings. It challenges their baseless assertions and demands evidence or a guarantor for their statements.
orig: سلهم أيهم بذلك زعيم

translation: Or have they partners? Then let them bring their partners, if they are truthful.
interpretation: This verse questions the idolaters who ascribed partners to Allah. It challenges them to bring forth their alleged partners if they are truthful in their claims. The verse implies that their idols have no power and cannot be considered partners with Allah, the One True God.
orig: أم لهم شركاء فليأتوا بشركائهم إن كانوا صادقين

translation: The Day when the shin shall be laid bare and they shall be summoned to prostrate themselves, but they shall not be able,
interpretation: This verse refers to the Day of Resurrection, when mankind will be called to prostrate before Allah, but the disbelievers will be unable to do so due to their arrogance and rejection of faith. The phrase "the shin shall be laid bare" is interpreted metaphorically as a reference to the severity and difficulty of that Day, when all will be exposed and nothing will remain hidden.
orig: يوم يكشف عن ساق ويدعون إلى السجود فلا يستطيعون

translation: Their eyes will be downcast, humbled, while they were called to prostrate when they were whole.
interpretation: This verse describes the humiliating state of the disbelievers on the Day of Judgment. Their eyes will be downcast in shame and humiliation, as they are reminded of being called to prostrate before God when they were alive and healthy, but they arrogantly refused to do so. Their failure to submit to God's commands will bring them disgrace and regret on that Day.
orig: خاشعة أبصارهم ترهقهم ذلة وقد كانوا يدعون إلى السجود وهم سالمون

translation: So leave me, [O Muhammad], with whoever denies this statement, and We will progressively lead them [to punishment] from where they do not know.
interpretation: This verse warns those who reject and deny the message of the Qur'an. It instructs the Prophet Muhammad to leave them to their disbelief, for Allah will gradually lead them towards punishment in a way that they do not expect or perceive. It implies that their denial will not prevent Allah's plan, and that they will face the consequences of their rejection in a subtle and gradual manner.
orig: فذرني ومن يكذب بهذا الحديث سنستدرجهم من حيث لا يعلمون

translation: But allow them respite, for My plan is indeed firm.
interpretation: Allah commands the Prophet to be patient with the disbelievers and not to be hasty in seeking punishment for them, for Allah's plan and scheme against them is firm and unbreakable. He will eventually seize them with a severe punishment from which they cannot escape.
orig: وأملي لهم إن كيدي متين

translation: Or is it that you ask them for payment, so they are weighed down by debt?
interpretation: This verse questions whether the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was asking the people for any payment or reward for conveying the message of Islam. It implies that the people should not feel burdened or indebted by the message, as the Prophet was not seeking any worldly gain or compensation from them. Rather, he was simply fulfilling his divine duty of delivering the revelation from Allah without expecting anything in return.
orig: أم تسألهم أجرا فهم من مغرم مثقلون

translation: Or do they have knowledge of the unseen, so they write it down?
interpretation: This verse questions the disbelievers who reject the message of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). It implies that they have no knowledge of the unseen or the future, yet they write down their own fabricated beliefs and ideologies. The verse challenges their arrogance and ignorance in rejecting the divine revelation when they have no access to the unseen realities known only to Allah.
orig: أم عندهم الغيب فهم يكتبون

translation: So be patient for the decision of your Lord, and be not like the Companion of the Fish, when he called out while he was distressed.
interpretation: This verse instructs the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to remain patient and steadfast in conveying the message of Islam and awaiting Allah's judgment, without becoming impatient or distressed like Yunus (Jonah), the "Companion of the Fish." When Yunus became frustrated with his people's rejection, he hastily left them before receiving permission from Allah. The verse reminds the Prophet to avoid such rash behavior and to persevere with wisdom and reliance upon Allah.
orig: فاصبر لحكم ربك ولا تكن كصاحب الحوت إذ نادى وهو مكظوم

translation: Had it not been for a favor from his Lord, he would have been left alone in the open, condemned.
interpretation: This verse suggests that if it were not for God's mercy and favor upon this person, they would have been abandoned and condemned in a desolate place. It highlights the importance of God's guidance and blessings in one's life, without which one could face a miserable fate.
orig: لولا أن تداركه نعمة من ربه لنبذ بالعراء وهو مذموم

translation: But his Lord chose him and made him one of the righteous.
interpretation: This verse indicates that God chose and selected the person mentioned for a special purpose, guiding him to become one of the righteous and pious individuals. It suggests that through God's guidance and favor, this person was able to attain a high spiritual rank and become counted among the virtuous servants of God.
orig: فاجتباه ربه فجعله من الصالحين

translation: And indeed, those who disbelieve would almost strike you down with their glances when they hear the reminder, and they say, 'Indeed, he is mad.'
interpretation: This verse refers to the intense hatred and resentment that the disbelievers harbored towards the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and his message. Their animosity was so severe that their piercing gazes seemed to want to strike him down whenever they heard him reciting the Qur'an and reminding them of its teachings. They dismissed him as being insane, unable to comprehend the profound wisdom and guidance contained within the divine revelation.
orig: وإن يكاد الذين كفروا ليزلقونك بأبصارهم لما سمعوا الذكر ويقولون إنه لمجنون

translation: And it is not but a reminder for the worlds.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the Qur'an is a universal reminder and guidance for all of humanity, not just a specific group or nation. It serves as a source of enlightenment and moral teachings for people across different civilizations and eras. The Qur'an's message transcends temporal and spatial boundaries, making it a timeless and universal revelation.
orig: وما هو إلا ذكر للعالمين

translation: The Inevitable Reality
interpretation: This chapter discusses the certainty of the Day of Resurrection and the inescapable reckoning that awaits all people. It emphasizes the reality of the Hereafter and warns against denying or disbelieving in it. The title "Al-Haaqqah" refers to the inevitable event that will strike and shake the foundations of everything.
orig: الحاقة

translation: What is the Inevitable Reality?
interpretation: This verse is referring to the Day of Resurrection or Judgment Day, which is an inevitable reality that will come to pass. It is asking rhetorically about the nature and significance of this momentous event, emphasizing its certainty and importance.
orig: ما الحاقة

translation: And what will make you know what the Striking Calamity is?
interpretation: This verse arouses the reader's curiosity about the nature of the "Striking Calamity," which is a reference to the Day of Resurrection or Judgment Day. The rhetorical question emphasizes the magnitude and awe-inspiring nature of this event, which is beyond human comprehension until it is witnessed.
orig: وما أدراك ما الحاقة

translation: Thamud and Aad denied the Striking Calamity.
interpretation: This verse refers to the denial and rejection of the Divine warnings by the ancient Arab tribes of Thamud and Aad. They arrogantly disbelieved in the message brought to them by the Prophets, and as a result, they were struck by a severe punishment or "Striking Calamity" from Allah for their defiance and disbelief.
orig: كذبت ثمود وعاد بالقارعة

translation: As for Thamud, they were destroyed by the overwhelming [blast].
interpretation: "The verse refers to the destruction of the people of Thamud, who were an ancient Arab tribe that lived in the northern parts of the Arabian Peninsula. They were punished by Allah for their disbelief and rejection of the message brought to them by Prophet Salih. The "overwhelming [blast]" mentioned in the verse likely refers to a powerful sound or earthquake that struck them as a punishment from Allah for their disobedience and arrogance."
orig: فأما ثمود فأهلكوا بالطاغية

translation: And as for 'Aad, they were destroyed by a furious wind, roaring and violent.
interpretation: This verse refers to the destruction of the ancient tribe of 'Aad who lived in the southern region of the Arabian Peninsula. They were punished by Allah for their disbelief and arrogance with a fierce, howling wind that spared nothing in its path. The wind is described as "furious" and "roaring and violent," emphasizing the intensity of Allah's punishment upon this defiant people who rejected the message of His messenger Hud (peace be upon him). Their destruction serves as a powerful lesson and warning against arrogance, ingratitude, and the rejection of divine guidance.
orig: وأما عاد فأهلكوا بريح صرصر عاتية

translation: He made it rage against them for seven nights and eight days in succession, so you could see the people therein lying like hollow trunks of date-palms.
interpretation: This verse describes Allah's severe punishment upon an ungrateful nation. The "it" refers to a furious wind that raged relentlessly for seven nights and eight days, leaving the people lying dead like hollow trunks of date-palms, completely destroyed. This depicts the utter devastation caused by Allah's wrath upon those who defied His commands.
orig: سخرها عليهم سبع ليال وثمانية أيام حسوما فترى القوم فيها صرعى كأنهم أعجاز نخل خاوية

translation: Do you then see for them any remnant?
interpretation: This verse questions whether there is any trace or remnant left of the disbelievers who denied the truth and persisted in their arrogance and misguidance. It implies that they have been completely destroyed and annihilated, leaving no remnant behind, as a consequence of their rejection of faith and their defiance of Allah's commandments.
orig: فهل ترى لهم من باقية

translation: And Pharaoh and those before him and the subverted cities committed sin.
interpretation: This verse condemns the arrogance and disbelief of Pharaoh and those who came before him, as well as the people of the overturned cities who rejected the messengers of Allah. It serves as a warning against following their footsteps of transgression and defiance against the commands of the Lord.
orig: وجاء فرعون ومن قبله والمؤتفكات بالخاطئة

translation: But they disobeyed the Messenger of their Lord, so He seized them with a severe punishment.
interpretation: This verse refers to those who reject the message of the Prophet and disobey the commands of God. Their disobedience leads to a severe punishment from God, which seizes them unexpectedly and leaves no escape. It serves as a warning against arrogance and defiance towards God's messengers and their teachings.
orig: فعصوا رسول ربهم فأخذهم أخذة رابية

translation: Indeed, when the water overflowed, We carried you in the sailing vessel
interpretation: "This verse refers to the story of Noah and the great flood. It reminds us that when the disbelievers exceeded all limits in their disobedience and wickedness, Allah saved Noah and the believers by commanding them to board the Ark, which sailed through the floodwaters by Allah's grace and protection."
orig: إنا لما طغى الماء حملناكم في الجارية

translation: And We will make it a reminder for you and whoever has an attentive ear will be mindful of it.
interpretation: "Allah says that He will make the Qur'an a reminder and a source of guidance for the believers. Those who have an attentive ear and a willing heart will benefit from it and be mindful of its teachings."
orig: لنجعلها لكم تذكرة وتعيها أذن واعية

translation: So when the Trumpet is blown with a single blast,
interpretation: This verse refers to the Day of Resurrection, when the Trumpet (or Horn) will be blown, signaling the end of this world and the beginning of the Hereafter. The "single blast" indicates that it will be a sudden and powerful event that will shake the entire universe and bring all life to an end. It serves as a warning for people to prepare themselves for that momentous occasion by living righteous lives and heeding God's commands.
orig: فإذا نفخ في الصور نفخة واحدة

translation: And the earth and the mountains were lifted and crushed with a single crushing.
interpretation: This verse describes the cataclysmic events of the Day of Resurrection, when the earth and mountains will be lifted and crushed with a single, powerful strike. It symbolizes the complete destruction of the physical world as we know it, and the overwhelming might of Allah on that tremendous Day. The verse conveys a sense of the earth’s fragility and insignificance before the power of its Creator.
orig: وحملت الأرض والجبال فدكتا دكة واحدة

translation: On that Day, the Striking Calamity will strike.
interpretation: This verse is referring to the Day of Resurrection or Judgment Day, which is described as "the Striking Calamity." It indicates that on that tremendous Day, a great and terrifying event will occur that will shake the entire universe. The verse emphasizes the certainty and inevitability of this event, leaving no doubt about its occurrence. It serves as a reminder of the accountability that all humans will face on that Day for their actions and beliefs in this world.
orig: فيومئذ وقعت الواقعة

translation: And the heaven will be rent asunder, for on that Day it will be frail and torn up.
interpretation: "This verse is describing the events of the Day of Resurrection. The "rending asunder" of the heaven refers to its splitting open and the removal of the barriers between the physical and spiritual realms. The heaven, which appears solid and impenetrable to us now, will become "frail and torn up" on that tremendous Day, losing its apparent strength and stability. This imagery serves to convey the magnitude of the upheaval that will occur when the present world order is shattered, and a new reality emerges."
orig: وانشقت السماء فهي يومئذ واهية

translation: And the angels will be on the sides thereof, and eight will uphold the Throne of their Lord that day, above them.
interpretation: This verse refers to the majesty and grandeur of Allah on the Day of Judgment. The angels will be surrounding the Throne of Allah, and eight of them will be carrying it above them, signifying Allah's supreme power and authority over all creation.
orig: والملك على أرجائها ويحمل عرش ربك فوقهم يومئذ ثمانية

translation: That Day you will be exposed; not a single one of your secrets will remain hidden from you.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Day of Judgment, when all human beings will be presented before God and their innermost secrets, intentions, and deeds will be laid bare. Nothing will remain hidden or concealed from God's knowledge on that Day. It serves as a reminder of God's absolute awareness of everything we do, even our most private thoughts and actions, and that we will ultimately be held accountable for them.
orig: يومئذ تعرضون لا تخفى منكم خافية

translation: Then as for him who is given his record in his right hand, he will say, 'Here, read my record!'
interpretation: This verse refers to the believers on the Day of Judgment who will receive their record of deeds in their right hand, which is a symbol of honor and success. They will joyfully invite others to read their record, confident in their good deeds and faith in Allah.
orig: فأما من أوتي كتابه بيمينه فيقول هاؤم اقرءوا كتابيه

translation: Indeed, I thought that I would be meeting my account.
interpretation: This verse suggests that the speaker had the belief or assumption that they would be held accountable for their deeds in the Hereafter. It implies an awareness of the Day of Judgment and the concept of accountability before God.
orig: إني ظننت أني ملاق حسابيه

translation: Then he will be in a pleasant life.
interpretation: This verse suggests that those who do good deeds and have faith in God will enjoy a pleasant and fulfilling life, either in this world or in the Hereafter. It promises a state of contentment, peace, and satisfaction as a reward for righteousness.
orig: فهو في عيشة راضية

translation: In a lofty Garden
interpretation: The verse refers to the reward of the righteous believers in the Hereafter, which is a lofty and exalted Garden in Paradise. This Garden represents the highest level of bliss, tranquility, and spiritual elevation that the believers will attain as a result of their faith and good deeds in this world. The use of the word "lofty" signifies the sublime and elevated nature of this reward, which transcends the limitations of the worldly life.
orig: في جنة عالية

translation: Its fruits will hang low and near
interpretation: This verse is describing the fruits of Paradise, which will be easily accessible and within reach for the believers to enjoy. It symbolizes the bountiful rewards and pleasures that await the righteous in the Hereafter, without any difficulty or hardship in attaining them.
orig: قطوفها دانية

translation: Eat and drink in satisfaction for what you have sent forth in the days gone by.
interpretation: This verse encourages believers to enjoy the blessings and provisions that Allah has granted them in this life as a reward for their good deeds and righteous actions in the past. It implies that the pleasures of this world are a result of one's efforts and deeds in the previous days. The phrase "in satisfaction" suggests contentment and gratitude for Allah's favors without indulging in excess or wastefulness.
orig: كلوا واشربوا هنيئا بما أسلفتم في الأيام الخالية

translation: But as for him who is given his record in his left hand, he will say, 'Oh, I wish I had not been given my record'
interpretation: This verse refers to those who will be given their records of deeds in their left hand on the Day of Judgment, indicating that they are among the disbelievers and wrongdoers. They will express regret and wish they had not been given their records, as it will expose their evil deeds and seal their fate in the Hellfire. This highlights the importance of faith, righteous actions, and accountability in the Hereafter.
orig: وأما من أوتي كتابه بشماله فيقول يا ليتني لم أوت كتابيه

translation: But I do not know what account will be for him.
interpretation: This verse suggests that the speaker is uncertain about the fate or reckoning that awaits the person being referred to. It expresses a sense of uncertainty and lack of knowledge regarding the ultimate consequences or judgment that this individual will face.
orig: ولم أدر ما حسابيه

translation: If only it had been the decisive one!
interpretation: This verse expresses a longing or wish that the event or situation being referred to had been the final and conclusive one, bringing an end to a particular matter or ordeal. It suggests a desire for resolution or finality, perhaps after enduring a difficult or protracted experience.
orig: يا ليتها كانت القاضية

translation: His wealth did not avail him anything.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that wealth and material possessions alone do not benefit a person in the Hereafter. True success lies in faith, righteousness, and seeking the pleasure of Allah. Wealth can be a means of good or evil, depending on how it is acquired and utilized. The verse warns against being arrogant or ungrateful due to wealth, as it will not help one on the Day of Judgment.
orig: ما أغنى عني ماليه

translation: My authority has vanished from me.
interpretation: This verse suggests a sense of loss of power, authority or control over a situation or circumstance. It could be interpreted as a lament over the diminishing of one's influence, dominion or ability to exert one's will. The speaker seems to be acknowledging a shift in their circumstances that has left them feeling powerless or without the means to assert their authority as they once could.
orig: هلك عني سلطانيه

translation: Seize him and bind him,
interpretation: This verse commands the angels to take a firm grip on the disbelieving soul at the time of death and bind it, restricting its movements. It symbolizes the soul's helplessness and the punishment that awaits those who reject faith.
orig: خذوه فغلوه

translation: Then they will burn in Hell.
interpretation: This verse is a stern warning to those who reject faith and disobey Allah's commands. It indicates that the ultimate consequence for such people is to be thrown into the blazing fire of Hell, which is a severe punishment for their disbelief and evil deeds. The Arabic word "صلوه" (salawh) conveys the intense and agonizing nature of this punishment, emphasizing the unbearable torment they will face in the Hellfire as a result of their rejection of the truth.
orig: ثم الجحيم صلوه

translation: Then [for them] is the chain whose length is seventy cubits, so insert him into that.
interpretation: This verse refers to the severe punishment that awaits the disbelievers in the Hereafter. The "chain" mentioned is a metaphor for the shackles and restraints that will be used to bind and torment them in Hell. The length of "seventy cubits" signifies the intensity and magnitude of their punishment, which will be fitting for their rejection of faith and their disobedience to God's commands.
orig: ثم في سلسلة ذرعها سبعون ذراعا فاسلكوه

translation: Indeed, he did not used to believe in Allah, the Most Great
interpretation: This verse is condemning the disbelief and rejection of Allah, the Most Great and Exalted. It suggests that the person being referred to was an unbeliever who denied the existence and greatness of Allah. This is a grave sin in Islam, as belief in the Oneness of Allah is the core principle of the faith.
orig: إنه كان لا يؤمن بالله العظيم

translation: Nor does he encourage the feeding of the poor.
interpretation: This verse criticizes those who do not encourage or motivate others to feed the poor and needy. It condemns the selfish attitude of those who have the means but fail to support the less fortunate members of society. The verse emphasizes the importance of charity and compassion towards the underprivileged.
orig: ولا يحض على طعام المسكين

translation: So no devoted friend has he here today.
interpretation: This verse suggests that on the Day of Judgment, the disbelievers will have no close friend or supporter to help them or intercede on their behalf. It highlights the utter loneliness and lack of assistance they will face on that tremendous Day.
orig: فليس له اليوم هاهنا حميم

translation: And no food except from the unclean things.
interpretation: This verse prohibits consuming impure or unlawful foods. It emphasizes the importance of consuming only pure and lawful sustenance, as prescribed by Allah. The term "ghisleen" refers to filthy or unclean things that are forbidden for consumption according to Islamic teachings.
orig: ولا طعام إلا من غسلين

translation: None will eat it except the sinners.
interpretation: This verse refers to a tree mentioned in the Qur'an called "Zaqqum," which is described as a bitter and poisonous tree that grows in Hell. It suggests that only those who have committed grave sins and disbelieved in God will be forced to consume this wretched tree as a punishment in the Hereafter.
orig: لا يأكله إلا الخاطئون

translation: But nay, I swear by what you see
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance and reality of what is visible and perceptible to human beings. It affirms that the truth can be found in the observable world and the signs that surround us, rather than relying solely on speculation or conjecture. The oath 'I swear by what you see' underscores the significance of empirical evidence and encourages contemplation on the tangible manifestations of God's creation.
orig: فلا أقسم بما تبصرون

translation: And what you do not perceive
interpretation: This verse refers to the many signs and proofs of God's existence and power that are not directly visible to the human eye, but can be perceived through reason, reflection, and spiritual insight. It implies that there are many realities and truths beyond the material world that we cannot fully comprehend with our limited senses and understanding. The verse encourages us to contemplate the unseen and to seek deeper knowledge and wisdom from God.
orig: وما لا تبصرون

translation: Indeed, it is a word [conveyed] by a noble messenger.
interpretation: This verse affirms that the Qur'an is not the word of Prophet Muhammad, but rather the Word of Allah conveyed through a noble messenger, referring to the Angel Jibreel. It emphasizes the divine origin and noble source of the Qur'anic revelation.
orig: إنه لقول رسول كريم

translation: And he is not one who utters the word of a poet - little is what you believe.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the words of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) are not mere poetic utterances or the words of a poet, as the disbelievers claimed. Rather, they are the Words of Allah revealed to him through the angel Gabriel. The phrase "little is what you believe" is a gentle rebuke to those who rejected faith, implying that their lack of belief stems from their own stubbornness and unwillingness to accept the truth.
orig: وما هو بقول شاعر قليلا ما تؤمنون

translation: And not by the word of a soothsayer - little is that you are reminded.
interpretation: This verse denies that the Qur'an is the word of a soothsayer or fortune-teller. It emphasizes that the Qur'an is the Word of God, and not the speech of those who claim knowledge of the unseen through divination or sorcery. The Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, is reminded that people rarely take heed of such warnings against following soothsayers.
orig: ولا بقول كاهن قليلا ما تذكرون

translation: A revelation from the Lord of the Worlds
interpretation: This verse indicates that the Qur'an is a divine revelation sent down by Allah, the Lord and Sustainer of all the worlds and creation. It affirms the Qur'an's transcendent and sacred origin, as it is not a product of human authorship but a celestial scripture revealed to the Prophet Muhammad by the Almighty.
orig: تنزيل من رب العالمين

translation: And if you were to say some fabricated statements against Us,
interpretation: If you (Prophet Muhammad) were to attribute some false statements to God, ascribing words to Him that He did not say, "We" would have seized you firmly and cut off your life artery.
orig: ولو تقول علينا بعض الأقاويل

translation: We would have seized him by the right hand
interpretation: This verse suggests that if the person referred to had not been guided by God's revelation, God would have seized or punished him severely, represented metaphorically by seizing him "by the right hand". It implies that God's guidance and mercy protected this person from a harsh punishment.
orig: لأخذنا منه باليمين

translation: Then We would have certainly cut off the aorta (al-watin).
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as a warning from Allah to those who reject faith and persist in disbelief and sin. The "aorta" (al-watin) refers to the main artery that carries blood from the heart. Cutting it off symbolizes ending one's life or means of survival. The verse suggests that if the disbelievers continued in their ways, Allah would have utterly destroyed them and terminated their existence in this world.
orig: ثم لقطعنا منه الوتين

translation: So there is none of you who can avert it [i.e., death].
interpretation: هذه الآية تشير إلى أن الموت حتمي وأنه لا أحد يستطيع تجنبه أو منعه، فهو أمر محتوم على جميع البشر ولا مفر منه. وهي تذكرنا بضرورة الاستعداد للموت والحياة الآخرة، والعمل الصالح في الدنيا قبل فوات الأوان.
orig: فما منكم من أحد عنه حاجزين

translation: And indeed, it is a reminder for the righteous.
interpretation: This verse indicates that the Qur'an serves as a reminder and guidance for those who have taqwa (righteousness, piety, and consciousness of Allah). It is a means for the God-fearing to remember their duties, increase their faith, and stay on the straight path. The Qur'an acts as a beacon of light, reminding the righteous of their purpose in life and their ultimate accountability before Allah.
orig: وإنه لتذكرة للمتقين

translation: And We certainly know that among you are deniers.
interpretation: This verse indicates that Allah is fully aware that some people reject and deny the truth brought by the Prophet Muhammad, despite clear evidence and signs. It implies that their denial stems from arrogance, stubbornness, or a lack of sincerity in seeking the truth, rather than genuine confusion or lack of understanding. The verse serves as a warning to those who reject faith, reminding them that their disbelief is known to Allah, and they will ultimately be held accountable for their choices.
orig: وإنا لنعلم أن منكم مكذبين

translation: And indeed, it is a regret upon the disbelievers
interpretation: This verse indicates that the Qur'an and the message of Islam will be a cause of regret and sorrow for those who reject faith and disbelieve in Allah's revelations. The disbelievers will realize their grave mistake when it is too late, and they will be filled with remorse and anguish for having turned away from the truth.
orig: وإنه لحسرة على الكافرين

translation: And indeed, it is the truth of certainty.
interpretation: This verse affirms the absolute certainty and truth of the Qur'an and its teachings. It emphasizes that the message of the Qur'an is not mere speculation or conjecture, but a firm and undeniable reality that should be accepted with full conviction. The "truth of certainty" refers to the undoubted and indisputable nature of the Qur'anic revelations, which are based on divine knowledge and wisdom.
orig: وإنه لحق اليقين

translation: So glorify the name of your Lord, the Most Great.
interpretation: This verse commands the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) to glorify and praise Allah, the Most Great, through words and deeds. It emphasizes the greatness and majesty of Allah and encourages us to recognize His supreme power and authority over all creation. The interpretation highlights the importance of worshipping Allah alone and acknowledging His transcendent qualities and attributes.
orig: فسبح باسم ربك العظيم

translation: A questioner asked about a torment that is going to occur
interpretation: This verse refers to an incident where someone questioned the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) about the punishment or torment that will befall the disbelievers on the Day of Resurrection. The verse implies that the questioner was skeptical or doubtful about the reality of this punishment, and sought clarification from the Prophet. The interpretation highlights the certainty of the divine punishment for those who reject faith and persist in disbelief, despite the warnings conveyed by the Prophet.
orig: سأل سائل بعذاب واقع

translation: For the disbelievers there is no incentive.
interpretation: This verse suggests that those who reject faith and guidance from God have no real motivation or driving force behind their actions, as they lack the spiritual awareness and connection with the Divine that could inspire and guide them towards righteous conduct and a higher purpose in life.
orig: للكافرين ليس له دافع

translation: From Allah, the Possessor of the ways of ascent.
interpretation: This verse refers to Allah as the One Who possesses the means and paths that lead to elevation, honor, and success in this life and the Hereafter. It implies that true ascension, both spiritual and worldly, comes only through Allah's guidance and assistance.
orig: من الله ذي المعارج

translation: The angels and the Spirit ascend unto Him in a Day the measure whereof is fifty thousand years.
interpretation: This verse refers to the ascension of angels and the Spirit (often interpreted as the Angel Gabriel) towards Allah on the Day of Resurrection, which will last for an extremely long period, described as being equivalent to fifty thousand years according to human reckoning. This emphasizes the vastness and magnitude of that Day, and the transcendence of Allah beyond the constraints of time as we know it.
orig: تعرج الملائكة والروح إليه في يوم كان مقداره خمسين ألف سنة

translation: So endure with a beautiful patience.
interpretation: This verse encourages the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, to remain patient and steadfast in the face of adversity and challenges with a graceful and praiseworthy patience. It emphasizes the importance of maintaining composure, perseverance, and trust in Allah during difficult times, and facing hardships with a positive and noble attitude.
orig: فاصبر صبرا جميلا

translation: Indeed, they see it [as] distant
interpretation: This verse indicates that the disbelievers perceive the Day of Resurrection or the fulfillment of Allah's promises as something far-fetched and unlikely to occur. They dismiss it as a distant possibility, failing to recognize its inevitability and proximity. This reflects their lack of faith and their erroneous perception of the truth.
orig: إنهم يرونه بعيدا

translation: And We will show it to you soon
interpretation: This verse implies that the truth and fulfillment of Allah's promises will become evident in the near future. It encourages patience and trust in the divine plan, as the realization of what was foretold is imminent.
orig: ونراه قريبا

translation: The Day when the heaven will be like molten copper,
interpretation: This verse describes the terrifying scene of the Day of Judgment when the sky, which appears solid and stable to us now, will become like molten copper, signifying its complete transformation and the loss of its familiar form and structure. This imagery conveys the immense upheaval and cosmic changes that will occur on that Day, shattering the current order and revealing the power of Allah.
orig: يوم تكون السماء كالمهل

translation: And the mountains will be like carded wool
interpretation: This verse is a metaphorical description of the state of the mountains on the Day of Resurrection. The simile "like carded wool" depicts the mountains as being light, fluffy, and scattered, having lost their solidity and firmness. This imagery conveys the idea that even the mightiest and most formidable structures on Earth will be reduced to a fragile and insubstantial state on that tremendous Day, signifying the overwhelming power of Allah and the transitory nature of this worldly existence.
orig: وتكون الجبال كالعهن

translation: And no intimate friend will ask [anything of] an intimate friend,
interpretation: On the Day of Judgment, close friends will not inquire about the condition of one another, as each person will be preoccupied with their own accountability before Allah.
orig: ولا يسأل حميم حميما

translation: They will see them, and the criminal will wish that he could be ransomed from the punishment of that Day by his children,
interpretation: This verse describes the scene on the Day of Judgment, where the disbelievers will witness the severe punishment awaiting them. The "criminal" refers to the disbeliever who rejected faith and committed sins. On that Day, he will desperately wish to ransom himself from the punishment by sacrificing his own children, which shows the intensity of the suffering and regret he will experience. However, this wish will be in vain as no ransom will be accepted on that Day.
orig: يبصرونهم يود المجرم لو يفتدي من عذاب يومئذ ببنيه

translation: And his wife and his brother
interpretation: This verse could refer to the wife and brother of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). It may also allude to the close relationships and bonds between believers, who are considered spiritual brothers and sisters in faith.
orig: وصاحبته وأخيه

translation: And his tribe which sheltered him.
interpretation: This verse refers to the Prophet Muhammad's tribe, the Quraish, who protected and sheltered him despite their opposition to his message in the early days of Islam. It highlights the bond of kinship and the tribal loyalty that existed in pre-Islamic Arabian society, where one's tribe would defend and support its members even if they disagreed with their beliefs or actions.
orig: وفصيلته التي تؤويه

translation: And whoever is on the earth entirely, then He will save him.
interpretation: This verse suggests that Allah has the power to save all beings on earth from any harm or difficulty. It implies that Allah's mercy and protection encompass all creatures, and He has the ability to guide and deliver them from adversity or hardship. The interpretation emphasizes Allah's supreme authority, compassion, and ability to provide salvation and security to all that exists on earth.
orig: ومن في الأرض جميعا ثم ينجيه

translation: Nay! Indeed, it is a scorching fire,
interpretation: This verse is referring to the scorching fire of Hell, which is a severe punishment for those who disbelieved and disobeyed Allah's commandments. The word "latha" denotes the intense heat and burning nature of the Hellfire, emphasizing its excruciating torment.
orig: كلا إنها لظى

translation: A remover for the thorns
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as referring to a tool or instrument used to remove thorns, specifically in the context of preparing food for roasting or grilling. It suggests the availability of practical tools and utensils in the divine realm or paradise, indicating a state of comfort and provision.
orig: نزاعة للشوى

translation: It calls whoever turns away and flees.
interpretation: This verse suggests that the Qur'an calls out to those who turn away from faith and guidance, urging them to reconsider their ways and return to the path of truth. It is an invitation to those who have strayed, reminding them that the door to repentance and guidance is always open.
orig: تدعو من أدبر وتولى

translation: And He collected, so He revealed
interpretation: This verse implies that Allah has gathered all knowledge and wisdom in the Qur'an, and has revealed it in a clear and comprehensive manner for the guidance of humanity. It highlights the divine source and profound wisdom contained within the sacred scripture.
orig: وجمع فأوعى

translation: Indeed, man was created anxious
interpretation: This verse highlights the inherent nature of human beings to experience anxiety and restlessness. It suggests that feelings of worry, impatience, and a sense of unease are part of the human condition, indicating that such emotions are natural and not necessarily a flaw or shortcoming. The verse may be interpreted as a reminder for individuals to recognize and accept this aspect of their existence, and to strive for patience and contentment despite the anxieties they may face.
orig: إن الإنسان خلق هلوعا

translation: If evil touches him, he is impatient
interpretation: This verse is referring to those who lack patience and become restless and anxious when faced with adversity or hardship. It highlights the importance of having steadfastness and trust in Allah during difficult times, rather than succumbing to despair and hopelessness.
orig: إذا مسه الشر جزوعا

translation: And when some good reaches him, he is niggardly,
interpretation: This verse refers to the behavior of an ungrateful person who becomes miserly and stingy when he receives some blessings or favors from Allah. Instead of being thankful and sharing with others, he hoards the good things for himself and becomes selfish.
orig: وإذا مسه الخير منوعا

translation: Except the worshippers
interpretation: This verse refers to those who are sincere and devoted in their worship of Allah. It implies that true worshippers will be exempt from the punishment and torment that will befall the disbelievers and wrongdoers on the Day of Judgment. The verse highlights the importance of sincere worship and obedience to Allah as a means of attaining salvation and His pleasure.
orig: إلا المصلين

translation: Those who are constant in their prayers
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of being steadfast and consistent in performing the obligatory prayers. It refers to those who are dedicated to establishing the ritual prayers at their prescribed times without fail or negligence. This quality of constancy in prayer is highly praised and considered a distinguishing characteristic of the righteous believers.
orig: الذين هم على صلاتهم دائمون

translation: And those within whose wealth is a known right
interpretation: This verse refers to the obligation of paying the prescribed share from one's wealth to those who are entitled to it, such as the poor and needy. It emphasizes the importance of fulfilling the rights of others from one's wealth, which is considered a "known right" that must be given to the deserving recipients.
orig: والذين في أموالهم حق معلوم

translation: For the petitioner and the deprived.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of caring for those in need, whether they are actively seeking assistance (the petitioner) or facing deprivation without making a request (the deprived). It encourages compassion and generosity towards all those facing hardship or lacking basic necessities.
orig: للسائل والمحروم

translation: And those who believe in the Day of Recompense.
interpretation: This verse refers to those who have faith in the Day of Judgment, when all people will be held accountable for their deeds and beliefs. It emphasizes the importance of believing in the ultimate reckoning and the consequences of one's actions in the Hereafter. This belief serves as a motivating factor to lead a righteous life and strive for good deeds.
orig: والذين يصدقون بيوم الدين

translation: And those who are fearful of the punishment of their Lord.
interpretation: This verse refers to those who have a sense of awe and fear of Allah's punishment, which motivates them to obey His commands and refrain from sins. Their fear stems from their belief in Allah's power and justice, and their understanding that disobedience has consequences. This fear is a positive trait that leads to righteousness and seeking Allah's pleasure.
orig: والذين هم من عذاب ربهم مشفقون

translation: Indeed, the punishment of their Lord is not something to be felt secure from.
interpretation: This verse warns that the punishment of Allah is severe and inescapable for those who reject His signs and disobey Him. It emphasizes that one should not feel secure or complacent about avoiding Allah's punishment, as it is a terrifying reality that will befall the disbelievers and wrongdoers. The verse instills a sense of fear and humility towards Allah's might and justice.
orig: إن عذاب ربهم غير مأمون

translation: And those who guard their private parts
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of chastity and guarding one's private parts from unlawful sexual relations. It encourages believers to exercise self-control and abstain from indecent behavior, which is essential for maintaining moral and spiritual purity. The interpretation highlights the virtue of modesty and restraint in fulfilling one's desires within the boundaries set by Allah.
orig: والذين هم لفروجهم حافظون

translation: Except from their wives or those their right hands possess, for indeed, they are not to be blamed.
interpretation: This verse outlines the permissible sexual relations in Islam. It states that men are allowed to have intimate relations with their wives and with female slaves whom they rightfully possess ("those their right hands possess"). However, any sexual relations outside of this lawful framework are considered blameworthy and prohibited.
orig: إلا على أزواجهم أو ما ملكت أيمانهم فإنهم غير ملومين

translation: But whoever seeks beyond that, then those are the transgressors
interpretation: This verse warns against going beyond the limits set by Allah and engaging in unlawful or immoral acts. It emphasizes that those who transgress the boundaries established by divine guidance are considered "transgressors" who deviate from the righteous path. The interpretation highlights the importance of adhering to the teachings of Islam and refraining from any actions that violate its principles and values.
orig: فمن ابتغى وراء ذلك فأولئك هم العادون

translation: And those who are faithfully true to their Amaanaat (all the duties which Allaah has ordained, honesty, moral responsibility and trusts) and to their covenants
interpretation: This verse praises those who are trustworthy and fulfill their covenants and obligations. It emphasizes the importance of being honest, upholding moral responsibility, and keeping promises and trusts in the sight of Allah.
orig: والذين هم لأماناتهم وعهدهم راعون

translation: And those who strictly guard their testimonies
interpretation: This verse refers to those who uphold the sanctity of their testimonies and do not distort or conceal the truth when called upon as witnesses. It emphasizes the importance of being truthful and just in bearing witness, which is a moral and legal obligation in Islam.
orig: والذين هم بشهاداتهم قائمون

translation: And those who strictly guard their prayers
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of being steadfast in performing the obligatory prayers at their prescribed times and with utmost sincerity and humility. It praises those who guard and protect their prayers from being neglected or performed carelessly, as prayers are a means of maintaining a strong connection with Allah and attaining spiritual purification and guidance.
orig: والذين هم على صلاتهم يحافظون

translation: Those will be in honored Gardens.
interpretation: This verse implies that righteous believers who follow the commands of God will be honored and rewarded with eternal bliss in the Gardens of Paradise. The word "mukramoon" (honored) suggests that they will be treated with utmost respect, dignity, and high esteem in the Hereafter as a result of their faith and good deeds in this world.
orig: أولئك في جنات مكرمون

translation: So those who disbelieved before you were hastening
interpretation: This verse refers to the disbelievers who came before the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and their haste in rejecting the truth and persecuting the believers. It implies that their rejection was not based on reason or contemplation, but rather on stubbornness and a desire to cling to their misguided ways. The verse serves as a reminder that the opposition faced by the Prophet was not unique, and that previous messengers also faced similar challenges from those who denied the truth.
orig: فمال الذين كفروا قبلك مهطعين

translation: On the right and on the left, in scattered groups.
interpretation: This verse implies that on the Day of Judgment, people will be divided into two groups: those who will be on the right side (the righteous ones destined for Paradise) and those who will be on the left side (the wicked ones destined for Hell). The word "عزين" (scattered groups) suggests that they will be separated and dispersed based on their deeds and beliefs in this world.
orig: عن اليمين وعن الشمال عزين

translation: Does every person among them aspire to be admitted to a Garden of Delight?
interpretation: This verse questions the arrogance and false hopes of those who reject faith and do good deeds, yet expect to enter Paradise. It implies that merely having wishful thinking without sincere belief and righteous actions is not enough to attain the eternal bliss of Paradise. One must strive to purify the soul, follow divine guidance, and live a life of obedience to Allah to deserve such a great reward.
orig: أيطمع كل امرئ منهم أن يدخل جنة نعيم

translation: Nay, We have created them from what they know.
interpretation: Allah is affirming that He created human beings from a sperm drop, which they are fully aware of. This verse emphasizes Allah's power and wisdom in creating human beings from a humble and insignificant origin. It serves as a reminder of our humble beginnings and our dependence on Allah, the Creator.
orig: كلا إنا خلقناهم مما يعلمون

translation: But no! I swear by the Lord of the easts and the wests that We are surely able
interpretation: This verse emphasizes Allah's absolute power and ability to do anything. The oath "by the Lord of the easts and the wests" refers to Allah being the Creator and Sustainer of the entire universe, from the rising of the sun in the east to its setting in the west. The phrase "We are surely able" affirms Allah's capability to accomplish whatever He wills, without any limitations. This verse instills a sense of certainty in Allah's might and reassures the believers of His ability to fulfill His promises and threats.
orig: فلا أقسم برب المشارق والمغارب إنا لقادرون

translation: That We will replace them with others better than them, and We will not be outrun.
interpretation: Allah is stating that He has the power to replace the disbelievers and wrongdoers with others who are better than them in faith and righteous deeds. Allah will not be outrun or outdone by anyone, as He is the Almighty and nothing is beyond His capability.
orig: على أن نبدل خيرا منهم وما نحن بمسبوقين

translation: So leave them to indulge and play until they meet their Day which they are promised.
interpretation: "This verse advises the Prophet to disregard those who mock and make fun of the divine message. It urges patience and steadfastness, for the disbelievers will ultimately face the consequences of their actions on the Day of Judgment that has been promised to them."
orig: فذرهم يخوضوا ويلعبوا حتى يلاقوا يومهم الذي يوعدون

translation: The Day they will emerge from the graves rapidly as if they were, towards an erected Nunub, hastening.
interpretation: This verse describes the scene of the Resurrection Day when all people will emerge from their graves in a hurry and rush towards the place of gathering, as if they are racing towards a raised flag or target.
