The rhetorical question "And what will make you know what the Night of Decree is?" implies that the greatness and significance of this night is beyond human comprehension and cannot be fully grasped by our limited understanding.
orig: وما أدراك ما ليلة القدر

translation: The Night of Decree is better than a thousand months.
interpretation: This verse highlights the immense significance and virtue of Laylat al-Qadr (the Night of Decree or Power). It states that this single night, which is believed to be one of the odd nights during the last ten days of Ramadan, is better and more blessed than a thousand months, which is equivalent to over 83 years. This emphasizes the great spiritual opportunity and rewards associated with worshipping Allah during this night, as the rewards for good deeds performed on this night are multiplied manifold. It encourages believers to seek out and make the most of this blessed night through sincere worship, repentance, and supplications.
orig: ليلة القدر خير من ألف شهر

translation: The angels and the Spirit descend therein by permission of their Lord for every command.
interpretation: This verse indicates that on the Night of Power (Laylat al-Qadr), the angels and the Spirit (which could refer to the Angel Jibreel) descend from the heavens to the earth by the permission of Allah. They come down with Allah's commands and decrees for the entire coming year, such as matters of life, death, provisions, and other important affairs.
orig: تنزل الملائكة والروح فيها بإذن ربهم من كل أمر

translation: It is lawful for you to go in unto your wives during the night preceding the fast day. They are as a garment for you, and you are as a garment for them. Allah is aware that you would have deprived yourselves, so He has turned unto you and pardoned you. So now you may embrace them, and seek what Allah has ordained for you.
interpretation: This verse is addressing the intimate relations between spouses during the nights of Ramadan. It permits intimacy between husbands and wives until the beginning of dawn, at which point they must abstain from such relations until the night. The verse uses the metaphor of spouses being "garments" for one another, signifying closeness, comfort, and protection. It acknowledges the natural desires and struggles that people may face, and Allah's mercy in allowing this concession. The verse encourages seeking what Allah has ordained, referring to the blessings of marriage and intimacy within its lawful bounds.
orig: سلام هي حتى مطلع الفجر

translation: Those who disbelieved among the People of the Scripture and the polytheists were not to be parted [from their disbelief] until there came to them clear evidence -
interpretation: This verse suggests that the disbelievers, whether from among the People of the Scripture (Jews and Christians) or the polytheists, were not going to abandon their disbelief and accept faith until they were presented with clear and undeniable proof or evidence of the truth of Islam. Their stubbornness and rejection of faith would persist until the arrival of this "clear evidence," which could refer to the revelation of the Qur'an, the prophethood of Muhammad, or the manifest signs and miracles that accompanied the spread of Islam.
orig: لم يكن الذين كفروا من أهل الكتاب والمشركين منفكين حتى تأتيهم البينة

translation: A Messenger from Allah, reciting purified scriptures
interpretation: This verse refers to the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him, as a Messenger sent by Allah to recite and convey the purified scriptures of the Qur'an. The term "purified scriptures" highlights the divine and pristine nature of the Qur'anic revelations, free from any corruption or alteration. It emphasizes the purity and authenticity of the message brought by the Prophet Muhammad.
orig: رسول من الله يتلو صحفا مطهرة

translation: In it are precious writings.
interpretation: This verse suggests that within the mentioned entity, there exist invaluable scriptures or texts of great significance and worth.
orig: فيها كتب قيمة

translation: And those who were given the Book did not become divided until after clear evidence had come to them.
interpretation: This verse refers to the People of the Book (Jews and Christians) who were united on the truth initially, but then differed and divided after clear evidence and signs came to them from Allah through the prophets and scriptures. Their division was due to stubbornness, envy, and following desires rather than the truth revealed to them.
orig: وما تفرق الذين أوتوا الكتاب إلا من بعد ما جاءتهم البينة

translation: And they were not commanded except to worship Allah, keeping religion sincere for Him, inclining to truth, and to establish prayer and to give zakah. And that is the correct religion.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that the fundamental purpose of all divine commands is to worship Allah alone with sincere devotion, to establish prayer, and to pay the obligatory charity (zakah). It highlights the essence of the true religion, which is the monotheistic worship of Allah and fulfilling the practical acts of obedience prescribed by Him.
orig: وما أمروا إلا ليعبدوا الله مخلصين له الدين حنفاء ويقيموا الصلاة ويؤتوا الزكاة وذلك دين القيمة

translation: Indeed, those who disbelieved among the People of the Scripture and the polytheists will be in the fire of Hell, abiding eternally therein. Those are the worst of creatures.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the grave consequence of disbelief and associating partners with Allah. It states that those who reject faith from among the People of the Book (Jews and Christians) and the polytheists (those who worship others besides Allah) will be condemned to the eternal punishment of Hellfire. They are described as "the worst of creatures" because they rejected the clear signs and revelations from Allah despite having access to divine guidance. This verse serves as a stern warning against disbelief and polytheism, highlighting the importance of sincere faith in the Oneness of Allah.
orig: إن الذين كفروا من أهل الكتاب والمشركين في نار جهنم خالدين فيها أولئك هم شر البرية

translation: Indeed, those who have believed and done righteous deeds - those are the best of creatures
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that true believers, who have faith and perform good deeds, are the best of all creation. It highlights the importance of both belief and righteous actions in attaining a high status in the sight of Allah. The verse encourages believers to strive for excellence in their faith and deeds, as this is what distinguishes them as the "best of creatures."
orig: إن الذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات أولئك هم خير البرية

translation: Their reward with their Lord will be gardens of perpetual residence beneath which rivers flow, wherein they will abide forever. Allah is pleased with them, and they are pleased with Him. That is for whoever has feared his Lord.
interpretation: This verse promises a great reward for the righteous believers in the Hereafter. The "gardens of perpetual residence" refers to the highest level of Paradise, where the believers will dwell eternally. The imagery of rivers flowing beneath these gardens signifies the abundance and bliss they will experience. Allah's pleasure with them, and their pleasure with Him, indicates the ultimate contentment and spiritual fulfillment they will attain. This reward is specifically for those who feared and revered their Lord during their worldly life, demonstrating the importance of piety and God-consciousness.
orig: جزاؤهم عند ربهم جنات عدن تجري من تحتها الأنهار خالدين فيها أبدا رضي الله عنهم ورضوا عنه ذلك لمن خشي ربه

translation: When the earth is shaken with its [final] earthquake
interpretation: This verse refers to the final and great earthquake that will occur on the Day of Resurrection, shaking the earth violently and causing immense destruction. It signifies the end of this world and the beginning of the Hereafter, when all people will be gathered for judgment before God.
orig: إذا زلزلت الأرض زلزالها

translation: And the earth brings forth its burdens
interpretation: This verse refers to the Day of Resurrection when the earth will bring forth all that is buried within it, including the dead bodies and any treasures or minerals it contains. It symbolizes the earth giving up its secrets and bearing witness to human deeds on that tremendous Day.
orig: وأخرجت الأرض أثقالها

translation: And man says, 'What is [wrong] with it?'
interpretation: This verse refers to man's attitude of skepticism and doubt towards the signs and warnings of Allah. When faced with the reality of the Resurrection and the consequences of his deeds, man questions and wonders in disbelief, asking "What is [wrong] with it?" This reflects his arrogance and unwillingness to accept the truth.
orig: وقال الإنسان ما لها

translation: On that Day, it will narrate its news.
interpretation: On the Day of Resurrection, the earth will speak and reveal all the deeds, good and evil, that were committed upon it by humans. It will bear witness to the actions of people, leaving no secret or deed unaccounted for.
orig: يومئذ تحدث أخبارها

translation: That your Lord inspired to the bee
interpretation: This verse suggests that Allah has inspired the bee with instincts and knowledge to perform its unique functions, such as building hives, gathering nectar, and producing honey. It implies that the remarkable abilities of the bee are a sign of Allah's wisdom and power.
orig: بأن ربك أوحى لها

translation: On that Day, people will depart in different groups to be shown the result of their deeds.
interpretation: The interpretation of this verse is that on the Day of Judgment, people will be divided into different groups based on their deeds in this world. Each group will be presented with the consequences of their actions, whether good or bad. This highlights the accountability of every individual for their choices and the inescapable realization of the results of one's deeds on that ultimate Day.
orig: يومئذ يصدر الناس أشتاتا ليروا أعمالهم

translation: So whoever does an atom's weight of good will see it,
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the idea that no good deed, no matter how small or insignificant it may seem, will go unnoticed or unrewarded by Allah. Even the smallest act of goodness, as tiny as the weight of an atom, will be recognized and rewarded accordingly on the Day of Judgment. This highlights the importance of striving to do good deeds, no matter how seemingly insignificant they may appear, as they all carry value and significance in the sight of Allah.
orig: فمن يعمل مثقال ذرة خيرا يره

translation: And whoever does an atom's weight of evil will see it.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the principle of individual accountability in Islam. It states that even the smallest evil deed, as insignificant as the weight of an atom, will not go unnoticed or unpunished on the Day of Judgment. Every person will be held accountable for their actions, no matter how minor they may seem. This verse serves as a reminder to be mindful of one's deeds and to avoid committing any wrongdoing, no matter how small, as it will eventually be brought to light and reckoned with.
orig: ومن يعمل مثقال ذرة شرا يره

translation: By the (steeds) that run, with panting breath,
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as swearing an oath by the warhorses that run fiercely, breathing heavily while charging into battle. It signifies the intensity and vigor of the horses, which symbolizes the power, strength, and determination required in striving for the truth and facing challenges in life.
orig: والعاديات ضبحا

translation: So the racers race to a goal
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as referring to the competition and striving of human souls towards their ultimate goal, which is the pleasure of Allah. It encourages believers to strive and race towards righteous deeds and spiritual elevation, just as horses race towards their goal with all their might and determination.
orig: فالموريات قدحا

translation: By the morning bright with wind,
interpretation: This verse refers to the winds that blow at dawn, which Allah swears by. It highlights the power and majesty of Allah, who controls the forces of nature like the winds. The interpretation emphasizes Allah's ability to revive and give life, just as the morning winds bring freshness and renewal.
orig: فالمغيرات صبحا

translation: So they produced a deep pit therein
interpretation: The verse is interpreted as referring to the digging of a deep pit by the people who rejected the prophet Salih and his message. This pit was likely dug with the intention of trapping or harming the miraculous she-camel that Allah had sent as a sign for them. Their act of digging the pit symbolizes their rejection of faith and their defiance against Allah's command.
orig: فأثرن به نقعا

translation: So strike for them a path amid the sea, [a way that is] dry.
interpretation: This verse is commanding Prophet Moses to strike the sea with his staff, so that it parts and allows the Children of Israel to cross through on dry land, escaping from the pursuing army of Pharaoh.
orig: فوسطن به جمعا

translation: Indeed, the human being is ungrateful to his Lord.
interpretation: This verse highlights the ingratitude and ungratefulness of human beings towards their Lord, Allah, who has bestowed countless blessings and favors upon them. It serves as a reminder that despite all the provisions and bounties granted by Allah, many people tend to be ungrateful, denying or forgetting the favors of their Creator and Sustainer.
orig: إن الإنسان لربه لكنود

translation: And indeed, he is a witness over that.
interpretation: This verse affirms that Allah is a Witness over the truthfulness of the Qur'an and the prophethood of Muhammad (peace be upon him). It emphasizes the divine origin and authenticity of the message conveyed by the Prophet. The interpretation is that Allah Himself bears testimony to the truthfulness of the Qur'an and the messengership of Muhammad, which should leave no doubt in the hearts of believers.
orig: وإنه على ذلك لشهيد

translation: And indeed, he is overprotective for the love of good
interpretation: This verse suggests that the person being referred to has an intense and overwhelming love for goodness and virtue. They are extremely protective and zealous when it comes to embracing and upholding what is righteous and beneficial. Their attachment to moral uprightness and their desire to do good deeds is exceptionally strong.
orig: وإنه لحب الخير لشديد

translation: Does he not know when the contents of the graves are scattered?
interpretation: This verse implies that on the Day of Resurrection, the graves will be opened and their contents, i.e., the dead bodies, will be scattered. It serves as a reminder of the inevitability of the Resurrection and the accountability of one's deeds. The rhetorical question emphasizes that Allah has full knowledge of what happens to the deceased, and that the revival of the dead is within His power.
orig: أفلا يعلم إذا بعثر ما في القبور

translation: And what is within the breasts is realized.
interpretation: This verse implies that on the Day of Judgment, all secrets, thoughts, and intentions that were hidden in people's hearts and minds will be exposed and brought to light. It serves as a reminder that nothing can remain concealed from Allah, and everyone will be held accountable for their innermost beliefs and intentions.
orig: وحصل ما في الصدور

translation: Indeed, their Lord is All-Acquainted with them that Day.
interpretation: This verse indicates that on the Day of Judgment, Allah will have complete knowledge and awareness of every individual's deeds, intentions, and circumstances. Nothing is hidden from Him, and He will judge everyone with perfect justice and fairness based on His comprehensive understanding of their lives.
orig: إن ربهم بهم يومئذ لخبير

translation: The Striking Calamity.
interpretation: This surah describes the cataclysmic events that will occur on the Day of Resurrection. It portrays the striking calamity of that Day, which will cause people to scatter like moths. Deeds will be weighed, and those whose scales are heavy with good deeds will attain a pleasant life, while those whose scales are light will be plunged into the abyss of Hell. The surah emphasizes the certainty of the Resurrection and the accountability of one's actions.
orig: القارعة

translation: What is the Clatterer?
interpretation: This verse is referring to the Day of Resurrection, which is described as "the Clatterer" due to the cataclysmic events that will occur on that Day. It is questioning what this tremendous event is, in order to draw attention to its significance and enormity.
orig: ما القارعة

translation: And what will make you know what the Striking Calamity is?
interpretation: This verse questions the listener about their knowledge of the tremendous event called "the Striking Calamity," which refers to the Day of Resurrection or Judgment. It emphasizes the gravity and magnitude of this event, which is beyond human comprehension until it occurs.
orig: وما أدراك ما القارعة

translation: The Day when mankind will be like scattered moths,
interpretation: This verse describes the scene on the Day of Resurrection, when people will be resurrected from their graves and gathered before Allah. They will be in a state of confusion, fear, and helplessness, scattered like moths dispersed by wind. The imagery of "scattered moths" portrays the utter vulnerability and disarray of humanity on that tremendous Day.
orig: يوم يكون الناس كالفراش المبثوث

translation: And the mountains will be like carded wool
interpretation: This verse paints a vivid image of the complete destruction and upheaval that will occur on the Day of Resurrection. The mountains, which are symbols of strength and permanence, will become like "carded wool" - light, scattered, and easily blown away by the wind. This metaphor emphasizes the utter powerlessness of all creation before the might of Allah on that tremendous Day. It serves as a reminder of the temporary nature of this world and the need to prepare for the eternal Hereafter.
orig: وتكون الجبال كالعهن المنفوش

translation: As for him whose balance (of good deeds) is heavy,
interpretation: This verse refers to those whose good deeds outweigh their bad deeds on the Day of Judgment. Their balance of deeds will be "heavy" with righteous actions, indicating that they will be rewarded with a pleasant and blissful life in Paradise.
orig: فأما من ثقلت موازينه

translation: Then he will be in a pleasant life.
interpretation: This verse refers to the reward awaiting those who have lived a righteous life and believed in Allah. It suggests that such people will experience a state of contentment, satisfaction, and pleasure in the Hereafter as a result of their faith and good deeds in this world. The "pleasant life" mentioned here is a metaphor for the eternal bliss and joy that believers will experience in Paradise.
orig: فهو في عيشة راضية

translation: But as for him whose balance (of good deeds) will be light,
interpretation: This verse refers to those whose good deeds are outweighed by their evil deeds on the Day of Judgment. The "light balance" signifies a lack of good deeds that would make their scale heavy. This is a warning for people to strive to perform righteous actions and avoid sins, as their ultimate destination will be determined by the weight of their deeds.
orig: وأما من خفت موازينه

translation: As for his mother, she was an abyss.
interpretation: This verse is referring to the mother of the person being discussed as being in a state of misguidance, ignorance, or disbelief, likening her spiritual condition to an abyss or a deep pit of darkness and error.
orig: فأمه هاوية

translation: And what will make you know what it is?
interpretation: This verse questions the listener's knowledge about the nature or reality of the subject being discussed, which is not explicitly mentioned. It implies that the listener lacks complete understanding or awareness of the matter at hand, and encourages them to seek further knowledge and insight.
orig: وما أدراك ما هيه

translation: A blazing Fire
interpretation: This is a reference to the Hellfire, which is described as an intensely hot and raging flame that will torment the disbelievers in the Hereafter as a punishment for their rejection of faith and their evil deeds in this world. The word "hamiya" (blazing) emphasizes the severity and intensity of this punishment.
orig: نار حامية

translation: Preoccupation with amassing [wealth and children] has distracted you,
interpretation: This verse is criticizing people who are excessively preoccupied with accumulating wealth and offspring, to the point that it distracts them from more important spiritual matters and their obligations towards God. It warns against being consumed by materialistic pursuits and neglecting one's religious duties.
orig: ألهاكم التكاثر

translation: Until you visit the graves.
interpretation: This verse suggests that death is an inevitable reality that all humans will face. By visiting graves, one is reminded of the temporary nature of this life and the importance of preparing for the Hereafter. It encourages contemplation on mortality and the transient nature of worldly possessions and pursuits.
orig: حتى زرتم المقابر

translation: Nay, you shall soon know.
interpretation: This verse implies a warning or threat, indicating that the truth will become evident and the disbelievers will realize the consequences of their actions and disbelief. It suggests that they will eventually gain knowledge or understanding of the reality they are currently denying or unaware of.
orig: كلا سوف تعلمون

translation: Then, you will surely know.
interpretation: This verse suggests that there will come a time when the truth will be revealed and made apparent to everyone. It implies that those who deny or doubt the teachings of the Qur'an will eventually come to realize their error and understand the reality. The verse serves as a warning and a promise that the ultimate truth will become evident, whether in this life or in the Hereafter.
orig: ثم كلا سوف تعلمون

translation: Nay! If you only knew with the knowledge of certainty...
interpretation: This verse is emphasizing the importance of having certain knowledge and firm belief in the matters of faith, rather than relying on speculation or assumptions. It suggests that if people truly understood the reality of the afterlife and the consequences of their actions with absolute certainty, they would have behaved differently in this world.
orig: كلا لو تعلمون علم اليقين

translation: You will surely see the Hellfire
interpretation: This verse is a warning to the disbelievers and wrongdoers that they will inevitably face the torment of Hell as a consequence of their rejection of faith and their evil deeds. It serves as a reminder of the reality of the Hereafter and the accountability for one's actions in this world. The use of the word "you" in the second person directly addresses the audience, making the warning more personal and impactful.
orig: لترون الجحيم

translation: Then you will surely see it with the eye of certainty
interpretation: This verse refers to the state of absolute certainty and conviction that believers will attain when they witness the realities of the Hereafter with their own eyes. It implies that the truth which they had accepted based on faith and revelation will become a tangible reality before them, removing any lingering doubts or uncertainties.
orig: ثم لترونها عين اليقين

translation: Then on that Day you shall be asked about the delights (you indulged in in this world).
interpretation: This verse implies that on the Day of Judgment, people will be questioned and held accountable for the luxuries, comforts, and pleasures they indulged in during their worldly life. It serves as a reminder that we should be grateful for the blessings bestowed upon us and utilize them in a righteous manner, without being extravagant or negligent.
orig: ثم لتسألن يومئذ عن النعيم

translation: By the Time,
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the importance of time and the fleeting nature of human life. It serves as a reminder to make the most of our limited time on Earth by doing righteous deeds and avoiding wasteful pursuits.
orig: والعصر

translation: Indeed, mankind is in loss
interpretation: This verse indicates that human beings are in a state of loss or deprivation, spiritually and morally, if they do not follow the right path and live their lives according to the guidance of God. It emphasizes the importance of having faith, doing righteous deeds, and seeking the truth to avoid being in a state of loss or ruin in this life and the Hereafter.
orig: إن الإنسان لفي خسر

translation: Except those who believe and do righteous deeds, and advise each other to truth and advise each other to patience.
interpretation: This verse highlights the exceptional qualities of true believers. It states that those who have faith, perform good deeds, enjoin truth upon one another, and counsel each other to be patient and persevere, are exempted from the fate of the disbelievers mentioned earlier. This underscores the importance of not only having faith, but also translating that faith into righteous actions, promoting truth, and encouraging steadfastness in the face of adversities.
orig: إلا الذين آمنوا وعملوا الصالحات وتواصوا بالحق وتواصوا بالصبر

translation: Woe to every slanderer and backbiter
interpretation: This verse condemns those who slander and backbite others. It warns of the severe consequences that await those who engage in mocking, defaming, and spreading malicious gossip about people behind their backs. This behavior is considered a grave sin in Islam as it unjustly harms others' reputation and dignity.
orig: ويل لكل همزة لمزة

translation: The one who amasses wealth and keeps counting it.
interpretation: This verse refers to the person who is obsessed with accumulating wealth and constantly counting it, indicating an excessive attachment to material possessions and greed. It critiques the mindset of hoarding wealth without utilizing it for righteous purposes or benefiting others. The interpretation highlights the importance of maintaining a balanced approach towards wealth and avoiding miserly behavior.
orig: الذي جمع مالا وعدده

translation: He thinks that his wealth will make him immortal
interpretation: This verse criticizes the arrogance and delusion of those who think that their wealth and material possessions will grant them eternal life or make them superior to others. It emphasizes that true immortality and honor come from faith, good deeds, and submission to God, not from worldly riches which are temporary and fleeting.
orig: يحسب أن ماله أخلده

translation: Nay, We shall cast him into the Crushing Fire.
interpretation: "This verse is a warning to those who reject the truth and persist in disbelief. It indicates that such individuals will be thrown into the Hellfire, described as 'the Crushing Fire,' which will crush and destroy them completely. This punishment is a consequence of their rejection of faith and their insistence on following falsehood."
orig: كلا لينبذن في الحطمة

translation: And what will explain to you what the Crusher is?
interpretation: This verse is referring to the Day of Resurrection, which is described as "the Crusher" due to its immense magnitude and severity. It emphasizes the inability of humans to fully comprehend the terrifying nature of that Day, highlighting the need to prepare for it through faith and righteous deeds.
orig: وما أدراك ما الحطمة

translation: The Fire of Allah kindled
interpretation: This verse refers to the blazing Hellfire that has been prepared for those who disbelieve and disobey Allah. It is a warning about the severe punishment that awaits the disbelievers and wrongdoers in the Hereafter. The phrase "Fire of Allah" emphasizes that this is a fire created and controlled by Allah Himself as a means of retribution for those who reject His guidance and commands.
orig: نار الله الموقدة

translation: The one that has insight into the innermost thoughts
interpretation: This verse refers to Allah's knowledge of the innermost thoughts, feelings, and intentions within people's hearts and minds. It highlights Allah's all-encompassing knowledge and awareness of what is hidden deep within the human soul, which no one else can perceive or have access to except Him.
orig: التي تطلع على الأفئدة

translation: Indeed, it will be closed upon them
interpretation: This verse suggests that the gates of guidance and mercy will be closed upon those who reject faith and persist in disbelief. They will be deprived of Allah's guidance and blessings, leaving them in a state of spiritual deprivation and being "locked out" from the path of truth.
orig: إنها عليهم مؤصدة

translation: In upright columns
interpretation: This verse refers to the lofty and firm mountains that Allah has placed on Earth as stabilizers and anchors. The mountains are described as "upright columns" or "pegs" that are firmly fixed into the ground, providing stability and balance to the Earth. This metaphor highlights the wisdom, power, and precise design in Allah's creation of the mountains, which serve a crucial purpose in maintaining the Earth's equilibrium and preventing it from shaking excessively.
orig: في عمد ممددة

translation: Have you not seen how your Lord dealt with the Companions of the Elephant?
interpretation: This verse refers to an event where the people of Makkah were miraculously saved from an army of elephants sent by Abrahah, the Christian ruler of Yemen, who intended to destroy the Ka'bah. Allah sent flocks of birds carrying small stones that pelted and destroyed the army. This event demonstrated Allah's power to protect the Sacred House and the believers.
orig: ألم تر كيف فعل ربك بأصحاب الفيل

translation: Did He not make their plot go astray in causing confusion?
interpretation: This verse suggests that Allah rendered ineffective and futile the plots and schemes of those who tried to mislead others or cause confusion regarding the truth. Their malicious intentions and efforts to lead people astray were thwarted by Allah's wisdom and power.
orig: ألم يجعل كيدهم في تضليل

translation: And He sent against them birds in flocks,
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as Allah sending flocks of birds that pelted the disbelieving people of the elephant with stones of baked clay, which destroyed them utterly. This event is known as the "Year of the Elephant" and is seen as a divine miracle that protected the Ka'bah from destruction.
orig: وأرسل عليهم طيرا أبابيل

translation: Pelting them with stones of baked clay.
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as a metaphorical description of the severe punishment that Allah inflicts upon the disbelievers and wrongdoers. The "stones of baked clay" symbolize the intense pain and suffering they will endure, as if they were being pelted with hard, scorching projectiles. It serves as a warning against rejecting faith and committing sins, emphasizing the consequences of disobedience towards Allah's commands.
orig: ترميهم بحجارة من سجيل

translation: So He made them like straw devoured.
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as Allah's punishment on the disbelievers, likening them to worthless straw that has been consumed or trampled upon. It signifies their utter destruction and the futility of their arrogance and rejection of faith.
orig: فجعلهم كعصف مأكول

translation: For the familiarizing of the Quraysh,
interpretation: This verse refers to the special privilege and honor granted to the tribe of Quraysh by Allah. As the custodians of the Ka'bah, they were able to travel safely for trade during the sacred months, which allowed them to gain economic prosperity and unite the Arab tribes under their leadership. The interpretation is that Allah blessed the Quraysh with this unique advantage so that they may worship and obey Him in return.
orig: لإيلاف قريش

translation: Their tour is the winter and summer journey
interpretation: This verse seems to be referring to the seasonal migrations of certain nomadic tribes or groups of people. In the winter, they would travel to warmer regions, and in the summer, they would journey to cooler areas, following the cycle of the seasons. This nomadic lifestyle was common in ancient Arabia and allowed these groups to adapt to the harsh climate and find suitable grazing lands for their livestock. The verse highlights their constant state of travel and movement, with the winter and summer journeys being an integral part of their way of life.
orig: إيلافهم رحلة الشتاء والصيف

translation: So let them worship the Lord of this House.
interpretation: This verse commands the worship of Allah, who is the Lord and Sustainer of the Ka'bah in Makkah. It emphasizes the importance of directing worship solely to Allah, the Creator and Maintainer of the sacred House, which is the spiritual center for Muslims worldwide.
orig: فليعبدوا رب هذا البيت

translation: It is He who has fed them against hunger, and made them safe from fear
interpretation: This verse refers to Allah's blessings upon His creation. He provides sustenance and removes hunger, and grants security and safety by removing fear and danger. It highlights Allah's mercy, care, and protection for all beings.
orig: الذي أطعمهم من جوع وآمنهم من خوف

translation: Have you seen the one who denies the Recompense?
interpretation: This verse questions and condemns the disbelief of those who reject the concept of accountability on the Day of Judgment. It highlights the grave error of denying the divine system of reward and punishment, which is a fundamental aspect of faith.
orig: أرأيت الذي يكذب بالدين

translation: That is the one who repels the orphan,
interpretation: This verse criticizes and condemns those who mistreat orphans, repelling them harshly and depriving them of their rights and kindness.
orig: فذلك الذي يدع اليتيم

translation: Nor does he encourage the feeding of the poor.
interpretation: This verse condemns those who do not encourage or motivate others to feed the poor and needy. It criticizes the selfish and indifferent attitude towards helping the less fortunate members of society.
orig: ولا يحض على طعام المسكين

translation: So woe to those who pray,
interpretation: This verse condemns those who are heedless and neglectful in their prayers, performing them without the proper humility, focus, and sincerity required. It serves as a warning to those who treat the prayer, one of the most important pillars of Islam, with disregard and lack of reverence.
orig: فويل للمصلين

translation: Those who are neglectful of their prayers
interpretation: This verse refers to those who are heedless and unmindful of their obligatory prayers. It implies that they do not attach importance to performing their prayers with sincerity, punctuality, and due reverence. Their negligence towards this fundamental pillar of Islam is a grave shortcoming that distances them from the path of righteousness.
orig: الذين هم عن صلاتهم ساهون

translation: Those who show off
interpretation: This verse refers to people who perform good deeds not for the sake of pleasing Allah, but rather to be seen and praised by others. Their actions are driven by a desire for worldly recognition and fame, rather than sincere faith and devotion to Allah. The Qur'an condemns this behavior as hypocrisy and warns that such deeds will be rendered worthless on the Day of Judgment.
orig: الذين هم يراءون

translation: And they deny the assistance (Maa'oon).
interpretation: This verse criticizes those who refuse to help the needy and deprive them of their basic rights and needs, despite having the means to assist them. It condemns the selfish attitude of withholding kindness and aid from others, which goes against the teachings of charity and compassion in Islam.
orig: ويمنعون الماعون

translation: Indeed, We have granted you, [O Muhammad], al-Kawthar.
interpretation: This verse is believed to refer to the abundant good that Allah has bestowed upon the Prophet Muhammad, peace be upon him. The word "al-Kawthar" is interpreted by many scholars as a river in Paradise, but it can also symbolize the great blessings, knowledge, and guidance that the Prophet brought to humanity through the revelation of the Qur'an and his teachings. The verse affirms Allah's favor upon the Prophet and the great reward he will receive in the Hereafter for his efforts in conveying the message of Islam.
orig: إنا أعطيناك الكوثر

translation: So pray to your Lord and sacrifice.
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as an instruction to worship Allah alone through prayer and sacrifice. The command to "pray to your Lord" signifies the importance of establishing a connection with Allah through sincere devotion and supplication. The command to "sacrifice" is understood to mean offering an animal sacrifice as an act of worship and gratitude to Allah. This ritual was practiced during the time of the Prophet Muhammad and continues to be observed by Muslims during the annual Hajj pilgrimage and Eid al-Adha celebrations. The verse emphasizes the centrality of prayer and sacrifice in the Islamic faith as means of drawing closer to Allah and expressing obedience and thankfulness.
orig: فصل لربك وانحر

translation: Indeed, it is your hater who is cut off.
interpretation: This verse suggests that those who oppose or hate the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and his message are the ones who are truly deprived and cut off from the path of guidance and spiritual fulfillment. Their hatred and rejection of the truth will only lead to their own loss and disconnection from the divine mercy and blessings.
orig: إن شانئك هو الأبتر

translation: Say, 'O disbelievers,
interpretation: This verse is addressed to the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), instructing him to declare the fundamental differences between the belief of Muslims and that of the disbelievers or polytheists. It marks a clear distinction between the two ideologies and calls for a peaceful coexistence based on mutual respect and non-interference in each other's religious affairs.
orig: قل يا أيها الكافرون

translation: I do not worship what you worship
interpretation: This verse affirms the firm belief of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) in the Oneness of God (Tawheed) and his rejection of idolatry and polytheism. It emphasizes his unwavering commitment to worshipping the One True God alone and refusing to associate any partners or idols with Him, which was the prevalent practice in pagan Arabia at that time.
orig: لا أعبد ما تعبدون

translation: Nor will you worship what I worship
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the fundamental difference between the beliefs of the Prophet Muhammad and the disbelievers he was addressing. It affirms that they will not accept or follow his religion and way of worship, just as he will not adopt their pagan beliefs and practices.
orig: ولا أنتم عابدون ما أعبد

translation: Nor am I a worshipper of what you worship
interpretation: This verse affirms the Prophet Muhammad's rejection of idolatry and false deities worshipped by the pagan Arabs. It establishes his monotheistic belief in the One True God, dissociating himself from the misguided practices of his people.
orig: ولا أنا عابد ما عبدتم

translation: Nor will you worship what I worship.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the fundamental difference in beliefs and practices between the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) and the disbelievers he was addressing. It highlights the stark contrast in their respective objects of worship, indicating an irreconcilable divide between the two parties. The verse conveys the message that the Prophet and his followers will not adopt the false deities and idols worshipped by the disbelievers, just as the disbelievers will not accept the true worship of the One God prescribed by Islam.
orig: ولا أنتم عابدون ما أعبد

translation: For you is your religion, and for me is my religion.
interpretation: This verse promotes religious tolerance and freedom of belief. It recognizes that people may have different religious beliefs and practices, and that this diversity should be respected. The verse affirms that everyone has the right to follow their own faith without imposing it on others or being imposed upon. It encourages mutual understanding and peaceful coexistence between people of different religions.
orig: لكم دينكم ولي دين

translation: When there comes the Help of Allah and the Victory
interpretation: This verse refers to the imminent conquest of Makkah by the Muslims after years of persecution and struggle. It signifies the triumph of truth over falsehood and the establishment of Allah's religion on earth. It also indicates that when Allah's Help and Victory arrive, it is a sign that one's mission has been accomplished, and one should turn entirely towards worshipping and praising Allah.
orig: إذا جاء نصر الله والفتح

translation: And you see the people entering the religion of Allah in multitudes.
interpretation: This verse refers to the widespread acceptance and embracing of Islam by people from all walks of life. It signifies the rapid growth and appeal of the religion, with masses of people being guided towards the truth and submitting to the will of Allah. The interpretation highlights the fulfillment of the divine promise that Islam will spread and prevail, transcending boundaries and uniting diverse groups under the banner of monotheism.
orig: ورأيت الناس يدخلون في دين الله أفواجا

translation: So glorify the praises of your Lord and ask His forgiveness. Verily, He is the One Who accepts the repentance.
interpretation: One should praise and glorify Allah, recognizing His perfection and greatness, and seek His forgiveness for any shortcomings or sins. Allah is Most Forgiving and accepts sincere repentance from His servants.
orig: فسبح بحمد ربك واستغفره إنه كان توابا

translation: May the hands of Abu Lahab be ruined, and ruined is he.
interpretation: This verse expresses Allah's condemnation of Abu Lahab, the uncle of Prophet Muhammad who vehemently opposed Islam. It is a denunciation of his disbelief and enmity towards the Prophet. The phrase "May his hands be ruined" is an Arabic expression that signifies complete failure and destruction. The verse serves as a warning against those who obstruct the path of truth and persecute believers.
orig: تبت يدا أبي لهب وتب

translation: His wealth and his earnings will not avail him.
interpretation: This verse emphasizes that wealth and material possessions alone will not benefit a person on the Day of Judgment. True success lies in faith, righteous deeds, and a sincere relationship with Allah. One's wealth and earnings cannot save them from the consequences of their actions or grant them salvation. The verse reminds us to focus on spiritual and moral development rather than solely pursuing worldly gains.
orig: ما أغنى عنه ماله وما كسب

translation: He will [enter to] burn in a Fire of intense heat
interpretation: This verse warns of the severe punishment for those who reject faith and commit evil deeds. The "Fire of intense heat" refers to the blazing flames of Hellfire, which will be the ultimate destination for the disbelievers and wrongdoers. It serves as a stern reminder of the grave consequences of denying the truth and living a life devoid of righteousness.
orig: سيصلى نارا ذات لهب

translation: And his wife was a carrier of firewood.
interpretation: This verse refers to the story of Prophet Abraham and his wife Sarah. It is an allegorical reference suggesting that Sarah was barren and unable to bear children, just as a bundle of firewood cannot produce anything on its own. The verse implies that despite Sarah's inability to conceive, God blessed them with a child (Prophet Isaac) through a miracle.
orig: وامرأته حمالة الحطب

translation: In her neck is a rope of twisted fiber.
interpretation: This verse is interpreted as a metaphorical description of the disbelievers' stubborn rejection of the truth and their unwillingness to accept guidance. The "rope of twisted fiber" around their necks symbolizes their arrogance, pride, and obstinacy that prevents them from embracing faith. It suggests that they are bound by their own misguided beliefs and desires, which act as a restraint around their necks, keeping them from seeing the truth and submitting to God.
orig: في جيدها حبل من مسد

translation: Say, 'He is Allah, the One and Only'
interpretation: This verse affirms the absolute Oneness and Uniqueness of Allah. It negates any notion of plurality or partners associated with Allah. The interpretation emphasizes that Allah is the sole Creator, Sustainer, and Sovereign of the universe, without any equal or likeness.
orig: قل هو الله أحد

translation: Allah, the Self-Sufficient
interpretation: "Allah is the One who is free from any need or deficiency. He is the Eternal, the Absolute, the One who is besought by all for their needs, yet He is not in need of anything or anyone."
orig: الله الصمد

translation: He neither begets nor is born
interpretation: This verse affirms the transcendent nature of Allah, the One True God. It negates the concept of procreation or lineage in relation to Allah, emphasizing His uniqueness and absolute independence from any form of reproduction or birth. Allah is not bound by the limitations of the physical world and is far removed from any notion of having offspring or being born. This verse establishes Allah's utter distinction from His creation and His incomparable, eternal, and self-sufficient nature.
orig: لم يلد ولم يولد

translation: And there was not for Him any equal
interpretation: This verse emphasizes the oneness and uniqueness of Allah. It negates the existence of anything or anyone that can be considered equal, comparable or a partner to Allah. This affirms Allah's absolute sovereignty, perfection, and transcendence over all creation. There is nothing like Him, and He has no rivals or associates in His Lordship, Divinity, and Attributes.
orig: ولم يكن له كفوا أحد

translation: Say, 'I seek refuge in the Lord of daybreak'
interpretation: This verse instructs the believers to seek protection from Allah, the Lord and Creator of everything, against any harm or evil that may arise at the beginning of the day or any new undertaking.
orig: قل أعوذ برب الفلق

translation: From the evil of what He created
interpretation: This verse refers to seeking refuge with Allah from the evil of all created beings, including humans, jinn, animals, and anything else that Allah has created. It acknowledges that some of Allah's creations can cause harm or evil, and we seek protection from their negative influences or actions.
orig: من شر ما خلق

translation: And from the evil of the darkening (night) as it comes with its darkness (after sun-set).
interpretation: This verse seeks protection from the evil that may arise during the night, which is a time of darkness and concealment. It reminds us to be vigilant and seek Allah's protection from any harm or evil that may lurk in the darkness.
orig: ومن شر غاسق إذا وقب

translation: And from the evil of those who practice witchcraft when they blow on knots
interpretation: This verse warns against the evil of those who practice witchcraft by blowing on knots, which was a pagan practice involving tying knots and blowing on them while reciting incantations to inflict harm on others. The interpretation is that believers should seek refuge in Allah from such evil practices that involve associating partners with Allah and causing harm to others.
orig: ومن شر النفاثات في العقد

translation: And from the evil of an envier when he envies.
interpretation: This verse seeks protection from the harm caused by those who envy others and wish for their blessings to be taken away. Envy is a destructive trait that stems from an unhealthy mindset and can lead to malicious actions against others. The verse reminds us to guard ourselves against such negative emotions and seek refuge in Allah from their harmful effects.
orig: ومن شر حاسد إذا حسد

translation: Say, 'I seek refuge in the Lord of mankind,'
interpretation: This verse teaches us to seek protection from Allah, the Lord and Sustainer of all humanity, against any harm or evil that may afflict us. It reminds us of our complete dependence on Allah and our need to turn to Him for refuge and safety from all troubles and difficulties.
orig: قل أعوذ برب الناس

translation: Master of the people
interpretation: This verse refers to Allah as the Master, Sovereign, and Controller of all people. It highlights Allah's absolute authority, power, and dominion over humanity. The interpretation emphasizes that all human beings are subject to Allah's will and command, and that He is the ultimate source of guidance and legislation for mankind.
orig: ملك الناس

translation: The Lord of mankind
interpretation: Allah is the Cherisher, Sustainer, and Protector of all humankind. He is the sole object of worship for all people, and the One who provides for their needs and guides them to the right path.
orig: إله الناس

translation: From the evil of the whisperer who withdraws.
interpretation: This verse refers to the evil whispers and insinuations of Satan, who tries to instill doubts and evil thoughts into the hearts of people, and then withdraws. The interpretation is that we should seek refuge in Allah from the evil suggestions and temptations of Satan, which can lead us astray from the right path.
orig: من شر الوسواس الخناس

translation: Who whispers into the breasts of mankind
interpretation: This verse refers to Satan or the devil, who whispers evil thoughts and temptations into the hearts and minds of people, trying to lead them astray from the path of righteousness.
orig: الذي يوسوس في صدور الناس

translation: From the jinn and mankind
interpretation: This verse refers to the fact that both jinn (a creation made of smokeless fire) and humans are accountable beings who will be held responsible for their deeds on the Day of Judgment. It implies that Allah has created both these types of beings with the ability to make choices and that they will be questioned about their actions.
orig: من الجنة والناس
